fields.headline: Porto 0 - 0 Liverpool
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

Porto Ovchinnikov, Jorge Costa, Nelson, Paredes, Secretario, Deco, Drulovic, Andrade, Chainho, Capucho, Pena. Subs: Espinha, Aloisio, Santos, Maric, Candido Costa, Romeu, Clayton

Liverpool Westerveld, Babbel, Henchoz, Hyypia, Carragher, Ziege, Hamann, Gerrard, Smicer, Owen, Fowler. Subs: Arphexad, Murphy, Heskey, Barmby, McAllister, Diomede, Wright.

Referee P Collina (Italy)

1 Are they on a roll to glory, or are they still as unpredictable as ever? No easy tie this for Liverpool as they attempt to prove the former and rediscover their European touch. Porto kick-off in a half-empty stadium after a minute's silence for the bridge tragedy in Portugal earlier this week. Owen and Fowler start up front for Liverpool.
2 Predictably gentle start as Babbel tries an ealy probing ball towards Owen on the right.
4 Porto free-kick after Deco is brought down 30 yards out; played short in front of the wall and Liverpool clear.
5 Pena attempts to drive through the middle but is closed down early. Porto with most of the possession in the early minutes.
6 Gerrard attempts to release Fowler towards the by-line with a looping ball over the top; Fowler unlucky not to get a free-kick when he has his heels clipped.
7 Drulovic gets in a cross on the left looking for Pena on the six-yard line; goes for a corner off Hyypia. Played short and Liverpool clear. Played back in for a second corner, and the same result.
11 Capucho slides the ball through to Nelson on the left but his cross is poor.
12 Two crosses in succession from Babbel on the right: the first is too high for Owen; the second goes for a corner...
12 ... too long for everyone by a mile.
14 Henchoz does well to clear an awkward cross into the Liverpool area by Capucho, who is doing a lot work on the right with not much help..
16 Pena blows a good chance for Porto when he fails to find Capucho running into space; Capucho looking frustrated at the service has ben getting.
20 Smicer jigs around on the left before the bal runs to Owen on the left of the six-yard box; Owen tries to cut it back to Fowler, but Porto clear for a corner...
21 ... plenty of scrappy stuff in the Porto area from the corner but keeper Ovchinnikov eventually restores order and claims.
24 Fowler looks for Owen running into the area, but Owen pokes his shot straight at Ovchinnikov.
26 Pressure from Porto as Carragher twice denies Capucho on the right; the ball goes in again, Smicer clears and gives it back, it is played back in again and finally Liverpool can rest easy.
29 Free-kick for Liverpool 30 yards out after Fowler is brought down. Ziege takes, Secretario clears.
30 Fowler tries send Owen away to his right when Smicer on his left was in a better position. Owen's return ball back in goes behind Smicer.
31 Porto corner after Chainho cuts it back from the by-line into the six-yard box from Drulovic's pass. Chainho and Nelson both fail to make their shots count from the corner.
33 Capucho again away on the right for Porto, and again let down by a poor pass, this time by Deco.
34 Booking Paredes for chopping down Smicer in the centre circle.
35 Porto free-kick just over 20 yards out. It is drifted across the wall for Gerrard to pick up and dribble out to safety. Gerrard then just fails to send Owen away in the Porto half.
38 Westerveld fouled when he tries to deny Deco 10 yards out.
40 Drulovic tries a snap shot from the left of the Liverpool area - wide.
41 Chainho shoots straight at Westerveld from 18 yards. Frantic scrambling about before Liverpool can clear for a corner. Comes to nothing.
45 Nelson shimmies through midfield before finding Capucho out on the left for once. He makes a meal of it and things break down for Porto. Half-time. The better chances have fallen to Liverpool with Porto looking not much more than ordinary. Liverpool have steadily come into the game with useful breaks from some solid defending.

46 Liverpool get the second 45 underway.
47 Two good chances created by Capucho; the second richoting away from Westerveld on the six-yard line as Pena came charging with Henchoz on his back.
49 Liverpool free-kick just over 25 yards out. Ziege takes, easy for Ovchinnikov.
50 Chainho plays a one-two with Pena on the left before delivering a poor pass into the area.
51 Liverpool left short when Deco gets on the end of a long ball behind the wide defender, but Deco can't create the shot after cutting inside.
52 Capucho again on the right; Henchoz turns his cross away for a corner. Drulovic takes for another corner. Porto looking much more lively this half...
53... Deco takes the second corner, Liverpool clear.
54 Porto free-kick 20 yards out to the left. Pena heads it behind for a goal-kick.
55 Substitution Murphy on for Ziege.
58 Substitution Aloisio on for Jorge Costa, who looks to have tweaked a hamstring.
60 Blistering strike by Gerrard after he chested the ball down nearly 30 yards out; would have swung back inside the left-hand upright had Ovchinnikov not been so alert. Will somebody please score. It's at times like this that, no matter how well a team is controlling the pace and keeping out the home side in the hope of an easier ride in the return leg, you just wish somebody would find the bloody net and make a game of it.
65 Now the crowd are struggling to raise a tune as the match gets stuck in a rut. But they wake up when Owen wins a corner on the left; it's loose in the six-yard box before Aloisio clears.
66 Pena blows the best chance of the match for Porto when he snatches at his left foot shot across the face of goal.
69 Porto free-kick 25 yards out. Drulovic takes, the ball is flicked on... offside.
70 Substitution Heskey on for Fowler.
73 Liverpool free-kick wide on the left of the Porto area. Gerrard takes, corner on the right. Comes to nothing.
74 Substitution Candido Costa on for Drulovic.
78 Chainho with a shot off the outside of his right-foot - well wide of the far post.
80 Substitution Barmby on for Owen.
81 Great determination by Henchoz when he first denies Pena and then chases off to snatch back the rebound from Chainho.
83 Henchoz again does well to hold up Pena 20 yards out when Liverpool are caught short. All ends with a Deco long-range shot wide fractionally wide of the left-hand upright.
85 Liverpool free-kick 20 yards out, square to goal. Murphy takes just over the crossbar.
90 A half-hearted attack by Liverpool in the dying minutes. Porto reply with a break and win a corner. Candido Costa takes, Heskey heads clear. Another Porto corner from a Deco free-kick 30 yards out. Comes to nothing. Full-time. What a relief - a good result for Liverpool away from home but desperate entertainment for the punters and minute-by-minute writers.

webTitle: Week 15: Darwin to Kakadu National Park

fields.headline: 51 and never been kissed...
fields.standfirst: During her first hectic week in Australia, Sue negotiates jumping crocodiles, leeches and dissolving roads, and still finds time to settle the question of whether or not she ever did kiss Paul McCartney...
fields.trailText: Week 15: Darwin to Kakadu National Park During her first hectic week in Australia, Sue negotiates jumping crocodiles, leeches and dissolving roads, and still finds time to settle the question of whether or not she ever did kiss Paul McCartney...
fields.body:
So, the first couple of weeks organized, let my whistle-stop tour of Australia begin. Already I have seen and learnt so much it will be difficult to fit it all in. On Saturday, I was off at 6am for a day trip with Adventure Tours to Kakadu National Park in a four-wheel-drive bus. We made lots of stops on the way, to look at barammundi fish and a tall cathedral termite mound, and to take the Jumping Crocodile Cruise on the Adelaide River. Here, in the wet season,  the crocodiles stay in the water instead of basking on the river banks where tourists can see them. To tempt them nearer, lumps of meat are hung on rods from the boat. This is limited to three lumps per trip, and if the crocs miss or there are more than three about, it's tough luck, as the park rangers don't want them to become dependant on this food supply.

We were lucky enough to have four lumps, and a white sea eagle swooped down to take one in an awesome display of precision diving. Two crocs obligingly jumped  to take their prize, but the third seemed to be more interested in eyeballing me as I was poised with camera ready. It was not until the boatman shouted a warning that I realised my elbow was actually out of the window - you've never seen an arm move so fast. Andy, our tour leader, seemed to have eagle eyes despite the fact that he was driving - he suddenly would stop the bus and turn round to show us a fan lizard with perfect camouflage on a tree trunk, a dingo lurking in the spear grass and even an olive python about 3m long - even he was excited at spotting this.

We finally reached the Fogg Dam Conservation Reserve, an area made up of flooded wetlands which stretched as far as the eye could see and which were covered with an abundance of wading birds with all sorts of weird legs. After stopping at our overnight camp at Stuart Wilderness, we ventured into the soggy vine forest for a short walk - short partly because of the abundance of leeches and mosquitoes, but also because the skies suddenly opened in a torrential rain storm. We were all faced with a choice: run for shelter or get soaked while hosing down our feet and shoes to get rid of any leeches. The majority, me included, chose the latter.

While waiting for the rain to stop we met Kevin and Ricky, our two Aborigine guides. They took us on a bush walk, showing us the various trees used by the Aborigines for food, fuel and drawing materials, and the woolybark and stringybark used to make didgeridoos. Standing several hundred metres apart, they demonstrated how they communicated by sign language. It was really interesting and they answered all our questions with patience and humour. That evening they put on a show of Aborigine singing, dancing and didgeridoo.  I left the audience participation to the youngsters.

Next day we were up at 6am and into Kakadu, many parts of which are flooded and inaccessible. We went up to Nourlangie Rock to see the Aboriginal rock paintings and the Cultural Centre, which was beautifully laid out and fascinating, then on to Gubara for a 6km walk which ended with a lovely swim at a waterfall. I had expected little tents with primitive cooking facilities at the camp site, and was pleasantly surprised at how civilised it all was, with permanent tents, showers, a fridge in the big communal kitchen tent and a power point to recharge the camera.

There were 11 of us on the tour, all youngsters apart from me and an older Danish couple - a different type of traveller from those I had been meeting on the rest of my trip. These people were mostly just working/travelling/partying round Australia and New Zealand. There can't be many young people left in Ireland - they're all here.They all  happily did the walks in an assortment of skirts, bikini tops and flip-flops, but they were good fun and full of questions and enthusiasm for all we saw. In the evening we played 'two truths and a lie', where you each make three statements, and everyone else has to guess which was the lie. Few got mine right.
1) I was once kissed by Paul McCartney
2) I once went out with a boy called Bertie Clack
3) I once played cricket for Sussex Junior Ladies (answer at the end).
The next day involved more walking, stunning waterfalls and swimming in the Gimbat area. The most impressive waterfall was the Motorcar Falls. This area could only be reached by a four-wheel-drive as a couple of the roads were flooded and partially washed away. Several people tumbled out of their seats as we rock'n'rolled our way through - exciting stuff.

And so we finally arrived back in Darwin, tired and grubby, but happy. Tuesday was spent sleeping, washing clothes and emailing off the group photo to everyone on the trip. I also hired a bike for a couple of hours to explore Darwin. I cycled along the coast and found myself  at an extremely posh marina with luxury houses and yachts. I stopped for a beer, but nobody spoke to me. Maybe it was the hire bike, the scruffy shorts, the scabby knees (from a trip over Bali's unfinished pavements) or the plasters on my feet that gave me away as not belonging to the yachting set.

The Kakadu trip came with a free day at Litchfield National Park which I took up on Wednesday. Litchfield is much smaller and less rugged than Kakadu, but very beautiful. It was another good day with walks to Wangi and Toher Falls and swimming at Buley Hole and Florence Falls. Our picnic lunch was invaded by 94 tourists off a cruise ship. I have never seen so much surplus flesh, and so many fancy sunhats or video cameras concentrated in one group before.

And that was the end of my taste of  the 'top end' of Australia - different again from all I have seen before. I'm glad I was there in the wet season with all the lush vegetation and amazing variety of wildlife. Thanks to Rosy, Graham, Jake and Theresa, Mark and Corina for all the tips. I have done my best but have missed loads. I am getting used to this upside-down land, where you can't tell the tourists from the residents, where the beer is served in bottles with polystyrene cups round them, where the $1 coin is  bigger than the $2 one and everyone really does say 'no worries' in response to everything.  Could you tell a saltie from a freshie if you met one in a billabong? I can now. I am writing a day early as I am off on a six-day tour to Alice Springs and Ayres Rock at 5.30am tomorrow. I will  miss Sam, who I believe has just been there, but hope to meet up with Milly when I get to Sydney. I try to keep an eye on what they're up to, but time in net cafes is a bit hectic (I was in this one before 9am to catch their 'happy hour'). I'll be writing from Alice next week. If anyone has contact with my two sons will they tell them to write to their mother please - I haven't heard from either for a month!

PS Answer: I was never kissed by Paul McCartney - although I did get a peck on the cheek from his brother, when Scaffold (who remembers Lily the Pink?) came to one of my student May balls...

webTitle: The battle to give every baby an equal start in life

fields.headline: The battle to give every baby an equal start in life
fields.trailText: Each year around 725,000 babies are born in the UK. Most will be completely healthy. Yet around 10% will need some kind of special care at birth; 1% will need the highest level of intensive care.
fields.body:
Each year around 725,000 babies are born in the UK. Most will be completely healthy. Yet around 10% will need some kind of special care at birth; 1% will need the highest level of intensive care.

Bliss - the national charity for the newborn - is dedicated to ensuring that every baby receives the best possible care. It works tirelessly to ensure that each sick baby has the greatest chance of growing up to enjoy a strong, healthy and fulfilling life.

Premature and sick babies born today have a far greater chance of survival than they did even 10 years ago. Today, 80% of babies born as early as 26 weeks (ie 14 weeks early) now survive and have a good chance of growing up into a healthy child. Bliss aims to improve these figures still further.

The charity concentrates its work in four key areas:

 Providing specialist equipment to the 253 neonatal units across the UK
Although medical and technological advances mean that sophisticated equipment is now available, NHS funds are always stretched. Bliss aims to ensure that every neonatal unit is fully equipped so it can provide the best possible care for sick newborn babies. Last year Bliss received requests for incubators, monitors, ventilators and other equipment costing over £4m.

 Training and support for neonatal nurses and midwives
Bliss sponsors study days for these professionals to help them update their skills and exchange ideas, views and share their experiences.

Supporting and funding research projects which will benefit the future care of sick babies
These studies provide accurate information and data to both parents and health professionals. It gives them all the latest up-to-date developments about the chances of survival for babies born early; and highlights new ways to improve the ways they are cared for.

Support and advice for parents and families of newborn babies needing special care
Bliss runs a free telephone information and support line. It also provides free leaflets about having a baby in special care. These also give parents information about the various support networks and organisation available to them. Details about local Bliss supporter groups are also available to parents. Family days, where parents can meet up to learn about neonatal care, are also staged around the UK.

Last year Bliss celebrated its 21th anniversary - in some style. Cherie Blair hosted a reception for Bliss supporters and funders in Downing Street.

The charity was also the beneficiary of a hugely successful Blue Peter Christmas appeal on BBC television. Originally a target of £500,000 was set for this New Life Appeal. This sum was reached within days. By the time the appeal closed the programme's young viewers had raised £2.2m. These funds enabled Bliss to provide specialist equipment for 150 hospitals.

Funding special baby care units in this manner also raises concerns within Bliss about future funding of neonatal medical care under the NHS. Research conducted by the charity revealed that charities committed £10m to neonatal health care last year. More worryingly, 80% of manufacturers' orders for incubators and ventilators came from charities, and not from the NHS.

Last October, Bliss launched a national media campaign to highlight its concerns. It argued that in the area of neonatal care, the NHS was becoming too reliant on charities. Suzanne Dobson, chief executive of Bliss said: "The situation is simply unsustainable." She argued that Bliss and other charities no longer funded "the icing on the cake" for the NHS, but were being forced to act as core providers.

This campaign sparked a national debate about how neonatal units are funded. Some £6.5m extra money was soon forthcoming from the government. The campaign has also led to Bliss taking a more proactive role in policy making and advocating new policies to improve provisions for sick newly born babies across the UK.

 Bliss is holding a family day on March 17. The event is open to anyone who has had a baby in "special care" and would like to share their experiences. It is being held at Marwell Hotel, next to Marwell Zoo, Winchester, Hampshire, starting at 10.30am. Attendance costs £10 per adult, including food and refreshments. Details: (freephone) 0500 618140.

Yet around 10% will need some kind of special care at birth; 1% will need the highest level of intensive care. Bliss - the national charity for the newborn - is dedicated to ensuring that every baby receives the best possible care. It works tirelessly to ensure that each sick baby has the greatest chance of growing up to enjoy a strong, healthy and fulfilling life. Premature and sick babies born today have a far greater chance of survival than they did even 10 years ago. Today, 80% of babies born as early as 26 weeks (ie 14 weeks early) now survive and have a good chance of growing up into a healthy child. Bliss aims to improve these figures still further. The charity concentrates its work in four key areas:  Providing specialist equipment to the 253 neonatal units across the UK Although medical and technological advances mean that sophisticated equipment is now available, NHS funds are always stretched. Bliss aims to ensure that every neonatal unit is fully equipped so it can provide the best possible care for sick newborn babies. Last year Bliss received requests for incubators, monitors, ventilators and other equipment costing over £4m.  Training and support for neonatal nurses and midwives Bliss sponsors study days for these professionals to help them update their skills and exchange ideas, views and share their experiences. Supporting and funding research projects which will benefit the future care of sick babies These studies provide accurate information and data to both parents and health professionals. It gives them all the latest up-to-date developments about the chances of survival for babies born early; and highlights new ways to improve the ways they are cared for. Support and advice for parents and families of newborn babies needing special care Bliss runs a free telephone information and support line. It also provides free leaflets about having a baby in special care. These also give parents information about the various support networks and organisation available to them. Details about local Bliss supporter groups are also available to parents. Family days, where parents can meet up to learn about neonatal care, are also staged around the UK. Last year Bliss celebrated its 21th anniversary - in some style. Cherie Blair hosted a reception for Bliss supporters and funders in Downing Street. The charity was also the beneficiary of a hugely successful Blue Peter Christmas appeal on BBC television. Originally a target of £500,000 was set for this New Life Appeal. This sum was reached within days. By the time the appeal closed the programme's young viewers had raised £2.2m. These funds enabled Bliss to provide specialist equipment for 150 hospitals. Funding special baby care units in this manner also raises concerns within Bliss about future funding of neonatal medical care under the NHS. Research conducted by the charity revealed that charities committed £10m to neonatal health care last year. More worryingly, 80% of manufacturers' orders for incubators and ventilators came from charities, and not from the NHS. Last October, Bliss launched a national media campaign to highlight its concerns. It argued that in the area of neonatal care, the NHS was becoming too reliant on charities. Suzanne Dobson, chief executive of Bliss said: "The situation is simply unsustainable." She argued that Bliss and other charities no longer funded "the icing on the cake" for the NHS, but were being forced to act as core providers. This campaign sparked a national debate about how neonatal units are funded. Some £6.5m extra money was soon forthcoming from the government. The campaign has also led to Bliss taking a more proactive role in policy making and advocating new policies to improve provisions for sick newly born babies across the UK.  Bliss is holding a family day on March 17. The event is open to anyone who has had a baby in "special care" and would like to share their experiences. It is being held at Marwell Hotel, next to Marwell Zoo, Winchester, Hampshire, starting at 10.30am. Attendance costs £10 per adult, including food and refreshments. Details: (freephone) 0500 618140.

webTitle: The Downing Street baby briber turns Healey's dream on its head

fields.headline: The Downing Street baby briber turns Healey's dream on its head
fields.trailText: March 8: Simon Hoggart responds to the Budget.
fields.body:
Politicians traditionally kiss babies and bribe the electorate. Yesterday Gordon Brown went one better and bribed babies - proof that there is indeed one born every minute.

But before the tax breaks for very young children, the chancellor gave us his traditional annual gloat. I have never seen the Tory party look so glum.

The definitive moment came when he boasted that next year he would repay £34bn in debt - "more in one year than all the debt repaid by previous governments over the past 50 years!"

When Israel won the six day war, Jewish people around the world suddenly saw themselves in a new light, as victors rather than victims. It was a profound psychological change. In the same way Labour MPs now see themselves as the party of economic competence.

They cannot quite grasp it, but they like it. It feels good. And the fact that like the six day war it may lead to plenty more trouble ahead does not bother them one little bit.

The Tories were thunderstruck by the chancellor's boast, as if their entire air force had, so to speak, been destroyed on the ground. Michael Portillo looked utterly miserable. Oliver Letwin and Francis Maude seemed positively distraught. Ann Widdecombe's eyes bulged alarmingly, as if her corsets had come to life and were squeezing the breath out of her. Michael Ancram, the normally ebullient party chairman, gave the impression of a man who has just detected a ferret climbing his trousers, north towards his Y-fronts.

Only Angela Browning allowed herself a little smile, but then it is possible that she was not sure what Mr Brown was talking about.

As Bob Marshall-Andrews remarked last month, the chancellor is a typical lowland Scot, who believes in the virtues of toil and plunder. We might add thrift and pillage. There were endless references to "hard-working families". He used the word "stability" 13 times (though poor old Prudence got only two mentions; Mr Brown is now a married man, and poor Prudence has been abandoned at the stage door, like so many other young, sobbing soubrettes).

At the same time, it was a budget for sin. Cigarettes and booze are not going up. Betting tax is to be abolished. This was not the Budget you would expect from a son of the manse.

Denis Healey used to muse whether it would be possible to put a tax on sex. By giving credits for the consequences of sex - babies - Mr Brown has, most surprisingly, gone off in the opposite direction.

He sat down to loud applause from his own lot and morose, morbid silence from the others. For there is a smell of death about the Tory party.

Mr Hague decided to apply the electrodes and bring his monster twitching back to life. It was a difficult job but he made a good effort. Mr Brown had always listed his tax cuts in the Budget speech, but left others to find the tax rises in the small print. "He is the thief who steals your car then comes back in the morning to return your hubcaps," he said.

"You can't fool all of the people all of the time, but you can fool all Labour MPs on Budget day," he went on. Quite right. Fooling your own party is a chancellor's most important job, and Mr Brown did it very well.

Meanwhile, Mr Hague cheered his own party up mightily. It will not do good in the long run, but he must have enjoyed it yesterday.

fields.headline: Brown sets it up, but will we all buy it?
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Budget 2001
Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Cast your mind back nine long years. Norman Lamont stood up to deliver his Budget speech with the economy deep in recession, businesses going bankrupt in droves and unemployment heading rapidly towards 3m. Yet, Lamont had one trump to play. He announced a tax cut in the form of a new 20% band of income tax, thereby setting the terms of the economic debate in the election campaign that was launched by John Major the very next day.
fields.body:
Cast your mind back nine long years. Norman Lamont stood up to deliver his Budget speech with the economy deep in recession, businesses going bankrupt in droves and unemployment heading rapidly towards 3m. Yet, Lamont had one trump to play. He announced a tax cut in the form of a new 20% band of income tax, thereby setting the terms of the economic debate in the election campaign that was launched by John Major the very next day.

This was the way things were during the long Conservative hegemony. As an election loomed, the chancellor would cut taxes and tie his Labour opponent up in knots by challenging him to match the reductions pound for pound.

The real political significance of Gordon Brown's address yesterday was that it turned the orthodoxy of the past 20 years on its head. One thing is certain: whenever the election is held, it will not turn into a Dutch auction on tax. Instead, it will be up to the Conservatives either to match Labour's 3.7% increases in public spending in each of the next three years or to say where they expect to make savings. All the signs suggest that William Hague and Michael Portillo will have just as much trouble convincing the voters that their plans add up as did Neil Kinnock and John Smith did in 1992.

Naturally, the picture is a bit more complex than this. Despite the extra money for schools and hospitals, the biggest single winner from yesterday's package was the road lobby, a rather inconvenient fact in the light of the prime minister's "greening of Britain" pledge on Tuesday. Nor is Brown's political victory complete. He may have rehabilitated the idea of higher public spending, but he has not even attempted to do the same for tax.

But the environmental damage caused by caving in to the road lobby will not be evident for some time, and higher tax is not an issue that political parties care to talk about when polling day is probably less than two months away. The real point of the Budget was to set the terms of combat for the election and that Brown has done. Unlike previous Labour chancellors, he has not presided over economic disaster or humiliation; indeed, the first chunk of his speech was given over to a familiar litany of achievement - lowest inflation, interest rates and unemployment in decades. There have been no devaluations, no visits from the International Monetary Fund, no crisis measures. The squeeze on spending came early, not late.

The benign state of the economy is not all the chancellor's doing. He was at pains yesterday to paint a black picture of the country on the day Labour came to power, but the reality was that he had the finest inheritance of any Labour chancellor. The economy was already doing well when the Conservatives left office, and through a mixture of luck and skill Brown has ensured that it has stayed that way. Had Kenneth Clarke still been at the Treasury, he too would have had barrowloads of money with which to cut taxes or increase spending.

But by securing a reputation for economic competence, Brown has been able to shift economic priorities in two distinct ways. The increases in spending on health and education over the next three years were large enough even without the top-ups announced yesterday, although they needed to be after the austerity of the first two years. The fact that some of the money is to be used for recruitment and retention drives in the NHS and in education is evidence of the problems caused by sticking to the spending plans laid down by Clarke ahead of the 1997 election. There is a lot more to do in a second term.

Second, Brown has been able to make the tax and benefit system more progressive, a stark difference from the consistently regressive trend between 1979 and 1997. A lot of the rhetoric of New Labour has been about its new-found admiration for risk-taking entrepreneurs, but the beneficiaries of fiscal policy have been those at the bottom of the income scale. The national minimum wage, the working families tax credit, reductions in income tax and national insurance contributions and the increases to child benefit and income-related benefit have helped the poor far more than the rich.

According to the Treasury's budget red book, every group of working age households has gained as a result of Labour's five Budgets since 1997. But whereas the richest 10% are better off by around £2 a week, the poorest 10% of working age households are almost £20 a week better off. The second poorest 10% of households are doing even better, because more of them are in work, and Brown's tax credits have been aimed at the working poor.

Will middle England swallow all this? They will provided interest rates stay low, and Brown's decision to spare drinkers and smokers higher excise duties will drive down inflation and keep pressure on the Bank to cut interest rates even though demand is being expanded. Cute that. Very cute.

"You can't fool all of the people all of the time, but you can fool all Labour MPs on Budget day," he went on. Quite right. Fooling your own party is a chancellor's most important job, and Mr Brown did it very well. Meanwhile, Mr Hague cheered his own party up mightily. webTitle: Comment: A bypass in our democracy

fields.headline: A bypass in our democracy
fields.standfirst:
Plans for a south coast motorway must be destroyed, not just hidden

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Plans for a south coast motorway must be destroyed, not just hidden.
fields.body:
The primary purpose of all new development is to provide contracts for developers. When they obtain permission to proceed, the value of the land they own can rise a thousandfold. Credit lines open, the Treasury unlocks its gates, and public funds are turned into private income.

Some developments have a secondary purpose: to deliver public benefits. But when there is no conceivable advantage for anyone outside the construction industry, their backers can proceed only with a little help from their friends.

In the 1980s, the Conservative government, assiduously lobbied by the road-building firms, set out to persuade the public that new roads relieve traffic and generate wealth. Local editors and businessmen were wined and dined by civil servants, public enquiries were rigged, consultation documents warned - in the face of all the evidence - that without more construction the economy would collapse.

But the biggest prize remained elusive. The road builders wanted a motorway along the south coast, from Folkestone in Kent to Honiton in Devon. The contracts would be worth more than £5bn. But the new road would pass through several marginal constituencies, destroying some of Britain's most beautiful landscapes and best protected ancient monuments. The Tories backed down. But developers never give up. This month Tony Blair, who promised on Tuesday to put the environment "at the top of the agenda", will decide whether or not to revive one of the most devastating developments ever proposed in Britain.

The roadbuilders' problem is that there is no earthly need for a motorway. Nearly all the cars on the south coast route are local, moving to and from the nearest towns. Long-distance traffic uses the M20, M25, M3 and A303. So it will have to be built by stealth. The scheme has been repackaged as a series of bypasses. When the bypasses are linked up, a motorway miraculously appears.

But before you can build your bypasses, first you must build your congestion. You must start at the most vulnerable point on the route, where traffic problems are already severe and deprivation can be used as an excuse for development. Hastings was the obvious choice.

So the lobbyists, working now through the local authorities and the local newspapers they recruited while the Tories were in power, relaunched the Hastings section of the south coast motorway as a "regeneration" scheme, linked to a new business park outside Bexhill. The town's proposed bypasses, the local papers claim on an almost daily basis, will reduce unemployment and relieve congestion.

Unfortunately the "multimodal study" commissioned to assess the scheme reached precisely the opposite conclusion. The new roads will draw employers out of Hastings, increasing joblessness there by 300. The long-term unemployed, most of whom live in the town centre and do not possess cars, will suffer most. The new housing attached to the bypasses will increase the workforce by 3,900, while the business park will supply a maximum of 3,100 jobs: unemployment will rise by 800.

And crucially, far from relieving congestion, the new scheme will compound it. The Hastings bypasses will load an extra 1,000 cars a day on to the A259 to the east, and 2,500 on to the A27 to the west. These volumes are insupportable. As the consultants' report concludes: "This additional traffic may create additional pressure for further road building along the strategic east/west axis." And that road building, will, in turn, load cars on to the surrounding roads, generating inexorable pressure for the completion of a motorway from Folkestone to Honiton.

Once you have recruited the newspapers, the MP, especially in a Labour marginal such as Hastings, falls into the bag. Mike Foster has pegged his political survival to the construction of the new roads. On the Today programme three weeks ago, I warned him that if he continued to claim that the new roads would reduce unemployment in Hastings, he would be lying to his constituents. He did not dispute this, but insisted that as the majority of Hastings residents wanted the project to go ahead, the roads had to be built. Anti-bypass campaigners report that as soon as local people are told what the multi-modal study really says, they change their minds.

Mr Blair has a stark choice. He can protect the taxpayer, the environment and the people of the south coast from a monstrous and wholly unnecessary scheme, or he can protect a man whose continued employment depends upon destroying other people's. It shouldn't be a difficult decision to make. But as as the election approaches and the MP totters, our newly green prime minister must be sorely tempted to bypass democracy.

comment@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Minister's culture website scorned
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: The director of the National Portrait Gallery last night denounced the government's cherished Culture Online site, reports Maev Kennedy.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The director of the National Portrait Gallery last night denounced the government's cherished Culture Online, a proposed website which would link all cultural institutions, as "a big shiny vote-catching new project", diverting desperately needed revenue funds from struggling museums.

Culture Online is a pet project of the culture secretary, Chris Smith, fitting his department's emphasis on access and education in museums, galleries and libraries. It is intended to provide a website for all cultural institutions, from national collections to performance art companies.

It would also help to fund getting all the national art collections on line.

The project has been greeted with such suspicion by the Tories that it is in danger of sinking the culture and leisure bill, under which it would be established.

The bill is bogged down in the House of Lords, with hundreds of amendments tabled as a wrecking measure, and is likely to run out of time before the election.

Charles Saumarez Smith, delivering the annual Association of Independent Museums lecture last night, dismissed Culture Online and other high profile high budget projects, as less important to the country than state revenue support for the existing museum sector.

He said the money was clearly available to solve the revenue crisis, now hitting both the national and regional museums.

"The Treasury has sat and watched while approximately a billion pounds of lottery money has been thrown away into a big tent on the marsh flats of north Greenwich.

"The Treasury is currently proposing that it should provide a sum of £150m to establish the largest internet start-up company through Culture Online.

"The lottery has provided approximately £1bn of public money over the last five years for the establishment of a series of new science centres.

"But what is more important to the country as whole? Is it better for the Treasury only to fund grand new projects while permitting the old to starve ?

"Or is it better that it identify an effective system of state-aided revenue support to secure the activities and endeavours and sustainable development of the museum sector to enable a thousand museums to flourish to the benefit of their local communities?"

Mr Saumarez Smith told the Guardian that he was not opposed to Culture Online, which could provide a valuable and extremely interesting service.

"But I am a tiny bit sceptical that it is an untried, untested, hypothetical project, and that it seems yet another example of the big money going to big new projects, at the expense of supporting existing museums."

In his lecture he criticised the government - and its predecessors - for failing to appreciate that the vitality of the museum sector came from independent initiative and variety, not from centralised top down imposed management structures and policies.

This pattern had inevitably become worse since the establishment of the heritage, now the culture, department, he said.

fields.headline: 5m Britons 'living on the breadline'
fields.standfirst: Bristol university centre for the study of social exclusion
fields.trailText: More than 5m people in Britain were living in conditions of absolute poverty during Tony Blair's third year in office, according to research published today on the number of Europeans living below the breadline.
fields.body:
More than 5m people in Britain were living in conditions of absolute poverty during Tony Blair's third year in office, according to research published today on the number of Europeans living below the breadline.

Using a definition of poverty agreed by 117 governments at the 1995 world summit as lack of food, safe drinking water, sanitation facilities, health, shelter, education and information, the study found 9% of British people said their income was a lot below what they needed each week to afford the absolute necessities of life.

The greatest concentration of poverty was among lone parents. More than two-fifths of those with one child said they had incomes below £163 a week, the amount needed to buy the goods and services that most people regarded as basic essentials.

More than half lone parents with two or more children had incomes below their absolute poverty level at £227 a week. And 25% of single pensioners fell below the £106-a-week threshold needed to surmount absolute poverty. In each case benefit levels were about 20% below the income needed to keep people out of absolute poverty if they had to remain on state support for more than about six months, the authors of the study estimated.

The Breadline Europe study, led by academics from Bristol University and the London School of Economics, was based on a social exclusion survey in September 1999, six months after the government began its anti-poverty drive.

Ministers had dismissed previous research showing that numbers in poverty grew over the first two years of the Labour government. They said the position would improve after introduction of the minimum wage and working families tax credit - bringing 1.2m children and 800,000 adults out of poverty by April 2002 and abolishing child poverty completely by 2020.

But time lags in the official data will force the government to go into the next election without hard evidence to demonstrate progress.

The key official poverty indicator, dating from a survey in 1998, will show there were 14m adults in households with less than half average income. This was nearly 1m more than in the early 1990s, and more than double the number in the early 1980s.

The Breadline Europe survey was based on more recent data and measured poverty against a different yardstick, based on the public's assessment of what are the absolute essentials of life. Households lacking at least six of these essentials because they could not afford them were categorised as a lot below the level of income needed to avoid absolute poverty.

David Gordon, senior research fellow at Bristol university and co-author of the report, said people's experiences differed from Treasury models of how they ought to behave.

"Absolute poverty is not supposed to exist in a country like Britain. But 9% of the population have reported their income was a lot below that needed each week to keep their household out of absolute poverty and a further 8% said their income was a little below."

Peter Townsend, professor of international social policy at the LSE and co-author, said the growth of poverty in Britain countered the trend in other western European countries.

"Some observers believe that, under successive governments, the country has been going so far down the road of residualising welfare that it has become detached from most of the other European states and is lamely following in the wake of the US," he said.

The study showed dramatic increases in extreme forms of poverty across eastern Europe over the past 10 years, but the figures could not be compared directly with the UK.

Simon Clarke, professor of sociology at Warwick university, said over 60% of Russians were living in poverty in 1998. "Over a quarter were in extreme poverty, with incomes of less than half that required to acquire basic means of subsistence. This compares to a rate of about 11% at the beginning of reform in 1992," he said.

webTitle: Blair and Ahern call Belfast talks

fields.headline: Blair and Ahern call Belfast talks
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Tony Blair and his Irish counterpart Bertie Ahern are to hold talks in Northern Ireland today with the main pro-agreement parties amid growing fears that political leaders will fail to overcome the deadlock in the peace process ahead of the election.
fields.body:
Tony Blair and his Irish counterpart Bertie Ahern are to hold talks in Northern Ireland today with the main pro-agreement parties amid growing fears that political leaders will fail to overcome the deadlock in the peace process ahead of the election.

As unionists and republicans warned of a stalemate in negotiations, Downing Street insisted last night that the prime minister was determined to resolve the impasse over IRA disarmament in the talks at Hillsborough Castle.

London and Dublin have abandoned any hope of reaching a definitive deal to save the peace process ahead of the election.

They have instead set their sights on brokering an interim deal which would tide the process over until after the election.

fields.headline: Hackers: the political heroes of cyberspace
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Hackers will tonight be declared the ideological heirs to the great protest movements of the 19th and 20th centuries, writes Stuart Millar.
fields.body:
Hackers, the most maligned species of the digital age, will tonight be declared the ideological heirs to the great protest movements of the 19th and 20th centuries.

Once hacking was regarded as the pastime of attention-grabbing nerds. But a meeting at the Institute of Contemporary Arts in London will be told how credible an activity it has become in the era of direct action. Old-fashioned hacking, the meeting will hear, has given way to hacktivism: a highly politicised underground movement using direct action in cyberspace to attack globalisation and corporate domination of the internet.

"Hacktivists have provided a new political ethic for the hacking activity of the past 'that tended to be more about narcissistic power games than any real protest against the system," said Paul Taylor, a sociology lecturer at Salford university. "Hacktivism can be seen as the latest manifestation of a long history of opposition to capitalism and its disorienting effects."

Targets - mainly multinational corporations and political parties - have been hit with a range of electronic weapons, from viruses to email bombs, which crash websites by bombarding them with thousands of protest messages.

Paul Mobbs of a British hacktivist group, the electrohippies collective, will tell the meeting that the internet "removes the advantages that larger or mainstream groups possess, for example money, influence and preferential access to media. No longer are small minorities restricted by lack of access. On the internet all access is roughly equal."

Companies are spending increasing amounts on protecting their computer systems while governments introduce tougher legislation.

Under the Terrorism Act, which came into power last month, anyone who tries to "seriously disrupt an electronic system" with the intention of threatening or influencing the government or the public, and does it to advance a "political, religious or ideological cause", can be classed as a terrorist.

Another new law, the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act, gives police and the security services the power to collect internet information without a warrant and to demand the keys to encrypted material.

fields.headline: House calls
fields.standfirst: New, affordable homes for rent are needed - particularly in London and the south-east. But powerful lobbies oppose plans by developers
fields.trailText: New, affordable homes for rent are needed - particularly in London and the south-east. But powerful lobbies oppose plans by developers.
fields.body:
In 10 years' time Alan Holmans will either be discredited or forgotten or, more likely, statues of him will be erected in the new estates around the south of England that will be needed to accommodate the explosive growth he projects in numbers of households.

The former civil servant turned Cambridge University researcher has become housing's Cassandra. His latest forecast says that across England 230,000 newly-built homes or conversions will be needed each year until at least 2016.

But look at what the Halifax said this week about house prices. They are rising by £47 a day, which is dandy for existing home owners but makes a decent home less and less affordable for many. The gap will have to be filled by government subsidy. Mr Holmans says 80-85,000 subsidised dwellings are going to be needed each year for the next decade and a half. Only 70-75,000 look like being built. The result will be "very severe worsening of overcrowding and housing standards", especially in London.

The not-for-profit housing associations and the Town and Country Planning Association have just published Mr Holman's latest calculation of the number of households that will come into being over the next two decades*. These "households" are not going to be people wandering the street suitcase in hand. Denied easy access to somewhere to stay people will stay with parents and relatives, share or otherwise squeeze into what is available. But there is a limit to how much boxing and coxing can go on.

The chart breaks the projection down region by region. In the south east outside London, 32,000 dwellings each year are going to be needed either for purchase or private rental without subsidy. London can do it, deputy mayor Nicky Gavron declared the other day, confident that London can grow from 7.4m to 8.1m total population by 2016. Coincidentally the Council for the Protection of Rural England (CPRE) - the Nimbys' best friend - declared its undying opposition to "urban sprawl" and building on green fields.

But London's physical capacity depends on the expansion of the tube - and other social infrastructure. And the protectors of rural England (who are usually reluctant to pay the tax needed to support the urban renewal) need to say where they think the growth being generated in Guildford, Basildon, Ashford and Watford will be placed. The advocates of recycling land within urban boundaries rarely acknowledge its costs including the impact of town cramming on existing urbanites who are going to have to live yet more cheek by jowl with their neighbours.

The CPRE likes to present developers as grasping house-builders, putting Barratt-style boxes on the greensward. But much of the demand is going to be for single-person dwellings that are affordable, which means public subsidy will have to be put not only into construction but also to help with the rent.

Broadly, in the three decades since 1970 median earnings have just about kept up with house prices. But the earnings of poorer households increased at an annual rate well below the long run average rise in house prices, especially in the south east. To afford a dwelling costing £106,000 (the average for England and Wales) you would need a household income of about £34,000, well above the average. And there are regional complications, for while house prices are cheaper north of Watford, wages are not markedly less.

The government is trying to make council and housing association rents more market sensitive. That tends to mean lowering them in the north and raising them in the south. But land prices in the south-east are accelerating and plans for new building often depend on heroic assumptions about future levels of housing benefit - which successive governments say they are going to cut but do not.

Some criticise Alan Holmans and the housing providers for crying wolf. Homelessness defined as those accepted by councils as in dire need is only 100,000 - the number "roofless" sleeping on the streets is now negligible. Politically, housing remains low profile. But Ken Livingstone and John Prescott see eye to eye on the need to offer teachers, nurses and police officers in the capital access to subsidised rented property - for how else could they afford to live in London? Disarray in the administration of housing benefit may be due to the growing gap between demand for and supply of affordable houses and flats.

Things, says Mr Holmans, can only get worse. Men's death rates are falling; immigration into the UK (usually into London and the south-east) is up. More men are living alone - if they can find somewhere to stay. They may have reasonable incomes but they are not yuppies who can afford docklands.

Over the years policy makers have talked about trying to make England outside the south-east more attractive, keeping the indigenous population of the Midlands and north at home and maybe even making the low housing- demand regions beckon people from the south. Short of forced marches, these schemes of internal redistribution of population are not going to be realised. fields.bodyText: In 10 years' time Alan Holmans will either be discredited or forgotten or, more likely, statues of him will be erected in the new estates around the south of England that will be needed to accommodate the explosive growth he projects in numbers of households. The former civil servant turned Cambridge University researcher has become housing's Cassandra. His latest forecast says that across England 230,000 newly-built homes or conversions will be needed each year until at least 2016. But look at what the Halifax said this week about house prices. They are rising by £47 a day, which is dandy for existing home owners but makes a decent home less and less affordable for many. The gap will have to be filled by government subsidy. Mr Holmans says 80-85,000 subsidised dwellings are going to be needed each year for the next decade and a half. Only 70-75,000 look like being built. The result will be "very severe worsening of overcrowding and housing standards", especially in London. The not-for-profit housing associations and the Town and Country Planning Association have just published Mr Holman's latest calculation of the number of households that will come into being over the next two decades*. These "households" are not going to be people wandering the street suitcase in hand. Denied easy access to somewhere to stay people will stay with parents and relatives, share or otherwise squeeze into what is available. But there is a limit to how much boxing and coxing can go on. The chart breaks the projection down region by region. In the south east outside London, 32,000 dwellings each year are going to be needed either for purchase or private rental without subsidy. London can do it, deputy mayor Nicky Gavron declared the other day, confident that London can grow from 7.4m to 8.1m total population by 2016. Coincidentally the Council for the Protection of Rural England (CPRE) - the Nimbys' best friend - declared its undying opposition to "urban sprawl" and building on green fields. But London's physical capacity depends on the expansion of the tube - and other social infrastructure. And the protectors of rural England (who are usually reluctant to pay the tax needed to support the urban renewal) need to say where they think the growth being generated in Guildford, Basildon, Ashford and Watford will be placed. The advocates of recycling land within urban boundaries rarely acknowledge its costs including the impact of town cramming on existing urbanites who are going to have to live yet more cheek by jowl with their neighbours. The CPRE likes to present developers as grasping house-builders, putting Barratt-style boxes on the greensward. But much of the demand is going to be for single-person dwellings that are affordable, which means public subsidy will have to be put not only into construction but also to help with the rent. Broadly, in the three decades since 1970 median earnings have just about kept up with house prices. But the earnings of poorer households increased at an annual rate well below the long run average rise in house prices, especially in the south east. To afford a dwelling costing £106,000 (the average for England and Wales) you would need a household income of about £34,000, well above the average. And there are regional complications, for while house prices are cheaper north of Watford, wages are not markedly less. The government is trying to make council and housing association rents more market sensitive. That tends to mean lowering them in the north and raising them in the south. But land prices in the south-east are accelerating and plans for new building often depend on heroic assumptions about future levels of housing benefit - which successive governments say they are going to cut but do not. Some criticise Alan Holmans and the housing providers for crying wolf. Homelessness defined as those accepted by councils as in dire need is only 100,000 - the number "roofless" sleeping on the streets is now negligible. Politically, housing remains low profile. But Ken Livingstone and John Prescott see eye to eye on the need to offer teachers, nurses and police officers in the capital access to subsidised rented property - for how else could they afford to live in London? Disarray in the administration of housing benefit may be due to the growing gap between demand for and supply of affordable houses and flats. Things, says Mr Holmans, can only get worse. Men's death rates are falling; immigration into the UK (usually into London and the south-east) is up. More men are living alone - if they can find somewhere to stay. They may have reasonable incomes but they are not yuppies who can afford docklands. Over the years policy makers have talked about trying to make England outside the south-east more attractive, keeping the indigenous population of the Midlands and north at home and maybe even making the low housing- demand regions beckon people from the south. Short of forced marches, these schemes of internal redistribution of population are not going to be realised. That means there will have to more building in the southern counties, whatever the green lobbies say - unless housing standards are sharply to decline. *Housing demand and need in England 1996-2016 from TCPA 0207 9308903. fields.headline: Save him for the nation
fields.standfirst:
Chris Smith has been an effective champion of the arts. His job must not be allowed to disappear

Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Chris Smith has been an effective champion of the arts. His job must not be allowed to disappear.
fields.body:
Yesterday, with a Budget flourish, the chancellor cleared a major stumbling block in the way of national museums wishing to offer free admission to all. The change in tax rules brings them into line with local authority museums in being able to reclaim VAT. It is most unlikely that this deft advance would have been achieved without the influence of a secretary of state for culture.

Yet news has emerged that the government may be planning to abolish the department and pass the creative industries - cinema, pop music and broadcasting, as well as the arts - into the tender care of the huge Department of Trade and Industry and the DfEE. The arts, which have gained a place in so many aspects of national life in recent years, are important "earners", but to place creativity alongside manufacturing industry in this way could only result in a huge loss of impact.

In the 60s, the Labour minister Jennie Lee cared passionately about the arts and became their legendary spokesman. However, hers was not a Cabinet position. When John Major created the Department of National Heritage in 1992, the arts minister finally crossed that Rubicon. The Tory years saw real progress, such as Virginia Bottomley's imaginative scheme to designate some regional museum collections as of national importance.

Then in 1997 the department was redefined and renamed. There have since been huge advances both in funding and in the place of culture in society. We see evidence of this change every day at Tate Modern where thanks to Chris Smith's commitment to free admission the national collections are evidently being enjoyed by tens of thousands of people who have never before been art enthusiasts or gallery visitors.

The term "National Heritage" had suggested a primary concern with preserving the past. But the present government has encouraged contemporary culture and when last week Tony Blair held a seminar on creativity in Britain, the discussion showed that the arts are increasingly a factor in the life of many different communities. The recent decision to publish a green paper on creativity in 2010, alongside policy papers on education, health and crime is further evidence of a wish to make the arts part of the "core script". Culture influences education, health, employment and national income. But if it does not remain a discrete entity within government, its more subtle concerns will be doubtless be marginalised.

The pity is that this proposal has emerged at a time when there has been real progress in the government's drive to widen access to the arts, with much of the momentum being due to the personal influence of Chris Smith. Can we really believe that he will be the last secretary of state for culture?

The closing of the VAT loophole for museums announced yesterday has not emerged out of the blue. On his appointment, he made it clear that free admission to museums would be a cornerstone of his programme. He has maintained free admission where it was in place and steadily delivered change in the charging museums, a step at a time, beginning with free admission for children and senior citizens in 2000.

Another of Smith's successes has been to ensure the continuation of public broadcasting by the BBC through the licence fee. It would have been easy to have abandoned this tradition, for which Britain has been widely admired, in the face of "the new realities" of multi-channel broadcasting.

Yet the role of arts and culture in our society remains difficult to define in conventional terms. Frequently it is misunderstood or misrepresented but we can all point to examples of the humanising influence in creating shared experience and a shared sense of community in modern society. Our European counterparts take it for granted that culture has a natural place in government.

Of course, film, pop music and broadcasting have emerged as key foreign earners, a fact acknowledged by the plan to hive them off to the DTI. However, to justify artistic activity mainly in terms of the economy does not take into account all the other benefits that flow from the energy of our musicians, designers, architects, artists and performers.

Increasingly, the secretary of state has found new money and has been able to argue that the arts play a part in education, should play a greater role in broadcasting, contribute to the environment, help reduce crime in urban areas and improve the life of those in hospital. It is increasingly recognised that the arts can have a meaning for all communities in every section of society. The department's emphasis on both making the best available to people, and looking for new ways of reaching audiences, has begun to have a profound impact. This work must be continued.

Sir Nicholas Serota is director of Tate.

webTitle: Just how good a chancellor is Gordon Brown?

fields.headline: Just how good a chancellor is Gordon Brown?
fields.standfirst:
Capitalism finds a friend who embraces the market - but wants to banish child poverty

Special report: Budget 2001
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Capitalism finds a friend who embraces the market - but wants to banish child poverty.
fields.body:
Back in the early 1980s at the height of Labour's civil war, Sir Keith Joseph, the architect of Thatcherism, confided to fellow Tory Norman Lamont that "one day there will be a Labour government that believes in capitalism, and that will be our greatest achievement".

As William Hague sat listening to Gordon Brown's Budget speech yesterday afternoon he could have been forgiven for thinking that Sir Keith's achievement was his biggest stumbling block on the road to Downing Street. Every leader of the opposition has trouble responding cold to the Budget speech, but for Mr Hague the problem was more acute than for most. As far as both the markets and the voters are concerned, Labour now offers the same sort of anti-inflationary and low tax environment that the Tories used to offer - only under Brown they have done it better.

Brown has become Labour's philosopher king, just as Nigel Lawson came to define Thatcherism's tenets. And as Lawson's stature sometimes led to uncomfortable relations with the lady next door, so the Brown-Blair alliance has seen its share of strains. Brown also shares with Lawson a fundamental conviction about how modern economies work: governments should concentrate less on pumping up demand and more on getting the supply side right. Under Brown's guidance, Labour has fully embraced the market, privatisation and low taxation. No clearer sign of how Labour thinking has changed is that Brown's first act in office was to establish an independent Bank of England. In 1945, Labour's first economic policy was to nationalise it.

Prudence for a purpose

The emergence of "Iron Gordon" has won plaudits from financial markets and rightwing commentators. But the chancellor has always said that "prudence is for a purpose" and designed to enable him to deliver traditional leftwing goals of redistribution. This has been controversial and sometimes politically damaging to his own party. But it is nothing to the headache it has given the Tories who, despite four shadow chancellors in as many years, have yet to come up with an answer.

As Lord Howe, Margaret Thatcher's first chancellor, explains, Labour's acceptance of the economic principles that shaped the Thatcherite philosophy compares with the Conservative party's decision to live with the welfare state. The Brown approach, he says, creates difficulties for Mr Hague because having defined the common ground, the Tories have now had it stolen from them. "We did what [Labour's Clement] Attlee did in 1945. He redefined the common ground and Rab Butler had to persuade the Conservative party to move on to it. Blair, perhaps more clearly than Brown, saw the need to move on to our common ground.

"But it makes it much harder for the people who have been designing it [to respond]. They tend to want to move still further to the right. It is a temptation for the 'no turning back group' to become the 'bash on regardless group'. I am sure that is not the right way to go."

Labour's manifestos trace its ideological shift over the past two decades; politically inevitable, given the scale of its landslide defeats in 1983 and 1987 and John Major's against the odds victory during the slump of 1992. The extent to which the political tide was running against Labour's traditional platform - a mixed economy, centralised control of nationalised industries and, among some members of the party, Keynesian demand management - is recalled by Lord Young, secretary of state for trade and industry in the 1980s. He relates the story of an American futurologist predicting in 1975 that the two European countries with the lowest standard of living in the year 2000 would be Albania and Britain. "We did change the world," he said. "The UK, which was the sick man of Europe, became the healthy man of Europe. There were three reasons. We gave the unions back to their members, reduced taxes and encouraged management to manage, and privatised. I remember Mrs Thatcher saying: 'The test of whether we have succeeded will be when all the entrepreneurial Britons come home'. In the 1980s they did.

"Mrs Thatcher's final victory was Tony Blair. Perhaps not so much Tony Blair but the acceptance [by Labour] that we have to have a competitive market economy. I genuinely felt in the 1987 that the outcome of that election would transform the life of the country. If we went with Neil Kinnock and the 1987 manifesto we would have been going back to where we were in the 1970s."

Emerging differences

Another former Tory chancellor, Lord Lamont, takes a rather different view. He believes Brown does have a distinct idea about what he wants to do with the credibility he has won by his tough macroeconomic stewardship. "What Gordon wants is to be the chancellor who solved the poverty trap", he says. This is where the real distinction between New Labour and Thatcherism has become clearer. Under the Conservatives the price of driving down inflation and making British industry more competitive was an explosion in inequality and an increase in relative poverty. Brown's policies have concentrated both on making business more productive, so far with scant success, and with quiet, but extensive redistribution. The minimum wage, the working families tax credit, the children's tax credit, increases in child benefit, and the minimum pension guarantee, have all been aimed at those at the bottom end of the income scale. Means testing has become much more prevalent, but bodies such as the Institute for Fiscal Studies say that benefits for the less well off have become more generous.

John Monks, the general secretary of the TUC, is one of those who gets impatient when people say Brown is a Tory in disguise. "He has been very successful. Look at the government's record on unemployment and inflation. He might have had some luck but everyone is entitled to a little luck. I think there has been a real difference.

"It may not have been all that clear for the first two years when he was sticking to [Tory] spending plans. Now he is releasing more money for areas such as health and education. I think he has done very well. He does not look at all like a Tory chancellor now."

This is where Brown's Conservative admirers start to have their doubts. They like Iron Gordon, but are getting a bit worried about a "Red Gordon" lurking in the shadows. "I don't think it makes an sense to go from famine to feast," says Lord Lamont. "There has been very strict control on public spending that I don't believe the Conservative party would have achieved - followed by 8% growth which is ludicrously high. I doubt if the public sector can cope. This is a tax and spend government. You are getting the tax first and the spending later."

Business, too, is starting to have one or two misgivings. There are concerns about higher public spending crowding out private sector investment and about the increasing regulatory burden.

Sir Clive Thompson, chief executive of Rentokil Initial and a former president of the CBI, is complimentary about Brown's handling of the big picture, but warns: "I think business is concerned that public spending as a proportion of GDP may well rise substantially because of the chancellor's plans for the future."

The sharpest criticisms of Mr Brown's handling of both the macroeconomy and the supply side come from his immediate predecessor, Kenneth Clarke, even though to an unjaundiced observer the policies of the two men display a great deal of continuity. But when he arrived in office, Brown rubbished Clarke, and Clarke now has no compunction about returning the favour. "When I was in office we were able to boast we had the fastest growth of the major western European economies. Gordon has not been able to repeat that boast."

Clarke has two big gripes. The first is that the Bank of England has been needlessly hawkish, creating an over-strong pound which has damaged manufacturing industry and agriculture. The second is the erratic way public finances have been handled, according to Clarke.

"There have been three lean years to be followed by four fat ones. He had no reason to squeeze public spending so ferociously for the first years. He cut the overall level of public spending by 0.5% in each of the first two years. Public spending is the lowest proportion of GDP since the 1960s. Now for four years were are going to get the highest rates of spending we have seen since the war. The government can't make its mind up. Sometimes it surprises by the extent to which it introduces private sector disciplines into the public sector, the next minute it is intervening in areas of the economy where it is not competent to do so."

But as Clarke admits, he found it utterly impossible in 1997 to convince the voters that Labour posed a threat to their living standards. Four years and five Budgets later, Mr Hague is struggling to do better, knowing all the time that oppositions do not win elections, governments do lose them.

fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The IRA today agreed to reopen negotiations on disarmament as Tony Blair launched a major new bid to end the deadlock threatening the future of the Northern Ireland peace process.
fields.body:
The IRA today agreed to reopen negotiations on disarmament as Tony Blair launched a major new bid to end the deadlock threatening the future of the Northern Ireland peace process.

The provisionals said they were prepared to have talks with General John de Chastelain's decommissioning body for the first time since June last year, but demanded the government deliver on promises on policing and demilitarisation.

The IRA's announcement came just before the prime minister and the republic's taoiseach Bertie Ahern started a series of meetings with Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble and Sinn Fein leader Gerry Adams at Hillsborough Castle near Belfast.

Mr Blair and Mr Ahern met first before breaking off for a series of one-to-one meetings with Mr Trimble, Mr Adams and the deputy first minister, Seamus Mallon.

Sinn Fein are resisting Ulster Unionist demands to begin emptying their arms dumps, and Mr Blair is under huge republican pressure to start clearing the south Armagh countryside of military surveillance towers.

More importantly, the republicans want him to make significant changes in government plans for future police arrangements in Northern Ireland.

The IRA said they remained committed to lasting peace but insisted all sides needed to play their part, including the British government.

Ulster Unionists immediately dismissed the announcement as an attempt by the IRA to cover their backs if today's talks break up without any significant progress. But republicans believe it could allow the sides inside Hillsborough Castle today some more negotiating space.

The reopening of negotiations between the IRA and General de Chastelain is certain to increase pressure on Mr Trimble to lift the ban on Sinn Fein's two Stormont ministers, Martin McGuinness and Bairbre de Brun, from attending north-south ministerial meetings.

Mr Trimble emerged from the talks describing the IRA statement as a "pre-emptive strike".

webTitle: Budget hints at manifesto pledge for housing repairs

fields.headline: Budget hints at manifesto pledge for housing repairs
fields.trailText: A member of the government's urban task force has predicted that a pledge to cut VAT for repair to homes could be one of the government manifesto pledges.
fields.body:
A member of the government's urban task force has predicted that a pledge to cut VAT for repair to homes could be one of the government manifesto pledges.

Yesterday's budget introduced a limited number of VAT changes which the treasury's red book claimed would help create an extra 3,700 new homes a year.

But once again, chancellor Gordon Brown resisted widespread calls for a cut in VAT to repairs.

But Tony Burton, director of policy at the Council for the Protection of Rural England and a urban task force member, claimed that a manifesto pledge was now likely to provide a second term Labour government with a mandate to equalise the rate of tax between new build and repairs.

"I don't think this is the end of the issue," said Mr Burton. "This was as far as he could go before an election. I would not be surprised if we saw that commitment in the manifesto."

He claimed the reason that Mr Brown did not go further was "political fear" of the powerful house builders lobby. He pointed out that house builders would claim that increase on new build would be a tax on house buying and a move to stoke the already over heated housing market.

On the budget itself, Mr Burton said: "There are useful measures here to boost regeneration, but the package itself is not enough."

The government is expected to set out which deprived areas will benefit from the stamp duty tax relief over the next few weeks. It has delayed the announcement while it sorts discrepancies in the index of deprivation that currently exist between England, Scotland and Wales.
