webTitle: Labour is 'the largest tax raising government of all time'

fields.headline: Labour is 'the largest tax raising government of all time'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown came under fire today for a budget which Tories allege makes the Labour administration "the largest tax raising government of all time."
fields.body:
Gordon Brown came under fire today for a budget which Tories allege makes the Labour administration "the largest tax raising government of all time."

Shadow trade and industry secretary David Heathcoat-Amory launched a blistering attack on yesterday's speech from the chancellor, accusing him of "subterfuge" and "sleight of hand" - and dubbing the cheering Labour backbenchers as "gullible."

In the second day of debate on Mr Brown's budget, Mr Heathcoat-Amory claimed the small print of Wednesday's speech meant a "parallel budget was emerging from the mist."

And he added: "They tax more than they have announced previously, but they spend less."

Answering for the opposition, he warned: "The government is taking a colossal risk. It is vulnerable to any downturn in the world economy, but more than that, even if there isn't a hiccup they are eroding the competitiveness of the British economy, on which all this expenditure depends."

The government was also attacked by the Liberal Democrats for failing Britain's farmers. Lib Dem Colin Breed, MP for South East Cornwall, said there were still too many low-income families in rural areas.

Yesterday's budget must have been a "bitter blow" for farmers because all they received was a "free tax disc" for their tractors, he said. Being outside the euro has been a disaster for farmers, he added.

And Tory veteran John Townend, MP for Yorkshire East said: "Clearly this government is not New Labour any longer. It is Old Labour disguised. It is a high tax government and this is the most outrageous breach of promises and commitments."

But Trade and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers hit back and insisted: "The Budget takes a balanced approach between prudent long term investment and targeted tax cuts for hard working people, pensioners and savers."

Mr Byers announced that the government would consider ways to help working parents pay for child care in their own homes, including a possible extension of the working families tax credit.

Under increases announced by Mr Brown yesterday, families on the scheme can claim £135 a week for child care costs but only if the youngsters are placed in nursery or with a childminder.

But parents working irregular hours - such as nurses on night shifts - who need to have their children looked after at home, are excluded.

Mr Byers told the Commons he had been made very aware of the difficulties when he met a group of mothers in Bolton.

"A number of them were nurses who graphically described to me the difficulties they had with providing quality child care whilst working irregular hours at their local hospital.

"They said support for child care costs in their own home would be a significant advance. It would also benefit families who have a child with a disability.

"I'm therefore pleased to be able to announce that we will now consider how we can help these families."

His announcement was greeted with warm murmurs of approval from several female Labour backbenchers.

fields.headline: Prudence pays off?
fields.standfirst:
The chancellor's last Budget before the general election leaves his history of meanness still in question

Special report: Budget 2001
Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: March 8: The chancellor's last Budget before the general election leaves his history of meanness still in question, writes Polly Toynbee.
fields.body:
The chancellor's final budget brought the curtain down on the end of New Labour, Act One with a mighty confident flourish. Flowers were thrown, opposition cabbages didn't even reach the stage. Now he retires to the dressing room to prepare for Act Two. Meanwhile the audience contemplates his grand opus so far, wondering what comes next.

This last great performance gave us the chancellor in red mode, poor children's friend, the stealth-taxing secret socialist. No other word but redistribution describes how the money has flowed towards the poorest with a little taken from the top. Why, even his henchmen now use the wicked R-word once banned from New Labour's lexicon. Average and poorer families were again the target of his munificence, new mothers, child care, paternity leave - a budget for poorer women, so a new mother will be £2,240 a year better off. Another 170,000 children will be lifted above poverty levels. And as more billions poured in for hospitals, schools, drug treatment, urban regeneration and myriad good causes - free museums, films, dilapidated churches, sports clubs - that now familiar Brown budget wonderment struck again.

For who could imagine a Labour chancellor with £16bn in his pocket, inflation licked, national debt and interest rates down, full employment within grasp? All pensioners (who claim) are in April lifted out of poverty - an unthinkable promise back in 1997, almost as extraordinary as ending child poverty. There has never been so big a step up for the poor. As for the rest? Good times brought jam to every social slice - 4% higher consumer spending each year, average living standards up rosily, mortgages an average £1,200 cheaper, growth outstripping all predictions. Happy days and the best is yet to come, as the public spending jam rolls out in earnest now.

So there are red roses aplenty for red Gordon. He has turned the political debate away from tax cuts - there were none, only extra credits for the poor. That was a crucial test of his nerve. How tempting with so much cash to knock another 1p off pre-election income tax. It was a 1999 error not repeated because it didn't need to be. Labour has gained in confidence since then and the public mood is with them - pressing for spending, not for tax cuts.

This chancellor congratulates himself on long-termism, but after an excellent first act, the end of his story is still unknown, judgment too early to make. For all the feel-good glow each of his budgets brings, there remains the big long-term question. Will he effect a fundamental and long-term shift in Britain's tax and spend regime? The year 2003-2004 is the crunch by which time the spending now laid out must have delivered undeniable results in health, education and transport - with public services proud, well-paid and thrusting ahead for all to see. Current public patience will run out by then. Tory posters reading "You paid the cash, so where are the nurses/teachers ..." and so on make people snort with scorn at Tory cheek now - but not by then if change is not everywhere about to be seen. As people get yearly richer, so expectations of public services rise too. Never before has a Labour government produced increases in public investment above trend growth, and yet the big picture is still a history of under-spending.

If it turns out that Act One was as good as it ever gets, then this first term was not enough. If recession rolls in on a dark tide from across the Atlantic, then we will look back and wonder how Labour did so little when the times were extraordinarily good. Why so timid, why so slow? The chancellor may have ended boom-and-bust but what we had instead in public spending was bust-and-boom. The depth of that bust is becoming ever more apparent: the price of prudence was painfully high. It will now not be until 2003-4 that Britain returns to the same level of public spending as a proportion of GDP that it inherited in 1997. A killer fact.

Of course it is not quite as simple as that. Within that total, the huge sums previously wasted on unemployment and debt interest have been redistributed to excellent effect. But none the less, over any length of time, the amount a country taxes and spends defines fairly accurately the quality of its public service. We will still not be spending nearly enough. It was Tony Blair himself who promised NHS spending would meet the EU average, thus drawing attention to the yawning gap between Europe and Britain in every other public sphere as well. The disastrous failure to spend in 2000 - with a massive £5bn capital undershoot - accidentally added to the time of famine, delaying results.

Another killer fact is that, despite the quite radical redistribution by government, the gap between the rich and poor has still widened under Labour. It always happens in prosperous times, but Labour made no attempt to claw back any of the extra income flowing in to top earners - let alone taxing their growing capital wealth. Indeed, capital gains and inheritance taxes have shrunk to insignificance. Let the Tories grumble about Labour's "45 new stealth taxes", the big picture is still that the rich are getting richer faster than the rest and the poor are still being left behind.

The ongoing comedy of Conservative policy - made not so much on the hoof as in the Magimix - gives Labour the chance to confront the tax question head on. William Hague, excited by George Bush's trillion dollar promise, now says he will make a mind-boggling £114bn tax cut. Suddenly lurching for a wild west alternative, the Tories now oblige Labour to talk honestly about tax. But an open advocacy of virtuous taxation has always been noticeably lacking in every Gordon Brown budget speech. He has extinguished public demand for tax cuts, but that's only half the battle. Hague's axe-man cuts require a broad and principled case to be made positively for taxes: they are not a "burden" if they buy the things that people want.

Praise of public wealth can face down the Tory nostrum that we each spend our own money better than the government does. If Labour's 10-year plans work as well as intended, there will be good evidence that public money well-spent buys much more collectively than citizens can each buy individually. But such words never spring easily to the chancellor's lips. This was a prudent budget - no horse-frightening in the City before an election. But future budgets need more radical shifts. Too often New Labour appeases and buys off opposing forces: this third-way strategy makes few friends or permanent changes. Long-term security for a left of centre government comes from persuading the public of the case for higher taxes - not from stealth or subterfuge. On taxes the people will not be fooled for long, but they might be persuaded to pay more.

fields.headline: And now for the election
fields.standfirst:
• £2bn extra for NHS and schools • £2bn tax cuts to help low paid • £2bn boost for motorists

Special report: election countdown
Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown yesterday put Labour on course for a resounding victory in a spring general election with a mixture of tax cuts and spending increases adding up to the most generous Budget giveaway since the late 1980s.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown yesterday put Labour on course for a resounding victory in a spring general election with a mixture of tax cuts and spending increases adding up to the most generous Budget giveaway since the late 1980s.

Although drivers were the biggest single gainers from the £5bn-plus package, the chancellor tried to set the tone for the forthcoming poll by boosting spending on schools and hospitals - and then challenging the Conservatives to match the increases.

However, he also sought to hedge his bets with a three-pronged approach: £2bn to appease last autumn's fuel protesters with reductions in petrol and diesel duties and cheaper excise licences, slightly less than £2bn on tax cuts mainly aimed at those on low incomes, and £1.8bn on higher public spending. All taxpayers will benefit from the widening of the 10p income tax band.

The chancellor said his package, the most generous since Nigel Lawson's 1988 Budget, could be afforded because the strength of the economy had given him scope to spend more and tax less while maintaining his pledge to repay government debt at record levels.

Tory MPs sat in stunned silence as Mr Brown's 52-minute speech painted a golden economic picture - in which inflation, interest rates and unemployment were at their lowest in a generation - and sought to underpin Labour's already huge opinion poll lead by offering help to a broad range of groups from smokers and drinkers to churches and sports clubs. The chancellor promised £1bn for inner-city renovation, VAT changes to permit free museum access, and extra help for Britain's film industry. He also abolished tax on gambling.

Rejecting William Hague's call for spending to be lower in order to finance across-the-board tax cuts, Mr Brown said: "Our priority has been and is Britain's public services. We will not cut investment but raise it."

Arguing that Conservative plans would result in spending cuts of up to £16bn a year, the chancellor added: "I have rejected this course for Britain's future not only because such deep cuts would move us from our long-term goals, and put hospitals at risk, but also because Britain must not repeat the short-termist mistakes of the 1980s: unfunded, unaffordable tax cuts, higher interest rates, cuts in necessary investment."

The chancellor targeted his tax cuts at the less well-off. A £5-a-week increase in the value of the working families tax credit, a boost from £8.50 to £10 in the new children's tax credit, together with an increase in the band at which income tax is levied at 10%, will leave a married couple with one earner and one child up to £1,200 a year better off if they are in the lower income groups. The same family with an annual income of more than £100,000 will be £132 a year better off.

Increases for health, education and crime-fighting mean real rises in public spending of 3.7% a year over the next three years, even higher than the 3.4% rises announced last summer. Although some City analysts said the overall size of the package was at the top end of what the economy could tolerate, reaction in the markets was muted. The Bank of England has the chance to give an instant verdict on the Budget today when it announces its latest decision on interest rates.

Mr Hague tore into the government as best as he could, complaining that the tax burden had risen from from 35.2% in 1996-7 to 38.2% this year. He accused Mr Brown of being the "10p up, 1p down chancellor" who had raised taxes by £28bn since 1997 - the equivalent of 10p on income tax. Mr Hague said the chancellor was like a thief "who steals your car and comes back next day to return your hub caps".

Charles Kennedy, the Liberal Democrat leader, and his Treasury spokesman, Matthew Taylor, took the opposite view, complaining of missed chances for higher spending on key services.

However, the chancellor's display of Labour's firepower prompted some MPs to predict that - despite the foot and mouth crisis - Tony Blair will not wait for a May 3 election, but call one almost immediately for April 5.

The chancellor announced an extra £1bn for headteachers - up to £15,000 for every school - and another £1bn for hospitals, between £500,000 and £1m per trust, in the fight to restore long-neglected services.

An additional £300m will be allocated over three years to help communities fight drug-related crime.

Mr Brown described his Budget as a response to a century in which the needs of children had been ignored. He announced £500m for an expansion of paid maternity and paternity leave and £1.2bn targeted at children in the poorest families - including a £1,000 "baby credit" from 2002.

Officials were less keen to emphasise the £1.9bn worth of cuts in petrol and vehicle taxes on smaller cars and lorries which Mr Brown confirmed after "consulation" since last November when militant hauliers were threatening renewed blockades if ministers did not heed their plight.

Special report: Budget 2001

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: March 8: This was not a Budget to win an election, but a Budget for an election that is already won, writes Hugo Young.
fields.body:
This was not a Budget to win an election, but a Budget for an election that is already won. Its handouts were slight, its promises distant, its perspectives closer to five years than five weeks. It was like a matching reward for the two years of parsimony with which Gordon Brown began his tenure. Having started in 1997 by creating a first-term platform to prove how conservative he could be, yesterday he built one for the second term in which he and Tony Blair must show how socialistic, at heart, they really are. They have shown long-term rigour, almost to a fault.

Given the size of the surplus, Mr Brown could have given far more away. Most of his predecessors would have done. He doesn't need to be paying down the national debt at this record-breaking rate. Given the imminence of May 3, or even June 7, he could have made blatant offerings to a much wider group of voters than families with children. But given that this is a Blair-Brown government, the most intimate and potent duumvirate of modern times, there was always a decent chance that it would exploit its political strength in order to take economically cautious decisions.

Though they've kept a close eye on the voters, this is what they have done. Before the Budget, uprating of pensions and then the minimum wage reminded many millions that the government was listening. The ministers have looked after the masses. New micro-measures are targeted to keep motorists and hauliers and drinkers happy. But the larger politics of the Budget are almost counter-intuitive. They marry the long road of economic reform to the long life of those who now plan undeviatingly to traverse it.

Over Mr Brown's five Budgets, the occasion has been transformed. The Budget is supposed to be an economic climax, and that's the way it is still treated. We all play the game. There are special supplements and ceremonially spacious television programmes. The details are breathlessly awaited. The rituals of pomp and circumstance have barely changed since the first Budget I can remember, which was Reginald Maudling's in the early 1960s.

While happy to go along with such ornamentalism, Mr Brown has changed the substance into something else. His Budgets have grown into a cunning mixture of measures already leaked and other measures, especially taxes, that the Budget statement itself may omit to specify at all. Once the sacred unveiling of an economic secret, it has become an amalgam of the repetitious and, sometimes, the unrevealed. Once the occasion for a grand overview of the great forces that touched the famous Budget Judgment, it is now an interim statement of work in progress by the chief executive of UK plc.

That's how Gordon Brown sounded yesterday, rattling through a long series of undifferentiated passages, no rise and fall, no break between, no rhetorical shape, some of them detailed, others vague, others alluding to future statements and documents to come. He seemed impatient more than triumphalist, though he had a happy story to tell. The great man was being briefly interrupted in his life's work of digging ever deeper into the entrails of the economy and society. He has been doing it, after all, for more than a decade - 24/7, as they say, every hour, every day, every week - since he was John Smith's deputy in the Kinnock shadow cabinet.

So there was something peremptory in his lack of need to explain his final Budget of the first term. Far from awaiting this definitive statement, Budget-watchers are now meant to have kept up with the copious preliminaries. Anyone who missed those earlier speeches and half-revelations, the unrepeatable sub-texts of the Budget statement itself, doesn't deserve to understand the sheer critical mass of strategy that lies behind it, the long-termism, the profundity of Brown-Blairite social reforms.

In this, Mr Brown is unlike any predecessor not only because of his own seriousness but because of the system he invented in the first week of his tenure. Handing monetary policy over to the monetary policy committee of the Bank was not only good for the stability of the economy. Almost as telling, it released the chancellor from the most neuralgic part of his job, fixing interest rates, thus giving a strategist such as Mr Brown time and space to undertake the deeper tasks for which he went into politics. Even in times as untroubled as the present, the aura of the monetary judgment in the old days would distract from the rest of the Budget.

Freed from that, Mr Brown continues on his path. The philosophy of work as the cure for all deprivation is replenished with every Budget. No worries there about recent evidence that Brits work their backs off for longer hours than anyone in Europe. Whether beset by drugs or burdened with children, people have to pass the fit-for-work test, for which the state will provide sticks as well as carrots.

That's the first common thread. The second, now, is the commitment to public services. The new billions announced yesterday were not as big as they could well afford to have been. It sounds as though the Treasury has been listening more than it would ever admit to the hyper-caution of the International Monetary Fund, which recently, to Mr Brown's rage, dared to cast a shadow of a doubt on his prudence.

But in the second term, for which this Budget is designed, will come the major political test for Blairism. There is another, of which the chancellor is acutely aware, the lamentable record of the British economy, despite the fine general out-turn of the last five years, in productivity.

A failure to make a serious impact on productivity over the next half-decade will leave the UK economy struggling against euroland. But the prime targets have to be education and health and crime, and also, I would say, defence, the quality of which will deserve to settle the fate of the Labour government by the end of the next parliament.

Mr Blair and Mr Brown understand that. They have a complicated relationship. No prime minister and chancellor have been more equal. None have been at the same time such rivals and such friends. But they have got where they are together, and taken the country on a track they did not argue about. They had a common vision of how the first term should start and how it should end. Their history together may produce an explosive chemistry, especially when their respective acolytes get together and start making trouble.

But the principals themselves have far more to be said for them than against them. The record Mr Brown was able to celebrate yesterday, however unexuberantly, did not have to happen. They made it happen.

Political life was rather different the last time Labour was in power.

Nearly four years in from the start of the 1974 government, Tony Benn recorded the state of things at the pre-Budget cabinet meeting, when Denis Healey had Mr Brown's job.

"Denis went on about industrial performance, design and marketing, just mouthing the phrases; in the end what we're saying is it's the working class that are responsible for all the troubles. I actually came away more depressed than I have ever been.

"Full employment is no longer on the agenda of a Labour government. They haven't even got a strategy for the 80s. They simply haven't got a strategy."

Things have improved just a little.

fields.headline: Brown conjures up £4bn to cheer voters
fields.standfirst:
Surplus Tax cuts and spending rise leave room for debt reduction

Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Surplus Tax cuts and spending rise leave room for debt reduction.
fields.body:
The chancellor yesterday pulled off the now familiar trick of cutting taxes and increasing spending by a total of £6bn without damaging the outlook for public finances, which are forecast to be slightly healthier than predicted in November's pre-Budget report (PBR).

Just under £2bn was set aside four months ago to pay for the package of measures to appease disgruntled motorists.

The extra £4bn came from a combination of higher than expected tax revenues, especially income tax, and lower than expected spending on debt interest and unemployment.

Mr Brown recycled the bulk of this £4bn windfall, splitting the hand-out roughly 50-50 between tax cuts and spending increases, with a bit left over to reduce his estimates of future borrowing.

Hence the Treasury's claim that the fiscal stance is at least as tight as in last year's Budget and PBR.

Taking the current Budget first, covering issues such as nurses' and teachers' pay, Mr Brown predicted that, with two months of the financial year to go, the surplus would be £23bn in 2000-01 instead of the £16.6bn forecast in November.

Over the next five years, he said it would fall to £17bn, £15bn, £8bn, £9bn and £9bn. In November the corresponding figures were £16bn, £14bn, £8bn, £8bn and £8bn. In each year, Mr Brown will meet his golden rule, that all current expenditure should be financed out of tax receipts.

The chancellor permits himself to borrow to finance capital expenditure, believing that, since projects such as new schools and hospitals benefit future as well as current generations, they should be required to pay part of the bill via debt interest payments.

Even so, public sector net borrowing, excluding windfall tax receipts, will be lower than predicted in November. In the current financial year there will be a net debt repayment of £16.4bn, up from £10.1 forecast in the PBR. In 2001-02, the repayment will be £6bn, unchanged from November's estimate.

Thereafter, the figures go into the red, with the government borrowing £1bn in 2002-03, the same as predicted in November, followed by borrowing requirements of £10bn in 2003-04 (£10bn), £11bn in 2004-05 (£12bn) and £12bn in 2005-06 (£13bn).

Despite these deficits, Mr Brown easily meets his other rule for the public finances, the so-called sustainable investment rule, which stipulates that the debt to GDP ratio should be kept stable below 40%.

In the current year, net debt is expected to be 31.8% of GDP, falling to 30.3% in the coming year, 29.6% in 2002-03 before beginning to edge up again to 29.7% in 2003-04, 29.9% in 2004-05 and 30% in 2005-06.

While rising towards the end of the forecast period, the debt to GDP ratio is still forecast to be lower in every year than forecast in the PBR, when the corresponding figures were 32.3% this year, 30.9% next, 30.1% in 2002-03, 30.2% in 2003-04, 30.3% in 2004-05 and 30.4% in 2005-06.

Mr Brown boasted: "In total because of the government's prudence, debt interest payments in the coming year will be £3.5bn lower than this year, releasing resources for our priorities.

"In 1997 Britain spent more on debt interest payments than all the money it spent on our schools. In 2001-02 we will be spending £10bn a year more on schools than on debt interest."

Mr Brown added that since 1997 lower unemployment has also reduced social security costs by £4bn a year, releasing resources for public services.

"Whereas from 1979 to 1997 42p in every extra pound spent went to debt and social security, now the figure is only 16p, leaving more than 80p in every extra pound to go direct to frontline public services."

Just under £2bn was set aside four months ago to pay for the package of measures to appease disgruntled motorists. The extra £4bn came from a combination of higher than expected tax revenues, especially income tax, and lower than expected spending on debt interest and unemployment. Mr Brown recycled the bulk of this £4bn windfall, splitting the hand-out roughly 50-50 between tax cuts and spending increases, with a bit left over to reduce his estimates of future borrowing. Hence the Treasury's claim that the fiscal stance is at least as tight as in last year's Budget and PBR. Taking the current Budget first, covering issues such as nurses' and teachers' pay, Mr Brown predicted that, with two months of the financial year to go, the surplus would be £23bn in 2000-01 instead of the £16.6bn forecast in November. Over the next five years, he said it would fall to £17bn, £15bn, £8bn, £9bn and £9bn. In November the corresponding figures were £16bn, £14bn, £8bn, £8bn and £8bn. In each year, Mr Brown will meet his golden rule, that all current expenditure should be financed out of tax receipts. The chancellor permits himself to borrow to finance capital expenditure, believing that, since projects such as new schools and hospitals benefit future as well as current generations, they should be required to pay part of the bill via debt interest payments. Even so, public sector net borrowing, excluding windfall tax receipts, will be lower than predicted in November. In the current financial year there will be a net debt repayment of £16.4bn, up from £10.1 forecast in the PBR. In 2001-02, the repayment will be £6bn, unchanged from November's estimate. Thereafter, the figures go into the red, with the government borrowing £1bn in 2002-03, the same as predicted in November, followed by borrowing requirements of £10bn in 2003-04 (£10bn), £11bn in 2004-05 (£12bn) and £12bn in 2005-06 (£13bn). Despite these deficits, Mr Brown easily meets his other rule for the public finances, the so-called sustainable investment rule, which stipulates that the debt to GDP ratio should be kept stable below 40%. In the current year, net debt is expected to be 31.8% of GDP, falling to 30.3% in the coming year, 29.6% in 2002-03 before beginning to edge up again to 29.7% in 2003-04, 29.9% in 2004-05 and 30% in 2005-06. While rising towards the end of the forecast period, the debt to GDP ratio is still forecast to be lower in every year than forecast in the PBR, when the corresponding figures were 32.3% this year, 30.9% next, 30.1% in 2002-03, 30.2% in 2003-04, 30.3% in 2004-05 and 30.4% in 2005-06. Mr Brown boasted: "In total because of the government's prudence, debt interest payments in the coming year will be £3.5bn lower than this year, releasing resources for our priorities. "In 1997 Britain spent more on debt interest payments than all the money it spent on our schools. In 2001-02 we will be spending £10bn a year more on schools than on debt interest." Mr Brown added that since 1997 lower unemployment has also reduced social security costs by £4bn a year, releasing resources for public services. "Whereas from 1979 to 1997 42p in every extra pound spent went to debt and social security, now the figure is only 16p, leaving more than 80p in every extra pound to go direct to frontline public services." webTitle: Brown sets it up, but will we all buy it?

fields.headline: Brown sets it up, but will we all buy it?
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Budget 2001
Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: March 8: The real political significance of Gordon Brown's address yesterday was that it turned the orthodoxy of the past 20 years on its head, writes Larry Elliott.
fields.body:
Cast your mind back nine long years. Norman Lamont stood up to deliver his Budget speech with the economy deep in recession, businesses going bankrupt in droves and unemployment heading rapidly towards 3m. Yet, Lamont had one trump to play. He announced a tax cut in the form of a new 20% band of income tax, thereby setting the terms of the economic debate in the election campaign that was launched by John Major the very next day.

This was the way things were during the long Conservative hegemony. As an election loomed, the chancellor would cut taxes and tie his Labour opponent up in knots by challenging him to match the reductions pound for pound.

The real political significance of Gordon Brown's address yesterday was that it turned the orthodoxy of the past 20 years on its head. One thing is certain: whenever the election is held, it will not turn into a Dutch auction on tax. Instead, it will be up to the Conservatives either to match Labour's 3.7% increases in public spending in each of the next three years or to say where they expect to make savings. All the signs suggest that William Hague and Michael Portillo will have just as much trouble convincing the voters that their plans add up as did Neil Kinnock and John Smith did in 1992.

Naturally, the picture is a bit more complex than this. Despite the extra money for schools and hospitals, the biggest single winner from yesterday's package was the road lobby, a rather inconvenient fact in the light of the prime minister's "greening of Britain" pledge on Tuesday. Nor is Brown's political victory complete. He may have rehabilitated the idea of higher public spending, but he has not even attempted to do the same for tax.

But the environmental damage caused by caving in to the road lobby will not be evident for some time, and higher tax is not an issue that political parties care to talk about when polling day is probably less than two months away. The real point of the Budget was to set the terms of combat for the election and that Brown has done. Unlike previous Labour chancellors, he has not presided over economic disaster or humiliation; indeed, the first chunk of his speech was given over to a familiar litany of achievement - lowest inflation, interest rates and unemployment in decades. There have been no devaluations, no visits from the International Monetary Fund, no crisis measures. The squeeze on spending came early, not late.

The benign state of the economy is not all the chancellor's doing. He was at pains yesterday to paint a black picture of the country on the day Labour came to power, but the reality was that he had the finest inheritance of any Labour chancellor. The economy was already doing well when the Conservatives left office, and through a mixture of luck and skill Brown has ensured that it has stayed that way. Had Kenneth Clarke still been at the Treasury, he too would have had barrowloads of money with which to cut taxes or increase spending.

But by securing a reputation for economic competence, Brown has been able to shift economic priorities in two distinct ways. The increases in spending on health and education over the next three years were large enough even without the top-ups announced yesterday, although they needed to be after the austerity of the first two years. The fact that some of the money is to be used for recruitment and retention drives in the NHS and in education is evidence of the problems caused by sticking to the spending plans laid down by Clarke ahead of the 1997 election. There is a lot more to do in a second term.

Second, Brown has been able to make the tax and benefit system more progressive, a stark difference from the consistently regressive trend between 1979 and 1997. A lot of the rhetoric of New Labour has been about its new-found admiration for risk-taking entrepreneurs, but the beneficiaries of fiscal policy have been those at the bottom of the income scale. The national minimum wage, the working families tax credit, reductions in income tax and national insurance contributions and the increases to child benefit and income-related benefit have helped the poor far more than the rich.

According to the Treasury's budget red book, every group of working age households has gained as a result of Labour's five Budgets since 1997. But whereas the richest 10% are better off by around £2 a week, the poorest 10% of working age households are almost £20 a week better off. The second poorest 10% of households are doing even better, because more of them are in work, and Brown's tax credits have been aimed at the working poor.

Will middle England swallow all this? They will provided interest rates stay low, and Brown's decision to spare drinkers and smokers higher excise duties will drive down inflation and keep pressure on the Bank to cut interest rates even though demand is being expanded. Cute that. Very cute.

webTitle: Hague claims 'cynical election ploy' will not fool voters

fields.headline: Hague claims 'cynical election ploy' will not fool voters
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Budget 2001
Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: William Hague yesterday attacked Gordon Brown for delivering a "cynical election budget" which would fail to compensate millions of taxpayers for the hike in "stealth taxes" since Labour came to power in 1997.
fields.body:
William Hague yesterday attacked Gordon Brown for delivering a "cynical election budget" which would fail to compensate millions of taxpayers for the hike in "stealth taxes" since Labour came to power in 1997.

The Tory leader said that voters would not be fooled by the chancellor who introduced the equivalent of a 1p tax cut yesterday after penalising people with the equivalent of a 10p tax rise in the past four years.

"He has produced a cynical election budget: the 10p up 1p down budget that gives with one hand when far more has already been taken back by the other," Mr Hague said. "He is like the thief who steals someone's car and comes back the next day to return the hub caps."

Seizing on yesterday's report by the rightwing Centre for Policy Studies, which claimed that Labour has imposed £36bn in stealth taxes, Mr Hague said that taxpayers have suffered across the board. "Taxes have gone up on marriages, mortgages, pensions, petrol, diesel, cars, homes, medical insurance, savings, small businesses, large businesses and the self-employed," he said. "And so to suddenly turn up today with tax reductions is a cynical election budget."

Voters would be suspicious of the budget, Mr Hague added, because many of the chancellor's claims over the past four years have subsequently turned out to be false.

Criticising Mr Brown for claiming that the tax burden on the average family has fallen to its lowest level in 30 years, Mr Hague said: "In saying that, he only included direct taxes and left out all of his stealth taxes on petrol, pensions, cars, alcohol, cigarettes and council tax.

"His statement would only be true for people who never drink, do not have a pension, do not even have a local council."

The chancellor had mistakenly assumed that voters were stupid because the average family was worse off by £670 a year under Labour, Mr Hague said.

He accused Mr Brown of hitting the poorest 20% of house holds with a tax burden that had risen under Labour from 36 to 40% of their gross income.

"He goes around posing as the friend of the least well off but what does he do? He hits them even harder. This is a budget whose tax reductions are entirely motivated by the onset of a general election."

The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, accused Mr Brown of offering a politically motivated budget, which emphasised tax cuts while neglecting public spending.

The chancellor had devoted five times as much financial priority to tax reductions as investing in health and education, he said, suggesting claims of £2bn spending on schools and hospitals in fact amounted to only £0.5bn because "all of next year's spending is simply money he failed to spend this year".

The budget had to be seen in the context of rising class sizes, longer hospital waiting lists, fewer police, more violent crime, immobilised public transport and a record number of winter deaths among pensioners, Mr Kennedy told MPs.

In replacing Tory deficits with a Labour war chest Mr Brown's "prudent approach" had squeezed public spending so savagely that the proportion of national income spent on schools, hospitals and pensioners was now less than under the previous government.

Mr Kennedy also lamented the absence of measures aimed at helping farmers struggling amid the foot and mouth crisis. He said Mr Brown had missed an opportunity to follow the lead of the Scottish parliament over scrapping tuition fees and providing free personal care for the elderly.

The leftwing Labour MP Diane Abbott (Hackney North and Stoke Newington) hailed the measures as a "masterly budget, presented in a masterly fashion by a masterly chancellor".

But she said there was underlying "this most modern of chancellors, a very old fashioned notion that there are the deserving poor - people who are prepared to leave their children however young and go out to work - and the undeserving poor - women who choose to stay with their children at least until school age".

She warned: "A Victorian distinction between the deserving and undeserving poor embedded in this system of tax credits does not reflect well on a 21st century Labour government."

Ms Abbott said that while many did benefit from initiatives like the working families tax credit, "sadly there are millions of poor people, particularly single mothers with very young children" who were not reached by such a system of tax credits.

fields.headline: Changing places
fields.standfirst: After two months in the antipodes Sam finally moves on to his next continent, where he is fed and watered by some kindly relations, and relaxes in a perfect replica of a traditional English pub
fields.trailText: Week 14, Perth to Johannesburg After two months in the antipodes Sam finally moves on to his next continent, where he is fed and watered by some kindly relations, and relaxes in a perfect replica of a traditional English pub
fields.body:
To my relief, Perth was much cooler than Alice Springs. I spent the day doing laundry, sorting out a few last minute things for Africa and having a quick look round the city. It was very attractive and quite easygoing. I would have liked to have spent longer there and perhaps travelled up the coast, but my next continent was calling and I had to be away.

The eleven-hour flight from Perth to Johannesburg was not enjoyable - we faced strong headwinds the whole way, which slowed us down and produced lots of turbulence. It was impossible to sleep and by the end of it I was feeling pretty sick. There was also some nutter who kept wandering round the plane talking to everyone and then shouting and storming off in a huff. One good thing, however, was that I had two seats to myself and plenty of room. Tip: if you are travelling on a 747, try to get the window seats at the back, where the rear of the fusilage begins to taper. Here it's too narrow for the normal three seats so you get two with plenty of room at the side. It's a bit noisier, but worth it to be able to stretch your legs.

Fortunately, I have some relations living in Johannesburg, so I didn't have to negotiate my way through this notorious city. I was picked up at the airport and shepherded out to the pleasant suburb of Fontainbleau. My relatives, Mike and Mavis, were incredibly kind and generous, feeding and watering me and letting me have my own room with a double bed! They were quite happy to let me sleep all day, which was just as well as I was exhausted. I think it must be a combination of the recent early mornings and jet lag, but I'm a bit run down at the moment and not at my best.

Mike has recreated a traditional English pub in his back room. This was beautifully set out and was just the reminder of home that I needed to relax. A few beers and a barbeque in their quiet garden and I was beginning to feel better.

Johannesburg is a strange mix of the first and third worlds. Top of the range Mercedes park next to packed, beaten up mini-buses which are used as local taxis. Huge American-style shopping malls sit next to cheap roadside stalls which sell everything under the sun. We drove out of the city and up into the surrounding hills. The dangers of the city centre mean that people are moving further and further into the suburbs. There are lots of new housing developments springing up, all with increased security measures such as road barriers and 24-hour guards.

We visited a local game park to see some new lion cubs, which were very sweet - their mother didn't seem to mind when we stopped only a few feet away. Soon I hope to be seeing the same sort of thing out in the wild.

A delightful twelve-hour bus ride to Bulawayo in Zimbabwe tomorrow. I can't wait.

fields.headline: Opposition politicians attack Budget 'spin'
fields.trailText: Chancellor Gordon Brown's Budget promise to raise investment in public services was derided as "spin" by opposition politicians today as the parties vied to establish their public spending credentials.
fields.body:
Chancellor Gordon Brown's Budget promise to raise investment in public services was derided as "spin" by opposition politicians today as the parties vied to establish their public spending credentials.

The Conservatives attacked as "misleading" Mr Brown's much-heralded £2bn boost for public services, while the Liberal Democrats questioned Labour's real commitment to greater public spending.

Ministers responded by pouring scorn on the Tories promise to match its spending plans and challenged them to spell out how they would cut taxes and maintain investment in the NHS and education.

"It is between a balanced approach which involves targeted tax cuts and good public investment as against huge cuts in public spending which inevitably lead to boom and bust which is the old Tory recipe," said Mr Brown.

But Lib Dem parliamentary chairman Malcolm Bruce desribed the Budget as a "missed opportunity," arguing that Mr Brown had produced a "pre-election Budget when what was needed was an investment Budget".

He added: "Gordon Brown has carried forward some underspends, spread small amounts of tax cuts across the field and not really given the commitment to sustained investment in improving the public services."

Shadow chancellor Michael Portillo dismissed Mr Brown's Budget as a "con" and pledged that a Conservative government would match Labour for spending plans on schools and hospitals.

Mr Portillo insisted the Tories would stick to their plans to cut public spending by £8bn to fund tax cuts, while matching Labour's expenditure on vital public services.

Labour hit back by claiming that the gap between their plans and those of the Tories was now between £10bn and more than £16bn.

Social security secretary Alistair Darling said: "The Budget plans mean that spending will now grow by 3.7% a year over the next three years.

"The Tories' spending rule, their only spending rule, is that spending should grow by 2.25% a year or less.

"This is the rock on which they stand. If they grow spending at 2.25% a year for the next three years, they must cut Labour's spending plans by more than £16bn by 2003/4.

Mr Darling was dismissive of Mr Portillo's claims that the Tories would match Labour's revised spending plans for schools and hospitals.

"When he is pressed, he says he will match us, but then he insists he will stick to 2.25%. He either has a rule or he doesn't ... There are two Portillos about."

fields.headline: C5 news move points to self-regulation
fields.trailText:
3.45pm update: Commentator Steve Barnett believes C5's move paves the way for a lighter regulatory regime, writes Amy Vickers.
10.30am: Channel 5 stretches ITC rules
fields.body:
Channel 5's plan to move its news out of peaktime is an example of what self-regulation will bring, according to broadcasting commentator Steve Barnett.

Mr Barnett, professor of communications at the University of Westminster, said the move, which is being discussed with the Independent Television Commission, was a precursor to the light-touch regulatory regime proposed by the recent government communications white paper.

"It's all part of the move to self-regulation," he added. "It's clear from the white paper that Channel 5 is going to be divested of most of its public service obligations."

Channel 5 is confident the ITC will approve its bid to move its news bulletin to 5.30pm.

Mr Barnett suggested this was because the broadcaster had already been given an informal steer by the ITC.

"I suspect Channel 5 has been told with a nod and a wink it can go ahead.

"It may have jumped the gun in PR terms but I think we can expect to hear the ITC has given formal approval," he concluded.

Liberal Democrat media spokesman Norman Baker said such a move would call into question Channel 5's future as a public service broadcaster with access to free broadcasting spectrum.

"One has to ask whether Channel 5 counts as a public service broadcaster," Mr Baker added. "What do they provide that warrants their status as a free to air broadcaster?"

Any attempt to water down the little they already do brings that further into question."

webTitle: Solution of Roman riddle could create new weapon to fight cancer

fields.headline: Solution of Roman riddle could create new weapon to fight cancer
fields.standfirst: 'The crossover from the classics to medicine is incredible'
fields.trailText: For almost 30 years, the collection of Roman wax tablets defied all attempts to decipher their meaning. Archaeologists tried in vain to unlock the secrets of life in first century Britain.
fields.body:
For almost 30 years, the collection of Roman wax tablets defied all attempts to decipher their meaning. Archaeologists tried in vain to unlock the secrets of life in first century Britain.

But by using a high resolution camera a team of Oxford University scientists and historians has gained a glimpse into everyday Roman activities, from shopping to a contract freeing a slave.

The tablets, on display at the Science Museum in London, date from AD85-125 and were excavated at a site at Hadrian's Wall in the 1970s. Each is made of a curved segment of hollowed out Scots pine, covered with a layer of wax on which notes were written with a metal stylus; in many cases the tablets were used over and over again by smoothing the wax to write a fresh note.

Some tablets list the food and clothes required by Roman garrisons. They reveal that life was far from easy for the average soldier protecting the northern frontier from marauding Picts.

He would have had to fork out 8% of his 25 denarii annual income to buy his uniform. If he wanted a cloak to protect him from the hostile climate, he would have had to hand over another 10% of his salary. Other essential items included radishes, quantities of human hair, necklace clasps and vehicle axles.

Another tablet describes a recruitment drive to persuade members of the Anavionenses tribe, who lived around the Annan river in south-west Scotland, to join the army. Another is a contract releasing a slave to work elsewhere in the empire as a free man.

Alan Bowman, a Roman history lecturer and expert in deciphering ancient documents, said yesterday: "It is a terrific thrill to read something which hasn't been read for almost 2,000 years. You are always going to find something new or unusual."

The breakthrough came almost by accident when Dr Bowman asked a friend, Mike Brady, an image analyst in Oxford's engineering department, to look at the tablets. The original wax had disappeared long ago, so that the only remaining marks were scratches on the wood where the stylus had pushed through, and some tablets had been used many times over.

At first Prof Brady was stumped. But he spotted another researcher reading a tablet by rolling it about in his hand to play the light on to it, creating shadows which highlighted the indentations of the writing.

With funding from the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council, the team used a high resolution camera, powerful directional light, and a specially developed mathematical formula to highlight the incisions and translate them into letters.

"If Alan hadn't pointed out that there was writing on them I wouldn't have had a clue," Prof Brady said. "As a layman I would have thrown them in the bin, but we cracked it and the best thing about it is that the basic idea behind the science was so simple."

The team believe that their approach will have a huge impact for historians trying to decipher ancient documents. But the potential benefits do not end there. Prof Brady, whose normal speciality is breast cancer, has discovered that the same principle and an adapted formula may offer an early detection system. Used on mammograms, the technique gives detailed images of the milk ducts, showing up any minor calcifications which can point to abnormalities.

Prof Brady said: "The best thing about this project has been the unexpected windfall for me. The crossover from the classics to medicine is incredible. It is serendipity."

webTitle: Hull launches degree in Yorkshire studies

fields.headline: Hull launches degree in Yorkshire studies
fields.trailText: From Monday, Yorkshire puddings and Wallace and Gromit are going to university as Michael Paraskos, Hull University's tutor of fine arts will be holding the first seminar of a new course, Yorkshire Studies.
fields.body:
From Monday, Yorkshire puddings and Wallace and Gromit are going to university as Michael Paraskos, Hull University's tutor of fine arts will be holding the first seminar of a new course, Yorkshire Studies.

Mr Paraskos will teach undergraduates about the county's art, literature, history and music.

This is the first course devoted to the study of a single English county, although there is a long tradition of Welsh, Irish and Scottish studies. On offer this year at UK universities are 41 Irish, 122 Scottish and 281 Welsh cultural studies courses.

Mr Paraskos denies that this is a Mickey Mouse exercise: "If Yorkshire is arguing for a parliament, there needs to be a cultural argument as well, otherwise why not have a parliament of the north? There is a rediscovery of political and social culture going on in a very similar way to the early assertions of a Scottish identity."

Yorkshire Studies will include everything from the Spice Girls' Mel B through to the composer Frederick Delius. Mr Paraskos will even be tackling flat caps and whippets on the way.

"They are important to Yorkshire. The reality of a place is based on the perception of an area both by the people who live there and by outsiders.

So, we are going to be exploring the clichs, which is part of what convinces us that Yorkshire has a strong cultural identity. In bland places like the Home Counties, it is very hard to pin down a strong identity."

Looking at the international progress Scottish and Irish studies have made, Mr Paraskos hopes that one day his course might even make it overseas.

"Imagine an American university offering courses in Yorkshire Studies."

fields.headline: Peter Gutkind
fields.standfirst:
Anthropologist and labour studies scholar with a commitment to the oppressed

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Anthropologist and labour studies scholar with a commitment to the oppressed.
fields.body:
Peter Gutkind, who has died aged 75, was an anthropologist, Africanist and a distinguished labour studies scholar who was committed to hearing and learning "from below". Peter researched and wrote for the oppressed, and would chastise the rest of us if we drifted away from such commitments. He was also a notable teacher who never wavered from a scholarship that opened up possibilities for both students and the subjects of his researches.

Gutkind was born in Berlin, but came to England in 1939 as one of the Jewish child refugees, to join his architect father, who was already living here. He was educated in Uttoxeter, Staffordshire, where he stayed with a Quaker family, and at Sibford school, in the Cotswolds. His mother and two grandmothers died in the death camps. In the last part of the war he worked with the Quaker ambulance service in London.

In 1946, he went to the US to study sociology at a Quaker college in the midwest, before going to the University of Chicago for postgraduate work in anthropology.

To put himself through graduate school, he worked in a Chicago steel mill. There he joined a team of black southern steelworkers, who had suffered the racism of both the north and the south. Peter, a young white academic, was welcomed as one of the team. At the end of the summer the team gave Peter a farewell present, telling him not to open it until he went home. He took the first layer of paper off and then another and another until he finally came to a small parcel with a note telling him it was for his graduate studies. Inside was $200, a large amount of the men's weekly wages.

His first research job was at the East African Institute of Social Research, Makerere, Uganda, in 1953. There, his research on urban areas in Kampala at a period of increasing migration from rural areas resulted in the report Townsmen in the Making (co-authored with Aidan Southall). The research directive had been to find out "what happens behind the bananas", and the report became a local best seller. It made racy reading, and every police officer was said to have a copy beside his bed.

Peter was full of intellectual energy, flexibility and interdisciplinary breadth, an ebullient extrovert capable of making friends even across language barriers. This stood him in particularly good stead during his work in Uganda. He extended his stay in that country with a scholarly account of the Kibuga, the royal capital of Buganda, which was the thesis for his higher degree at the University of Amsterdam.

After periods in New York, Jamaica and Holland, he eventually joined the anthropology department at McGill University, Montreal, where he stayed from 1963-86. While there, he was elected president of the African Studies Association of the United States. At McGill, he concentrated his research on the anthropology of unemployment, later becoming a specialist in labour history. He undertook intensive research on the boat people of the Ghana coast. He published a volume, Urban Anthropology, in 197, and also took on the editorship of the Sage series on African Modernisation and Development, editing a dozen successful volumes.

After retirement in 1986, he was offered a research fellowship at the University of Warwick, where a labour studies programme was being established. The many overseas students who came to study on the labour studies programme - and who remained in contact with Peter until his death - are a lasting tribute to him.

During this period of his life, Peter revisited Europe. He and his wife, Alice, travelled to the Netherlands, France and, most importantly, Germany. There, Peter found the house in Berlin where he was born and had lived as a boy. He recovered his own history in the way that he had done in his writings about others.

Throughout his life, Peter was an implacable opponent of racism of every sort. He campaigned against the hostility meted out to asylum-seekers and he was long a supporter of Amnesty International. For Peter, his thoughts on the holocaust and his experiences as a Jewish refugee child were defining experiences for an internationalist and a humanitarian. He opposed the persistent attempts to privilege the Jewish experience in the Holocaust and thus silence comment on other victims. He would always return to the importance of maintaining an international outlook.

He is survived by his wife, Alice, whom he married in 1951, and three daughters and a son.

 Peter Gutkind, anthropologist, born September 16 1925; died February 17 2001.

webTitle: Budget gives a chance to fill the classroom gaps

fields.headline: Budget gives a chance to fill the classroom gaps
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: William Atkinson is the head teacher of Phoenix high school in White City, west London, an inner city comprehensive that was officially "failing" when he took over in 1995.
fields.body:
William Atkinson is the head teacher of Phoenix high school in White City, west London, an inner city comprehensive that was officially "failing" when he took over in 1995.

With his school one of hundreds in the south east struggling to cope with the impact of teacher shortages, he welcomed the Budget's education measures as likely to help him recruit more staff, and support both pupils and teachers with additional resources.

"This is my third headship, and I have seen many education changes under different governments," he said. "But the significant difference under Labour has been the substantial extra money being brought directly into schools. I am pleased that in the latest Budget the government is continuing this policy".

Mr Atkinson - pictured above - who is said to have been the inspiration for the recent BBC TV series Hope and Glory, starring Lenny Henry as the head of a struggling school, saw the measures - notably further direct grants for heads and bonuses to attract "returners" to the teaching profession - as much needed help to take the pressure off school budgets and also help to recruit and retain teachers.

"The overall package sounds very good and very even handed because it will benefit all schools," he said. "This will help us enormously. Even if it is a pre-election ploy, it is a three year spending commitment which makes it easier to plan ahead."

Teachers were key to delivering the government's standards agenda, he said, which meant that heads had particular difficulties when there were serious shortages. "I've been very worried about teacher morale and recruitment," he said.

"At the moment I am fifteen teachers short, which means that one third of my staff are supply teachers".

At Phoenix, which has 800 pupils aged 11-16 on its roll, problems came to a head just before Christmas, when anything between four and nine classes had to be taught together in the dining hall.

"I absolutely did not want to send students home, as in many cases it was quite a struggle to get them to school in the first place," he said. "And I did not want to pass those problems on to parents."

The prospect of a further tranche of cash going direct to schools without the need for complex and lengthy bidding was a major boost, Mr Atkinson agreed. Schools are allocated the money based on pupil numbers, so as a result of last year's Budget, for example, he got £47,000; while the autumn statement led to a promise of a further £60,000 next month. "Among my concerns is the fact that, too often, to get extra resources, we are forced into a time-consuming bidding process, which leads many schools to employ consultants in an effort to maximise their chances of being successful," he added. "That really can't be right. It is so much easier when we get the money direct.

The extra cash earmarked by the government for capital projects was essential, he concluded.

"Extra money for school repairs has made a real difference as you can't teach students properly when they are subjected to leaky roofs and broken windows".

"That really can't be right. It is so much easier when we get the money direct. The extra cash earmarked by the government for capital projects was essential, he concluded. "Extra money for school repairs has made a real difference as you can't teach students properly when they are subjected to leaky roofs and broken windows". webTitle: Bleak times for social care recruitment in Wales

fields.headline: Bleak times for social care recruitment in Wales
fields.trailText: Low morale, poor pay, stress and fear of being involved in a high-profile case of departmental failure are making it increasingly difficult to attract staff to social care in Wales. Maggie Murray reports.
fields.body:
Low morale, poor pay, stress and fear of being involved in a high-profile case of departmental failure are making it increasingly difficult to attract staff to social care in Wales.

The Waterhouse report, which detailed the tragic consequences of abuse in care homes in north Wales, and a number of critical joint reviews into local authority social services departments, are seen by many working in social care in Wales as contributing to the problem.

"Waterhouse certainly has not helped in the sense that it has created a feeling that there is a special problem surrounding the integrity of people working in residential child care in Wales. The reality is that there is no problem but the public perception can be damaging for morale," said Hugh Gardner, chair of the association of directors of social services in Wales.

"Authorities that have had unfortunate reports through joint reviews find that staff tend to vote with their feet. We have seen staff move from authorities that have experienced damaging reporting."

Now, as a result of serious concern over the recruitment and retention of staff in the sector, the National Assembly of Wales has commissioned a working party - the "task and finish group" - to investigate the issues over the next two months.

Chaired by Graham Williams, chief inspector of the social services inspectorate Wales and including key players in social care in Wales, the 14-strong group will consult with employers, the assembly itself, and major organisations in Wales.

Once it has reported back, an additional £500,000 that the assembly has earmarked for recruitment and retention will be made available.

Latest data from the Central Council for Education and Training in Social Work (CCETSW Cymru) shows that around half the 22 local authorities in Wales are now reporting a shortage of social workers, especially in child and family services. Research by the organisation also shows that newly qualified staff are likely to stay in child care work for an average of only three years.

The national assembly has also warned that the numbers of people applying for social work training have been falling, despite an increase in service demand. It predicts that 2,000 new staff will be needed every year between now and 2006.

But, despite the problems within the SSS, the voluntary sector in Wales is experiencing less difficulty in recruiting social workers, according to CCETSW Cymru.

"Local authorities undertake most of the child protection and statutory work and the voluntary sector can offer more development workwe think this is why they are able to recruit more easily," said Rhian Huws Williams, head of CCETSW Cymru and a member of the task and finish group.

Together with the headline cases that have attracted adverse publicity, practitioners working in social care also see other factors influencing recruitment and retention.

"The brief that we are looking at covers a large spectrum of workers, from the low paid in social care, who are usually without formal qualifications, to the professionally qualified social worker," said Dominic Macaskill of public sector union Unison, which will also be contributing to the debate over the next few weeks.

"For both groups of staff there are implications because of the serious social deprivation in Wales which results in a number of social consequences. We need to address these issues so that we can recruit and retain staff in the sector."

He added: "For unqualified social care staff, there is little recognition of the importance of the role they fulfil. For instance, in some areas of Wales, medication policies have been introduced where staff are being trained to give certain medicines.

"That is extra responsibility and additional stress for them in fulfilling a role similar to that of a nurse. Yet the pay and the profile of these workers remains low so it is not surprising that it is more attractive to go and work in the local supermarket with better pay and less stress."

According to Mario Kreft of Care Forum Wales, who also sits on the task and finish group, the picture in the private care sector is uniformly bleak.

"In England, the problems of recruitment and keeping staff are patchy, but here in Wales the problem is more or less across the board," he said.

He added that the setting up of the group at last gives Wales the chance to grapple with the recruitment and retention crisis.

fields.headline: Old Trafford closure threat
fields.trailText: Manchester United fans must remain seated during matches or parts of Old Trafford will be closed, Trafford council have warned.
fields.body:
Manchester United fans must remain seated during matches or parts of Old Trafford will be closed, Trafford council have warned.

The council have told the club that if fans persist in standing at Tuesday's Champions League game against Sturm Graz, some areas of the stadium will be closed for at least one game.

The threat follows recent games against Valencia and Arsenal at Old Trafford when fans ignored warnings from stewards to sit.

Sir Alex Ferguson is to hold a news conference tomorrow to urge fans to obey the rules at games.

Barry Brotherton, council cabinet member for community safety, said the problems were mainly in the East Stand and part of West Stand which is steeply sloped.

He said: "There is a serious possibility of an accident and the council cannot afford to turn a blind eye to that. What we intend to do is, if there is no improvement at the Sturm Graz game, we know there are certain areas where people persist in standing, and we'll threaten to withdraw the operating licence from those parts of the ground.

"We do understand that people get excited but in the end safety has to come first."

The areas would be closed for one game and the situation would then be reviewed, Mr Brotherton added.

Trafford safety inspectors will monitor supporters on CCTV and will recommend shutting any areas where there is persistent standing.

Andy Walsh, from the Independent Manchester United Supporters Association, said: "Fans are aware there is a problem but we have been working with the club to resolve it. Closing the ground is not the answer."

webTitle: Child murder report reveals poor communication and cooperation

fields.headline: Child murder report reveals poor communication and cooperation
fields.standfirst: Why Chelsea Brown wasn't taken into care by the experienced social workers involved in her case is baffling, writes Linda Steele, but an independent inquiry uncovered the familiar problem of inadequate communications and poor inter-agency working
fields.trailText: Why Chelsea Brown wasn't taken into care by the experienced social workers involved in her case is baffling, writes Linda Steele, but an independent inquiry uncovered the familiar problem of inadequate communications and poor inter-agency working.
fields.body:
Chelsea Brown. Yet another name, so soon after Anna Climbie, to add to the terrible roll of children who have been tortured and killed by violent adults meant to care for them.

And, while the cases are different, the one similarity that sticks out is that these were children known to social services, whose families received visits from social workers and who were failed, terribly, by the system.

Two-year-old Chelsea was murdered by her father, Robert Brown, who has just been jailed for life for the crime. (Chelsea's mother, Maria Brown, was jailed for 18 months for child cruelty.)

Brown was not only a convicted robber but had a criminal record for violence against children. He battered his daughter over time - and social services were worried. Indeed, her social worker, Norma McDevitt, had visited him 27 times in the 10 weeks before Chelsea's death in December 1999.

Because of her concerns, on November 12, Ms McDevitt took Chelsea to have her injuries examined by a specialist children's doctor. The paediatrician said that six out of nine areas of bruising "had no plausible explanation". At least one of the toddler's injuries was deliberately inflicted - or "consistent with non-accidental injury", in the jargon.

Under the council's own procedures, an apparently deliberate injury should have triggered police involvement and a multi-agency case conference. Incomprehensibly, it didn't happen. The little girl went home - to her brutal fate.

Had procedures been followed, it's highly likely that Chelsea would still be alive. "What should have happened is the police should have been involved in a joint investigation - and had they been involved, the case would have proceeded to a child protection conference ... and a much better outcome," said child protection expert Hilary Owen.

Ms Owen was called in by Derbyshire social services to conduct an independent inquiry into the case. Her report holds this moment up as the point at which Derbyshire county council failed in its statutory responsibility to the little girl. And it's the point where our understanding of how this terrible tragedy could have happened begins to break down.

Why Chelsea wasn't taken into care seems baffling. The social workers involved in the case had decades of experience between them. Their track record was good. "They have successfully supported many children who were on the child protection register and in other family situations," says Bruce Buckley, Derbyshire's director of social services.

Ms McDevitt has been on sick leave since the murder and is said to be "devastated". Mr Buckley says: "Nothing can take away from the severity of what happened to Chelsea but what this man has done [has caused] immense distress among large numbers of staff."

The one hint of a half-explanation that Ms Owen has uncovered is the old problem of inadequate communications and poor inter-agency working. "The case was characterised by other agencies [health and the probation service] being happy to leave all the assessments to the social worker and that wasn't appropriate. The only other proactive professionals were the family support centre workers," she says.

"Nothing can take away from the severity from what happened to Chelsea but what this man has done [has caused] immense distress among large numbers of staff," says Mr Buckley.

But the council is not shying away from its responsibility. "We are not prevaricating. Mistakes were made," says Mr Buckley. "Our response is to make sure that no other child suffers as Chelsea suffered at the hands of Robert Brown."

To that end, the social services department has already implemented around three-quarters of Ms Owen's report recommendations. Four that are under way but not completed involve other agencies - police, health, and probation. "Some are like redrafting our procedures to encompass the [recommended] changes - and that needs to be done on a multi-agency basis," says Mr Buckley.

He lists the key improvements that have been put into practice.

"One of the main ones is that a child should not be returned to a schedule 1 offender [convicted of violent offences against a child] without a thorough discussion with a senior child protection officer or without a multi-agency child protection conference. We've implemented that.

"We want to ensure that there is regular refresher training for frontline managers. We're doing that.

"We're making sure that social workers have easier access to managers and more encouragement for better communication between staff and managers."

Ms Owen points out that: "Social workers work with a huge amount of risk." Just days before her death, Derbyshire social workers had indeed been weighing up the risks involved in leaving the toddler with her parents and were considering removing her.

While the report found that Brown's murderous actions could not have been predicted, had social services, health or probation professionals made that crucial decision to follow procedures, bring in police and call a case conference, after the doctor pointed out the likelihood she was being beaten, it is almost certain that Chelsea would still be alive.

Report recommendations to social services:
 Staff must be reminded that non-accidental injuries must lead to strategy meeting or discussion with police and child protection manager;
 Supervision of service managers should include looking at child protection cases;
 Managers supervising child protection social workers must be trained in analysing and evaluating their work;
 Child protection managers should record all case discussions, decisions and reasons;
 Recording of injuries must be reviewed;
 Children under supervision orders should be reviewed as often as care order cases;
 The amount of assessment required when applying for residence orders must be formally considered;
 A senior area childcare manager must agree before a child is returned to the home of a schedule 1 offender - and they should consider a multi-agency case conference.

Report recommendations to the area child protection committee (ACPC):
 Children on the child protection register with injuries should have an expert medical assessment;
 All agencies must be proactive (and managers and supervisors may need child protection training to achieve this);
 Full case conference minutes should be sent to all workers involved in child protection plans;
 Area child protection committee training must be reviewed - particularly management of injuries training.

Report recommendations to health service:
 GPs must have systems for sharing information regularly with health visitors about at-risk children;
 Health visitors' concerns must be reported to a key social worker and a named child protection nurse; health visiting assessments must be in addition to other meetings;
 GPs and staff in minor injuries units should have child protection training - with updates;
 When a hospital doctor is assessing a child for abuse, they should check that the social worker understands their concerns and should discuss them with the social work manager, if necessary. A paediatric consultant should be called if there are serious concerns;
 Staff should get clinical supervision.

Report recommendations to probation service:
 A parent with a child on the child protection register who is aso an offender under supervision should be classified as risk alert;
 Case manager or senior probation officer should attend every child protection case conference;
 Supervision of offenders should be reviewed after each case conference;
 All probation officers should get foundation child protection training; those working on child protection cases should attend ACPC training.
