webTitle: A nation divided by one language

fields.headline: A nation divided by one language
fields.standfirst: Politics still obscure the real debate about the United States' language policy, says James Crawford
fields.trailText: "If you live in America, you need to speak English." According to a Los Angeles Times poll, that was how three out of four voters explained their support for Proposition 227, the 1998 ballot initiative that dismantled bilingual education in California. Many Arizonans cited the same reason for passing a similar measure (Proposition 203) last year.
fields.body:
"If you live in America, you need to speak English." According to a Los Angeles Times poll, that was how three out of four voters explained their support for Proposition 227, the 1998 ballot initiative that dismantled bilingual education in California. Many Arizonans cited the same reason for passing a similar measure (Proposition 203) last year.

Ambiguous as it is, this rationale offers some clues about the way Americans think about language. No doubt for some the statement has a patriotic subtext: one flag, one language. Rejecting bilingual education was a way to "send a message" that, in the United States, English and only English is appropriate for use in the public square.

Other voters merely seemed intent on restating the obvious. English is so dominant in the US that non-English speakers are at a huge disadvantage. Thus schools must not fail to teach English to children from minority language backgrounds. Students' life chances will depend to a large extent on the level of English literacy skills they achieve.

Immigrants have generally understood these truths more keenly than anyone, and behaved accordingly. As the linguist Einar Haugen observes, "America's profusion of tongues has made her a modern Babel, but a Babel in reverse."

There is no reason to think the historic pattern has changed. Although the number of minority language speakers has grown dramatically in recent years, thanks to a liberalisation of immigration laws in 1965, so has their rate of acculturation. Census figures confirm the paradox. While one in seven US residents now speaks a language other than English at home, bilingualism is also on the rise. A century ago the proportion of non-English speakers was nearly five times as large. As the population becomes increasingly diverse, newcomers seem to be acquiring the national language more rapidly than ever before.

The political problem is that many Americans have trouble believing all this. One conservative organisation claims: "Tragically, many immigrants these days refuse to learn English! They never become productive members of society. They remain stuck in a linguistic and economic ghetto, many living off welfare and costing working Americans millions of tax dollars every year."

Such perceptions are not uncommon. Perhaps this is because Americans who came of age before the 1970s had little experience of linguistic diversity. Growing up in a period of tight immigration quotas, they seldom encountered anyone speaking a language other than English, except foreign tourists.

So today, when Spanish and Vietnamese are heard routinely in public and when bilingual government services in Tagalog and Gujarati are not unknown, some Americans conclude that the hegemony of English is threatened, and perhaps their "way of life" as well. Suddenly they are endorsing coercive measures, as suggested by the US English lobby, to "defend our common language". An English Only movement based on these premises came to prominence in the 80s. Thus far it has succeeded in legislating English as the official language of 23 states, although such declarations have been primarily symbolic, with few legal effects as yet.

The campaign's ideological effects have been more significant. In particular English Only agitation has made bilingual schooling a lightning rod for political attacks from people concerned about immigration policy, cultural change and the expansion of minority rights. Debating the best way to teach English to children becomes a form of shadow-boxing that has less to do with pedagogical issues than with questions of social status and political power.

It does not help that the pedagogical issues are so poorly understood. Monolinguals tend to regard language learning as a zero-sum game. Any use of children's mother tongue for instruction, the assumption goes, is a diversion from English acquisition. Thus assigning English learners to bilingual classrooms would seem to delay their education.

Research has shown that precisely the opposite is true. Far from a waste of learning time, native-language lessons support the process of acquiring a second language while keeping students from falling behind in other subjects.

Stephen Krashen, of the University of Southern California, has documented the "transfer" of literacy skills and academic knowledge between various languages ? even when alphabets differ substantially. "We learn to read by reading, by making sense of what we see on the page," Krashen explains. Thus "it will be much easier to learn to read in a language we already understand". And literacy need not be relearned as additional languages are acquired. "Once you can read, you can read."

Other studies confirm that by the time children leave well-structured bilingual programs, typically after four to five years, they are outperforming their counterparts in non-bilingual programs, and in some cases students from native-English backgrounds as well. Yet such success stories remain poorly publicised. Until recently bilingual educators have done little to explain their methods and goals, while the US media have become increasingly sceptical. "If all I knew about bilingual education was what I read in the newspapers," says Krashen, "I'd vote against it, too."

Mixed messages have compounded the public relations problem. Bilingual education, which began as an effort to guarantee equal educational opportunities, is increasingly promoted as a form of multicultural enrichment. To counter the English Only mentality, advocates have coined the slogan English Plus. They argue that the US remains an underdeveloped country where language skills are concerned. In a global economy more multilingualism, not less, would clearly advance the national interest.

Some English-speaking parents have been receptive to the "bilingual is beautiful" pitch. Over the past decade a growing number have enrolled their children in "dual immersion" classrooms alongside minority children learning English. Yet despite excellent reports on this method of cultivating fluency in two languages, no more than 20,000 English-background students are participating. Compare that with the 300,000 Canadian anglophones in French immersion programmes, in a country with one-tenth the population of the US.

By and large English Plus appeals primarily to language educators and ethnic leaders - that is, to those who already value bilingual skills. Other Americans remain suspicious of the "plus". Most harbour the false impression that bilingual education is primarily about maintaining Hispanic culture. Knowing a foreign language is wonderful, they say, but shouldn't English come first? The US language policy debate rarely seems to get past that question.

James Crawford is a former Washington editor of Education Week and an independent writer and lecturer on the politics of language. See http://ourworld.compuserve.com/homepages/jwcrawford/ His latest book is "At War With Diversity: US Language Policy In An Age Of Anxiety" (Multilingual Matters, 2000)

Far from a waste of learning time, native-language lessons support the process of acquiring a second language while keeping students from falling behind in other subjects. Stephen Krashen, of the University of Southern California, has documented the "transfer" of literacy skills and academic knowledge between various languages ? even when alphabets differ substantially. "We learn to read by reading, by making sense of what we see on the page," Krashen explains. Thus "it will be much easier to learn to read in a language we already understand". And literacy need not be relearned as additional languages are acquired. "Once you can read, you can read." Other studies confirm that by the time children leave well-structured bilingual programs, typically after four to five years, they are outperforming their counterparts in non-bilingual programs, and in some cases students from native-English backgrounds as well. Yet such success stories remain poorly publicised. Until recently bilingual educators have done little to explain their methods and goals, while the US media have become increasingly sceptical. "If all I knew about bilingual education was what I read in the newspapers," says Krashen, "I'd vote against it, too." Mixed messages have compounded the public relations problem. Bilingual education, which began as an effort to guarantee equal educational opportunities, is increasingly promoted as a form of multicultural enrichment. To counter the English Only mentality, advocates have coined the slogan English Plus. They argue that the US remains an underdeveloped country where language skills are concerned. In a global economy more multilingualism, not less, would clearly advance the national interest. Some English-speaking parents have been receptive to the "bilingual is beautiful" pitch. Over the past decade a growing number have enrolled their children in "dual immersion" classrooms alongside minority children learning English. Yet despite excellent reports on this method of cultivating fluency in two languages, no more than 20,000 English-background students are participating. Compare that with the 300,000 Canadian anglophones in French immersion programmes, in a country with one-tenth the population of the US. By and large English Plus appeals primarily to language educators and ethnic leaders - that is, to those who already value bilingual skills. Other Americans remain suspicious of the "plus". Most harbour the false impression that bilingual education is primarily about maintaining Hispanic culture. Knowing a foreign language is wonderful, they say, but shouldn't English come first? The US language policy debate rarely seems to get past that question. James Crawford is a former Washington editor of Education Week and an independent writer and lecturer on the politics of language. See http://ourworld.compuserve.com/homepages/jwcrawford/ His latest book is "At War With Diversity: US Language Policy In An Age Of Anxiety" (Multilingual Matters, 2000)

fields.headline: NTL sinks further into red
fields.trailText:
3pm: Cable operator NTL has sunk further into the red as its £8bn debt burden eats into revenues, reports Dan Milmo.
Jan 25: NTL unveils ambitious targets
fields.body:
Cable operator NTL has sunk further into the red as its £8bn debt burden eats into revenues.

The US-listed company is growing at a rate of knots, but the 11 acquisitions it made in the UK over the last 18 months have come at considerable cost.

Interest payments on NTL's debt cost the company £630m last year, taking its pre-tax loss to £1.97bn from a relatively small £500m in 1999.

However, chief executive Barclay Knapp said NTL should achieve its year-end revenue target of £2.6bn after it racked up £1.8bn in sales last year.

Mr Knapp added that NTL was well set for 2001 after launching its digital TV service last year and buying Swiss rival Cablecom and the consumer arm of telecoms giant Cable & Wireless.

"We completed the two largest transactions in our company's history, we have launched new products in all our major markets and we have been carrying out an extensive business review to reduce our cost base," said Mr Knapp.

The company will now concentrate on increasing its revenue per customer figure from £36 this year to £60 in 2003 and winning new customers will become a lower priority.

But NTL, with 600,000 subscribers, is still playing catch-up with its rivals in the UK digital TV market.

It hopes to raise this figure to 1.25m by year end, leaving it some distance behind market leader BSkyB, which has over 4m digital customers.

However, analysts claim NTL has a unique advantage through its ability to offer "bundled" services which combine telecoms, TV and the internet.

NTL hopes these services will become a growing attraction to the 8.4m households which are now covered by its network.

webTitle: Arms and the men: is the IRA serious about decommissioning?

fields.headline: Arms and the men: is the IRA serious about decommissioning?
fields.standfirst:
With both sides convinced that the other will not back down, the stalemate in Ireland shows little sign of abating

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: With both sides convinced that the other will not back down, the stalemate in Ireland shows little sign of abating, writes Derek Brown
fields.body:
On the face of it, the IRA's announcement that it is to resume contact with the international arms decommissioning body is a colossal bit of cheek.

It's 10 months since the various parties to the Northern Ireland peace process agreed, in effect, to move forward towards overall - and already belated - implementation of the deal.

Decommissioning was an essential component of that deal, and nothing whatever has happened.

Come to that, precious little has been done since the Decommissioning Commission - to give it its ludicrous official title - was set up in September 1997 under former Canadian general John de Chastelain.

True, the IRA has opened up a couple of its arms dumps, believed to contain some trifling quantities of weapons, to inspection by two international observers, Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa and Martti Ahtisaari of Finland.

But they have no official role in the overall process, which has remained becalmed on a sinister sea of mutual recrimination.

To many unionists, the problem is as simple as its solution: let the IRA give up its guns and explosives, and then there can be progress on all other fronts.

But then republicans too have a simple analysis: let the unionists and the British government honour their side of the bargain, and that will allow the decommissioning process to proceed.

These are not just chicken-and-egg positions. If it was simply a question of which side should jump first, it would not be beyond the ingenuity of the parties - and the British and Irish governments - to devise a timetable preserving the honour of all.

The much greater problem lies with the fundamentally differing perception that each side has of the other - and, indeed, of itself.

Leaving aside the rabble of loyalist paramilitaries and the diehard sectarian bigots, the unionist community is genuinely and deeply offended by the idea of government being even partially in the hands of representatives of an armed and illegal organisation.

Even in their wilder dreams and speeches, they don't expect the IRA simply to pack in. But they do expect it, demand it, to move towards a substantial disarmament as the quid pro quo of power-sharing.

From the republican point of view, disarmament or decommissioning, or whatever it is called, smacks uncomfortably of surrender. Worse, it carries an implication of collaborating with the enemy - the basest crime in the republican code.

Already, the movement is wracked by dissent over the Good Friday deal. Just as unionists are appalled by the idea of Sinn Fein ministers in the power-sharing executive, so militant republicans are aghast that those same ministers are serving, in effect, under the British Crown.

Republicans and unionists alike are deeply frustrated by what both see as lack of progress.

The republicans - and indeed the more moderate nationalists - are angry about the perceived watering-down of police reform plans. They are exasperated by slow progress towards the establishment of cross-border institutions.

Above all perhaps, they are aggrieved by the emphasis being put on IRA disarmament, when the British army remains a potent (and as they see it, alien) force in the province.

Unionists, of course, have an entirely different perspective on all these issues. They accuse the republicans of cynically abusing the decommissioning process to extract ever greater concessions.

For the IRA now to meet General de Chastelain is all very well, they say, but it must be prepared not just to talk, but to act.

And so the argument goes on, in circles, while every day carries the risk of breakdown and reversion to armed conflict.

Already, one powerful external factor - the Clinton administration in Washington - has been removed from the process. The next move is down to the British and Irish governments.

Tony Blair and his Dublin counterpart Bertie Ahern are meeting the various parties in Belfast today, more in the hope of patching up the peace enterprise than in any realistic expectation of making it work properly.

With the British election looming, Northern Ireland has again slid down the priority list in Westminster. If General de Chastelain has any tricks up his negotiating sleeve, now is the time for him to produce them.

webTitle: 'This outbreak is going to last a long time'

fields.headline: 'This outbreak is going to last a long time'
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth crisis
fields.trailText: Farmers were warned today that the foot and mouth crisis showed no sign of disappearing as seven more outbreaks were confirmed, pushing the total number of cases to 103.
fields.body:
Farmers were warned today that the foot and mouth crisis was far from over as seven more outbreaks were confirmed, pushing the total number of cases to 103.

The chief veterinary officer, Jim Scudamore, said: "We will not see the disease disappearing at the end of this week and this outbreak is going to last for a long time."

Fifteen outbreaks confirmed yesterday, including in four previously unaffected counties, and eight more cases this morning, have effectively put an end to faint hopes that the spread of the disease was about to peak.

Mr Scudamore added: "We have such a large number of tracings and movements (of animals) to follow still."

He said the biggest problem now presenting itself was that the disease seemed to be spreading most rapidly among cattle which have come into contact with sheep carrying the virus.

Since the outbreak began more than two weeks ago officials have tirelessly sought to trace the movements of some 100,000 sheep which passed through markets where the disease was believed to have been present.

With Britain in the lambing season, Mr Scudamore urged sheep farmers to look out for signs of the disease in their livestock. It could cause an abnormally high rate of death in young lambs and abortions in pregnant sheep. Other classic symptoms are lameness and listlessness.

Mr Scudamore appealed for any farmers who bought sheep outside the main sales rings at Longtown market, a focal point for tracing the disease, to contact their local animal health officer as soon as possible.

It also emerged that last night's decision to postpone Cheltenham's prestigious horseracing festival could cost up to £10m in lost trade.

As many as 175,000 people were due to attend the races next week from as far afield as Ireland and France for one of the main dates of the racing calendar.

Meanwhile, the Queen Mother, who is due to attend a race meeting at Sandown Park in Surrey tomorrow, will also have to do her bit to help prevent the spread of the disease.

It is believed she will be advised to wear wellies and wade through a bath of disinfectant at the track.

The attempt to contain the outbreak on Dartmoor, where tens of thousands of animals are threatened, was also stepped up.

fields.headline: Pensioners' increase outpaces inflation
fields.standfirst:
 Single OAPs to get £72.50  £115.90 for couples

Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown, yesterday sought to defuse pensioners' anger about Labour's record in its first four years with a comprehensive set of reforms designed to end pensioner poverty. He said it would allow "today's workforce - tomorrow's retirement pensioners - to plan ahead".
fields.body:
Gordon Brown, yesterday sought to defuse pensioners' anger about Labour's record in its first four years with a comprehensive set of reforms designed to end pensioner poverty. He said it would allow "today's workforce - tomorrow's retirement pensioners - to plan ahead".

The basic state pension is to increase by more than the average wage, rising by £5 a week for a single person to £72.50 from April. Couples will see their basic go up from £107.90 to £115.90 - a 7.4% increase.

Further increases are already pencilled in for April 2002 - to £75.50 for single pensioners and £120.70 for couples. This is in addition to retaining the winter allowance and the free television licence for the over 75s.

The minimum income guarantee is to be simplified with one rate for all those who qualify. From April, single pensioners will be guaranteed an income of £92.15, and couples a minimum £140.55.

Better off pensioners will benefit from income tax changes thanks to the extension of the 10p tax rate, an above inflation uplift in the personal allowance for the over 65s and a £600 rise in the income limit for these age related allowances.

A pensioner couple each with £8,000 income before tax will be £87 a year better off; those on £20,000 each will gain £312 between them after the income tax changes kick in.

But helping tomorrow's pensioners to plan today is as high on the chancellor's agenda.

"Since November, we have been consulting on our new pension credit, to be introduced in 2003. Pensioner couples with incomes below £200 and single pensioners with incomes below £135 a week, will receive the new pension credit," Mr Brown said.

The pension credit is set to give "extra support" to around half of all pensioner households. It will allow those with lower retirement incomes, which are nevertheless above the basic state pension level, to keep a large proportion of their savings income or income from their company pensions.

He said the intention -from 2003 - is to abolish capital rules which penalise pensioners with savings above £3,000, end the weekly means test, and increase the minimum income guarantee by linking this to rises in earnings throughout the next parliament.

Age Concern director general Gordon Lishman hailed Mr Brown as the first chancellor in 20 years to raise the basic state pension above the rate of inflation. But he criticised the Treasury for creating a "massively complex system and endless form filling for pensioners" who relied on the pension credit and minimum income guarantee.

Jack Jones, president of the National Pensioners' Convention, said pensioners wanted a more substantial increase in the basic state pension rather than more means tested benefits.

fields.headline: On the farm
fields.standfirst: Foot and mouth, torrential rain - but our diarist's husband will get to celebrate his birthday
fields.trailText: Foot and mouth, torrential rain - but our diarist's husband will get to celebrate his birthday.
fields.body:
It's Peter's 49th birthday, and I'm embarrassed to admit we almost forgot. We managed - after a major search of the house - to find a suitable card for the breakfast table (with a sheep on the front) and I've escaped once again to Corbridge (12 miles away) to find a little something to mark the day and cheer him up. The post brought fresh cards at around noon (with yet more sheep) and a detailed information pack from Maff, showing in glorious technicolour the hideous and obviously painful symptoms of foot and mouth.

Torrential rain has now added to the daily problems of looking after the sheep. The powerful quad bike struggles to traverse the slushy snow and puddle-filled hollows. We then have to empty the heavy wooden sheep troughs of rainwater and move them to drier ground. There are around 140 of these spread throughout the fields, each one feeding 10 sheep at a time.

Among the larger groups of pregnant ewes, the greediest sheep stand at one end of the troughs in readiness for when Peter or Graham start pouring out the specially prepared ewe nuts from 25 kilo bags. They grab a mouthful or two and then run frantically down the feeding line for a second and even third helping. It can be quite comical to watch them pushing and barging to gain a larger share. If you are unlucky enough to be bumped into, or caught by the horn of a Blackface ewe, you can end up flat out in the mud or the snow, or both. This is highly unpleasant because before you can even try to stand up, the rest of the flock runs over the top of you in a desperate attempt to eat all the food from the sack you were previously carrying.

Back at the farmhouse, the phone calls keep coming day and night, and I'm certain the bills around the district for this quarter will be enormous, but as no one is using their car much, perhaps this will balance itself out.

Once a vet has attended a suspected case of foot and mouth, they enter a strict, five-day quarantine and cannot attend another farm, even in extremis.

fields.headline: The miracle of life
fields.standfirst: One couple's amazing story of their newborn son shows how even in the darkest moments hope  survives eternal
fields.trailText: One couple's amazing story of their newborn son shows how even in the darkest moments hope survives eternal
fields.body:
Carrie Franks, 36, is a managing director of a publishing company and lives in London with her husband, Andy. When Carrie fell pregnant she and Andy were delighted. For the first four months Carrie felt great and everything was going to plan.

After 20 weeks Carrie noticed she was bleeding. At the hospital, doctors discovered that the placenta and uterus had separated. The bleeding became heavier and Carrie was kept in hospital for two weeks. Suddenly she went into labour.

Baby Alex was born weighing only 1lb 1oz (482g). The midwife told Carrie that her son was already dead. After cleaning the baby the midwife gave him to Andy for him to hold. Suddenly Alex came to life in Andy's arms. Alex was whisked away and taken to the hospital's resuscitation unit.

The next four days were a nightmare for Carrie. "I had a baby but every time I saw him I thought it would be the last," she says.

Babies born so young often do quite well, then get worse very quickly. Carrie and Andy were told not to get their hopes up too high. The consultant neonatologist Sian Harding explained that even if Alex survived he might have severe disabilities. Carrie and Andy were given the option of switching off the ventilator.

Carrie and Andy were only prepared to do so if brain scans showed bleeding in Alex's brain. As no bleeding was detected, Alex's struggle for life continued, and the ventilators stayed on.

Alex caught several infections during his first 12 months. He nearly died when infected fluid built up around his heart. Again Carrie and Andy were told to prepare for the worst. But Alex survived.

Alex remained in hospital for 11 months. Finally he was strong enough to be taken home by Carrie and Andy.

During this 11-month ordeal Carrie and Andy were helped and given support by other parents who Bliss had put them in touch with. Carrie was so grateful that she decided to train as a parent supporter herself so that she could help other parents in the future.

"I feel lucky that Andy and I have been blessed with a baby who really is a miracle. Our story will be inspirational to other parents," says Carrie.

"Although it's great to talk to the medical staff, there's nothing better than talking to a parent who has been through it." And as for young Alex: "We're not out of the woods yet, but he is such a happy child. He hardly ever cries. The doctors say it's inconceivable that he will not have some developmental problems, but so far so good. His hearing is fine, but he has problems with his vision in one eye."

fields.headline: Napster faces two new lawsuits
fields.trailText:
2.45pm: The embattled dotcom could face further fines of up to £100,000 per song traded, reports Amy Vickers.
8.30am: Web whizz plans legal version of Napster
Mar 7: Napster fails to satisfy court
Mar 6: Vivendi gives Napster hope
Feb 21: Napster to settle copyright case
fields.body:
Adding insult to injury, Napster has been served two new law suits.

The embattled song-swapping service could face further fines of up to £100,000 per song traded if found guilty of wilful copyright infringement in these latest cases.

Rival online music distributor EMusic and the producer of the Grammy awards have now entered the anti-Napster contingency.

However, cynics claim the latest suits are merely PR exercises and have come too late in the proceedings to have any merit.

Little known outfit EMusic has filed a copyright infringement suit against Napster.

It has accused Napster of unfair competition practices because it deals in illegitimately copyrighted material.

The National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, which produces Grammies, also issued a writ against Napster.

It claimed millions of copies of songs performed by artists such as U2, Madonna and the Eminem at last month's awards were being traded through the service.

The new lawsuits could further drain Napster's cash resources.

On April 10, a federal court will decide whether all the different lawsuits should be turned into class actions.

If this happens, Napster could be inundated with many more legal claims.

fields.headline: Celebrity Big Brother line-up unveiled
fields.trailText: 2.45pm: Anthea Turner and Chris Eubank are to star in Channel 4's Celebrity Big Brother, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Channel 4 has confirmed the final line-up for Celebrity Big Brother.

Boyzone bad boy Keith Duffy will be joined by the slimmed down TV talk show presenter Vanessa Feltz, comic Jack Dee, former boxer Chris Eubank, former GMTV presenter Anthea Turner and Brookside star Claire Sweeney, who plays Lindsay Corkhill.

The announcement ends weeks of speculation about the line-up, which was also tipped to include DJ and media mogul Chris Evans.

The only real surprise in the line-up is Ms Sweeney, who is currently caught in the middle of a lesbian love triangle involving her mother and former lover Shelley.

Former Spice Girl Mel B was originally tipped to be on the show, but pulled out at the last minute due to ill-health.

And Frank Skinner and Mariella Frostrup, who were also thought to be appearing, will not be on the programme.

Jack Dee said he agreed to appear on the programme "because Lenny Henry threatened to kill me if I didn't agree", while Anthea Turner said "Richard Curtis bribed me with Hobnobs".

The week-long celebrity Big Brother will begin on Friday March 9, with the final eviction on March 16.

As with last summer's hit show, the contestants will take turns to nominate a candidate for eviction. On the final night viewers will choose who to kick out from shortlist of three.

But unlike the original Big Brother, there will be no opportunities to see celebrities in the shower or toilets.

fields.headline: Sun casts its vote for Blair
fields.trailText: 11am: Labour can breathe a sigh of relief after the Sun declared its support for the party following yesterday's Budget, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Labour can today breathe a sigh of relief after the Sun, the most influential paper during elections, declared its unequivocal support for the party.

In an incredible gushing leader splashed over the front page, the paper concludes: "Blair has done enough to win our backing."

The front page headline puts it even more simply: "It's in the bag, Tony. You might as well call election now."

The Sun, whose Trevor Kavanagh is regarded as the most powerful political editor in the lobby, stated clearly it is backing Mr Blair for a second term in government.

"It is now crystal clear," says the Sun, "after Gordon Brown's Budget, that the election is in the bag."

The paper continues: "Yesterday's Budget was an astounding achievement - and we're not just talking about Brown's welcome emphasis on children and families, car owners and welfare reform. It was astounding because £34bn of our national debt is to be paid off this year alone."

The newspaper's backing is an important litmus test for an election victory. Its hostility towards Neil Kinnock during the 1992 election was partly blamed for the party's painful defeat.

On the day of that general election, it memorably splashed with a picture of Mr Kinnock's face in a lightbulb.

"If Kinnock wins today, will the last person to leave Britain please turn out the lights?" it said.

The headline was followed by a crushing defeat for Labour, leading the Sun to boast that it was "the Sun wot won" the election for John Major's Conservatives.

The chancellor's giveaway Budget yesterday won over virtually all the other papers although traditional Tory papers the Telegraph and the Daily Mail were grudging.

 The Daily Mail, whose clout among the middle-classes makes it one of Labour's most feared papers, admits the election is in the bag for Mr Blair but it is still circumspect. "Mr Brown appears to have pulled off that rare feat: a pre-election Budget that doesn't look too blatant an opportunist, vote grabbing exercise." But it notes that if the public finances are in good health it is because Labour has "stuck rigidly for two years of Tory spending plans". But the worst thing the Mail had to say was that the "deliberately modest package was dull enough to send anyone to sleep".

 The Mirror's verdict is unsurprisingly unstinting with its support for Labour. It gave over its front page over to a gushing cartoon of Mr Brown as Gladiator Russell Crowe, who "strode into the election arena with a vote-winning budget".

 The Guardian was more measured in its praise with columnist Polly Toynbee noting the discrepancy between the healthy state of public finances and underspending on essential services, but nevertheless endorsed "a budget to build on".

 The Daily Telegraph, in spite of some sniping about Gordon Brown and his media relationship with "Prudence" was forced to concede that "his case is strong".

 The Times: Gordon Brown's Budget will lift the curtain on Labour's act two. The Budget was a strictly economic occasion that will be welcomed, in the short term at least, by the voters. In the long term, the continued success of Mr Brown will depend on the economy. But his wider aim is now clear: the reinvention of social democracy.

 The Financial Times: No mention of the Budget in the FT's leader column.

 The Independent: The Budget was more about politics than the economy. Voters will welcome Gordon Brown's decision to put public services first, but some of the measures were mere gimmicks and stunts. The expected economic slowdown will prove the real test.

 Daily Express: The chancellor is no Flash Gordon. Gordon Brown has paved the way for Labour to sweep to victory in the general election. This was a budget delivered by a chancellor who recognised that concessions were needed but was not going to make any flashy gestures.

 Daily Star: The chancellor has dared to be dull. The Budget may not contain many fireworks, but it will cement the genuine prosperity Britain has been enjoying for the past few years.

fields.headline: Springer set to host C5 game show
fields.trailText: 1.15pm: Jerry Springer is being lined up to present Channel 5's £1m entertainment game show Greed, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Jerry Springer is being lined up to present Channel 5's £1m entertainment game show Greed.

The broadcaster is close to signing up the renowned US talk show host to front Greed, which will feature the largest cash prize ever offered by Channel 5.

Greed is a 60-minute show combining elements of Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? and The Weakest Link.

In each instalment of the 11-part series, teams of five compete for the £1m prize by answering a series of questions.

The person answering the first question quickest becomes the team leader.

This individual then decides after each round whether the group should continue or take the money and can also overrule answers made by other team members.

As the prize money goes up, the questions become more difficult.

The team members also get a chance to eliminate each other in a "terminator" sudden-death round.

Greed is due to go out in the spring.

The move forms part of Channel 5's drive to step up its programming performance, as part of a strategy by majority shareholder RTL to increase the broadcaster's audience share.

RTL, which owns 65% of Channel 5, has been at loggerheads with United Business Media, owner of the remaining 35% of the broadcaster.

United has opposed RTL's demands for big increases in the Channel 5 programming budget.

The Greed format is owned by Pearson Television, an RTL subsidiary.

fields.headline: Earle slams four-letter advertising
fields.trailText:
1.45pm: The author and former TV presenter Liz Earle has slammed the increasing use of bad language in advertising. By Claire Cozens.
Mar 7: Media Medium FCUKing genius
Mar 1: Beattie lashes out against TV prudes
Mar 1: French Connection to sell condoms
Mar 1: Beattie's letter to bland adland
fields.body:
The author and former TV presenter Liz Earle has launched an outspoken attack on the increasing use of bad language in advertising in the wake of French Connection's new FCUK campaign.

In a letter published in today's Telegraph, Ms Earle described the retailer's new campaign as "truly abhorrent".

She complained that the giant posters - which carry the slogan "fcukinkybugger" - were in the direct eyeline of children looking out of car windows in traffic jams.

Ms Earle said the campaign was a "sad indictment" of the advertising industry.

"If corporations and their agencies cannot regulate themselves, it is time for stricter regulations to be placed upon them," she said.

"I notice the company has deferred from using FCUK in its children's ads," she added.

"Perhaps in the current social climate 'FCUK children' is still just beyond the tastelessness of even the French Connection marketing department and its advertising agency."

Ms Earle's comments will revive the row over the long-running campaign, which has infuriated and delighted in equal measure.

The Advertising Standards Authority, which regulates press and poster adverts, today confirmed that it has launched a formal investigation into the campaign after it received more than 30 complaints.

The slogan, created by Trevor Beattie, has attracted widespread criticism from both the advertising industry and the regulators.

But French Connection founder Stephen Marks credits Mr Beattie's advertising with turning around the fortunes of French Connection to make it one of the few profitable high street fashion chains.

Last week, Mr Beattie accused the Broadcast Advertising Clearance Centre of censorship after it barred the latest commercial from being shown on TV.

The film will instead be shown only in cinemas.

Ms Earle's views echo those of the broadcaster and politician Trevor Phillips, who recently spoke out against a Broadcasting Standards Commission ruling that it was acceptable for a black man to call the Queen a bitch.

Mr Phillips said the decision had given the stamp of approval to sexist and abusive language and was a "catastrophe" for parents of young children.

fields.headline: US troops open fire on Albanian guerrillas
fields.standfirst: Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: US soldiers fired on ethnic Albanian guerrillas near the Macedonian border yesterday as pressure mounted on Nato to take tougher action against the rebels in cooperation with Serbia.
fields.byline: Richard Norton-Taylor, Rory Carroll in Pristina and Nick Wood in Skopje
fields.body:
US soldiers fired on ethnic Albanian guerrillas near the Macedonian border yesterday as pressure mounted on Nato to take tougher action against the rebels in cooperation with Serbia.

In the first armed engagement involving K-For peacekeepers in the area, two Albanian guerrillas were wounded inside Kosovo across the border from the Macedonian village of Tanusevci, where Macedonian troops and ethnic Albanian guerrillas clashed for two days this week.

The US troops moved into the Kosovo border village of Mijak in search of weapons. When a group of four men in black uniforms with red patches pointed their weapons at them, the peacekeepers opened fire, the US military said. The guerrillas did not fire back.

The shooting lasted 10 to 15 minutes and ended with a badly wounded Albanian being evacuated to the US military hospital at Camp Bondsteel. The US troops were last night searching for the other men.

Although there was mist the American foot patrol's distinctive uniform meant that its members could not have been mistaken for Macedonians, said a K-For official. Mijak, just a few hundred metres inside the Kosovo border, is on a ridge overlooking forested valleys.

"We are prepared for any response," said Major James Marshall, a spokesman for the US peacekeepers. "We will use all means necessary. We don't want any more violence, but this will be up to those armed men."

A European diplomat, reflecting concern about Washington's reluctance to act against ethnic Albanians - and cooperate with the Serbs - said: "The US is getting its act together".

In a separate incident, two Yugoslav soldiers were killed and two others seriously injured when their vehicle hit a landmine. The soldiers were outside the village of Oreovica, on the edge of a buffer zone between Kosovo and the rest of Serbia.

The village is near the town of Presevo, about 230 miles from Yugoslavia's capital, Belgrade. The entire population of Oreovica is Albanian.

The Nato allies were yesterday discussing whether to allow Serbia to conduct armed patrols in a short strip of its external border with Macedonia, as well as in the nearby Presevo valley.

"Nato can only facilitate but leaving things as they are is not an option," an alliance spokesman said last night. But the US was reportedly still reluctant to allow Serb forces closer to the border with Kosovo.

Kosovan Albanian leaders attacked the proposal to let Serbian forces into the buffer zone, claiming it could spark fresh violence in the Balkans.

"The army which until recently committed massacres in Kosovo cannot return to Kosovo or to a part of the Kosovo-Macedonian border, especially not to the triangle between Kosovo, Macedonia and Serbia," Kole Berisha, vice-president of the moderate Democratic League of Kosovo party said. A three-mile "ground safety zone" within Serbia and running along the border with its province of Kosovo was imposed by Nato after the 1999 Kosovo war. It has allowed guerrillas from Kosovo to infiltrate the border region which is inhabited by ethnic Albanians.

British defence official said yesterday that the prospect of joint K-For/Serb patrols could not be ruled out.

The conflict has also drawn in Macedonia, 30% of whose population is ethnic Albanian. This week Albanian insurgents killed three Macedonian soldiers near the Kosovan border.

A Macedonian police spokesman, Stevo Pendarovski, said yesterday that about 300 ethnic Albanians, mostly women and children, had fled their homes in villages along the border.

The Macedonian president, Boris Trajkovski, played down the latest violence: "I don't believe that we'll have again the situation here as we have had over the last few days, and we are there only to isolate the presence of these terrorists."

The Macedonian government, which includes ethnic Albanians, risks alienating its ethnic minority if it adopts tough tactics against the guerrillas, or alienating the Slav majority if it does too little, western diplomats said yesterday.

Macedonia has called for a high-level meeting at Nato headquarters in Brussels tomorrow- an indication of its growing concern about the deteriorating security situation. It has criticised the alliance for not taking firmer action earlier and wants a solution involving international troops.

fields.headline: Japanese justice goes on trial
fields.standfirst: The conviction of a Nepalese worker for the murder of a Tokyo prostitute has raised serious questions about the treatment of foreigners in Japan, writes Jonathan Watts
fields.trailText: The murder conviction of a Nepalese worker has raised questions about the treatment of foreigners in Japan, writes Jonathan Watts.
fields.body:
In 1997, the very different paths of Yasuko Watanabe, a 39-year-old "office lady" and Govinda Prasad Mainali, a 34-year-old Nepalese restaurant worker, crossed with sordid and tragic consequences.

Shortly after they met, Watanabe's body was found in a deserted building near Mainali's apartment and the Nepalese man was arrested for murder.

Watanabe had led an exceptional double life: by day, she was a high-flying economist for one of Japan's most prestigious companies; by night, a prostitute who turned tricks in Tokyo's sleazy Shibuya district.

She walked the streets in Murayama-cho, an area filled with love hotels. Each night after finishing at the office of Tokyo Electric, the graduate from the elite Keio university would have sex with customers in cars, parks or hotel rooms.

According to the extensive domestic reportage on the case, she touted for business in a long wig, swigging beer and calling out to businessmen, "Do you want to play?"

A methodical worker, she kept a detailed record of her clients inclding their names and how much they paid.

It suggests that she was a Robin Hood of hookers who would charge Japanese businessmen up to £300, but only a tenth of this amount to clients from developing nations.

Mainali had sex with her on at least two occasions, but any gratitude he might have initially felt at the charitable price must have soon turned to a wish that he'd never met her.

He was arrested and tried for murder, the two main pieces of evidence being a condom containing his semen and a pubic hair found near the body, though other unidentified hairs were also found nearby.

In April last year, a lower court acquitted Mainali, saying the case against him was flimsy and circumstantial. The judge accepted that the two condom and hair could have been left during a previous liaison.

This was a stunning decision in a country where 99.8 per cent of criminal trials end with a conviction, but it did not provide relief for Mainali. As he was preparing to leave his cell, prosecutors won a new order to have him jailed so that he could not leave the country while they appealed the ruling.

This imprisonment of a man declared innocent sparked a furious response among human rights groups.

"It's not possible, legally, to detain a person who has been acquitted, but they did it anyway," Hideki Morihara of Amnesty International told the Washington Post. "It's a breach of Japanese law and international law."

The outrage grew in December, when a high court reversed the previous decision and sentenced Mainali to life imprisonment even though no new evidence had been presented by the prosecution.

"The victim worked for a major company and held a high position," said the presiding judge as the Nepalese man screamed out his innocence.

In their coverage of the case, newspapers have been largely sympathetic towards Mainali and printed rare criticism of Japan's legal system by lawyers and human rights groups.

"The system is rotten. The criminal courts are comatose: they do what the prosecutors tell them," said Katsuhiko Tsukuda, one of the lawyers defending Mainali.

According to Shinichi Sano, author of a book on the "Office Lady Murder", the high court's decision is based on fabricated depositions and ambiguous material evidence.

"With this case, the Japanese legal system has committed suicide," Sano said. "The ruling was influenced by the unconsciously held racial prejudice of the Japanese against a foreigner from an Asian country to which Japan provides large sums of economic aid.

"Just as the confused behaviour of Watanabe exposed the dark side of Japanese society, so the unfair treatment of Mainali has exposed the dark sides of the Japanese legal system."

fields.headline: Mandelson report out tomorrow
fields.standfirst: Special report: Peter Mandelson
fields.trailText: The report into the Hinduja cash for passports affair will be published tomorrow morning, Downing Street confirmed today.
fields.body:
The report into the cash for passports affair will be published tomorrow morning, Downing Street confirmed today.

A Downing Street spokesman said the prime minister, Tony Blair, now has the report.

The inquiry, conducted by Sir Anthony Hammond, is expected to clear Peter Mandelson, the former Northern Ireland secretary, of lying over his part in £1m Millennium Dome donor Srichand Hinduja's passport application.

Mr Mandelson resigned in January after apparent inconsistencies emerged in his account of a personal phone call to immigration minister Mike O'Brien about the case.

The former minister said he could not remember the conversation but Mr O'Brien, insisted that Mr Mandelson had called.

Mr Mandelson was accused of misleading the culture secretary, Chris Smith, (who had to answer a parliamentary question on the subject) and the prime minister's office over the phone call.

The report is also likely to exonerate the minister for Europe, Keith Vaz, in his efforts to get a passport for the Hinduja brothers, but will heavily criticise the chaotic and inadequate way in which the home office keeps its records.

The Hammond inquiry has found no documentary evidence that the conversation took place. Nor does it appear that any civil servant in the department definitely recalls any verbal reference to the conversation Mr O'Brien cites.

But Sir Anthony is likely to conclude the call did, on balance, occur, in part because Mr O'Brien, as a more junior minister at the time, was more likely to recall the conversation than Mr Mandelson.

fields.headline: About Super Dario Land
fields.trailText: Super Dario Land (SDL) was started in the 1993/94 season and has prospered to this day.
fields.body:
Super Dario Land (SDL) was started in the 1993/94 season and has prospered to this day.

At odds with the club initially (they thought we'd hit programme sales!) we slowly developed an 'understanding'. A daily version of fans views and opinion can now be found online at the Crewe section of From The Terrace (www.fromtheterrace.co.uk) which also carries some of the articles that feature in the monthly hard copy of SDL. Still only £1 since 1994/95 season, SDL is produced 10 times each season.

The latest issue went on sale vs Tranmere (03/03/01), with two further issues due out in early April and late April - trumpeting our latest fantastic survival, obviously.

You can get hold of SDL as you approach the ground on matchdays from sellers that in no way look like programme seller but still get asked 150 times each game "is that the programme?". This in no way annoys us, oh no.

For the record, SDL is a mix of opinion, fans thoughts and articles, a few memories, an in-depth look at Gresty Road goings-on, a few cartoons and pictures, plus plenty of anti-Stoke abuse. Why we bother with these Second Division no-hopers is beyond me...

Jules Hornbrook Editor of SDL and author of The Gradi Years book

fields.headline: Prudence pays off?
fields.standfirst: The chancellor's last Budget before the general election leaves his history of meanness still in question.
fields.trailText: The chancellor's last Budget before the general election leaves his history of meanness still in question, writes Polly Toynbee
fields.body:
The chancellor's final budget brought the curtain down on the end of New Labour, Act One with a mighty confident flourish. Flowers were thrown, opposition cabbages didn't even reach the stage. Now he retires to the dressing room to prepare for Act Two. Meanwhile the audience contemplates his grand opus so far, wondering what comes next.

This last great performance gave us the chancellor in red mode, poor children's friend, the stealth-taxing secret socialist. No other word but redistribution describes how the money has flowed towards the poorest with a little taken from the top. Why, even his henchmen now use the wicked R-word once banned from New Labour's lexicon. Average and poorer families were again the target of his munificence, new mothers, child care, paternity leave - a budget for poorer women, so a new mother will be £2,240 a year better off. Another 170,000 children will be lifted above poverty levels. And as more billions poured in for hospitals, schools, drug treatment, urban regeneration and myriad good causes - free museums, films, dilapidated churches, sports clubs - that now familiar Brown budget wonderment struck again.

For who could imagine a Labour chancellor with £16bn in his pocket, inflation licked, national debt and interest rates down, full employment within grasp? All pensioners (who claim) are in April lifted out of poverty - an unthinkable promise back in 1997, almost as extraordinary as ending child poverty. There has never been so big a step up for the poor. As for the rest? Good times brought jam to every social slice - 4% higher consumer spending each year, average living standards up rosily, mortgages an average £1,200 cheaper, growth outstripping all predictions. Happy days and the best is yet to come, as the public spending jam rolls out in earnest now.

So there are red roses aplenty for red Gordon. He has turned the political debate away from tax cuts - there were none, only extra credits for the poor. That was a crucial test of his nerve. How tempting with so much cash to knock another 1p off pre-election income tax. It was a 1999 error not repeated because it didn't need to be. Labour has gained in confidence since then and the public mood is with them - pressing for spending, not for tax cuts.

This chancellor congratulates himself on long-termism, but after an excellent first act, the end of his story is still unknown, judgment too early to make. For all the feel-good glow each of his budgets brings, there remains the big long-term question. Will he effect a fundamental and long-term shift in Britain's tax and spend regime? The year 2003-2004 is the crunch by which time the spending now laid out must have delivered undeniable results in health, education and transport - with public services proud, well-paid and thrusting ahead for all to see. Current public patience will run out by then. Tory posters reading "You paid the cash, so where are the nurses/teachers ..." and so on make people snort with scorn at Tory cheek now - but not by then if change is not everywhere about to be seen. As people get yearly richer, so expectations of public services rise too. Never before has a Labour government produced increases in public investment above trend growth, and yet the big picture is still a history of under-spending.

If it turns out that Act One was as good as it ever gets, then this first term was not enough. If recession rolls in on a dark tide from across the Atlantic, then we will look back and wonder how Labour did so little when the times were extraordinarily good. Why so timid, why so slow? The chancellor may have ended boom-and-bust but what we had instead in public spending was bust-and-boom. The depth of that bust is becoming ever more apparent: the price of prudence was painfully high. It will now not be until 2003-4 that Britain returns to the same level of public spending as a proportion of GDP that it inherited in 1997. A killer fact.

Of course it is not quite as simple as that. Within that total, the huge sums previously wasted on unemployment and debt interest have been redistributed to excellent effect. But none the less, over any length of time, the amount a country taxes and spends defines fairly accurately the quality of its public service. We will still not be spending nearly enough. It was Tony Blair himself who promised NHS spending would meet the EU average, thus drawing attention to the yawning gap between Europe and Britain in every other public sphere as well. The disastrous failure to spend in 2000 - with a massive £5bn capital undershoot - accidentally added to the time of famine, delaying results.

Another killer fact is that, despite the quite radical redistribution by government, the gap between the rich and poor has still widened under Labour. It always happens in prosperous times, but Labour made no attempt to claw back any of the extra income flowing in to top earners - let alone taxing their growing capital wealth. Indeed, capital gains and inheritance taxes have shrunk to insignificance. Let the Tories grumble about Labour's "45 new stealth taxes", the big picture is still that the rich are getting richer faster than the rest and the poor are still being left behind.

The ongoing comedy of Conservative policy - made not so much on the hoof as in the Magimix - gives Labour the chance to confront the tax question head on. William Hague, excited by George Bush's trillion dollar promise, now says he will make a mind-boggling £114bn tax cut. Suddenly lurching for a wild west alternative, the Tories now oblige Labour to talk honestly about tax. But an open advocacy of virtuous taxation has always been noticeably lacking in every Gordon Brown budget speech. He has extinguished public demand for tax cuts, but that's only half the battle. Hague's axe-man cuts require a broad and principled case to be made positively for taxes: they are not a "burden" if they buy the things that people want.

Praise of public wealth can face down the Tory nostrum that we each spend our own money better than the government does. If Labour's 10-year plans work as well as intended, there will be good evidence that public money well-spent buys much more collectively than citizens can each buy individually. But such words never spring easily to the chancellor's lips. This was a prudent budget - no horse-frightening in the City before an election. But future budgets need more radical shifts. Too often New Labour appeases and buys off opposing forces: this third-way strategy makes few friends or permanent changes. Long-term security for a left of centre government comes from persuading the public of the case for higher taxes - not from stealth or subterfuge. On taxes the people will not be fooled for long, but they might be persuaded to pay more.

For all the feel-good glow each of his budgets brings, there remains the big long-term question. Will he effect a fundamental and long-term shift in Britain's tax and spend regime? The year 2003-2004 is the crunch by which time the spending now laid out must have delivered undeniable results in health, education and transport - with public services proud, well-paid and thrusting ahead for all to see. Current public patience will run out by then. Tory posters reading "You paid the cash, so where are the nurses/teachers ..." and so on make people snort with scorn at Tory cheek now - but not by then if change is not everywhere about to be seen. As people get yearly richer, so expectations of public services rise too. Never before has a Labour government produced increases in public investment above trend growth, and yet the big picture is still a history of under-spending. If it turns out that Act One was as good as it ever gets, then this first term was not enough. If recession rolls in on a dark tide from across the Atlantic, then we will look back and wonder how Labour did so little when the times were extraordinarily good. Why so timid, why so slow? The chancellor may have ended boom-and-bust but what we had instead in public spending was bust-and-boom. The depth of that bust is becoming ever more apparent: the price of prudence was painfully high. It will now not be until 2003-4 that Britain returns to the same level of public spending as a proportion of GDP that it inherited in 1997. A killer fact. Of course it is not quite as simple as that. Within that total, the huge sums previously wasted on unemployment and debt interest have been redistributed to excellent effect. But none the less, over any length of time, the amount a country taxes and spends defines fairly accurately the quality of its public service. We will still not be spending nearly enough. It was Tony Blair himself who promised NHS spending would meet the EU average, thus drawing attention to the yawning gap between Europe and Britain in every other public sphere as well. The disastrous failure to spend in 2000 - with a massive £5bn capital undershoot - accidentally added to the time of famine, delaying results. Another killer fact is that, despite the quite radical redistribution by government, the gap between the rich and poor has still widened under Labour. It always happens in prosperous times, but Labour made no attempt to claw back any of the extra income flowing in to top earners - let alone taxing their growing capital wealth. Indeed, capital gains and inheritance taxes have shrunk to insignificance. Let the Tories grumble about Labour's "45 new stealth taxes", the big picture is still that the rich are getting richer faster than the rest and the poor are still being left behind. The ongoing comedy of Conservative policy - made not so much on the hoof as in the Magimix - gives Labour the chance to confront the tax question head on. William Hague, excited by George Bush's trillion dollar promise, now says he will make a mind-boggling £114bn tax cut. Suddenly lurching for a wild west alternative, the Tories now oblige Labour to talk honestly about tax. But an open advocacy of virtuous taxation has always been noticeably lacking in every Gordon Brown budget speech. He has extinguished public demand for tax cuts, but that's only half the battle. Hague's axe-man cuts require a broad and principled case to be made positively for taxes: they are not a "burden" if they buy the things that people want. Praise of public wealth can face down the Tory nostrum that we each spend our own money better than the government does. If Labour's 10-year plans work as well as intended, there will be good evidence that public money well-spent buys much more collectively than citizens can each buy individually. But such words never spring easily to the chancellor's lips. This was a prudent budget - no horse-frightening in the City before an election. But future budgets need more radical shifts. Too often New Labour appeases and buys off opposing forces: this third-way strategy makes few friends or permanent changes. Long-term security for a left of centre government comes from persuading the public of the case for higher taxes - not from stealth or subterfuge. On taxes the people will not be fooled for long, but they might be persuaded to pay more.

fields.headline: More efficient killing fields
fields.trailText: In the movie Jaws was the hidden horror that would rip your legs off and turn your insides into offal. In reality such a fate is most likely to be delivered by a man-made anti-personnel landmine, ostensibly banned by the Ottawa convention, but still maiming and killing an estimated 25,000 people a year.
fields.body:
In the movie Jaws was the hidden horror that would rip your legs off and turn your insides into offal. In reality such a fate is most likely to be delivered by a man-made anti-personnel landmine, ostensibly banned by the Ottawa convention, but still maiming and killing an estimated 25,000 people a year.

A report last week by Landmine Action reveals that Nato governments are investing in mine-like technologies, some of which are specifically designed to get around the landmine ban. They include anti-vehicle mines with anti-handling devices or sensitive fuses, such as the German AT-2, which can be detonated by someone stumbling across it or even by the proximity of someone wearing a wristwatch.

The Italian government destroyed its entire stock of AT-2 mines in 1997. But Britain's Ministry of Defence has an estimated 100,000 in stock. On the horizon, however, is a new generation of victim-activated technologies that look and operate nothing like "traditional" mines.

They include so called "self-healing" minefields developed by Sandia Laboratories in the United States. These mines have ultrasonic sensors and a piston-driven foot, enabling them to hop 10 metres in the air. Equipped with primitive neural network systems, such "intelligent" mines are able to detect the distance to neighbouring mines, sense when some are missing, and leap around until the pattern is virtually re-established.

Other victim-seeking lethal technologies identified by the report include "off-the-shelf" systems such as the automated, camera-mounted, concealed machine-guns produced by the US company Autauga Arms; the French Ruggieri DIPS area-denial system, which consists of a multiple grenade launcher capable of firing a variety of disorientating chemical and wounding ammunition; or the dart-firing Robart, of the Rand Corporation's Arroyo Urban Operations team.

Already on the horizon are formidable autonomous systems based on the Australian company Metal Storm's variable-lethality enforcement guns, which can fire ammunition electronically without mechanical triggers, in salvos at a rate of 90,000 rounds per minute. A sensor-activated, 100-barrel multiple mortar targeting system has been devised by Metal Storm with $240,000 assistance from the Australian government to produce a sensor-activated "landmine replacement".

The search for alternative landmines has become intensely commercial with the US government initiating a three-track approach to enable it to sign the Ottawa treaty in 2006. Track three, which is concerned with finding alternative operational concepts (which include "precision-guided munitions, autonomous robotic systems, combat identification systems and improvements to direct and indirect fire systems") has been allocated $228m. Some of these will involve getting around Ottawa's provisions by leaving no ordnance in the ground. Instead a virtual minefield has been created, based on satellite surveillance and computer-held maps, which can unleash mortar or missile fire against anyone or thing that crosses the threshold of any of the virtual mines.

A key area in the public relations quest for humane mines is in the work undertaken for the US joint non-lethal weapons programme. The report describes variants of the Claymore mine using rubber balls. There are also tranquillising chemicals and anxiety-causing drugs with a variety of delivery mechanisms; entanglements including bounding net mines; pre-encapsulated malodorant smells such as faeces, rotting meat, skunk and body odour. There are also directed energy weapons. Some use the microwave part of the electromagnetic spectrum. These are seen as offering a "tunable" response as so-called "progressive penalty munitions".

With reputations and big contracts at stake, some of these sci-fi alternatives have, like Ronald Reagan's Star Wars, promised more than they can deliver. Programmes such as nets fired from canisters have been dropped - sometimes because they were lethal in practice, other times because the science did not add up.

Systems most likely to find favour are ones using tested technology. These include a landmine based on high voltage electroshock devices manufactured by the US companies Tasertron and Primex Aerospace. Once the device lands it is immediately capable of victim activation by a trip device and a variety of other sensors.

When activated, barbed darts are fired in a 120-degree multi-directional pattern reaching out between 5m and 10m. Then 50,000 volts are pulsed through the target sufficient to paralyse through an inch of clothing. Four darts are fired at different angles to get anyone crouching to avoid a mid-torso strike. Tasertron claims that "the electronic pulse will temporarily incapacitate anyone within an inch of the darts by overriding the brain's signal to near-surface motor control nerves, causing uncontrollable spasms of the subject's motor control functions. The subject will fall and be temporarily incapacitated. The subject remains conscious and alert, but cannot control his muscles. A timing circuit will permit keeping the subject incapacitated until they can be taken into custody by nearby troops."

Not surprisingly, Amnesty International is calling for a suspension of all trade in such devices as part of their "stop the torture trade campaign", because electroshock devices have become the universal tool of the torturer. It would be ironic if a version capable of industrialising the practice becomes part of the landscape of modern warfare.

President George Bush is due to decide shortly on the status of the US alternative anti-personnel mine programme. The odds are that he will agree to unleash this arsenal on future generations.

Alternative Anti-Personnel Mines - The Next Generations is published by Landmine Action, 89 Albert Embankment, London SE1 7TP, price £8.50. Steve Wright is director of the Omega Foundation

fields.headline: Job cuts at Express imminent
fields.trailText: 8.30am:Redundancies at the Express are imminent with a fresh round of cutbacks expected within days, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The Express is close to finalising details on an as-yet unspecified number of editorial job cuts.

Bosses at the paper are expected to announce job cuts, rumoured to involve between 50 and 100 staff, imminently.

The job cuts have been expected ever since Richard Desmond took over the paper in November.

They will follow Mr Desmond's decision to make journalists on the Express's City pages produce additional copy for a new Daily Star City page.

One senior insider said: "A plan including some redundancies will be put forward in the next few days".

A spokesman for the company categorically denied that any list of names had been drawn up by either editor Chris Williams or Mr Desmond.

He said: "Staffing levels are under constant review. There is no hit list."

Under the rules the Express must undergo a 90-day consultation period if the number of redundancies involves 100 or more staff.

However, anything between 20 and 99 redundancies require just 30 days' notice.

Before former editor Rosie Boycott left, it was made known that Mr Desmond wanted to bring staffing levels down to those of other papers.

He was aghast when he learned that the Mirror operated on a journalistic headcount of just under 300 while the Express had 440 staff.

Journalists on the City desk are aggrieved at the extra workload, which comes with no extra staff or resources.

And some fear the strategy of making journalists double up across the Express and Star titles could be replicated across other desks such as showbusiness.

Shortly after he bought the paper Mr Desmond axed over 60 advertising, marketing and support staff from Express Newspapers, prompting a furious response from Ms Boycott.

Under employment legislation, the new owner of a company is obliged to wait for 90 days before making more than 100 staff redundant.

This three-month period is nearly up, and Mr Desmond now believes the time has come to wield the axe.

Neither Mr Williams nor Mr Desmond was available for comment.

fields.headline: House calls
fields.standfirst: New, affordable homes for rent are needed - particularly in London and the south-east. But powerful lobbies oppose plans by developers.
fields.trailText: New, affordable homes for rent are needed - particularly in London and the south-east. But powerful lobbies oppose plans by developers, writes David Walker
fields.body:
In 10 years' time Alan Holmans will either be discredited or forgotten or, more likely, statues of him will be erected in the new estates around the south of England that will be needed to accommodate the explosive growth he projects in numbers of households.

The former civil servant turned Cambridge University researcher has become housing's Cassandra. His latest forecast says that across England 230,000 newly-built homes or conversions will be needed each year until at least 2016.

But look at what the Halifax said this week about house prices. They are rising by £47 a day, which is dandy for existing home owners but makes a decent home less and less affordable for many. The gap will have to be filled by government subsidy. Mr Holmans says 80-85,000 subsidised dwellings are going to be needed each year for the next decade and a half. Only 70-75,000 look like being built. The result will be "very severe worsening of overcrowding and housing standards", especially in London.

The not-for-profit housing associations and the Town and Country Planning Association have just published Mr Holman's latest calculation of the number of households that will come into being over the next two decades*. These "households" are not going to be people wandering the street suitcase in hand. Denied easy access to somewhere to stay people will stay with parents and relatives, share or otherwise squeeze into what is available. But there is a limit to how much boxing and coxing can go on.

The chart breaks the projection down region by region. In the south east outside London, 32,000 dwellings each year are going to be needed either for purchase or private rental without subsidy. London can do it, deputy mayor Nicky Gavron declared the other day, confident that London can grow from 7.4m to 8.1m total population by 2016. Coincidentally the Council for the Protection of Rural England (CPRE) - the Nimbys' best friend - declared its undying opposition to "urban sprawl" and building on green fields.

But London's physical capacity depends on the expansion of the tube - and other social infrastructure. And the protectors of rural England (who are usually reluctant to pay the tax needed to support the urban renewal) need to say where they think the growth being generated in Guildford, Basildon, Ashford and Watford will be placed. The advocates of recycling land within urban boundaries rarely acknowledge its costs including the impact of town cramming on existing urbanites who are going to have to live yet more cheek by jowl with their neighbours.

The CPRE likes to present developers as grasping house-builders, putting Barratt-style boxes on the greensward. But much of the demand is going to be for single-person dwellings that are affordable, which means public subsidy will have to be put not only into construction but also to help with the rent.

Broadly, in the three decades since 1970 median earnings have just about kept up with house prices. But the earnings of poorer households increased at an annual rate well below the long run average rise in house prices, especially in the south east. To afford a dwelling costing £106,000 (the average for England and Wales) you would need a household income of about £34,000, well above the average. And there are regional complications, for while house prices are cheaper north of Watford, wages are not markedly less.

The government is trying to make council and housing association rents more market sensitive. That tends to mean lowering them in the north and raising them in the south. But land prices in the south-east are accelerating and plans for new building often depend on heroic assumptions about future levels of housing benefit - which successive governments say they are going to cut but do not.

Some criticise Alan Holmans and the housing providers for crying wolf. Homelessness defined as those accepted by councils as in dire need is only 100,000 - the number "roofless" sleeping on the streets is now negligible. Politically, housing remains low profile. But Ken Livingstone and John Prescott see eye to eye on the need to offer teachers, nurses and police officers in the capital access to subsidised rented property - for how else could they afford to live in London? Disarray in the administration of housing benefit may be due to the growing gap between demand for and supply of affordable houses and flats.

Things, says Mr Holmans, can only get worse. Men's death rates are falling; immigration into the UK (usually into London and the south-east) is up. More men are living alone - if they can find somewhere to stay. They may have reasonable incomes but they are not yuppies who can afford docklands.

Over the years policy makers have talked about trying to make England outside the south-east more attractive, keeping the indigenous population of the Midlands and north at home and maybe even making the low housing- demand regions beckon people from the south. Short of forced marches, these schemes of internal redistribution of population are not going to be realised. That means there will have to more building in the southern counties, whatever the green lobbies say - unless housing standards are sharply to decline.

*Housing demand and need in England 1996-2016 from TCPA 0207 9308903.

David Walker is a director of Places for People Group, a large provider of social housing.
