fields.headline: Arms decommissioning in Northern Ireland
fields.standfirst: The Provisional IRA is to renew contact with the independent arms decommissioning body - but there is little hope that it is yet prepared to give up its weapons. Derek Brown explains
fields.trailText:
The Provisional IRA is to renew contact with the independent arms decommissioning body - but there is little hope that it is yet prepared to give up its weapons. Derek Brown explains
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.body:
What is the decommissioning body?
It's officially called the Decommissioning Commission. The bureaucratic babble is intended to soothe republican pain over what is - or should be - disarmament. We mustn't talk about 'surrender' though; the correct usage is that arms should be 'put beyond use'.

Who's in charge?
Former Canadian general John de Chastelain. He is well respected in Northern Ireland, and in London and Dublin. But he is hardly overworked: his commission was set up in September 1997, since when, apart from desultory contacts with republican and loyalist paramilitary groups, it hasn't made any significant progress.

Have any weapons been put beyond use?
A small number of IRA arms dumps have been inspected by two internationa observers, Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa and Martti Ahtisaari of Finland They have no official connection with the Chastelain commission, but the IRA leadership prefers to deal with them to avoid charges by its own militants that it is meekly going along with the decommissioning process. The inspections took place in June and October last year.

But didn't the IRA promise to decommission its arms?
It's more complicated than that. The organisation is committed to its ceasefire, but says that the decommissioning process is conditional on the implementation of other parts of the Good Friday peace accord. Most crucially, on radical reform of the Royal Ulster Constabulary; the establishment of all-Ireland political institutions, and the 'demilitarisation' (ie British army withdrawal) of nationalist areas of Northern Ireland.

Aren't those things happening?
Not exactly. The proposed RUC reforms have been watered down, say the republicans. The all-Ireland institutions are moribund, because unionists refuse to cooperate there with Sinn Fein representatives. Although the army has scaled down its presence, soldiers are still entrenched in districts such as South Armagh.

Any hopes of a breakthrough?
The IRA's willingness to resume contacts with General de Chastelain must be encouraging, but as one Belfast observer said this morning, they must be prepared to do more than discuss the weather. Unionist frustration with the snail's pace of disarmament is fast reaching boiling point - as is republican frustration over the snail's pace of police and political reform.

What are the British and Irish governments doing?
Tony Blair and his counterpart in Dublin, Bertie Ahern, have tacitly given up hope of making significant progress before the coming British general election. But rather than be seen to do nothing, they are holding yet another round of talks in Belfast today with the pro-Good Friday political parties, including the Ulster Unionists and Sinn Fein.

fields.bodyText: What is the decommissioning body? It's officially called the Decommissioning Commission. The bureaucratic babble is intended to soothe republican pain over what is - or should be - disarmament. We mustn't talk about 'surrender' though; the correct usage is that arms should be 'put beyond use'. Who's in charge? Former Canadian general John de Chastelain. He is well respected in Northern Ireland, and in London and Dublin. But he is hardly overworked: his commission was set up in September 1997, since when, apart from desultory contacts with republican and loyalist paramilitary groups, it hasn't made any significant progress. Have any weapons been put beyond use? A small number of IRA arms dumps have been inspected by two internationa observers, Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa and Martti Ahtisaari of Finland They have no official connection with the Chastelain commission, but the IRA leadership prefers to deal with them to avoid charges by its own militants that it is meekly going along with the decommissioning process. The inspections took place in June and October last year. But didn't the IRA promise to decommission its arms? It's more complicated than that. The organisation is committed to its ceasefire, but says that the decommissioning process is conditional on the implementation of other parts of the Good Friday peace accord. Aren't those things happening? Not exactly. The proposed RUC reforms have been watered down, say the republicans. fields.headline: Don't believe the virus hype
fields.standfirst: Put your concerns about the Naked Wife, I Love You and Anna Kournikova bugs behind you, says Online editor Neil McIntosh. The real affliction these days is the hysteria that surrounds them
fields.trailText: Put your concerns about the Naked Wife, I Love You and Anna Kournikova bugs behind you, says Online editor Neil McIntosh. The real affliction these days is the hysteria that surrounds them.
fields.body:
David Perry lives and breathes computer viruses.

For the last ten years he has caught them, taken them to bits and studied them, broadcast across the world about what he has found, and addressed countless conferences. He works for a major antivirus firm, Trend Micro, and in his time has worked for other big names in the virus war including McAfee and Symantec.

So, as you'd expect, he's the kind of guy who takes these malicious bits of computer code pretty seriously. So seriously, in fact, he worries about the day when some creaking system in a hospital ward gets infected and crashes, endangering some vital piece of life support equipment. "I really believe that in the future someone could die as a result of a virus," he told me yesterday.

All of which made Perry's comments to a specialist meeting earlier this week extremely puzzling. Perry was in Munich for the 10th annual conference of the European Institute for Antivirus Research, and he delivered a paper and speech which had the virus community abuzz.

For, instead of talking (for instance) about the dangers of Microsoft Outlook and visual basic - two tools of choice for today's easily assembled computer virus - he talked of "a growing problem, and one not addressable by conventional engineering the problem of ignorance, of mistaken or misinformed action."

His worry? That there is a growing gap between real viruses and the surrounding mythology. That, increasingly, the real virus is the hype.

A perfect example he cites was the Anna Kournikova outbreak of last month. Just in time for Valentines Day, a very simple virus created using a simple toolkit spread across the net. Victims - expecting a titillating picture of tennis star Kournikova - clicked on an executable file, which then used the users address book to mail copies of itself to all the names in it.

Within hours of the virus being identified by several large virus protection companies, breathless public relations people were hitting the phones. This one, they told me and several other journalists, was as big as the Love Bug outbreak of the previous year, spreading fast and threatening to bring the world's email to a crashing halt.

It did nothing of the kind, of course, but thanks to the efficient work of the public relations folk the virus still served some kind of purpose. The virus protection businesses quoted in the resultant press got a little boost, and lots of computer users were left worried about their machines being invaded.

Perry, a former help desk staffer, knows only too well what happens next. A deep suspicion is born; of the internet, of email, of computers themselves. Users panic, reformatting drives and wasting vast amounts of time recovering from their own blunders, even when they never had a virus.

The hype machine, says Perry, talks up the danger out there. Symantec, makers of Norton Anti-Virus, boasts on its webpage today that its software covers you against 48,816 viruses. What they don't mention is that only 800 viruses have ever infected a computer anywhere, and that only around 200 (including this week's fave, the "Naked Wife" virus) are doing the rounds at the moment.

"All the others are kept under lock and key at the antivirus companies themselves," Perry told me. "Most virus writers fear breaking the law by releasing their code into the wild, so they email it directly to the antivirus companies asking 'is this dangerous?' We say 'oh, yes, it's dangerous', and then lock it away."

It is said boxers never see the punch that gets them. Similarly, the deadly virus that creeps into vital hospital systems, without the aid of a headline-grabbing naked wife or a Kournikova, could be the one that causes the tragedy he dreads.

It's time to calm the hype down and get real, says Perry, before his industry cries "wolf" one too many times.

webTitle: How the papers greeted Mr Brown's Budget

fields.headline: How the papers greeted Mr Brown's Budget
fields.trailText:
The Guardian
Mr Brown refuse(d) the obvious trick - a penny cut in income tax - in favour of a mix of tax breaks targeted at the poorest and around £2bn extra for public spending. In other words he has chosen to stake Labour's electoral hopes on the belief that when voters face a choice between £8bn worth of Tory tax cuts and Labour's promise of investment in the schools and hospitals, they will go for the latter. If that is right, and every sign points that way, it marks a victory not just for Labour but for the whole progressive, social democratic cause.
fields.body:
The Guardian
Mr Brown refuse(d) the obvious trick - a penny cut in income tax - in favour of a mix of tax breaks targeted at the poorest and around £2bn extra for public spending. In other words he has chosen to stake Labour's electoral hopes on the belief that when voters face a choice between £8bn worth of Tory tax cuts and Labour's promise of investment in the schools and hospitals, they will go for the latter. If that is right, and every sign points that way, it marks a victory not just for Labour but for the whole progressive, social democratic cause.

Daily Mail
Once again, this is a redistributive budget. Once again, there is little in it for the middle classes. And once again, it reveals this Calvinist chancellor's almost touching faith in social engineering But there is another side to the roseate picture painted yesterday. If the public finances are in robust good health, it is only because the chancellor stuck rigidly for two years to Tory spending plans, while imposing swingeing stealth taxes.

The Sun
Gordon Brown is not New Labour. He is a socialist chancellor who is convinced he knows how to spend our money better than we do. He is taking money from the better off and funnelling it out to poor families on the assumption that they deserve it. Gordon had better make sure over the next three years that the public services are demonstrably improving. The NHS is chaotic - and unhealthy. The same applies to other public services, including transport. Unless taxpayers who have forked out large chunks of their own money see some serious improvements in the next few years they will want to know why.

The Independent
With increases in child benefit, the child tax credit and the working families tax credit, even the most cynical observer might begin to be convinced that the pledge to eliminate child poverty does amount to more than the usual windy New Labour rhetoric Less convincing were the naked bits of electioneering. For such a prudent man, Mr Brown wasted money fighting "the war against drugs": gesture politics designed to placate the more reactionary elements of the media. The money would have been better spent on rehabilitation.

The Times
The additional spending directed to the NHS and schools has only increased Labour's political gamble that a significant boost in state expenditure over the next three years will yield similarly big dividends. The track record of Whitehall in this field does not inspire confidence, even inside the Treasury. This may explain why Mr Brown is beginning to hedge his bets and prepare to adjust official strategy. The most notable aspect of the new money for health, education and "the war on drugs" is that it will be sent directly to institutional managers, bypassing the departments and local authorities.

Financial Times
Mr Brown is certainly entitled to choose these spending priorities (health and education) and he has astutely wrong-footed the Conservatives by allocating an extra £2bn over three years to these popular causes. It reinforces the question to the opposition as to whether it would make cuts in these programmes to finance tax reductions. But Mr Brown ducks the question of whether such a rate of expansion is sustainable, even assuming steady economic growth. Of course it cannot be over the long term, unless taxes are to be raised.

The Mirror
In his early years as chancellor, Gordon Brown's motto was prudence with a purpose. Now we can see what he meant. It was tough for the nation because, after all those years of Tory cuts, money was desperately needed to improve services. Thanks to massive repayments of debt and huge cuts in unemployment, 80% of government spending can now go where people want it to.

The Daily Telegraph
What is on offer this year apparently is a new approach to tax and benefits for which the slogan might be "women and children first", if that phrase were not associated with shipwrecksLike most of Mr Brown's other schemes however, potential beneficiaries will have to do everything Gordon's way. The new children's tax credit, like the working families' tax credit before it, has already thrown up a thicket of bureaucracy.

Daily Express
There were enough substantial public spending and benefit improvements to show that Labour has not lost its social conscience...The extra cash promised for children in low-income families, up to £51 a week for each child, is a creditable step towards eradicating the shameful statistic of one third of Britain's children living in poverty.

fields.headline: Campaign
fields.standfirst: Publication date: March 9
fields.trailText: March 9: The Food Standards Agency is planning a campaign to explain its work to the public.
fields.body:
The Food Standards Agency is planning a major advertising campaign to explain its work to the public.

Former MindShare chief executive Mandy Pooler is to be given a new role overseeing WPP's media operations.

US telecoms giant Sprint has hired Strawberry Frog to launch it in Europe.

Procter & Gamble has appointed Saatchi & Saatchi to carry out a marketing project called Golden Households.

Royal & SunAlliance has hired Chime Communications to rebrand its 12 property companies and estate agents.

Jason Coward has been made managing director of WCRS while his predecessor, Charles Vallance, has been given the role of executive strategy director.

Waitrose has postponed a TV campaign because of the outbreak of foot and mouth disease.

The Independent has shortlisted Claydon Heeley Jones Mason, Soul and Walsh Trott Chick Smith for its advertising account.

The Conservative party will next week step up its general election campaign with a £1m poster blitz urging voters not to give Tony Blair another four years in power.

Many of Britain's top agencies have failed to meet a professional standard set by the Institute of Practitioners in Advertising.

fields.headline: Houllier relies on forward threat
fields.trailText: Amid renewed doubts as to Liverpool's pedigree, Gérard Houllier will play an attacking game tonight and is likely to continue with his policy of playing two strikers.
fields.body:
Gérard Houllier will usher his Liverpool team back on to the European stage in Portugal this evening having again been reminded that, for all his best efforts this season, there are still questions to be answered, critics to be silenced.

On Saturday evening, only seven days after his players had returned the League Cup to Anfield, the malcontents were queuing up to have their say on radio phone-ins after Liverpool's defeat at Leicester. After all, 12 months ago Liverpool's astonishing loss of form cost them a Champions League place.

Having beaten - just - the Serie A leaders Roma in the previous round, Liverpool are fancied to reach the Uefa Cup semi-finals, although Houllier is taking nothing for granted.

"The Uefa Cup is a tournament awash with teams of very high quality," he said. "If the inference is that we will, in some way, find it easier against Porto, that is wrong because I think everyone appreciates how good they are."

However, on Sunday Porto were jeered by their own fans despite a 2-0 win over Farense which kept them in third place in the Portuguese league.

Houllier is likely to stick with his policy of playing two strikers. "I prefer to go for goals; it is how we have played in all our away legs in Europe."

He will be without the Finnish forward Jari Litmanen, who has not recovered from a calf muscle injury, but the goalkeeper Sander Westerveld and centre-back Stéphane Henchoz, who were injured at Leicester, should be fit.

Porto (probable, 4-5-1 ): Ovchinnikov; Nelson, Costa, Aloisio, Esquerdinha; Capucho, Paredes, Deco, Santos, Drulovic; Pena.

Liverpool (probable, 4-4-2): Westerveld; Babbel, Hyypia, Henchoz, Carragher; Barmby, Gerrard, Hamann, Smicer; Heskey, Owen.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Bringing up baby becomes easier
fields.trailText: There are to be large increases in maternity pay aimed at making it easier for new mothers to have a period at home after their child is born before they return to work.
fields.body:
There are to be large increases in maternity pay aimed at making it easier for new mothers to have a period at home after their child is born before they return to work.

Statutory maternity pay, or SMP, at present paid at a flat rate of £60.20 a week after the first six weeks, is to go up to £75 from next year and to £100 from April 2003.

Maternity allowance, paid to self-employed women and others not eligible for SMP, will go up by the same rate.

All women entitled to SMP or maternity allowance - approximately 360,000 a year - will get either the new flat rate or, as under present rules, 90% of their previous average earnings if that is lower.

From April 2003 the period of maternity pay at the enhanced rate will also increase from 18 to 26 weeks, giving mothers on SMP or maternity allowance entitlement to a further eight weeks of pay.

Working fathers will also for the first time be given the right to two weeks' paid paternity leave at the same £100 flat rate from April 2003.

Adoptive parents, who are entitled to only 13 weeks' unpaid leave, will be paid for adoption leave for the same period and at the same flat rate as SMP.

Adoptive parents will be able to choose which of them takes time off work and receives payment. From April 2002, the Sure Start maternity grant will go up from the £300 one-off payment to £500.

The grant is part of the government's programme aimed at promoting the wellbeing of children under four years old in Britain's most disadvantaged areas.

It is payable to all low income families provided they meet basic health check requirements for their child.

The increase will benefit some 215,000 families on income related benefits and tax credits every year.

Christine Gowdridge, the director of the Maternity Alliance, said: "The £40 increase in maternity pay over two years is very significant, especially for low incomes families - a real boost at a time when they need it most. "

John Edmonds, general secretary of the GMB public service workers' union, said: "Gordon Brown has thrown a lifeline to thousands of working mothers.

"Many working women are forced into a devil's choice between spending time with their child during the vital first months or leaving their child to earn income to support it through its early years.

"These measures will go a long way to freeing women from the maternity trap."

Kate Green, the director of the National Council for One Parent Families, said: "This is a tremendous step."
fields.bodyText: There are to be large increases in maternity pay aimed at making it easier for new mothers to have a period at home after their child is born before they return to work. Statutory maternity pay, or SMP, at present paid at a flat rate of £60.20 a week after the first six weeks, is to go up to £75 from next year and to £100 from April 2003. Maternity allowance, paid to self-employed women and others not eligible for SMP, will go up by the same rate. All women entitled to SMP or maternity allowance - approximately 360,000 a year - will get either the new flat rate or, as under present rules, 90% of their previous average earnings if that is lower. From April 2003 the period of maternity pay at the enhanced rate will also increase from 18 to 26 weeks, giving mothers on SMP or maternity allowance entitlement to a further eight weeks of pay. Working fathers will also for the first time be given the right to two weeks' paid paternity leave at the same £100 flat rate from April 2003. Adoptive parents, who are entitled to only 13 weeks' unpaid leave, will be paid for adoption leave for the same period and at the same flat rate as SMP. Adoptive parents will be able to choose which of them takes time off work and receives payment. From April 2002, the Sure Start maternity grant will go up from the £300 one-off payment to £500. The grant is part of the government's programme aimed at promoting the wellbeing of children under four years old in Britain's most disadvantaged areas. It is payable to all low income families provided they meet basic health check requirements for their child. The increase will benefit some 215,000 families on income related benefits and tax credits every year. Christine Gowdridge, the director of the Maternity Alliance, said: "The £40 increase in maternity pay over two years is very significant, especially for low incomes families - a real boost at a time when they need it most. " John Edmonds, general secretary of the GMB public service workers' union, said: "Gordon Brown has thrown a lifeline to thousands of working mothers. "Many working women are forced into a devil's choice between spending time with their child during the vital first months or leaving their child to earn income to support it through its early years. "These measures will go a long way to freeing women from the maternity trap." Kate Green, the director of the National Council for One Parent Families, said: "This is a tremendous step."

fields.headline: Food agency plans £10m advertising campaign
fields.trailText: 12pm: The government is planning a £10m advertising campaign to promote Britain's food industry. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The government is planning a multimillion pound advertising campaign to combat the disastrous image of Britain's food industry in the wake of the foot and mouth outbreak.

Government body COI Communications has been quietly approaching advertising agencies to put forward ideas on how the government's Food Standards Agency should position itself.

The FSA was launched in April last year to bring together all aspects of food safety under a single banner.

Public confidence in the food we eat is now at an all-time low.

A recent survey commissioned by the FSA showed that less than half the population is happy with the present food safety regime.

Concern was widespread about the way abattoirs and butchers handled raw chicken and beef, as well as hygiene in fast-food outlets, markets and supermarkets.

Related stories

Feb 26: Foot and mouth hits C4

fields.headline: Scholes to United's rescue
fields.standfirst:
Seitaridis 25 | Scholes 90
Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: Paul Scholes scored an injury-time equaliser to keep alive Manchester United's quarter-final hopes after Sir Alex Ferguson's men failed to convert earlier chances and were often outplayed.
fields.byline: David Lacey at the Spiros Louis stadium
fields.body:
Manchester United's capacity for brinkmanship seems limitless. A goal from Paul Scholes in stoppage-time redeemed a slipshod performance by Sir Alex Ferguson's team and denied Panathinaikos, who had nothing to lose, the victory their superior football had deserved.

The result means that Sturm Graz, having lost 5-0 to Valencia, need to win by more than two goals at Old Trafford on Tuesday to deny United a fifth successive place in the last eight. But if both Manchester United and Valencia win, the Spanish side will top the group, leaving the English champions to face the possibility of being paired with Real Madrid in the quarter-final.

In truth the prospect of another match with Real, who eliminated United in last season's quarter-final, was barely worth thinking about last night as the poor away form which in the first round had seen Ferguson's side beaten by PSV Eindhoven and Anderlecht caught up with them.

Before half-time United defended too deep and invited Giorgios Karagounis, Nikolaos Liberopoulos and Derek Boateng to infiltrate space behind Roy Keane and Scholes with shrewd passing and movement. In the second half United tightened up and acquired a better shape, but they were caught on the break several times before Scholes scored. With better finishing Panathinaikos would surely have put the contest beyond reach.

For a team supposedly in a state of flux and still recovering from a change of coach, Panathinaikos achieved a remarkably composed performance.

United never really got to grips with their opponents' accuracy and imagination, seldom tracked down Boateng and struggled to check the influence of Goran Vlaovic.

The speed and penetration of Ryan Giggs was badly missed on the left and on the other flank David Beckham was yet again a peripheral presence, achieving few crosses of quality and doing equally little when he drifted into the middle.

As a result Andy Cole and Dwight Yorke had to hunt for the ball and were usually crowded out near goal. For the last quarter-hour Ferguson brought on Ole Gunnar Solskjaer and Teddy Sheringham, who missed a sitter of a header in the 87th minute, leaving Scholes to become the man to save the night.

United were given a warning in the 14th minute when for once Fabien Barthez's habit of racing out to meet a through-pass and demonstrate his ball skills let him down. For an instant it looked as if Liberopoulos had been granted a shot at an empty net but the striker failed to get the ball under control.

The next chance, however, was accepted with alacrity. After 25 minutes a free-kick from Vlaovic on the right was cleared low by Yorke to Giorgios Seitaridis, who met it on the half-volley and, with Barthez unsighted, drove the ball into the left-hand corner of the net from 25 yards.

Gary Neville briefly revived United's spirits eight minutes before half-time when he exchanged passes with Yorke before cutting in from the right to draw a sharp, feet-first save from Antonis Nikopolidis. By then, however, Panathinaikos were dominating and should have been further ahead.

In the 43rd minute a through-pass from Boateng sent Liberopoulos clear of a square defence. As Barthez advanced, the striker could have slipped the ball past him but instead chose to pass to Vlaovic, on his right, and the Croatian was flagged offside. To cap it all the replay showed Vlaovic to be level when the pass was made.

More chances were missed in the second half and Panathi naikos were to pay for their profligacy. With stoppage-time running out, Luke Chadwick, on for Mikael Silvestre, met a half-clearance from Beckham's corner with a vague prod forward which Scholes, pivoting as he met the ball, drove into the net.

Now United need only avoid another evening of pratfalls on Tuesday. But to make a serious impact later in the competition they will have to play much better than this.

 A second-half hat-trick from Walter Pandiani helped Deportivo La Coruna to overturn a three-goal deficit and win 4-3 against Paris St-Germain in Group B. It set up next Tuesday's decider with Milan, who lost 2-0 at Galatasaray. Deportivo now need only to draw at the San Siro to qualify.

Panathinaikos : Nikopolidis; Seitaridis, Goumas, Henriksen, Fyssas; Basinas (Pflipsen, 85min), Boateng, Karagounis, Percy Olivares,Vlaovic; Liberopoulos (Warzycha, 66).

Manchester United : Barthez; G Neville, Stam, Brown, Silvestre (Chadwick, 64); Beckham, Keane, Scholes, P Neville (Sheringham,79); Yorke, Cole (Solskjaer, 79).

Referee : KE Nilsson (Swe).

webTitle: In brief: Soderbergh KO's Tyson from Ocean's Eleven

fields.headline: Soderbergh KO's Tyson from Ocean's Eleven
fields.standfirst: Plus: Schwarzenegger cagey about political future; Amish basketball team triumph perfect for Hollywood; Attenborough luvvies up to Gordon Brown
fields.trailText: Plus: Schwarzenegger cagey about political future; Amish basketball team triumph perfect for Hollywood; Attenborough luvvies up to Gordon Brown
fields.body:
 Oscar-nominated Steven Soderbergh has decided against casting renegade boxer Mike Tyson in his new film Ocean's Eleven. According to the New York Daily News, the director of Traffic and Erin Brockovich had initially considered including a staged Las Vegas boxing scene between Tyson and British heavyweight champion Lennox Lewis. Now he has decided to pair Lewis with the lesser known Vladimir Klitschko instead. Explaining his decision, Soderbergh implied that he might have found Tyson a tough actor to control. "My sense was that it would not be a tension-free set," he told the Daily News. "And I believe in a tension-free set."

 Arnold Schwarzenegger appears to be prevaricating over whether to run for state governor of California in the mid-term elections of 2002 (see earlier story). Just hours after the actor appeared to hint that he was too busy making movies, his spokeswoman ignited further speculation with a more flexible statement. "He's not obviously made up his mind yet," said Jill Eisenstadt. "He said he would be sorting things out over the course of the next several months and will come to a conclusion then about whether he will run or not As far as he's concerned the door is not closed." Assuming he decides to run, Arnie would be seeking to unseat Democratic incumbent Gray Davis, whose staff have already been faxing copies of the recent, extremely negative Premiere article on Schwarzenegger to national newspapers (see earlier story). In the meantime, some of Arnie's former co-stars have stood up to condemn the magazine's allegations. Linda Hamilton labelled it "a fantasy", while Jamie Lee Curtis dismissed the piece as "a politically motivated hack job."

 Bruckheimer Films has paid a six-figure sum to secure the film rights to an article entitled Higher Education published in the March 5 issue of Sports Illustrated. Written by journalist Gary Smith, Higher Education recounts the tale of the late Perry Reese, a black basketball coach who guided an all-white Amish high-school through a championship season. Gregory Allen Howard (creator of the similarly-themed Remember the Titans) will write the screenplay.

 Gordon Brown's budget found one big (and very vocal) supporter in veteran film-maker Richard Attenborough. Attending the Bradford Film Festival last night, Lord Attenborough praised the chancellor's decision to extend tax relief for UK film production through to April 2005 (see other story). "No government has given the support to the British film industry that Gordon Brown and this government has," Attenborough told reporters, before adding his final ringing endorsement: "I love Gordon Brown."

fields.headline: Jobs go as Musicunsigned closes site
fields.trailText:
11.30am: The online talent scout Musicunsigned.com has closed its website to conserve cash, reports Amy Vickers.
8.30am: Web whizz plans legal version of Napster
Mar 7: Napster fails to satisfy court
fields.body:
Another internet company has been forced to close despite having more than £1.5m left in the bank.

Online music talent scout Musicunsigned.com, which raised £3m when it floated on the AIM stock market in October, said it had decided to close its website to conserve remaining cash.

"The board of Musicunsigned has taken this decision to protect the company's remaining funds and seek a suitable business to acquire," said non-executive chairman Chris Roberts in a statement.

He added that the board was talking to suitable "cash generative businesses" but refused to name them.

Music website dotmusic could be a likely target, as could music3w.com, which recently got into difficulties.

Sceptics cast doubt over whether Musicunsigned would actually go ahead with an acquisition, saying this was a diversionary tactic to deter asset strippers.

Eleven employees at Musicunsigned, the ambitious website set up to promote new bands to the music industry, are being made redundant.

It became clear Musicunsigned had difficult times ahead when it laid off staff in January.

The company had also established its own record company, MU Recordings, to release unsigned material.

It was also in planning to launch an online radio station.

Related stories
Mar 8: Web whizz plans legal version of Napster
Mar 7: Napster fails to satisfy court

fields.headline: With a sense of pride
fields.standfirst: Jules Hornbrook, editor of Crewe fanzine Super Dario Land and Crewe From The Terrace (www.fromtheterrace.co.uk), wants you to take someone along to Gresty Road
fields.trailText: Jules Hornbrook, editor of Crewe fanzine Super Dario Land and Crewe From The Terrace (www.fromtheterrace.co.uk), wants you to take someone along to Gresty Road.
fields.body:
Just because you edit a fanzine or update an unofficial website, most people assume you'll have a wholly negative attitude towards the club. Not so, and increasingly I have found myself speaking nothing but good about the Alex. Possibly something I've eaten!

Still, I took an old college friend along to the last Alex home game. A true Geordie, he'd been to Crewe games before, during the early 90s. He even came to Wembley back in 1993, such was my enthusiasm to spread the word according to Dario Gradi as we started our ascent up the leagues. It ended in tears eight years ago, but my black-and-white buddy was hooked.

It never ceases to amaze me how your enthusiasm for a footy team can rub off onto people. And it's often ordinary people, men and women who are not infected by the football bug. They are rational types, fully capable of doing something different on a Saturday afternoon. Mad fools! But after an afternoon with them, I've managed to convince friends that checking the Saturday results (well, the Crewe result at least) is an essential part of any weekend.

And they do, and when a casual phone call takes place on a Monday morning, often months since previous contact, they can tell you all about the latest Alex game and, most impressively, where we are in the table. If only I could bottle it and turn it into ticket sales!

But I digress, so back to the man from the Toon army. He didn't need much converting all those years ago, as his Newcastle upbringing had already instilled all the necessary football ingredients. He gladly came along to Alex games home and away. And way back before the Newcastle renaissance - let's be honest, when they were crap pre-Keegan - even the Gresty Road of old didn't look too bad. But following the transformation of St James' Park, I was a tad wary that he might find even the new-look Alexandra Stadium a little humble.

I needn't have worried. Any true supporter can appreciate progress - whatever the level, whatever the location. As we walked along Nantwich Road before the game, he even likened our ground to that of his beloved Newcastle. Like the monster that dominates the Newcastle skyline, so too does the main stand of Gresty Road. He was impressed. And as we walked out from the concourse and up the steep steps of the main stand it was obvious that he was enjoying the occasion. More than anything, it gave me a huge sense of pride, that someone else could come along and see what's been achieved at Crewe.

It's ridiculous when you think about it. It's only a building, a pile of bricks that houses a bunch of screaming maniacs once a fortnight. But we know otherwise. It's our temple, and we're immensely proud of it. I still can't understand my need to bring others (non-Crewe fans) along. But I do. I want them to become hooked. I want them to talk of Crewe Alexandra, see the eyebrows raised on non-believers' faces, and then convince them that we are no longer a music-hall joke.

Perhaps it's the ongoing struggle to survive in First Division? Battling against the odds, holding our heads up high despite the increasingly tough conditions. Maybe that's why I want to trumpet our success to everyone and anyone prepared to listen!

This is all leading up to something. I think we've all got an important part to play in promoting the Alex. Crowds may be up in recent seasons, but wouldn't it be excellent to see a full Gresty Road every week? If you haven't bent someone's ear already, why not try bringing a friend, member of the family or even someone from work to one of the forthcoming home games? I've always loved introducing people to the Alex, and seeing their reaction when they realise that it's not a bad experience. They might not have become season-ticket holders, but they still come along to games every now and then.

Most importantly, they always speak about the Alex with a smile on their faces. As I've said already, it gives me an immense sense of pride

fields.headline: 8. Crewe Alexandra
fields.standfirst: Jules Hornbrook, editor of Crewe Alexandra fanzine Super Dario Land, gives us the lowdown on Gradi's club
fields.trailText: What makes us different
fields.body:
What makes us different

The Alex are all about youth development and extending a friendly face deep into the community. It must get boring to neutrals at times, but Dario Gradi really has installed a conveyor belt that keeps turning out talented young players. Eleven of this season's U17 squad have just been given three-year professional contracts!

The high points

Beating Brentford at Wembley in May 1997 to lift us to the First Division was pretty special, but the play-off semi-final a few weeks earlier against Luton has a permanent place in my heart. A passionate encounter, 2-0 down and we came back to win overall, but the Luton fans flooded onto the pitch and applauded us. No trouble, just mutual respect Add to that, we'd lost 6-0 at Kenilworth Road earlier in the season!

The low points

Thinking that Crewe Alexandra (as we then knew it) was about to come to an end. They announced an alliance with Liverpool in early 1997 and everyone suspected that we'd become a nursery club. And just imagine all those scallies asking to mind yer car for a fiver! But it's not happened, and we have prospered.

What's going on at the moment?

We have just announced (March 2001) a £450,000 loss for the last financial year. Small potatoes, especially as we've hardly sold anyone for ages. In fact, that's our strength, slowly building a strong squad without being plunged into debt. We will never buy to survive, and the fans love the fact that Dario Gradi will continue to throw youngsters into the first team. Dean Ashton, just turned 17, has recently played five games and scored three! The future is getting brighter

Last match

We have just thrashed Tranmere 3-1 at Gresty Road. They might be able to beat Premier League opposition in the cup, but when it comes to the bread and butter of league action they can only afford margarine. They're going down with QPR and Sheffield Wednesday.

Next match

Birmingham (away) this coming Saturday will be very tough. I doubt they batter us, but we will do well to take a 1-1 draw. I never rule out a late, cheeky goal for the Alex however!

Sore point

We've run out of moans! The Alex have been slow to react to many things across the years, but most of it has boiled down to prudent housekeeping. We asked for a better club shop - it arrived, eventually, and is slowly getting better. We still don't sell ourselves enough, considering our many good points. Again, there have been recent ticket initiatives and there seems to be a genuine desire to listen to the fans. Wow - can this really be true?

The chairman

This is starting to get boring. He's a decent bloke. He doesn't poke his nose into Gradi's affairs, and doesn't alienate the fans with ludicrous ideas and suggestions. And no, he doesn't run onto the pitch trying to juggle footballs, despite being a promising footballer in his younger days. Low profile, but effective. Doesn't take a salary!

Rivals

Unlike Millwall, nobody dislikes us - and we Do care! We enjoy hating the Clayheads (Port Vale and Stoke) but neither can survive in the First Division and now ply their tacky trades in Division Two. Same for Wrexham, Chester and Shrewsbury - all lower division fodder we left behind several years ago. Stockport consider themselves Mancs, so only Nantwich Town can save the local derby - when they rise up from the North West Counties leagues in about 40 years' time!

Kit

I'd love to see a simple, plain red home shirt. But they continue to tinker, adding bits of white and blue as they (and the manufacturers) see fit. They've also removed the railway wheel from the club bade design (and I don't have to tell you how much that angered the people of a railway town).

Merchandise

They're not quite innovative enough to have vast arrays of merchandise, so the bulk of it is your standard mugs, scarves and diaries. They was a tacky bed spread at Christmas, but better the local kids falling asleep beneath Alex tat than more expensive Man Utd rubbish!

Mascot

Grrrrresty the lion, but more like a pussycat. I love violent mascots like Wolfie and Cyril the Swan. Gresty throws sweets to kids at half time (and I never get any) and doesn't fight. The funniest thing I saw was Wolfie tripping Gresty and trying to start a scrap. Gresty didn't want to know, and merely adjusted his ill-fitting head and sloped off with his tail between his legs. We can't be feeding him enough meat.

Heroes

Dean Ashton (just 17) is already a hero. Local (ish) lad, big, strong and already scores goals. He will play for England and net us several million within two years.

As for all-time, I can only talk about player from my era (last 25 years of watching), so Craig Hignett at his best would be hard to beat.

Few players from other clubs earn respect, but on the few occasions Niall Quinn played against Crewe he was a quality player. He even chatted to Alex fans in the bar afterwards, and one of my mates' dads (80 years old) threatened to punch him!

Villians

Colin Cramb (stroppy Jock) came, played, caused bother, saved us, fell out with everyone, promised to be good, and then went to Bury on loan. I thought being sent to Coventry was bad enough! Love him, hate him, wanted him to succeed - he'll never play for Crewe again. Then again

The ground

Gresty Road: respectable, modest, home.

The crowd

It's really hotting up at the moment, and soon it should sound like a rowdy library! Yes we're struggling to make some serious noise, but it is improving. We've got a decent drummer, and we used to have a trumpet. Trouble is, the new stand and this all-seater lark split many of the singers up.

Local knowledge

There's some decent boozers in Crewe, and most see away fans mingling with the Alex fans. The Brunswick, Barrel and Pig (British Lion) are all within staggering distance of the ground. No hotdog stands (apart from when Birmingham bring their own - seriously), but we have got the Chippy of the Year in Crewe town centre. Wow! You must visit the 16-year-old programme sellers (well, probably 15 but I didn't know officer). A posse of five lovelies congregates near the away end entrance. It's worth your admission money alone.

Links

'We Are Crewe' is the other zine, and works closely with SDL. Both monthly, and both a good read at one pound. As for web sites, Crewe FTT (www.fromtheterrace.co.uk) has the quality writing and is updated most days with new articles and decent opinion from the fans.

fields.headline: Vodafone plans summer start for GPRS
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Vodafone will begin a full commercial service in the summer using GPRS technology, writes David Teather.
fields.body:
Vodafone yesterday said it would begin a full commercial service in the summer using GPRS, the technology expected to be the catalyst for a step change in the use of wireless internet.

The technology is expected to make wireless internet far more user friendly than existing services. GPRS - or general packet radio service - will bring data speeds equivalent to desktop computers and an "always on" internet connection. It has been dubbed generation 2.5, ahead of the introduction of UMTS, the third generation of mobile technology, in 2003.

Vodafone chief executive Chris Gent, above, also disclosed that Vizzavi, its internet portal venture with Vivendi Universal, is recording 4,000 registrations per day and daily page views on mobiles of up to 200,000 in Britain. It aims to to have 2m registered users in Europe by the end of the second quar ter. Investment in Vizzavi will reach euro 1.6bn (£1bn) by the end of 2002, the company said, with break-even forecast at earnings before interest, depreciation and amortisation level by the end of 2003.

Revenues from data are being driven by short messaging services. In a presentation to investors, Vodafone said 47% of its customers in Europe were active SMS users. The service is just being introduced in the US.

webTitle: The footy comedy quiz show is dead

fields.headline: The footy comedy quiz show is dead
fields.standfirst: Jules Hornbrook, editor of Crewe Alexandra fanzine Super Dario Land, on the latest Sky One lack-of-success story
fields.trailText: I never thought I'd discuss TV shows on a football website, but the great game needs protecting from some of the comedians who seriously believe that humour can be lifted from the terraces and plonked on a sterile set without losing its bite. Super Dario Land happily offers praise where praise is due, but we're more than happy to brandish the sword when called upon.
fields.body:
I never thought I'd discuss TV shows on a football website, but the great game needs protecting from some of the comedians who seriously believe that humour can be lifted from the terraces and plonked on a sterile set without losing its bite. Super Dario Land happily offers praise where praise is due, but we're more than happy to brandish the sword when called upon.

Jumpers For Goalposts kicked off on Monday night with all the razzmatazz and flashing lights of an Old Firm match, but delivered entertainment on a par with a rainy Tuesday night's Halifax v Torquay spectacular. Absolute crap, with apologies to the Third Division strugglers who, unlike Sky One's latest offering, will probably survive another season!

We've been fed a heady diet of Question of Sport and They Think It's All Over for several years now, and Sky are obviously desperate to leap aboard the bandwagon. But while Nick Hancock is actually funny, and Sue Barker appealing (sexy even, in an eighties tennis kind of way), Simon Day comes over like the dreary music hall compere he is destined to always be.

The BBC has genuine sports stars blending well with the proven talent of Ally McCoist, John Parrot, David Gower and even Gary Lineker. Sky's best shot was Noel Gallagher who may be able to write songs but has none of his arrogant brother's stage presence or gritty swagger.

There was a feeble attempt to mimic or adapt other shows' ideas and themes, supposedly putting an additional humorous slant on already proven features. It was like Kingstonian trying to play a passing game, only briefly managing to look like a league team. Jumpers For Goalposts is definitely Conference standard!

The only highlight was the ever-brilliant Ron Manager, aka Paul Whitehouse. The only man capable of an adlib, he carried the rest like a true pro. But for all his wonderful mannerisms and perfect delivery, we were subjected to every football cliché under the sun. The scriptwriters (yes, I assume there are guilty men on the touchline somewhere) must be sweating ahead of next week's show wondering what material they can use. They've exhausted it all while still managing to remain unfunny.

There was a brief rally towards the end as Gallagher and Les Ferdinand managed to be themselves for a bit. But Paul Daniels (really) and some posh bird from one of those house makeover shows contributed nowt. If there had been extra time I would have been forced to switch off.

As I channel hopped after the fat lady brought JFG to an end (if the last letter of that unfortunate acronym had been a 'K' we might hope to see the show shot in the not too distant future), I caught the quality of John Inverdale's Onside. A serious sports show, an intelligent host, and often rather heavy-going subject matter, this was still funnier by far.

In fact, Jumpers For Goalposts would have been caught off-side long before the end, and really the referee should have sent the buggers off to save us any further pain...

fields.headline: Boycott plans new London paper
fields.trailText: 11.30am: Rosie Boycott, ex-editor of the Daily Express, is considering a sensational comeback with a brand new London daily.
fields.body:
Rosie Boycott, ex-editor of the Daily Express, is considering a sensational comeback with a brand new London daily.

The plan is at an early stage, but Ms Boycott is understood to have discussed the idea with City financiers, according to the Financial Times.

Ms Boycott wants to set up a features-based weekday newspaper that will rely heavily on classified advertising and will require only one edition a day.

It is not expected to compete with the Evening Standard, which is owned by Associated Newspapers and has a stranglehold on the distribution market.

However, Ms Boycott is certain there is room for another daily publication in a market of 9m people which is served by just one newspaper.

Ms Boycott is understood to have been inspired by New York's Village Voice, which has a more artistic slant than the average evening newspaper.

The former editor of the Independent and Independent on Sunday will be keen to take charge of a publication without a big-name proprietor, following her strained relationships with Lord Hollick and Richard Desmond at the Express.

fields.headline: Rangers sign £1m Gayle
fields.trailText: Wimbledon striker Marcus Gayle has completed a shock £1m move to Rangers.
fields.body:
Wimbledon striker Marcus Gayle has completed a shock £1m move to Rangers.

The 30-year-old has completed his medical after flying in from London late last night and will be unveiled at a press conference today.

Gayle will not be eligible to play against Dundee United in Sunday's Scottish Cup quarter-final. However, he is expected to make his Rangers debut against Dundee next Wednesday.

A delighted Gayle, who has seen his salary treble to £15,000-a-week, told Rangers' official website: "To be honest, I'm still in shock but I'm absolutely delighted to get the chance to represent such a great club.

"John [Hartson] has told me what a wonderful club this is," he added. "He just could not stop talking about how brilliant the whole set-up was. He was a very sad that it didn't work out for him in Glasgow.

"This is such a massive club to come to and I realise that it's going to be a major change to be playing in front of 50,000 in every home game."

"However, I have coped with playing in the Premiership and scored goals there. I have watched Rangers on TV and I've seen that Tore Andre [Flo] has done well.

Gayle was at Wimbledon for eight years, making 445 appearances and scoring 73 goals. However this season he has looked out of touch, scoring just once in 19 appearances.

Ironically, Gayle's old Wimbledon strike partner John Hartson almost became a Rangers player in September in a £6m transfer but failed a medical.

fields.headline: C4 airs favourite TV music moments
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Channel 4 viewers can vote for whether Iggy Pop simulating sex with a furry animal is their favourite TV music moment, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Channel 4 viewers will get the chance to vote for whether Iggy Pop simulating sex with a small furry animal is their favourite TV music moment.

The viewers poll will decide which TV music footage comes out top in The Greatest TV Music Moments.

The two-hour show has been commissioned by Channel 4 from Initial, a subsidiary of Big Brother producer Endemol UK, for a Saturday night slot in the autumn.

Other landmark events in televised music coverage featuring in the show will include:

 How many times Shaun Ryder said "fuck" in one year on network TV  The Beatles' global broadcast of All You Need Is Love  What the chambermaid found in John and Yoko's bed after their week-long bed-in for peace  Exclusive footage of legendary bands including the Clash playing live  The truth behind the KLF and their million-pound bonfire

"We've got debut performances, horror stories, bust-ups, landmark moments and unfeasible haircuts," said Initial managing director Tim Hincks.

"The 40 Greatest TV Music Moments will be both culturally relevant and comically irreverent - the story of popular music as told by television."

Initial has also signed up celebrities including racing tipster John McCririck and former boxer Chris Eubank to shoot webcam rants for Channel 4's night time schedule 4Later.

The 30-second clips, which are branded The Collective, will also feature DJs Roger Sanchez and Brandon Block and go out in between 4Later shows at the end of March.

Contributors to The Collective use a PC and webcam to send Channel 4 clips of themselves ranting about topical issues, telling jokes and doing impressions.

Initial is also talking to other celebrities about taking part in the experimental venture, which is also being developed as a 30-minute show.

The Collective has been running on 4Later since September, featuring contributions from ordinary people.

fields.headline: Front Row TV hires PagetBaker PR
fields.trailText: 10.30am: PagetBaker Associates is to handle PR for UK pay-per-view movie channel Front Row, writes Julia Day
fields.body:
PagetBaker Associates has been appointed to handle PR for UK pay-per-view movie channel Front Row Television.

The win comes after PagetBaker worked on the December relaunch of the NTL and Telewest-owned cable channel. No pitch was held for the business.

The PR agency, formed in May 2000 by Will Paget and Lisa Baker, will be responsible for all consumer and trade PR activity for Front Row.

"This is an exciting time for the development of the Front Row channel and as such we felt it important to appoint an agency that showed an instinctive understanding of the brand, its messages and the sector in which we operate," said Front Row marketing communications manager Gaby Flannery

PagetBaker's clients include production company Double Negative, TV consultancy The ON Demand Group and online swapping facility www.swaphut.com and the Guardian Edinburgh International Television Festival.

Related story
Dec 6: Front Row relaunches with TV ad blitz

webTitle: Fox pays out $19m in plagiarism suit

fields.headline: Fox pays out $19m in plagiarism suit
fields.trailText: A jury has found in favour of a Detroit teacher who claims that he is the real author of the Arnold Schwarzenegger film, Jingle All the Way
fields.body:
A jury in Ann Arbor, Michigan, yesterday resolved a long-running plagiarism suit by naming Detroit teacher Brian Webster as the bona-fide author of the 1996 Arnold Schwarzenegger film Jingle All the Way. The film's backers, Fox, were ordered to pay out a whopping $15m (£10.26m) in compensation, plus $4m (£2.73m) legal costs.

One would have imagined that few people would want to claim credit for Jingle All the Way, a duff Yuletide tale in which Arnie pants and wheezes his way through town in search of a Christmas gift for his son. But biology teacher Webster claims that Fox stole his idea for the film after reading the script he sent in. His lawsuit contended that the film's credited screenwriter, "Ed McQueen", was actually a pseudonym for Fox script reader Randy Kornfield.

After weighing up the evidence, the jury agreed with him and ruled for the little David instead of the multinational Goliath. Fox must now pay $15m (£10.26m) to Murray Hill Productions, the small independent company which bought the film's rights from Webster. It is thought that Webster will walk away with a sizeable portion of that sum.

"I'm delighted for Brian Webster, who is the rightful creator of this project," Murray Hill president Robert Laurel said yesterday. "Hopefully it will send a message that you can't take the little guy's work and pass it off as your own." Fox said that it will appeal against the ruling. In the meantime, Webster is jingling all the way to the bank.

But biology teacher Webster claims that Fox stole his idea for the film after reading the script he sent in. His lawsuit contended that the film's credited screenwriter, "Ed McQueen", was actually a pseudonym for Fox script reader Randy Kornfield. After weighing up the evidence, the jury agreed with him and ruled for the little David instead of the multinational Goliath. Fox must now pay $15m (£10.26m) to Murray Hill Productions, the small independent company which bought the film's rights from Webster. It is thought that Webster will walk away with a sizeable portion of that sum. "I'm delighted for Brian Webster, who is the rightful creator of this project," Murray Hill president Robert Laurel said yesterday. "Hopefully it will send a message that you can't take the little guy's work and pass it off as your own." Fox said that it will appeal against the ruling. In the meantime, Webster is jingling all the way to the bank.

fields.headline: Dow Jones posts profit warning
fields.trailText: 11.15am: Advertising revenues at the Wall Street Journal plummeted by a staggering 42% last month, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Financial Times owner Pearson is looking over its shoulder nervously after US rival Dow Jones posted a drastic profit warning.

Dow Jones said advertising revenues at its flagship title the Wall Street Journal fell by a staggering 42% last month.

They could fall by the same margin in March.

Analysts at SG Securities today downgraded Pearson's shares from "hold" to "underperform" amid fears the weakening advertising climate in the US will quickly move across the Atlantic.

"Despite advertising providing only 10% of revenue, we remain cautious over a potentially sharper lagged slowdown in global financial advertising stemming from the US," said an SG spokesman.

Dow Jones is reeling from a softening in the US economy.

Fewer flotations mean there are fewer advertisements from banks announcing their participation in the share offerings.

The effect of this has been compounded by the financial woes of technology firms - which have reduced their advertising budgets after their clients cut back on IT spending - and the collapse of big-spending dot.com start-ups

Dow Jones is cutting jobs and costs to offset the fall in revenues but it admitted forecasting its prospects for the rest of the year would be very difficult.

However, a Pearson spokesman brushed off analysts' concerns, saying the Financial Times was less exposed to the US market and does not rely as heavily on dot.com advertising.

"Advertising revenues were up 34% last year - and rose 8% in the first two months of this year - so the picture is different for us," he said.

But the Dow Jones announcement has underlined analysts' concerns about the health of the whole European advertising market, which relies heavily on contributions from US companies.

"US companies control 60% of global advertising spend and, if the US economy is hit by recession, they will pull back from European markets," said Neil Carter, media analyst at ABN Amro.

Mr Carter added a hoped-for recovery in the advertising market in the second half of this year is also in doubt.

"Maybe we are at the bottom of the curve but right now there is a significant risk the second-half recovery will not materialise," he said.

Attention will now turn to Lord Hollick's United Business Media.

The publisher makes more than 80% of its profits from the US market.

fields.headline: China plans rapid water diversion
fields.trailText: China will speed up a "mega-project" to divert billions of cubic metres of water from the Yangtze to the Yellow River, despite serious concern about the environmental consequences, officials said in Beijing yesterday.
fields.body:
China will speed up a "mega-project" to divert billions of cubic metres of water from the Yangtze to the Yellow River, despite serious concern about the environmental consequences, officials said in Beijing yesterday.

One of the three routes through which the water is to be diverted requires the evacuation of 220,000 people, while the water on a second route will be badly polluted, the officials admitted. But they insisted that the "complexities" of the project could be handled and that no time should be wasted.

"It is a strategic project to optimise water resources, designed to direct surplus water to the north," said Chen Bangzhu, head of a committee discussing the project at this week's meeting of the national people's congress - China's annual parliament.

Since central China has more water than it needs, it is thought that diverting some will alleviate the rapidly worsening shortages in the north.

Water shortage is a particularly sensitive issue in Beijing, where the water table is falling rapidly while demand grows as living standard improve. An increasing number of sandstorms sweeping into the capital from Mongolia is a vivid and constant reminder of how large areas to the north have been reduced to desert.

Environmentalists have warned that large-scale tampering with water systems may have untold adverse effects, and that much more effort should be made to save water first.

A study of Chinese water policy by an Australian scholar, Gavan McCormack, warns that "the ecological implications ... are completely unforeseeable".

The project, written into the new five-year plan, will be "as huge as the Three Gorges Dam project", one committee member said.

It will cost at least £11.6bn over the next 10 to 15 years.

Its "central route" will carry water from the Danjiangkou reservoir north along a 780-mile channel. Raising the level of the reservoir and building the channel will force the "relocation" of 220,000 people.

"The relocation issue is always difficult, because it involves a huge population, large areas and some political sensitivity," Tan Qinglian, a former minister of construction, said yesterday.

The "eastern route" will siphon water from the lower reaches of the Yangtze, starting at Yangzhou, in Jiangsu province, and following the northern route of the old imperial Grand Canal.

The main line of this route will be about 720 miles long.

Yuan Guolin, a committee member, said the problem with this route was unsatisfactory water quality. Intensive efforts to deal with the pollution would be needed.

The project has been given added impetus by the prime minister, Zhu Rongji, who instructed officials in October to work for an "early start". With such a high-level sponsor, doubts about the wisdom of the project are less likely to get a hearing.

Mr Zhu told the people's congress on Monday that a lack of water resources was a "serious limitation" on development, and said that the plan should be speeded up.

The government originally intended to choose only one of the three possible routes, but it now seems determined to pursue them all. The eventual target is to transport as much as 48bn cubic metres of water north each year. Work on the central and eastern routes could begin in the next year.

A third "western route" presents daunting engineering problems and will take longer to get under way. It is designed to divert water from the upper reaches of the Yangtze and its tributaries to the Yellow River.

webTitle: VAT change ends entry charge era

fields.headline: VAT change ends entry charge era
fields.trailText: Free entry to Britain's national museums and art galleries came a step closer yesterday after the chancellor announced changes in VAT.
fields.body:
Free entry to Britain's national museums and art galleries came a step closer yesterday after the chancellor announced changes in VAT.

Until now any museum scrapping charges lost its business status and was not allowed to reclaim the VAT it paid on items it purchased.

Yesterday's move rectifies this and fulfils the government's long-standing pledge to provide free access to museums and galleries.

It was welcomed by campaigners, who said the old system had cost the institutions millions of pounds. The government will consult museums and galleries on the details of the scheme, which will be introduced by September.

The V&A in London, where visitor numbers halved after charges were introduced, immediately responded with a promise to reintroduce free admission "as soon as possible".

The announcement ended a bitterly fought campaign. Culture secretary Chris Smith lobbied for the change, and the concession was anticipated in last year's Budget. There was deep disappointment when it failed to materialise.

"This is an outright victory, it is fantastic news," said David Barrie, director of the Art Fund, the independent charity which has led the campaign. "I believe it will lead to a major extension of free admission. It is nice, for once, to be able to congratulate the government wholeheartedly on something really well done."

Sir Nicholas Serota, the director of the Tate, and Neil MacGregor, director of the National Gallery, praised the commitment of the culture secretary. "Chris Smith has been an ardent and consistent advocate of the principle of free admission to the national collections. The benefits of his policy are vividly demonstrated by the huge number of visitors to Tate Modern," Sir Nicholas said.

The initiative means the end of the much criticised compromise, Quids In, which would have given grants to museums to help cut their entry charges to £1. It was supposed to start next autumn.

fields.headline: UK advertising group 'ready for slump'
fields.trailText: 11am: Cordiant says it is well prepared for the economic downturn after posting a 79% rise in profits, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
UK advertising group Cordiant says it is well prepared for the looming economic downturn after posting a 79% rise in profits.

The world's 10th largest communications company said the £500m it won in new business last year will help it weather any slowdown in marketing spend.

"The group now believes it is better positioned... to mitigate the impact of an economic slowdown, if one should occur, on marketing expenditures," Cordiant said in a statement.

The company's earnings for last year were boosted by the acquisition of US marketing groups Lighthouse Global Network and Healthworld, taking its pre-tax profits from £32.3m to £57.5m.

Revenues soared 53% to £513m, with the US market providing just under one-third of the group's earnings.

"High performance, not size, is our focus. We could not be more enthusiastic about the potential of the group we are building," said Cordiant chief executive Michael Bungey.

Despite the slump in the US economy, Cordiant reported a weakness in the UK market as it reorganised its Bates Worldwide advertising network.

The group surprised analysts by reporting that trading in north America "remains strong", due to its decision to concentrate on marketing services.

Marketing now provides 60% of Cordiant's revenues and has been a key factor in protecting it from cutbacks in companies' advertising spending.

The company decided last year to move away from advertising and concentrate on marketing services.

Cordiant's shares rose 5% to 301p in early trading.

Related story
Feb 29: Sorrell predicts tough year

fields.headline: Freud wants Groucho
fields.trailText:
9.15am PR guru Matthew Freud is in pole position to take control of the Groucho Club, the exclusive haunt of TV celebrities and media excutives.
Groucho on It list
fields.body:
PR guru Matthew Freud is on the verge of taking control of the Groucho Club, the exclusive haunt of TV celebrities and media excutives.

A new company headed by Mr Freud has had an £11.8m offer accepted in principle dashing the hopes of "It Girl" Tara Palmer-Tomkinson.

She and Benjamin Fry chairman of the Zoo hotel company and founder of trendy K club made an offer direct to shareholders on March 5.

A statement from the Groucho club however made it plain that exclusive negotiations were now being conducted with Mr Freud and his partners Rupert Hambro, investment banker and chairman of Lord Peter Palumbo's new club the Walbrook and Joel Cadbury, head of restaurant, club and pub company Longshot Ltd.

The board of the club, which counts Janet Street-Porter among its shareholders, recommended shareholders not to tender their shares to Zoo Hotels.

Mr Freud was unavailable for comment but he a well-known penchant for the restuarant and entertainment business.

He once had shareholdings in the Pharmacy restaurant in West London and is currently involved in a trendy keep fit club in Soho's Brewer Street.

The company's final offer however will only go ahead once a financial audit has been conducted of the club.

fields.headline: C5 stretches ITC rules with news move
fields.trailText: 10.30am: Channel 5 is confident the watchdog will approve its plan to move its news out of primetime, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The rules that require Channel 5 to screen news in the primetime schedules will be tested to the limit as the station prepares to axe its 6pm bulletin.

The broadcaster is planning to shift the news to the earlier non-primetime slot of 5.30pm and is confident watchdogs will approve the move.

Channel 5 claims the move complies with Independent Television Commission rules that require it to broadcast a bulletin in peaktime.

The station believes the change will be in keeping with ITC rules because it is extending the duration of bulletin from 30 to 60 minutes.

This means the show will finish in primetime.

The ITC rules state the station must screen a bulletin at some point between 6pm and 10.30pm.

The extra half-hour will take the form of an interactive talk show to be produced by Anglia.

The new bulletin will be called 5 News and Talk.

Related story
Feb 27: C5 bids to move news to 5.30pm

fields.headline: Kostunica thwarts western hopes
fields.standfirst: The Yugoslav president is far from the puppet the west had hoped for, reports our foreign affairs specialist Simon Tisdall
fields.trailText: 8 March: The Yugoslav president is not the puppet the west had hoped for, writes Simon Tisdall.
fields.body:
Vojislav Kostunica, the man who replaced Slobodan Milosevic as Yugoslav president after last autumn's "people's power" revolution, is proving to be a bit of a disappointment to many in the west.

In a speech this week in Banja Luka, in Bosnia-Herzegovina, Kostunica said that US and European leaders should stop fretting about Milosevic's extradition to the Hague war crimes tribunal and focus instead on ethnic Albanian violence in and around Kosovo.

Unlike Milosevic, Kostunica is a genuine democrat. When he came to power, that seemed more important to outsiders than his avowedly nationalist outlook.

Serbia's desperate need of western economic assistance after years of sanctions and Nato's devastating 1999 bombing campaign also suggested that Kostunica would be a compliant partner in restoring regional stability.

Instead, Kostunica has doggedly adhered to his strongly held view that the Serbs were the principal victims of the Balkan wars of the past 12 years.

He has repeatedly criticised Nato peacekeepers for their actions in UN-administered Kosovo (which remains sovereign Yugoslav territory) and for failing, in his view, to combat Albanian "terrorism" in Serbia's Presevo valley and the adjoining border with Macedonia.

And despite the increasingly furious protestations of Carla Del Ponte, the war crimes tribunal's chief prosecutor, Kostunica continues to argue against the extradition of Milosevic.

Ms Del Ponte described Kostunica as an "unreconstructed nationalist' this week and said she had found him "hostile" during a recent meeting in Belgrade. She threatened to seek punitive measures through the UN if Yugoslavia persisted in obstructing her work.

Some leading Serb politicians believe Milosevic must be surrendered to the Hague. An opinion poll published last week suggested most Serbs agree. But others say he should be tried at home on charges ranging from attempted murder to fraud, that convincing evidence will take time to collect and that extradition requires a new act of parliament.

Ms Del Ponte gives such arguments short shrift. Her tribunal has no shortage of evidence against Milosevic relating to war crimes and crimes against humanity, she says. So just hand him over.

The US takes a similar view. It has set the end of this month as a deadline for at least the commencement of cooperation with the Hague. If the deadline is missed, it threatens to withhold $100m (£70m) in aid.

There was speculation meanwhile about a possible compromise under which Milosevic would be surrendered to the tribunal but allowed to stand trial in a special session on Serbian soil.

Kostunica's comments in Banja Luka that the west, distracted by the Milosevic case, was failing in its principal task of bringing "prosperity and peace" to Kosovo, will further alienate the Nato allies. There is also more than a touch of hypocrisy here.

Given Serbia's deplorable record with respect to Kosovo's Albanians, and in dealing with Muslim populations in general, Kostunica's sudden concern for Kosovan welfare looks unconvincing to say the least.

Despite serious security problems on Kosovo's borders with Macedonia and Serbia and continuing ethnic Albanian violence within the province, the presence of the 42,000 peacekeepers has enabled the UN administration to make considerable progress. The west also continues to provide large amounts in aid, bilaterally and more broadly through the EU's Balkan Stability Pact.

The US coordinator for assistance to eastern Europe, Larry Napper, told a Kosovo donors' meeting in Pristina last month that Washington had pledged more than $700m in 1999 and that up to $94.3m was available in 2001, depending on what other donors provided. He noted that more than 3,000 police officers have now been trained by the UN.

Napper said the US assessment was that "the economic and political situation in Kosovo has greatly improved since we last met in November, 1999" - a statement even Kostunica would be hard-pressed to rebut.

Speaking at a Balkan summit convened in Skopje, Macedonia, last month, Chris Patten, the EU's external affairs commissioner, also said progress had been made. And he directly addressed Kostunica's concerns.

"We have strongly condemned the violent and illegal terrorist actions by ethnically motivated extremist armed groups in south Serbia which could destabilise the region," Patten said, in a clear reference to ethnic Albanian insurgents in Presevo. "It is time for every Kosovar to make a stand against violence and outlaw its perpetrators."

Since Napper and Patten spoke, Nato has stepped up border patrols, extended cross-border surveillance, moved up reinforcements and agreed to hand over control of parts of the Presevo buffer zone to Kostunica's forces.

The Nato operation, known as K-For, is still open to criticism - particularly when it comes to the reluctance of US commanders to take risks. But Kostunica's claims that the west is ignoring the security situation and Kosovo's prosperity and merely obsessing instead about Milosevic clearly do not hold water.

Clues to Kostunica's behaviour must be sought elsewhere. For a start, as Yugoslav president, his domestic powers are very limited. After last December's opposition victory in Serbia's parliamentary elections, he risks being eclipsed. So he needs to make his presence felt.

Second, he wants to hold together what remains of his country. Montenegro's moves towards independence, which may take a leap forward after this April's elections, are an affront to his nationalist credo.

Independence threatens further to erode his power-base - and Yugoslavia's very existence. But he knows that the west, too, is nervous about a Montenegrin secession. The same goes for the prospect of an independent Kosovo.

Third, Kostunica knows that in his tussles with the west, he can count on Russia's support. Vladimir Putin has taken over from Boris Yeltsin as a champion of Orthodox Slavs. He weighed in this week, saying Nato's peacekeeping problems proved the west should never have intervened in Kosovo in the first place.

Kostunica also knows that Belgrade's support is critical if the 1995 Dayton power-sharing agreement in Bosnia, presently under threat from breakaway Croat hardliners, is to continue to work. The reason he was in Banja Luka this week was to sign an agreement signalling closer ties with the Bosnian Serbs.

Kostunica may be calculating that ultimately, Nato and the west will need a viable, friendly Yugoslavia more than they need the truculent, unbiddable Albanians they intervened in Kosovo to protect. Historically speaking, this has usually been the case. And it may be so again, notwithstanding the war of 1999. In this bigger drama, the ultimate fate of Milosevic plays but a small part.
