Unlike Milosevic, Kostunica is a genuine democrat. When he came to power, that seemed more important to outsiders than his avowedly nationalist outlook. Serbia's desperate need of western economic assistance after years of sanctions and Nato's devastating 1999 bombing campaign also suggested that Kostunica would be a compliant partner in restoring regional stability. Instead, Kostunica has doggedly adhered to his strongly held view that the Serbs were the principal victims of the Balkan wars of the past 12 years. He has repeatedly criticised Nato peacekeepers for their actions in UN-administered Kosovo (which remains sovereign Yugoslav territory) and for failing, in his view, to combat Albanian "terrorism" in Serbia's Presevo valley and the adjoining border with Macedonia. And despite the increasingly furious protestations of Carla Del Ponte, the war crimes tribunal's chief prosecutor, Kostunica continues to argue against the extradition of Milosevic. Ms Del Ponte described Kostunica as an "unreconstructed nationalist' this week and said she had found him "hostile" during a recent meeting in Belgrade. She threatened to seek punitive measures through the UN if Yugoslavia persisted in obstructing her work. Some leading Serb politicians believe Milosevic must be surrendered to the Hague. An opinion poll published last week suggested most Serbs agree. But others say he should be tried at home on charges ranging from attempted murder to fraud, that convincing evidence will take time to collect and that extradition requires a new act of parliament. Ms Del Ponte gives such arguments short shrift. Her tribunal has no shortage of evidence against Milosevic relating to war crimes and crimes against humanity, she says. So just hand him over. The US takes a similar view. It has set the end of this month as a deadline for at least the commencement of cooperation with the Hague. If the deadline is missed, it threatens to withhold $100m (£70m) in aid. There was speculation meanwhile about a possible compromise under which Milosevic would be surrendered to the tribunal but allowed to stand trial in a special session on Serbian soil. Kostunica's comments in Banja Luka that the west, distracted by the Milosevic case, was failing in its principal task of bringing "prosperity and peace" to Kosovo, will further alienate the Nato allies. There is also more than a touch of hypocrisy here. Given Serbia's deplorable record with respect to Kosovo's Albanians, and in dealing with Muslim populations in general, Kostunica's sudden concern for Kosovan welfare looks unconvincing to say the least. Despite serious security problems on Kosovo's borders with Macedonia and Serbia and continuing ethnic Albanian violence within the province, the presence of the 42,000 peacekeepers has enabled the UN administration to make considerable progress. The west also continues to provide large amounts in aid, bilaterally and more broadly through the EU's Balkan Stability Pact. The US coordinator for assistance to eastern Europe, Larry Napper, told a Kosovo donors' meeting in Pristina last month that Washington had pledged more than $700m in 1999 and that up to $94.3m was available in 2001, depending on what other donors provided. He noted that more than 3,000 police officers have now been trained by the UN. Napper said the US assessment was that "the economic and political situation in Kosovo has greatly improved since we last met in November, 1999" - a statement even Kostunica would be hard-pressed to rebut. Speaking at a Balkan summit convened in Skopje, Macedonia, last month, Chris Patten, the EU's external affairs commissioner, also said progress had been made. And he directly addressed Kostunica's concerns. "We have strongly condemned the violent and illegal terrorist actions by ethnically motivated extremist armed groups in south Serbia which could destabilise the region," Patten said, in a clear reference to ethnic Albanian insurgents in Presevo. "It is time for every Kosovar to make a stand against violence and outlaw its perpetrators." Since Napper and Patten spoke, Nato has stepped up border patrols, extended cross-border surveillance, moved up reinforcements and agreed to hand over control of parts of the Presevo buffer zone to Kostunica's forces. The Nato operation, known as K-For, is still open to criticism - particularly when it comes to the reluctance of US commanders to take risks. But Kostunica's claims that the west is ignoring the security situation and Kosovo's prosperity and merely obsessing instead about Milosevic clearly do not hold water. Clues to Kostunica's behaviour must be sought elsewhere. For a start, as Yugoslav president, his domestic powers are very limited. After last December's opposition victory in Serbia's parliamentary elections, he risks being eclipsed. So he needs to make his presence felt. Second, he wants to hold together what remains of his country. Montenegro's moves towards independence, which may take a leap forward after this April's elections, are an affront to his nationalist credo. Independence threatens further to erode his power-base - and Yugoslavia's very existence. But he knows that the west, too, is nervous about a Montenegrin secession. The same goes for the prospect of an independent Kosovo. Third, Kostunica knows that in his tussles with the west, he can count on Russia's support. Vladimir Putin has taken over from Boris Yeltsin as a champion of Orthodox Slavs. He weighed in this week, saying Nato's peacekeeping problems proved the west should never have intervened in Kosovo in the first place. Kostunica also knows that Belgrade's support is critical if the 1995 Dayton power-sharing agreement in Bosnia, presently under threat from breakaway Croat hardliners, is to continue to work. The reason he was in Banja Luka this week was to sign an agreement signalling closer ties with the Bosnian Serbs. Kostunica may be calculating that ultimately, Nato and the west will need a viable, friendly Yugoslavia more than they need the truculent, unbiddable Albanians they intervened in Kosovo to protect. Historically speaking, this has usually been the case. And it may be so again, notwithstanding the war of 1999. In this bigger drama, the ultimate fate of Milosevic plays but a small part. webTitle: Brosnan film falls victim to Hollywood strike action

fields.headline: Brosnan film falls victim to Hollywood strike action
fields.trailText: A sci-fi blockbuster about chaos theory has become the biggest casualty of the threatened Hollywood strikes after Pierce Brosnan demanded a final rewrite
fields.body:
The forthcoming writers and actors strike which is due to shut down Hollywood this summer claimed its most high-profile victim this week as A Sound of Thunder, a sci-fi blockbuster starring Pierce Brosnan, was effectively taken off the production schedule.

A saga of chaos theory, A Sound of Thunder is based on a short story by Ray Bradbury that concerns a lepidopterist who catches a butterfly and, in doing so, sets off a chain of increasingly earth-shattering events. The picture had been due to begin shooting on April 16 so that it could be completed before the strike date.

But Brosnan was reportedly unsatisfied with the script and demanded a final rewrite from creators Joshua Oppenheimer and Thomas Dean Donnelly. However, the backers estimated that this would have bumped the film's schedule forward and left it in danger of being closed down in a half-finished state.

At present the film's fate hangs in the balance. "It's one of those facts of life," said executive producer Nicholas Clermont. "You just have to deal with it. I'm confident that this will eventually go, but it is disappointing."

fields.headline: Boost for drugs research
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown's offer of tax breaks to encourage British pharmaceutical companies to wage war on "killer diseases" won cautious approval yesterday - and a warning that more could be done.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown's offer of tax breaks to encourage British pharmaceutical companies to wage war on "killer diseases" won cautious approval yesterday - and a warning that more could be done.

The Budget held out the possibility of a 50% tax credit on research and development into medicines to combat malaria, tuberculosis and HIV/Aids in the developing world, following consultation with the drugs industry and other parties.

Mr Brown also said he wanted the UK to push for a new international purchase fund for global health, "that will not only develop new life-saving drugs but make existing drugs more widely available".

The proposals - first outlined in the pre-Budget report last November - call for discussions on incentives to encourage the pharmaceutical industry to increase its donations of drugs to developing countries.

webTitle: New IRA statement won't break stalemate

fields.headline: New IRA statement won't break stalemate
fields.standfirst:
While the IRA's latest move may increase the momentum towards peace, it will not be enough to prompt a pre-election settlement, says Henry McDonald

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: While the IRA's latest move may increase the momentum towards peace, it will not be enough to prompt a pre-election settlement, says Henry McDonald.
fields.body:
The IRA's latest statement can be likened to a carefully crafted move in a game of chess. By creating the impression of movement in the peace process - the offer of talks with General de Chastelain's decommissioning body rather than the opening of more arms dumps for inspection or the sealing of secret caches - the Provisionals attempt to prompt the British and Irish governments to make further concessions to them and apply pressure on the Ulster Unionists.

The prospect of IRA re-engagement with General de Chastelain must be matched by moves on the scaling down of the British military presence in south Armagh and more policing reforms that go beyond Chris Patten's recommendations into changing the RUC.

Alone however, a telephone call from the IRA to the General's office will probably not be enough to entice David Trimble, Northern Ireland's First Minister, into lifting his ban on fellow Sinn Fein ministers attending cross-border meetings with their southern Irish counterparts -a key element of the Good Friday Agreement which republicans cherish.

Trimble, with one eye on the looming election and the threat of taking major hits from Ian Paisley's anti-Agreement DUP, is unlikely to lift his ban. Only an IRA move to concrete or permanently seal the bunkers that contain tonnes of explosives, guns and ammunition - putting arms beyond use - would allow Trimble to drop his sanctions and allow the Agreement to be implemented in full.

The IRA statement may of course be a precursor to further moves on decommissioning but given the enormous resistance inside the Provisionals, particularly in areas like South Armagh, to putting weapons beyond use (an ideological step too far for many), the chances of a comprehensive deal are slim.

And while the IRA have surprised us before, last May's statement allowing international inspectors to check some of their dumps, the likelihood is that all parties to the Agreement will enter the general election in a political stalemate. Moreover, post-election the political landscape of Northern Ireland may have altered radically with the majority of unionists now supporting parties and candidates opposed to the Good Friday Agreement.

If Tony Blair and Bertie Ahern, both in Belfast today, were therefore able to achieve a settlement prior to the election it would mark one of the most remarkable and unlikely achievements in modern political history.

fields.headline: 40,000 jobs stay in the script
fields.standfirst: Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: The extension of film industry tax relief until 2005 will secure up to 40,000 jobs, the industry said last night. By Maev Kennedy.
fields.body:
The extension of film industry tax relief until 2005 will secure up to 40,000 jobs, the industry said last night.

"This is hugely important for the British film industry," said John Woodward, chief executive of the Film Council.

"Section 48 reliefs have been vital to the recent resurgence of film production in the UK and there is now a firm foundation for growth and exports over the next few years."

The Film Council had been frantically lobbying the culture department and the Treasury in the last six months as fear spread in the industry that the tax concessions for overseas films - there are separate tax breaks for British films - were in real danger. The breaks are seen as being directly responsible for a record £500m worth for foreign filming in Britain last year.

Blockbuster movies being made in the UK last year included the film that every eight-year-old is waiting for, Harry Potter, as well as Tomb Raider, The Mummy Returns, and the Steven Spielberg/Tom Hanks co-production Band of Brothers

The culture secretary, Chris Smith, said: "The government's long term aim is to create a more sustainable and better capitalised film industry."

fields.headline: Collymore retires from game aged 30
fields.standfirst: Exclusive: Stan to open trendy clothes shop?
fields.trailText: Stan Collymore's uneasy relationship with football ended in divorce last night when he announced that he was calling time on his troubled career - without informing current club Real Oviedo.
fields.body:
Stan Collymore's uneasy relationship with football ended in divorce last night when he announced that he was calling time on his troubled career - without informing his Spanish club.

Only five weeks after joining Real Oviedo and less than 48 hours since publicly stating he was happy in La Liga, Collymore announced he was retiring to spend more time with his son Thomas and girlfriend Estelle.

His unexpected announcement brought a stinging response from Spain. "We were expecting Stan to be back for the weekend match against Espanyol and the first we have heard of his decision is through the press," said the Oviedo spokesman Miguel Solis.

"He told us he was going home for a few days because his girlfriend was pregnant. We respect his decision but a Spanish player would not have behaved like that. Surely respect should go both ways."

Collymore has not made a single first-team start since joining Oviedo on a free transfer from Bradford City at the end of January, and the team's coach Raddy Antic has criticised his fitness level. He played for 22 minutes in their 1-0 defeat at Celta Vigo on Sunday and in a radio interview on Tuesday said he was enjoying life and intent on being a success.

"I'm glad to have come to Spain because I've found peace and all I'm interested in now is football," he said. "My first experiences of Spain are unforgettable and I'm sure I will find lots of happiness here."

But yesterday's statement said that, having just turned 30, "the time was right to explore other career opportunities".

Those are likely to involve media work but even if Collymore decides to stay away from football for good his turbulent career, plagued by dressing-room problems and off-field controversies at Nottingham Forest, Liverpool, Aston Villa, Leicester City and Bradford, ensures a place for him in football's hall of notoriety.

Once a record £8.5m signing for Liverpool, his rich potential was never fulfilled and after several incidents, notably an alleged assault on Ulrika Jonsson in June 1998, he was admitted to the Priory clinic with depression.

There had been no clues that he was planning to retire and his decision surprised former colleagues. "It's a very sad day for Stan," said Frank Clark, his former manager at Nottingham Forest. "I have always said: 'Play as long as you possibly can, because you are a long time finished.' At 30, Stan's potential has been wasted, really."

Collymore's former Aston Villa team-mate Paul Merson said: "Stan could be turning his back on the most productive and rewarding days of his whole career."

fields.headline: £1bn plan to eradicate urban decay
fields.trailText: Thousands of empty houses could be brought back into use after a large cut in value added tax levied on the cost of refurbishing vacant properties.
fields.body:
Thousands of empty houses could be brought back into use after a large cut in value added tax levied on the cost of refurbishing vacant properties.

In a £1bn, five-year package of regeneration to breathe new life into run-down inner cities and less favoured regions, the Treasury announced last night that VAT would be slashed from 17.5% to 5% on an estimated 150,000 properties which have been empty for three years or more. Buildings empty for 10 years will be given a zero rating.

Although the chancellor shied away from meeting demands from a government urban task force for full VAT harmonisation at 5% on the cost of building new houses - at present zero-rated - and refurbishing older ones, housing charities and builders welcomed yesterday's policy shift.

Calling for balanced economic growth for every region, Gordon Brown acknowledged that rising prosperity in the country as a whole "still left people in too many places behind." With an eye on tax breaks in US cities, he talked of harnessing public and private investment with new fiscal incentives to extend opportunities and enterprise "from some of the country to all of the country".

To speed up regeneration, he also announced six tax initiatives - ranging from accelerated tax relief at 150% for cleaning up tens of thousands of acres of contaminated land to 100% first-year capital allowances for bringing empty flats over shops back into the residential market.

In addition, consultation would take place on further corporation tax relief for firms investing in new urban regeneration companies which have been set up in Liverpool, Sheffield, east Manchester and the old steel town of Corby. Up to eight others are planned

To cut the cost of small business borrowing in poorer areas, a new community investment tax credit would be introduced alongside the first community development venture capital fund - a partnership between government, financial institutions and the charitable sector.

In addition, the small business service would offer up to £2,000 worth of advice for any start up company drawing up a business plan.

Last night regeneration minister Beverley Hughes hailed the £1bn package as a significant step forward for urban renewal. But housing organisations were also enthusiastic.

Ashley Horsey, chief executive of the Empty Homes Agency, a charity partly funded by the Department of the Environment, estimated that the VAT cut would mean that the average cost of renovating an empty property would be slashed by £1,200 to under £9,000.

Although an estimated 760,000 houses and flats are empty at any one time, the 150,000 likely to qualify for the new 5% rate are reckoned to be the hard core. "This is fantastic news - a big step in the right direction," Mr Horsey added. "It tells us that this government really is serious about bringing empty properties back into use."

The House Builders' Federation was clearly overjoyed that VAT had not been slapped on the cost of building new homes. Pierre Williams, its spokesman, added: "The government is acknowledging our massive efforts to use brownfield [recycled] land wherever possible, and the industry is well on the way to reaching a target of building 60% of new homes by 2008."

Although it is now estimated 57% of building is taking place on recycled land, the federation called for a speedier, "can-do" approach from local planning authorities. The chancellor will later this week underline his determination to strengthen the role of eight regional development agencies by giving them greater freedom to spend money from a "single pot" budget - due to rise by £500m to £1.7bn by 2003-2004.

The RDAs have frequently complained they have no power to switch resources between these programmes.

webTitle: The Downing Street baby briber turns Healey's dream on its head

fields.headline: The Downing Street baby briber turns Healey's dream on its head
fields.trailText: Politicians traditionally kiss babies and bribe the electorate. Yesterday Gordon Brown went one better and bribed babies - proof that there is indeed one born every minute.
fields.body:
Politicians traditionally kiss babies and bribe the electorate. Yesterday Gordon Brown went one better and bribed babies - proof that there is indeed one born every minute.

But before the tax breaks for very young children, the chancellor gave us his traditional annual gloat. I have never seen the Tory party look so glum.

The definitive moment came when he boasted that next year he would repay £34bn in debt - "more in one year than all the debt repaid by previous governments over the past 50 years!"

When Israel won the six day war, Jewish people around the world suddenly saw themselves in a new light, as victors rather than victims. It was a profound psychological change. In the same way Labour MPs now see themselves as the party of economic competence.

They cannot quite grasp it, but they like it. It feels good. And the fact that like the six day war it may lead to plenty more trouble ahead does not bother them one little bit.

The Tories were thunderstruck by the chancellor's boast, as if their entire air force had, so to speak, been destroyed on the ground. Michael Portillo looked utterly miserable. Oliver Letwin and Francis Maude seemed positively distraught. Ann Widdecombe's eyes bulged alarmingly, as if her corsets had come to life and were squeezing the breath out of her. Michael Ancram, the normally ebullient party chairman, gave the impression of a man who has just detected a ferret climbing his trousers, north towards his Y-fronts.

Only Angela Browning allowed herself a little smile, but then it is possible that she was not sure what Mr Brown was talking about.

As Bob Marshall-Andrews remarked last month, the chancellor is a typical lowland Scot, who believes in the virtues of toil and plunder. We might add thrift and pillage. There were endless references to "hard-working families". He used the word "stability" 13 times (though poor old Prudence got only two mentions; Mr Brown is now a married man, and poor Prudence has been abandoned at the stage door, like so many other young, sobbing soubrettes).

At the same time, it was a budget for sin. Cigarettes and booze are not going up. Betting tax is to be abolished. This was not the Budget you would expect from a son of the manse.

Denis Healey used to muse whether it would be possible to put a tax on sex. By giving credits for the consequences of sex - babies - Mr Brown has, most surprisingly, gone off in the opposite direction.

He sat down to loud applause from his own lot and morose, morbid silence from the others. For there is a smell of death about the Tory party.

Mr Hague decided to apply the electrodes and bring his monster twitching back to life. It was a difficult job but he made a good effort. Mr Brown had always listed his tax cuts in the Budget speech, but left others to find the tax rises in the small print. "He is the thief who steals your car then comes back in the morning to return your hubcaps," he said.

"You can't fool all of the people all of the time, but you can fool all Labour MPs on Budget day," he went on. Quite right. Fooling your own party is a chancellor's most important job, and Mr Brown did it very well.

Meanwhile, Mr Hague cheered his own party up mightily. It will not do good in the long run, but he must have enjoyed it yesterday.

webTitle: The hand of Raul draws eye of Uefa

fields.headline: The hand of Raul draws eye of Uefa
fields.trailText: The Real Madrid striker Raul faces disciplinary action from Uefa after scoring with his hand against Leeds United in the Champions League on Tuesday night.
fields.body:
The Real Madrid striker Raul faces disciplinary action from Uefa after scoring with his hand against Leeds United in the Champions League on Tuesday night.

Uefa yesterday condemned Raul punching Real's first goal in their 3-2 win at the Bernabeu. "We will be taking action against Raul," said a spokesman. "The disciplinary committee have confirmed they have opened the case against him concerning allegations he deliberately cheated."

Replays indicated the striker had intentionally handled the ball, and after celebrating with his team-mates he kissed his left hand.

Uefa will also investigate Real's Luis Figo on suspicion of provoking a yellow card that will see him suspended for their last group game but clear for the quarter-finals, for which Real have already qualified.

Arsène Wenger is unlikely to allow Dennis Bergkamp to travel to Germany by road or rail for Arsenal's Champions League game at Bayern Munich on Wednesday.

The striker was left behind for Arsenal's trip to Lyon last month. Wenger said after Tuesday's 1-0 victory over Spartak Moscow that he would almost certainly ignore the Dutchman if his other strikers were fit.

"I can get to Munich and would be happy to get there," said Bergkamp. "We'll see what happens but after what happened last time I don't expect to go."

The international players' union Fifpro is likely to take the European Commission to court over new rules governing transfers. "We are still thinking about it but really we have no other choice," said Fifpro's secretary-general Theo van Seggelen.

The Republic of Ireland's World Cup qualifier in Cyprus on March 24 will go ahead despite the foot and mouth crisis, the Football Association of Ireland said yesterday.

Christoph Daum, who lost his job with the German national team after testing positive for cocaine, has been appointed coach of the Turkish club Besiktas in place of Nevio Scala, who was sacked. Ipswich completed the signing of the Sunderland defender Chris Makin for £1.25m.

fields.headline: Touch magazine folds
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Black music and lifestyle glossy Touch has closed after failing to secure a buyer, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Black music and lifestyle glossy Touch has closed after failing to secure a buyer.

Touch editor Vince Jackson confirmed staff had been told on Monday that the magazine would go into voluntary liquidation.

Touch, which was originally called Free!, was launched in the late 80s..

It developed a strong core readership and became the magazine of record for black music in the UK.

An insider said Touch's closure was "indicative of a lack of belief in black magazines across the board".

"You see advertisers buying into the images of black culture but when it comes to supporting the magazines with advertising, they can't put their money where their mouths are," he said.

The source said the popularity of black music in the charts had failed to register with advertisers.

He said that potential buyers got cold feet when it came to taking on a magazine aimed at black readers.

"If this were Dazed & Confused, someone would have come in and rescued it," he added.

The magazine was believed to be selling around 35,000 copies a month, but the lack of advertising led to mounting debts.

Seven staff have been laid off.

It is understood Touch's publisher Joe Pidgeon had conversations with several publishing houses in a bid to sell the magazine but Mr Jackson would not confirm the names of potential buyers.

Music magazines across the board have been squeezed recently as they have been hit by the fragmenting advertising market.

However, more mainstream clubbing and dance-music titles such as Mixmag, which was bought several years ago by Emap, have performed well.

fields.headline: 5m Britons 'living on the breadline'
fields.trailText: More than 5m people in Britain were living in conditions of absolute poverty during Tony Blair's third year in office, according to research published today on the number of Europeans living below the breadline. John Carvel
fields.body:
More than 5m people in Britain were living in conditions of absolute poverty during Tony Blair's third year in office, according to research published today on the number of Europeans living below the breadline.

Using a definition of poverty agreed by 117 governments at the 1995 world summit as lack of food, safe drinking water, sanitation facilities, health, shelter, education and information, the study found 9% of British people said their income was a lot below what they needed each week to afford the absolute necessities of life.

The greatest concentration of poverty was among lone parents. More than two-fifths of those with one child said they had incomes below £163 a week, the amount needed to buy the goods and services that most people regarded as basic essentials.

More than half lone parents with two or more children had incomes below their absolute poverty level at £227 a week. And 25% of single pensioners fell below the £106-a-week threshold needed to surmount absolute poverty. In each case benefit levels were about 20% below the income needed to keep people out of absolute poverty if they had to remain on state support for more than about six months, the authors of the study estimated.

The Breadline Europe study, led by academics from Bristol University and the London School of Economics, was based on a social exclusion survey in September 1999, six months after the government began its anti-poverty drive.

Ministers had dismissed previous research showing that numbers in poverty grew over the first two years of the Labour government. They said the position would improve after introduction of the minimum wage and working families tax credit - bringing 1.2m children and 800,000 adults out of poverty by April 2002 and abolishing child poverty completely by 2020.

But time lags in the official data will force the government to go into the next election without hard evidence to demonstrate progress.

The key official poverty indicator, dating from a survey in 1998, will show there were 14m adults in households with less than half average income. This was nearly 1m more than in the early 1990s, and more than double the number in the early 1980s.

The Breadline Europe survey was based on more recent data and measured poverty against a different yardstick, based on the public's assessment of what are the absolute essentials of life. Households lacking at least six of these essentials because they could not afford them were categorised as a lot below the level of income needed to avoid absolute poverty.

David Gordon, senior research fellow at Bristol university and co-author of the report, said people's experiences differed from Treasury models of how they ought to behave.

"Absolute poverty is not supposed to exist in a country like Britain. But 9% of the population have reported their income was a lot below that needed each week to keep their household out of absolute poverty and a further 8% said their income was a little below."

Peter Townsend, professor of international social policy at the LSE and co-author, said the growth of poverty in Britain countered the trend in other western European countries.

"Some observers believe that, under successive governments, the country has been going so far down the road of residualising welfare that it has become detached from most of the other European states and is lamely following in the wake of the US," he said.

The study showed dramatic increases in extreme forms of poverty across eastern Europe over the past 10 years, but the figures could not be compared directly with the UK.

Simon Clarke, professor of sociology at Warwick university, said over 60% of Russians were living in poverty in 1998. "Over a quarter were in extreme poverty, with incomes of less than half that required to acquire basic means of subsistence. This compares to a rate of about 11% at the beginning of reform in 1992," he said.

fields.headline: Olympic hero powers Kellogg's relaunch
fields.trailText: 10.30am: Kellogg's has signed up Olympic cycling champion Jason Queally to promote its Sustain and Start cereals, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Kellogg's has signed up British Olympic cycling champion Jason Queally in a four-year deal to relaunch its Sustain and Start cereals as the food of sporting heroes.

The quirkily named Queally follows in the footsteps of one of the country's favourite sporting sons, Steve Cram, whose golden-haired image adorned packets of Start in the 1980s.

Packets of both brands will feature pictures of Queally, who won gold and silver medals at last year's Sydney Olympics.

The company is aiming to position the two brands as healthy breakfast cereal ideal for sportsmen and women.

An on-pack promotion kicks off the relaunch in June, offering the chance to win one of five training bikes used by Jason in the run-up to the Olympics.

"We are thrilled to have joined forces with Jason and hope his sporting achievements and the goodness of Sustain and Start will inspire cereal fans to make the most of their sporting ability," said Peter Smith, UK brand manager of Kellogg's.

Related story

Feb 27: Rover extends Olympic sponsorship

webTitle: Soft line on health risks draws fire

fields.headline: Soft line on health risks draws fire
fields.trailText: The chancellor came under fire from health professionals yesterday for "going soft" on drinkers and smokers in a sharp change of policy that many interpreted as a populist pre-election gambit.
fields.body:
The chancellor came under fire from health professionals yesterday for "going soft" on drinkers and smokers in a sharp change of policy that many interpreted as a populist pre-election gambit.

Gordon Brown froze duty on beers, wines and spirits following complaints from the drinks industry about a surge in smuggling, and added a surprise tax break for smaller brewers. Tax on a packet of cigarettes went up just 6p, in line with the rate of inflation.

The Royal College of Physicians said it was disappointed, pointing out that the government had previously pledged to increase cigarette tax by 5% in real terms every year.

The college's president, Sir George Alberti, said: "Tobacco and alcohol are the UK's major killers and causes of disease - this does nothing to discourage consumption of either."

Clive Bates, the director of lobbyist Action on Smoking and Health, echoed this view, pointing out that an inflationary rise in tobacco tax would not keep pace with rising salaries.

"This means cigarettes will become more affordable," he said. "They want to have a popular, smokers' Budget just before the election."

The Treasury said the price of a packet of five small cigars will typically rise by 2p, while 25 gram packs of hand-rolling and pipe tobacco will now cost 5p and 3p more respectively.

There was a mixed response from the tobacco industry.

Gallaher said: "We called for a freeze. We are disappointed that there is any increase, but give a cautious welcome to the chancellor moving away from excessive above-inflation duty increases."

Forest, the smokers' action group, said the change in policy was insignificant, and called on Mr Brown to copy a recent reduction in tobacco duty in Sweden.

For drinkers, Mr Brown extended a freeze on spirits duty to encompass beer and wine, citing "the competitive position of the industry".

This was interpreted as a reference to complaints about a flood of cheap imports from the continent - a report this week by Stuart Neame, the chairman of the Independent Family Brewers of Britain, found that each extra penny of tax on beer led to an extra 25,000 pints being brought in by "booze cruisers" daily.

In a bonus for real ale enthusiasts, the Treasury said it was "minded" to introduce a lower rate of duty for smaller brewers. This follows concern for the future of companies such as Shepherd Neame, Young & Co and Fuller, Smith & Turner, following the emergence of powerful "mega-brewers" such as Interbrew and Scottish & Newcastle.

webTitle: Extension of film industry tax relief secures 40,000 jobs

fields.headline: Extension of film industry tax relief secures 40,000 jobs
fields.trailText: The extension of film industry tax relief until 2005 will secure up to 40,000 jobs, the industry said last night
fields.body:
The extension of film industry tax relief until 2005 will secure up to 40,000 jobs, the industry said last night.

"This is hugely important for the British film industry," said John Woodward, chief executive of the Film Council.

"Section 48 reliefs have been vital to the recent resurgence of film production in the UK and there is now a firm foundation for growth and exports over the next few years."

The Film Council had been frantically lobbying the culture department and the Treasury in the last six months as fear spread in the industry that the tax concessions for overseas films - there are separate tax breaks for British films - were in real danger. The breaks are seen as being directly responsible for a record £500m worth for foreign filming in Britain last year.

Blockbuster movies being made in the UK last year included the film that every eight-year-old is waiting for, Harry Potter, as well as Tomb Raider, The Mummy Returns, and the Steven Spielberg/Tom Hanks co-production Band of Brothers

The culture secretary, Chris Smith, said: "The government's long term aim is to create a more sustainable and better capitalised film industry."

fields.headline: FBI warns Gladiator film star of kidnap plot
fields.trailText: The FBI is investigating a plot to kidnap the film star Russell Crowe, less than three weeks before the Academy Awards ceremony at which he is tipped to win an Oscar for best actor in the movie Gladiator.
fields.byline: Duncan Campbell in Los Angeles and Michael Ellison in New York
fields.body:
The FBI is investigating a plot to kidnap the film star Russell Crowe, less than three weeks before the Academy Awards ceremony at which he is tipped to win an Oscar for best actor in the movie Gladiator.

The threat is being taken seriously enough for Crowe to have been accompanied by undercover officers to the Golden Globe awards in Los Angeles in January.

"We are aware of the situation," said a spokesman for Crowe, whose latest film, Proof of Life, has just opened in Britain. In it he plays the part of a negotiator hired to secure the release of a kidnapped engineer in South America.

"The FBI has been extremely helpful in guiding us through this and we are taking the necessary security precautions."

FBI agents wore tuxedos to mingle with stars and industry insiders at the Golden Globe awards in Beverly Hills, an FBI spokeswoman, Laura Bosley, said. The FBI normally declines to comment on pending investigations, but decided to make an exception in this case after the media got wind of the inquiry.

The bureau learned of the kidnap threat just before the ceremony on January 21, and interviewed Crowe to see if he had any idea who might be behind such a plot. A decision was then made to accompany the New Zealand-born actor and advise him on security precautions during his time in the US. Crowe's private security staff was also increased.

Scotland Yard's special operations division was put on alert by the FBI shortly before Crowe flew to London.

"A kidnap threat involving Crowe was passed to Scotland Yard by the Americans," a security service source said. "There was some assessment and it was given a low grading. The matter was discussed with Crowe and left in the hands of his own security guards. We didn't have any involvement after that."

The actor lives in Australia but spends much of his time working in the US. He has often complained about the attention that goes with being a major star, and the stories that have appeared about him.

Crowe, who was beaten to the best actor award at the Golden Globes by Tom Hanks, recently separated from Meg Ryan after a highly publicised affair that started on the set of Proof of Life.

Well-known actors are frequently the victims of stalkers. Jodie Foster was stalked by John Hinckley Jr, who claimed that his attempted assassination of Ronald Reagan was an attempt to impress her. Many others have required police protection after being pursued by fans. However, the stalkers are usually disturbed people who want to gain the star's attention, rather than people planning a kidnap. Frank Sinatra Jr, the singer's son, was the victim of a kidnapping, but in general attempts on high-profile figures are rare.

Crowe is the favourite to win the Oscar for best actor at the Academy Awards on March 25. He has been nominated for his role in the Ridley Scott film Gladiator as a Roman general who becomes enslaved as a gladiator and fights to avenge the deaths of his wife and son. He earned a previous Oscar nomination for his role as a tobacco industry whistle-blower in The Insider.

fields.headline: 'Whassup?' man takes top advertising accolade
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The man behind Budweiser's 'whassup?' campaign is to be named advertiser of the year, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The man behind Budweiser's hugely successful "whassup?" campaign is to be named advertiser of the year at this year's Cannes International Advertising Festival.

August A Busch IV, head of marketing at Budweiser manufacturer Anheuser-Busch, will receive the accolade on June 23.

The award is in recognition of his company's domination of the US brewing industry and the outstanding and consistent quality of its advertising campaigns.

Last year, the Cannes Lions Film Grand Prix - the top advertising prize - was awarded to the "whassup?" campaign.

Previous winners have included Renzo Ross, founder of the fashion brand Diesel, and Virgin chief Richard Branson.

fields.headline: Bragg hails Corrie as 'people's art form'
fields.trailText: 10.15am: LWT's arts chief claims Coronation Street could be as culturally significant as Marcel Duchamp's urinal, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
LWT controller of arts Lord Melvyn Bragg has claimed Coronation Street could in future be as culturally significant as Marcel Duchamp's urinal.

Lord Bragg said the latest art was in "artefact, sculpture, conceptual work", adding that "the late 20th century in this country contained the seeds of what might be a future battle over its cultural character".

"For instance, is Coronation Street likely to be more valued and influential in the long run than the urinal named as art by Marcel Duchamp?", he added, speaking at Leeds University last night in his capacity as chancellor.

"Tracy Emin's bed is in a direct line from the urinal. Duchamp's urinal is accepted as an important and great icon of 20th century art.

"What of the claim that Coronation Street, the flag bearer of the big message on television for the last 40 years, might be art, might well outlive the lavatory?" he said in the Edward Boyle Lecture.

Lord Bragg dubbed Coronation Street "the people's art form" and said it would set the agenda for a new phase in the 21st century definition of culture.

fields.headline: £200m to bust drugs culture
fields.trailText: A £200m fund to wage war on drugs, backed by a celebrity anti-drugs campaign with prominent business and sports personalities, was announced yesterday.
fields.body:
A £200m fund to wage war on drugs, backed by a celebrity anti-drugs campaign with prominent business and sports personalities, was announced yesterday.

The cash, to be made available over the next three years, will go to police commanders and local authority anti-drugs coordinators to fight drug-related crime and break up networks of local dealers.

The money is to be channelled through the 350 partnerships against crime and disorder across England, bringing together police, local authority, drug action teams and voluntary organisations to devise local anti-crime strategies.

A Home Office spokeswoman said payments to the neighbourhood partnerships would average between £500,000 and £1m, with similar funds available in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.

A further £15m is be made available to finance an advertising campaign which will feature anti-drugs messages from sports and business personalities to help reduce the demand for illegal drugs. "The war against drugs will never be won by government alone but neighbourhood by neighbour hood across the country, so further resources will be announced to support a new campaign, involving prominent figures from the world of business and sports to mobilise communities against drugs," said the chancellor.

The extra money was welcomed by DrugScope, the charity which represents those who work with drug abusers. "There is evidence that disrupting local drug markets can prove effective and any support for local communities is welcome," said director Roger Howard. "We are disappointed that more resources are not being channelled into helping drug users reintegrate into society when they come out of prison following treatment."

The funds compare with £3bn a year spent on the fight against drug abuse, more than two thirds spent on law enforcement.

Last week, Tony Blair announced extra initiatives as part of the government's 10-year anti-crime plan, in which he floated ideas such as a national register of drug dealers and specialist drug courts.The government believes that the campaign against drug abuse is central to its anti-crime plan. Almost two thirds of the 100,000 most persistent offenders misuse hard drugs, including heroin and cocaine.

fields.headline: Pensioners' increase outpaces inflation
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown, yesterday sought to defuse pensioners' anger about Labour's record in its first four years with a comprehensive set of reforms designed to end pensioner poverty. He said it would allow "today's workforce - tomorrow's retirement pensioners - to plan ahead".
fields.body:
Gordon Brown, yesterday sought to defuse pensioners' anger about Labour's record in its first four years with a comprehensive set of reforms designed to end pensioner poverty. He said it would allow "today's workforce - tomorrow's retirement pensioners - to plan ahead".

The basic state pension is to increase by more than the average wage, rising by £5 a week for a single person to £72.50 from April. Couples will see their basic go up from £107.90 to £115.90 - a 7.4% increase.

Further increases are already pencilled in for April 2002 - to £75.50 for single pensioners and £120.70 for couples. This is in addition to retaining the winter allowance and the free television licence for the over 75s.

The minimum income guarantee is to be simplified with one rate for all those who qualify. From April, single pensioners will be guaranteed an income of £92.15, and couples a minimum £140.55.

Better off pensioners will benefit from income tax changes thanks to the extension of the 10p tax rate, an above inflation uplift in the personal allowance for the over 65s and a £600 rise in the income limit for these age related allowances.

A pensioner couple each with £8,000 income before tax will be £87 a year better off; those on £20,000 each will gain £312 between them after the income tax changes kick in.

But helping tomorrow's pensioners to plan today is as high on the chancellor's agenda.

"Since November, we have been consulting on our new pension credit, to be introduced in 2003. Pensioner couples with incomes below £200 and single pensioners with incomes below £135 a week, will receive the new pension credit," Mr Brown said.

The pension credit is set to give "extra support" to around half of all pensioner households. It will allow those with lower retirement incomes, which are nevertheless above the basic state pension level, to keep a large proportion of their savings income or income from their company pensions.

He said the intention -from 2003 - is to abolish capital rules which penalise pensioners with savings above £3,000, end the weekly means test, and increase the minimum income guarantee by linking this to rises in earnings throughout the next parliament.

Age Concern director general Gordon Lishman hailed Mr Brown as the first chancellor in 20 years to raise the basic state pension above the rate of inflation. But he criticised the Treasury for creating a "massively complex system and endless form filling for pensioners" who relied on the pension credit and minimum income guarantee.

Jack Jones, president of the National Pensioners' Convention, said pensioners wanted a more substantial increase in the basic state pension rather than more means tested benefits.

webTitle: Champion of the children on target

fields.headline: Champion of the children on target
fields.trailText: Budget measures targeted at helping low-and middle-income families boost the government's policy of eradicating child poverty.
fields.body:
Budget measures targeted at helping low-and middle-income families boost the government's policy of eradicating child poverty.

From June, the adult benefit in the working families' tax credit (WFTC) will go up by £5 above inflation. A similar increase is proposed in the disabled person's tax credit (DPTC). The new rates, combined with the increases in the national minimum wage, will guarantee a family on WFTC a minimum income of £225 a week from next October, up from £214 a week in April.

Working parents will also get more help with the expense of childcare from June through an increase in the limits for eligible costs in the childcare tax credit component of WFTC. These go up from £100 to £135 for families with childcare costs for one child and from £150 to £200 for families with two or more children.

Because this credit covers up to 70% of eligible childcare costs, the changes mean a maximum of £94.50 per week for one child and £140 for two children towards registered childcare costs.

As predicted, the new children's tax credit (CTC) will be worth up to £10 a week when it comes into effect in April. This is £1.50 a week more than the starting rate announced in last year's Budget and represents a tax cut for about 5m families with children under 16. The CTC replaces the married couple's allowance but is available to unmarried couples and single parents.

To increase support for families with very young children - "the time when family income tends to fall as family costs rise", as the chancellor put it - from April 2002 the CTC will be increased by a further £10 a week for families in the year of a child's birth.

The Treasury has confirmed that this "baby bonus", which will be worth up to £1,040 for about 500,000 families each year, will be paid at this higher rate for the entire tax year (from one April to the next) in which a baby is born. If, for example, a family claims the bonus payment for a baby born in September, it will receive a lump sum backdated to the previous April and the rest through their pay packets on a monthly basis until the following April.

Families on income-related benefits who will not benefit from the increases in WFTC or the CTC, will get an increase of £1.50 a week in the child allowances in income support and jobseeker's allowance from October 2001, to match the rise in the CTC in this Budget.

As announced in last year's Budget, child benefit goes up in line with indexation from April to £15.50 for the first child and £10.35 for subsequent children.

Martin Barnes, director of the Child Poverty Action Group, said: "This is a good Budget for families and children. The chancellor has proved that he is a champion for children by his dogged and persistent commitment to children and low-income families."

More than 3m children would remain in poverty, however, and the government could and should do more. "If the momentum of this Budget is maintained, income poverty for children could be ended within 10 years and not 20."

Kate Green, director of the National Council for One Parent Families, said: "The chancellor's measures are a shot in the arm for working lone parents who will now be a step closer to a decent income. The substantial increase in the childcare tax credit is tremendous for lone parents for whom the cost of childcare is still a major barrier to work.

"We are also pleased to see the chancellor signal some recognition of the importance of full-time parenting with the £1.50 increase for children in income support."

Kate Green, director of the National Council for One Parent Families, said: "The chancellor's measures are a shot in the arm for working lone parents who will now be a step closer to a decent income. The substantial increase in the childcare tax credit is tremendous for lone parents for whom the cost of childcare is still a major barrier to work. "We are also pleased to see the chancellor signal some recognition of the importance of full-time parenting with the £1.50 increase for children in income support."

webTitle: The price of care falls by the wayside

fields.headline: The price of care falls by the wayside
fields.trailText: Comment: The absence of a national standard in relation to the cost of care is a real impediment to care homes reaching high standards.
fields.body:
After what seems like a very long time - the consultation closed on 21 January last year - the new standards for the conduct of care homes for older people have finally been published. There are 38 standards and they will form the basis for the work of the National Care Standards Commission from April 2002.

The two critical words are "national" - the standards will apply equally to residential and nursing homes in London, Lancaster and Looe. And "minimum" - in some cases homes will already be exceeding them, though there is no cause for complacency and the standards should be a platform from which higher standards can be developed.

Beginning with the business of making a choice, homes will be required to produce a statement of aims, objectives and philosophy, along with a statement of the services and facilities provided and the terms and conditions for residence. They will be expected to produce a brochure or user's guide describing these matters in plain English.

These steps are intended to provide prospective users and their families with sufficient information for them to make an informed choice about where they will live and should be helpful. However, many families will come up against the single most important impediment to choice - the lack of funding.

No amount of brochures will compensate for council purchasing policies that have the effect of excluding older people from homes charging above the "local rate". Unless the prospective resident has friends or charitable sources willing to provide a top-up, bridging the gap between what the provider charges and what the purchaser is prepared to pay, the choice will be strictly limited.

When Counsel and Care responded to the consultation, we underlined the need to establish a national standard in relation to the cost of care, as well as to the conduct of care homes. The absence of such a standard remains a real impediment to homes reaching high standards that they and their staff set out to achieve.

Much of the debate over the past year has focused on the physical space requirements and rapidly became polarised between providers resistant to the proposed new standards because of the difficulties they would find in complying, and those who inspect or advocate for residents who wanted to see rapid improvements. That issue has been pushed off the agenda, for the time being at least, by allowing a very long lead-in time - to April 2007 - for the introduction of larger room sizes. Private space is important to all of us, and will not become less important as we grow older, but maybe now we can get on with addressing some of the other equally important issues that have been obscured by this topic.

From April 2002, policies and procedures must be in place to protect residents from abuse. The establishment of a register of staff considered unsuitable to work with vulnerable people will provide additional protection. But this alone will not deal with a "dripping tap" of affronts to the dignity and wellbeing of residents. Our contacts with residents, their relatives, managers and care staff tell us that there is a great deal of scope for staff adversely to affect the lives of residents.

A raised voice, a thoughtless word or just not being available to lend a sympathetic ear to someone, perhaps because of pressure of other work, may each in their own small way contribute to unfulfilled lives. One of the most telling findings from interviews conducted for the Office of Fair Trading 1998 report, Older people as consumers in care homes, was that residents reported staff were too busy to talk to them.

A still largely untrained workforce presents a threat to the welfare and wellbeing of residents. So it is encouraging that the standards address the training needs, qualifications and skills mix of the staff group. At least half the care staff should be trained to NVQ level 2 by 2005 - a high but necessary target. But there will be problems with recruitment and retention that will affect the ability to achieve this target so long as the care sector is unfavourably placed to compete with commercial organisations in the labour market.

Once again, then, the issue of a fair price for care rears its head. Until such a time as agreement can be reached on a target price, providers will continue to express concerns about their capacity to deliver care, staffing and services to all the standards against which they will be inspected.

Campaigners working to protect and promote the rights of older people have had enough of the government saying that councils have had increased resources and enough of councils telling us they are under-resourced. Squeezed in the middle are older people whose care depends on these issues being satisfactorily resolved.

Publishing national minimum standards is an important milestone. Let's ensure that they don't become a millstone consigning more homes to closure with a narrowing of choice for consumers.

 Les Bright is deputy chief executive of Counsel and Care, a registered charity providing information, advice and advocacy for older people and their families. It also conducts research, publishes the findings and seeks to influence policy and practice.

fields.headline: Web whizz plans legal version of Napster
fields.trailText:
8.30am: A British entrepreneur is close to launching an online music-swapping service called Wippit, writes Amy Vickers.
Mar 7: Napster fails to satisfy court
Mar 6: Vivendi gives Napster hope
Feb 21: Napster to settle copyright case
fields.body:
A respected British internet entrepreneur is launching an online music-swapping service that is close to securing record company backing.

Paul Myers is making his audacious move just as well-publicised rival Napster faces closure.

The courts ruled that Napster's service - which offered free copies of millions of tracks from artists ranging from Madonna to the Beatles - was "bootlegging".

Mr Myers is the founder of X-Stream, the UK's first free internet service provider.

He has just signed a key technology deal that will allow music lovers to download their favourite tracks legally.

He claims he has already received an enthusiastic response from record companies.

Mr Myers's deal with technology company Cantametrix means royalty payments to record companies and artists can be carried out automatically - something Napster could not do.

Mr Myers has yet to get the record companies to commit to his Napster-like service, to be called Wippit.

However, he said he was involved in early negotiations with all the players and expected to be able to announce "a bunch of independents" within weeks.

He expects Wippit, which is being tested by users, to be ready to launch by the end of May.

Mr Myers, who is widely respected, is confident of the venture's success. "Resistance is futile - the record companies realise the market is changing rapidly," he said.

"Every day, billions of downloads are going on and denying this is like locking the park gates to keep the crows in."

The new technology means Wippit users will have access to whole, easily identifiable tracks and every download is logged and paid for.

"Not only can we identify correctly each recording, we have a viable system to ensure a payment is made," said Mr Myers.

To pay the royalties, Wippit will charge an annual fee of between £35 and £50. For that price, users will receive an unlimited number of music downloads.

Meanwhile, Napster continues to dominate the headlines.

Mr Myers, along with other music experts, expects Napster to close down, especially now it has been given three days to rid itself of all illegal material.

Related stories

Mar 6: Vivendi gives Napster hope
Feb 21: Napster to settle copyright case

fields.body:
European football's governing body UEFA is close to appointing a UK web agency to revamp its website for next year's Champions League.

Former Freeserve managing director Julian Hardy has resurfaced as head of start-up software company X-Imp.

MSN UK has signed a number of marketing deals with dating website Match.com.

Search engine Webtop has made 15 of its 50 staff redundant to cut costs.

Clothing brand Pringle is launching an international website this week but presumably not at Pringle.com - it doesn't own the URL.

Carlton Interactive will use product placement and "in-game ads" on its new site for Crossroads.

fields.headline: Have fibre, won't travel
fields.standfirst:
Most people think the term 'broadband' means something to do with listening to the radio. Victor Keegan shows it is much more
More net news
fields.trailText: Most people think the term 'broadband' means something to do with listening to the radio. Victor Keegan shows it is much more
fields.body:
Ruskin Kerslake, aged 26, has just been propelled by accident into the vanguard of Britain's information revolution. He is probably the first person in the country to have their apartment wired with ultra-fast fibre optic cable - the Holy Grail of the "broadband" digital age. This is because he happens to live in a large block of flats in central London which NTL, the cable company, is fitting with fibre as a showcase for what the future could look like. Kerslake happened to be the first to be connected. This enables his computer, a laptop, to send and receive data at nearly 40 times the speed of a standard 56k modem and with the potential to go ten or fifteen times faster than that.

He describes the experience as "brilliant" and claims it has changed the way he does business. Now he is hooked. If he moves home, he says, it will have to be to another with a fibre link.

A fast link is tailor-made for the job he does. He is a sales engineer for an international company selling CRM (customer relationship management) software packages. When he used to send demonstration packages using up 10MB (megabytes) online to customers it used to take hours which would stop him doing anything else, even sending email, during that period. Now he can send large amounts of data quickly and carry on emailing.

Recently he was providing support for an order the company was chasing in Eastern Europe. Normally he would have had to send his passport to be approved and then fly there - taking up four or five days. But with the fast link he was able to demonstrate the product online. This saved his company all that time enabling him to do other things. The only limiting factor, he said, was the poor quality of the phone line at the other end. The company won a similar contract in Sweden without him having to leave his small apartment in Dolphin Square.

Most of the time he is now travelling or working from home. He only goes into the office once or twice a week. He says: "Since being wired up, the time I have spent at home has increased. I can be up and working at 8am instead of being on a train. I haven't lost any productivity recently through train delays. It is the biggest benefit in my working life - but it also underlines the importance of going into the office and seeing colleagues."

He can also set up an international conferencing facility enabling him to talk to or message groups of colleagues and clients around the world simultaneously thereby avoiding the need - and the cost - of all of them flying to a mutually convenient airport hotel. Each of the participants has a colour code on screen to confirm that they are still there. This avoids a situation in which one of them carries on talking for an hour not realising there is no one at the other end.

He adds: "The only real problem is remembering to turn it off. Otherwise working for a global company becomes a 24 hour a day job. It is so easy to leave it on and rush over to it whenever the email pings."

There are compensations. The high-speed connection enables him to download music from Napster, the US file-swapping service, almost instantaneously instead of having to wait ages. This enables him to have music while he works. And judging by the pressures of the online work load, it sounds as though he needs it.

Despite Kerslake's enthusiasm, broadband connectivity isn't exactly the new rock 'n' roll. A recent survey for NTL found that 70% of the population had not even heard of the word and 30% of those who had heard of it thought it referred to radio. Yet the quest to deliver broadband - capable of high speed video transmission - to every home has been the ultimate objective of the information revolution.

It has been a long time coming. In 1986, the government set up the Macdonald committee to decide how it should be done. Two years later - surprise, surprise in the Thatcher era - it concluded that the future of communications in the UK should be left to market forces not Grand Design.

It ruled out the alternative of allowing BT to spend up to £20 billion to build a national fibre optic grid - the Rolls-Royce version of broadband - in exchange for being allowed to deliver entertainment (meaning video on demand). The main reason for not considering this proposition was that it would have enhanced the monopoly position of BT at a time when the government was trying to encourage competition from the fledgling cable companies. Cynics wondered whether the Thatcher government would have turned down a national grid for electricity as not being practical politics.

About the same time, Ian Mackintosh wrote an influential book (Sunrise Europe) advocating a transnational broadband grid for the whole of Europe: this was intended to kick start the digital revolution and give Europe a platform from which to exploit the fruits of the revolution around the world.

Remember, in those days the world wide web wasn't even remotely on anyone's horizon. All the talk was about building what Al Gore dubbed (or at least popularised) the "information highway" or high speed links between computers.

Now, 15 years later, broadband in its various guises (cable modems, ADSL and fibre optics) is only just being rolled out on a national scale. It is only within the past few weeks that fibre optic links all the way to the home have been installed in the UK in a real-world situation. And that is just in one - admittedly large - block of flats.

Even when installed, broadband won't wield its true magic until most of the population has it. It is the old story. One mobile phone (or fax machine) is useless. But the more people sign up the greater the network effects. Once every citizen has the capacity to video phone each other then it could truly revolutionise entertainment, education and business.

The "killer application" for the new technology may well be a service that doesn't even exist at the moment. Who ever thought that the capacity to send text messages from a mobile (put in as an afterthought) would become the fastest growing service in recent memory?

At the moment we are in a chicken and egg situation. Software companies aren't writing applications for true broadband because not enough people are on it. At the same time consumers aren't buying in sufficient numbers to bring the price down because they can't see the applications.

Today, Online offers a taste of what is to come by sampling three different ways of experiencing broadband. It will all look different in another 15 years.

High speed internet access for consumers

Now

Dial-up modems Speed: 56k. Price: £0-20, various suppliers.

It is how the bulk of home users log on. Connections are dialled up, and the low speed means limited audio and video.

ISDN Speed: 128k. Price: £27 from BT (www.bt.com).

Marketed as Home Highway by BT, ISDN now looks poor value and ready to die a lingering death. Twice the speed of dial-up, but you still have to pay call charges.

DSL (Digital Subscriber Line) Speed: 500k - 2000k. Price: £40 - £160, various suppliers.

Ten times faster than dial-up, and always on. Technical problems, and BT reluctance, means it is not as widespread as you might hope. There is also a waiting list for installation.

Cable modems Speed: up to 512k. Price: £20, NTL and Telewest (Blue Yonder).

The cheapest way to get broadband, but only an option for those who live in cabled areas. Speed depends on how many neighbours are logged on. Cable firms also do not have a great reputation for customer service.

URLs: www.btopenworld.co.uk , www.ntl.com , www.blueyonder.co.uk

Future

Fibre Speed: up to 100,000k Price: unknown.

The Holy Grail of broadband, completely eradicating the traditional bottleneck between your computer and the net.

Third generation mobile (UMTS) Speed: 300k - 2000k. Price: unknown, five successful bidders in UK.

Bidders blew £22.5bn last year to buy the right to offer 3G mobile telephone services to the UK. Now they've got to make the technology work. If they do, it could deliver video and the internet to your mobile phone. Costs may be high because of last year's government auction.

Fixed wireless Speed: up to 5000k. Price: unknown, various suppliers.

Put a receiver on an outside wall, wire it into your PC and enjoy super-fast net access, goes the wireless dream. A lacklustre government auction last year for frequency created doubts, however, that wireless will be offered to much of the population.

fields.headline: Rebel with a cable
fields.standfirst:
Instant connection at a low cost. David Birch sings the praises
More net news
fields.trailText: Instant connection at a low cost. David Birch sings the praises
fields.body:
I am now in the vanguard of the broadband revolution. Last month, I had a cable modem installed for my home computer. This came after nine months of waiting for BT to install ADSL. Finally, BT told me I couldn't have it because I live too far away from an exchange. Apparently my neighbourhood in north-west Surrey is destined to be left behind on the internet superhighway.

Frustrated, I telephoned my cable company, NTL, and was astonished to hear they not only had a broadband internet product for home users, but said they could install it in a week. I was even more flabbergasted when they did. A man in a van turned up - on time - and in less than an hour, I was up and running.

The service is permanently on line. It costs £24.99 a month, including modem rental, and there are no call charges. The modem acts like a long piece of wire connecting my Macintosh to the internet via an Ethernet port. The setup was seamless. I just flipped my Mac's TCP/IP connection from PPP to Ethernet via DHCP Server and it worked first time.

My reason for wanting broadband - apart from my nature as an early adopter of everything - was speed. I often work from home and send huge PowerPoint and Word documents back and forth via email, as well as downloading documents from the web.

True, I appreciate the extra bandwidth. Now, when I need a home file for the office, there's no messing around with Zip disks. I simply connect to my home machine from work and get the file I want. But speed itself has turned out to be less life-changing than the fast - or rather, instant - connection time and the low cost.

Now that my home computer is permanently connected to the internet, it has become an extension of my computer. It's like having a large hard disk available at all times. I've stopped downloading documents to store on my system, and started saving just the links. When I need a software upgrade, a game patch, or a new device driver, I start downloading and get on with something else.

Since I'm no longer waiting for connection, I use my PC to find out things that used to involve phone calls or flipping through the newspaper, such as what's on TV, whether I've paid my Visa bill, and what kind of washing machines are on sale at Currys.

But I have made a sobering discovery. Instant access cannot make up for old-fashioned human error. I have not been able to check my online banking account because I seem to have forgotten my password. I will have to make a phone call to straighten that out. Oh, well.

Here are a couple of recent "always on" behaviour modifications that strike me as interesting. I have started listening to Radio 5 on the internet. I still listen to Radio 4 on the radio, since it is FM stereo and the reception is good. But Radio 5 is medium wave and poor quality, so it comes through clearer on the internet. I'm still annoyed that I can't listen to football on Saturday afternoon this way. Another audio example is Napster: more than once during the week I have used it to download tracks that I own because I am too lazy to search for them in another room.

The early experiences gained from the transition to broadband suggest some thing about the impending transition from 9.6kbps GSM circuit-switched data (eg, current Wap services) to the world of next generation high-speed mobile phone services. I predict it won't be the bandwidth that is the driver (hence my scepticism about video as the major revenue stream for mobile operators), but the fact that connection is instant and has low marginal cost. With a permanent connection, for example, why store phone numbers in your phone? If your phone is permanently connected, you might as well leave the phone numbers on your PC at home: the phone can get them whenever it needs them. The entire internet will seem as if it is stored on your handset.

Even though £24.99 a month for instant connectivity may seem reasonable, it's worth remembering that we pay about a third more in Britain for broadband access than users in the US or even Germany, due to a lack of competition at the retail level.

I may be in the vanguard for some time. Despite all the hype about DSL, cable modems, and other broadband technologies, most internet users will be stuck with low-speed, dial-up modems for the foreseeable future.

webTitle: Festival falls to foot and mouth

fields.headline: Festival falls to foot and mouth
fields.standfirst:
Cheltenham will move to April after sheep cause postponement
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The Cheltenham Festival was last night called off after it was found the course could not meet new requirements laid down by the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food .
fields.body:
The Cheltenham Festival was last night called off after it was found the course could not meet new requirements laid down by the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food .

On Monday, the ministry ruled that meetings could not be held on land that had been used to graze livestock within the previous 28 days. That figure, upped from 14 days, meant that the festival had to be postponed because sheep were grazing on the Prestbury Park course until the middle of last month.

The British Horseracing Board said last night that attempts would be made to hold the multimillion-pound meeting in April, either extending the Cheltenham meeting at present schemed in for April 18-19 or holding the festival the following week.

Edward Gillespie, Cheltenham's managing director, apologised to owners, trainers and the 150,000 racegoers who had booked tickets.

"This is a most unexpected and dreadful blow for everyone who has been preparing their horses and planning to come to Cheltenham next week," he said. "I know this will be an enormous disappointment to the entire racing community."

Gillespie continued: "We were confident of achieving all the precautions required, but when the rule regarding livestock was changed we found we could no longer comply with the instruction.

"It was of paramount importance that the meeting would only go ahead with the full compliance of the instructions. We had no option but to abide by this ruling."

There was a possibility that the festival could have gone ahead next week almost as planned, because the 28-day exclusion period expires on March 15, the day of the Gold Cup. The option to tack the first two days on after Gold Cup day, on the Friday and Saturday, was discussed but rejected by the BHB.

Tristram Ricketts, the board's secretary general, said: "BHB was of the view that it is not in the interests of racing as a whole to re-stage the fixture in the days immediately following the existing programme days. The BHB continues to act with the utmost care and has therefore decided that the fixture should be postponed."

Cheltenham's efforts to press on with the festival in the middle of the escalating foot and mouth crisis split racing opinion down the middle.

Irish trainers had already decided not to run their horses and France was considering doing the same although, ironically, the French authorities yesterday looked set to allow their horses to travel.

After a seven-day ban, racing resumed at Lingfield yesterday under strict guidelines laid down by the BHB and the Jockey Club in conjunction with Maff.

Bookmakers will wait for clarification of the conditions surrounding the postponement of the Festival before deciding on the possible refund of ante-post stakes, although they had already agreed to return stakes on Irish-trained runners because of the exceptional circumstances.

"If the races remain open only to the original entries then all bets stand," said William Hill's spokesman David Hood. "But if the races are completely reopened it is likely all bets are void and everyone starts afresh."

The loss of Cheltenham, where a massive turnover is guaranteed, is a major blow to the bookmaking industry and business would not be the same at a rescheduled date.

Whether the thousands of punters who have already paid for tickets and inclusive packages for the meeting would be compensated was last night unclear, but the BHB may announce refunds at a press conference today.

Racing loses out through a serious loss of levy. The Grand National generates about £750,000 in levy turnover each year and Cheltenham comes close to that figur,e according to the Levy Board chief executive Rodney Brack.

Cheltenham itself is heavily insured against loss. "Finance is not a factor to us," said Gillespie last week. But with the racecourse profiting by £4.5m on a turnover of £10m, there is no substitute for those three days in March.
