We did a survey of singles in the UK and found that more than half felt they could fall in love with someone they met online. I call it falling in love from the inside out. As we as consumers get our needs met more easily, quickly and efficiently, we'll begin to derive real benefits from, and see the real promise of, the net. Is online dating capturing the imagination of the net community? Online dating has definitely come of age. In 1995 the concept was not necessarily understood and probably even deemed questionable. We've come to see that it's a sound business model - probably one of the better ones out there. Match.com is a subscription-based model. Our members can use many of the site's features free, including posting a profile, finding matches, reading and responding to dating-related content and attending some of our off-line events. If they wish to contact a match they subscribe. Fees are a month for £17, six months for £50 or a year for £68. We've registered more than five million members, and have around 1.5m users on the site now, with at least 37,000 in the UK. We're registering around 14,000 new users a day. Do you feel the net is still male orientated? I think that's changing. Among my peers I see more and more women getting online. I think it's still a case of "if you build it they will come". If there's content and services available for women online that meet their needs, they will log on. When we launched Match.com in 1995, only around 10% of the demographic of the net were women, whereas it's now risen to about 40%. Is there a difference in surfing habits between genders? I think women use the net to make their day-to-day life easier. Their approach is practical. We book travel online, we date, we shop and do research online. I have a toddler and I'm constantly online answering the questions that a toddler asks, like "how does a fish breathe?". Men derive practical benefits, too, but I also think they have more fun online. They enjoy playing games and surfing to see what they come up with. Any favourite places on the net? Because of my toddler I'm constantly going to Ask Jeeves (www.askjeeves.com/ ). I use My Yahoo (my.yahoo.com/) everyday for stocks, movies and so on and I book my travel through Expedia (www.expedia.com). Visit www.match.com

fields.headline: Web watch
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Global Google | Mir re-entry
fields.body:
Global Google

Google, the web's best search engine, has silently opened a UK site (www.google.co.uk). You can click a radio button to restrict searches to UK pages. There are other international versions too, such as www.google.de and www.google.fr , though www.google.dk is a bookstore. Google has also launched an i-mode service, for users of Japan's mobile phone system, which you can find at www.google.com/imode.

Spaced out

Some of the people who live in the South Pacific may see an unusual and very expensive firework during the next week, when Russia's Mir space station re-enters the Earth's atmosphere. But for the best view, an expedition plans to observe the re-entry from a chartered plane flying at 25,000 feet.

Details are on the website at www.mirreentry.com, along with a history of Mir and a QuickTime movie simulation of its expected destruction.

Cool dudes

Online columnist Douglas Rushkoff, who teaches media culture at New York University, has been interviewing people who create and flog popular culture to teenagers for America's PBS public broadcasting television network. The Merchants of Cool programme also has a website at www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/cool/.

Although mostly text, the website does include some RealPlayer video clips to download.

Yippie-yi-yo

Country and western songs are not likely to get many mentions here, but check out the chorus: "My dot com done come and gone/The wheels came off and it didn't take long/All that venture capital's spent/And our website didn't even make a cent."

Rick Glaze is no rhinestone cowboy, but a business analyst with the ambition to become a Silicon Cowboy - which happens to be the title of his first CD.

Lyrics and samples are at www.siliconcowboyonline.com

Search and see

Here is an idea whose time has manifestly not come, at least in the UK. Room 102 (www.room102.com) is a search engine/directory that also serves up images of the sites it finds. You can have them in high bandwidth, low bandwidth or thumbnail format, unless you want plain text.

The directory is the familiar Open Directory, Dmoz, which is also used by Google. Room 102 is more of demo: the company hopes to sell its SlideShow technology to every other portal site.

Code 404

It is a crushing indictment that many whole web sites are less interesting than some people's error pages, for which the code is 404. See whateverhost.com/404.htm, for example, or www.cga94.com/notHere.htm for a short, sharp shock.

If you want more, Jenni Ripley (mentioned here before) is still collecting error pages at www.plinko.net/404/. Don't forget to try her effort www.plinko.net/404/404.htm

Uncool droids

Warner Brothers has released a "teaser trailer" and poster for its forthcoming film, Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone: go to harrypotter.warnerbros.com/web/dailyprophet/article.jsp?id=movie_trailer1.

However, no one has forgotten the trail of 15-year-old girls in England, Singapore and the US who have been put under pressure by Warner's lawyers for running Harry Potter fan sites. The fightback is continuing with the Defense Against the Dark Arts (DADA) project organised by Megora McGonagall, the American girl who runs the Daily Prophet fan site (www.dprophet.com); and Potter War (www.potterwar.org.uk ), which is mirrored at www.screamingfist.com/Pwar/.

DADA is running an petition while other young victims are helping to organise a worldwide boycott of Harry Potter merchandise.

New & noted

 The world's greatest thinkers are being packaged at www.boxmind.com

 Doomed? Vote at www.dotdoomed.com on whether companies are hot or not.

 The red nose's home on the web at www.comicrelief.com is hungry for money.

 Don't forget: the next commercial web event in the UK is Mother's Day on March 25; www.interflora.co.uk/mothers is just the start.

 It plays you: www.majestic.ea.com

webTitle: Minister pledges to extend firearms ban to replicas

fields.headline: Minister pledges to extend firearms ban to replicas
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: The ban on handguns is to be extended to replica firearms, amid police fears of a new trend among teenagers to carry such "weapons", the Home Office minister, Charles Clarke, said yesterday.
fields.body:
The ban on handguns is to be extended to replica firearms, amid police fears of a new trend among teenagers to carry such "weapons", the Home Office minister, Charles Clarke, said yesterday.

He was opening an exhibition at the Houses of Parliament of more than 30 replica weapons, including a deactivated Uzi machine pistol, an SA-80 assault rifle and handguns.

"Our aim is to get to a position where replica firearms are banned," said Mr Clarke. "But the definition of what is a replica firearm is a question that needs careful consideration. Would toys of a much smaller size than the real thing fall under such a ban, and what about the kind of imitation that is used on stage?"

The exhibition was staged by the Gun Control Network, which campaigned for the ban on handguns after the Dunblane school massacre. The group claims that imitation weapons pose a real threat and are freely available by mail order and in some toy shops and army surplus stores.

Gill Marshall-Andrews, its chairwoman, welcomed the government's backing for its latest campaign but called for legislation. "We do want to see something happening about this soon. The proliferation of these weapons is alarming."

Commander Mike Fuller of the Metropolitan police's anti-firearms Operation Trident, said: "One undesirable trend we are seeing is young people carrying these imitation and replica firearms as fashion accessories. It's an unhealthy fashion, but there is a cultural aspect to it within a section of black youths who follow 'gangster rap' and that type of music."

He said the Met supported a ban on replica firearms being carried in public places but acknowledged that legislation would have to be carefully drafted to enforce the ban.

A Home Office spokeswoman said a ban was unlikely to involve plastic toys such as water pistols: "What we are most concerned about is replicas which look like real guns with anything short of a close inspection."

Gun sports enthusiasts claim that gun crime has risen since the ban on handguns was imposed in 1997. They cite official figures showing that gun crime rose to a peak in 1999-00 when 42 people were shot dead and guns were used in nearly 3,700 crimes.

fields.headline: Second sight
fields.standfirst:
eToys' move sends a shiver down the spine, says Victor Keegan
More net news
fields.trailText: eToys' move sends a shiver down the spine, says Victor Keegan
fields.body:
Last week's decision by eToys, the US online toy company, to file for bankruptcy ought to send a shiver down the spines of all remaining dot.com companies. eToys is the biggest casualty yet and the most worrying. It was once valued at an unbelievable $12bn on the stock market. Now it is worth nothing. Until recently it was possible to regard the shakeout as nothing more than the inevitable consequences of the predictable attrition rate among new companies - some 50% of which fail in their first four years. Now it is beginning to look systemic.

If nothing else, the fate of eToys ought to blow apart the strange proposition that was all too freely adopted as part of internet business folklore: that first movers had an advantage. It was never true before the net came along (ask Microsoft, Dell or Compaq).

Second movers usually have the advantage because they capitalise on the mistakes of the innovators. That is why Britain fought beneath her weight for most of the post-war years as others developed the inventions we failed to exploit ourselves. Second-mover status gave Japan a huge competitive advantage as her industry improved on the designs of others - at least until the last decade when internal financial problems put the Japanese miracle into cold storage.

But the worry now is not that eToys failed because it was an inexperienced first mover, but because the business model that it and thousands of others adopted was itself fatally flawed. The internet is not an obvious place to make a fortune out of selling old economy goods. Why?Because consumers expect rock-bottom prices while the company is still landed with the huge costs of marketing (including making itself known to the public) and delivery. It is a great model for me as a customer but not for the company trying to sell to me.

It is different, of course, if you are selling new economy goods such as music or books that can be digitised and sent down the telephone as ones and zeros. In that case the middle person is definitely being shut out (though not entirely, because online sales breed new kinds of intermediaries such as streamers).

It is fairly easy to sell commoditised old economy goods you don't need to touch and feel - like books and wine - from the web, especially when there are valued-added services such as search engines to guide you to products you like. But this may not guarantee survival because canny customers can use the search engine then buy from the cheapest source elsewhere.

The interesting question is what eToys may be telling us about Amazon's chances of survival. Amazon, the world's biggest book store, is a brilliant site for customers, up there with the very best. It has been fleet of foot and innovative - even if too heavy-handed in its interpretation of intellectual property rights.

But that doesn't make it a viable long-term proposition. At the moment there is no imminent danger because Amazon has still got warehousefuls of money in the bank, thanks to the booty from earlier capital-raising exercises.

This raises the new paradox of business-to-consumer (B2C) web companies that applies as much to Britain's Lastminute.com as to Amazon. Many of them only exist today on the back of money raised on the capital markets a year or more back. But it would never have been given had investors known then what they know now about the viability of the B2C business model.

Amazon, like so many other web companies, is in a race to secure enough market dominance to be able to raise charges before it burns its way through its legacy money. Others are gobbling up competitors or forging links or mergers with old economy companies in order to survive.

Some, like Confetti.com, the one-stop wedding services company, are doing both. It has taken over its main competitors and an old-economy catalogue company. Last week Sir Bob Geldof's Deckchair travel company laid off a third of its staff to seek a link with a rival online company. Part of the problem facing companies like Deckchair is that airtravel companies such as easyJet and Go have successfully cut out the middleperson by selling straight to customers.

It could be argued that Amazon itself only exists because of the failure of publishers to get their act together by selling books directly to the public and cutting out the intermediaries. No one, ultimately, can sell books more cheaply than the publisher (or author).

This year will see an acceleration of three trends. First, online companies will continue to gobble each other up to get as close as they can to a monopoly position so they can increase prices. Second, there will be "second generation" internet companies built to exploit the inherent strengths of the web rather than selling old economy goods in a different way.

Third, old economy companies will pick up the remains of the failed dot.coms at bargain prices to provide an extra outlet (and shop window) for their wares.

The most dramatic recent example is the John Lewis partnership. It was rather slow to embrace the net (unlike its subsidiary, Waitrose) but has now been catapulted into the vanguard by its take-over of the UK arm of the troubled US e-tailer, Buy.com.

In this way, the online companies that were supposed to replace old economy monoliths will in fact be swallowed by them once they have got their act together.

We have been here before. Remember how the Today newspaper, the pioneer of new technology, was going to change the face of the newspaper industry? It did. It forced the rest of the industry to adopt the new technology much earlier than it would otherwise have done. Today closed down and the late adopters flourished.

No one is talking much about first-mover advantage in the newspaper industry.

fields.headline: 15-year term for death crash driver
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: An unrepentant motorist who killed six people in a car crash after drinking 13 pints was yesterday handed the longest sentence in British legal history for causing death by dangerous driving.
fields.body:
An unrepentant motorist who killed six people in a car crash after drinking 13 pints was yesterday handed the longest sentence in British legal history for causing death by dangerous driving.

Peter Noble, 39, who denied the offence, was jailed for 15 years, a sentence welcomed by road safety groups.

But relatives of the victims said the sentence should have been longer. Jamie Holmes, 21, whose mother, Diane, and grandparents, Roy and Audrey, were killed when Noble's Land Cruiser hit their Daewoo on their way home from a birthday party, said: "We have all got life sentences."

Noble, a former demolition foreman, lied repeatedly throughout the inquiry after the crash near Sheffield. He even tried to shift the blame for the crash on one of the three passengers who died in his Land Cruiser: John Hayward, 42. The other two victims were David Wood, 35, and Dennis Royston, 36.

Judge Alan Goldsack QC said as he jailed Noble at Sheffield crown court that he had shown "breathtaking arrogance in the witness box and failing to show the slightest signs of remorse".

Noble, of Thorpe Salvin near Rotherham, had told the jury: "If I hadn't had any drink at all I could not have done any more. I did not feel out of control or drunk. I felt sure of myself and safe."

He also admitted that the accident had happened while he was banned for four years over a previous drink driving offence.

The court heard that he had run away after being cut from his car by firefighters at Kiveton Park, South Yorkshire, and then snared his teenage son and ex-girlfriend into plotting a cover story.

Rachel Renshaw, 30, whom he contacted by mobile after the crash, was sentenced to 180 hours' community service. Carl Noble, 19, who took him a change of clothing at his hideout at his sister's house, was given a conditional discharge.

webTitle: Disability ruling spells ruin for ex-Met man

fields.headline: Disability ruling spells ruin for ex-Met man
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: A respected officer who had a nervous breakdown after 28 years of unblemished service with the Metropolitan police is facing financial ruin after a test case ruling that he is not entitled to a disability pension.
fields.body:
A respected officer who had a nervous breakdown after 28 years of unblemished service with the Metropolitan police is facing financial ruin after a test case ruling that he is not entitled to a disability pension.

The decision of the appeal court overturned a judgment that entitled Eric Stunt to backdated pay of up to £20,000 and leaves him facing legal costs of up to £50,000.

Mr Stunt, 59, said yesterday: "I will have to sell my home. My savings have gone. I cannot understand why the Met has treated me this way."

The ruling could have significant consequences for the emergency services, because the court supported a view that Mr Stunt's breakdown had not been sustained during "the execution of his duties".

He claimed that the illness, which forced him into early retirement in August 1994, was the direct result of intolerable pressure from an unwarranted complaint against him. A doctor certified that he was "permanently disabled by depression".

Mr Stunt had been regarded by the Met as a valued and experienced officer who had chosen not to seek promotion because he enjoyed working on the beat.

He was first on the scene of the Irish National Liberation Army bomb that killed the Tory MP Airey Neave at the House of Commons in March 1979, cradling the shadow cabinet member in his arms as his life slipped away, even though there was a risk of a secondary explosion. Mr Stunt said the sight of Mr Neave, whose legs had been blown off and who was gargling blood, would remain with him for ever.

An incident on July 9 1993 proved the turning point in his career. He arrested a headmaster at the St Stephen's Gate entrance of the Palace of Westminster who, he claimed, had become abusive because he was not allowed to "queue barge".

Three weeks later Mr Stunt was informed that the teacher had made a formal complaint against him, triggering an investigation.

The crown prosecution service dismissed the case, saying there was no basis for charges, and a police complaints authority review concluded no further action should be taken against him.

While the complaint hung over his head, his health deteriorated sharply. A consultant psychiatrist described how Mr Stunt felt he was being "treated like a criminal". "He felt a mixture of anger, frustration and hopelessness at fighting against a seemingly implacable system."

Mr Stunt said yesterday: "I saw my whole career being put on the line because of an unfounded complaint against me. I was a good, respected officer, and I found the experience of the internal investigation extremely oppressive."

Mr Stunt applied for an injury award pension, which would have topped up his allowance by up to £300 a month. "I missed reaching my 30 years in service, which would have given me a full pension," he said.

The high court ruled last May that he was entitled to the injury award allowance. The Met challenged the decision, and the appeal judges ruled last month that the investigation which brought on his depression did not constitute normal "police duty".

A Met statement said Mr Stunt "was merely subject to normal disciplinary procedures. In order to obtain an enhanced pay it was necessary to show that he was injured in the execution of his duties".

The decision of the appeal court overturned a judgment that entitled Eric Stunt to backdated pay of up to £20,000 and leaves him facing legal costs of up to £50,000. Mr Stunt, 59, said yesterday: "I will have to sell my home. My savings have gone. I cannot understand why the Met has treated me this way." The ruling could have significant consequences for the emergency services, because the court supported a view that Mr Stunt's breakdown had not been sustained during "the execution of his duties". He claimed that the illness, which forced him into early retirement in August 1994, was the direct result of intolerable pressure from an unwarranted complaint against him. A doctor certified that he was "permanently disabled by depression". Mr Stunt had been regarded by the Met as a valued and experienced officer who had chosen not to seek promotion because he enjoyed working on the beat. He was first on the scene of the Irish National Liberation Army bomb that killed the Tory MP Airey Neave at the House of Commons in March 1979, cradling the shadow cabinet member in his arms as his life slipped away, even though there was a risk of a secondary explosion. Mr Stunt said the sight of Mr Neave, whose legs had been blown off and who was gargling blood, would remain with him for ever. An incident on July 9 1993 proved the turning point in his career. He arrested a headmaster at the St Stephen's Gate entrance of the Palace of Westminster who, he claimed, had become abusive because he was not allowed to "queue barge". Three weeks later Mr Stunt was informed that the teacher had made a formal complaint against him, triggering an investigation. The crown prosecution service dismissed the case, saying there was no basis for charges, and a police complaints authority review concluded no further action should be taken against him. While the complaint hung over his head, his health deteriorated sharply. A consultant psychiatrist described how Mr Stunt felt he was being "treated like a criminal". "He felt a mixture of anger, frustration and hopelessness at fighting against a seemingly implacable system." Mr Stunt said yesterday: "I saw my whole career being put on the line because of an unfounded complaint against me. I was a good, respected officer, and I found the experience of the internal investigation extremely oppressive." Mr Stunt applied for an injury award pension, which would have topped up his allowance by up to £300 a month. "I missed reaching my 30 years in service, which would have given me a full pension," he said. The high court ruled last May that he was entitled to the injury award allowance. The Met challenged the decision, and the appeal judges ruled last month that the investigation which brought on his depression did not constitute normal "police duty". A Met statement said Mr Stunt "was merely subject to normal disciplinary procedures. In order to obtain an enhanced pay it was necessary to show that he was injured in the execution of his duties".

fields.headline: I'm your cigarette packet, can we have a little chat?
fields.standfirst: Special report: smoking
fields.trailText: For smokers still in doubt about the health risks involved in each puff, a loud reminder is on the way. Molins, one of Britain's leading suppliers to the tobacco industry, has secretly developed a cigarette packet that talks.
fields.body:
For smokers still in doubt about the health risks involved in each puff, a loud reminder is on the way. Molins, one of Britain's leading suppliers to the tobacco industry, has secretly developed a cigarette packet that talks.

The firm has applied for a patent for the idea, which was developed by engineers at its Coventry research centre. A tiny speaker concealed within the packet is activated each time the lid is opened.

New Scientist magazine, which discovered the unpublicised patent application, reports this week that the speaker could deliver a cancer warning "in any of several languages". Alternatively, it could play a tune, such as the funeral march or the Police hit Every Breath You Take.

Molins' finance director, David Cowen, said: "It's quite a neat idea which may or may not have a commercial use."

The company supplies machines used in the production of cigarettes. Its customers include the world's top tobacco companies, including British American Tobacco, Gallaher and Imperial Tobacco.

Mr Cowen admitted that the idea of a singing cigarette packet might get a cool reception from the major manufacturers. "I think it's unlikely that the funeral march is what customers would want."

The concept is a long way from reaching newsagents' shelves. He said: "We don't have a patent yet - that's a process which can take up to four years. This is one of many applications filed by Molins. It's just an idea, developed in the normal course of business."

There was a muted response yesterday from the tobacco industry, which is already smouldering this week from a decision by the European Union to increase the size of written health warnings on packets.

A spokesman for BAT said: "We've not seen this box yet so it's difficult to comment. But if we were approached, I'm sure we'd look at it."

Gallaher, best known for Benson & Hedges and Silk Cut, said: "We're not going to comment on another company's patent ideas."

Anti-smoking activists were more positive. Amanda Sandford of Action on Smoking and Health said: "A tinny voice telling you to quit smoking is a bit gimmicky. I'm not sure people would take it seriously. But if it does ever come to fruition, it wouldn't be such a bad idea."

She added: "I can't see it happening if it's left to the industry to do voluntarily. They would have to make audible health warnings compulsory."

The technology used in the gadget is similar to devices used in talking greetings cards. A stiff plastic strip is stuck on the hinged lid of the cigarette packet. When extended, this activates a microchip, which powers a tiny microphone hidden in the base.

Smokers have some experience of noisy devices: musical lighters have been available for many years.

Molins, which has its headquarters in Milton Keynes, hit hard times in the 1990s when the south-east Asian economic crisis triggered sharp cutbacks in the tobacco industry.

Although its main business is supplying the tobacco industry, the firm also makes machines for other purposes. It hit the headlines in 1996 by coming up with the technology to make the world's first pyramid-shaped tea bag, the PG Tips tetrahedron.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText:
• A childishly contrived case of mistaken identity as we call the Vaudeville Theatre to ask David Yelland how he is managing to moonlight opposite Derek Jacobi in the forthcoming play God Only Knows. "You scurrilous lot!" exclaims the actor who shares the alopecian Sun editor's name."I'm delighted to go under the same name. Actually, David Yelland wrote to me when he was working for the New York Post and I was doing An Ideal Husband on Broadway. 
'Here we are, two Englishmen in New York with the same name,' he said. 'We really should meet up.' Lovely, I thought." Lovely indeed, if not quite in keeping with the frontier spirit of David's hilarious leaders on America. "But I was too busy," remembers our other David Yelland wistfully, "and I rather regret we never met."

 A childishly contrived case of mistaken identity as we call the Vaudeville Theatre to ask David Yelland how he is managing to moonlight opposite Derek Jacobi in the forthcoming play God Only Knows. "You scurrilous lot!" exclaims the actor who shares the alopecian Sun editor's name."I'm delighted to go under the same name. Actually, David Yelland wrote to me when he was working for the New York Post and I was doing An Ideal Husband on Broadway. 'Here we are, two Englishmen in New York with the same name,' he said. 'We really should meet up.' Lovely, I thought." Lovely indeed, if not quite in keeping with the frontier spirit of David's hilarious leaders on America. "But I was too busy," remembers our other David Yelland wistfully, "and I rather regret we never met."

Then it must fall to this Diary to play fixer and set up that long-postponed meeting. Should plans to take him to the UK Press Gazette awards in a fortnight fail, surely it could do no harm if, in time-honoured Sun tradition, the alternative David Yelland were invited to edit the paper for a day? Let us know, David Yelland 1.

 Further indications of Little Alan Duncan's special relationship with his constituents (you will remember how those reading only the local Rutland and Melton press remain unaware of the opposition spokesman for trade and industry's links with a Yemeni arms dealer and Clinton-pardoned crook Marc Rich) come with whispers that he has dispensed with regular surgeries in favour of a "by appointment" system.

A call to Alan's lair means we must dice once more with his three-headed assistant Claire, who reluctantly confirms that Alan's surgeries are the political equivalent of the Royal Variety Show. Then quick as a flash she unleashes the interpersonal qualities that caught her employer's eye by refusing to give her surname in a three minute stand-off, before finally hissing "Gagneux" and hanging up. Well done, Claire, you trusty gatekeeper! And well done Alan, for your novel streamlining.

 Pity our farmers if you must, but spare a thought for our soldiers who also suffer from foot and mouth. The regimental mascot of the Royal Fusiliers, a goat called Billy, is in quarantine, and had to miss last week's St David's Day parade. We wish him well.

 Something of a belated foot and mouth special with the news that the description of the area of infection in Devon has been widened to include Widecombe. We ring Ann Widdecombe's press officer, Nicole Hughes, to see if madam might be persuaded to chuck us another morsel from her bottomless pit of unfunny knee-jerk quotes. "I'll have a try for you," promises Nicole.

 Chillingly headed "Bel Mooney Website", the email this Diary has been dreading for some weeks arrives at last. "Any possibility of an explanation as to why your plans for this haven't materialised??" demands the anonymous sender. Lack of strength is the obvious answer, but it's a poor show, so www.bel-mooney.co.uk is reinstated as Website of the Month forthwith. The passage of time means Bel's spat with the Sunday Times magazine over spiked biker copy has been annexed to the Variety Show section of the site, but promising new items include a planned satellite TV show and a stilted reunion with an old school friend. More soon.

 Maddeningly, we are no nearer taking a statement from the Times's managing editor George Brock on his love of country dancing. When we get though to his office, his PA says that George is away in the States until Monday and cannot be reached. Weaving Grand Ol' Right and Lefts with the products of vertical family trees, no doubt? "I've got no idea," she giggles. "He's at a technology conference." Ah well, till Monday, then.

webTitle: Tories urge block on war crimes court

fields.headline: Tories urge block on war crimes court
fields.standfirst: Special report: war crimes in the former Yugoslavia
fields.trailText: The government was yesterday urged to suspend plans to ratify a treaty setting up an international court after military commanders warned it could lead to British troops being prosecuted for war crimes.
fields.body:
The government was yesterday urged to suspend plans to ratify a treaty setting up an international court after military commanders warned it could lead to British troops being prosecuted for war crimes.

Senior officers say the treaty setting up the court - which covers war crimes as well as genocide and crimes against humanity - could also bind British troops into such restrictive rules of engagement that their lives might be put at risk.

A bill incorporating the UN-sponsored treaty into British law is going through the Lords before passing to the Commons. Iain Duncan Smith, the shadow defence secretary, said yesterday, he thought the government should put the issue "on hold and think again about how they proceed."

"The problem is, how does this work against the very people who may themselves have to undertake the necessary military action to do that?

He told BBC Radio 4's The World at One programme that if the court did come into effect there would almost certainly be pressure to prosecute Nato commanders if there was any repeat of incidents like the accidental attack on an Albanian refugee convoy by American warplanes in Kosovo.

Admiral Sir Michael Boyce, chief of defence staff, echoed concerns expressed vigorously in private by his military colleagues, when he told the Commons armed forces bill select committee on Tuesday night he was not opposed "in principle" to the armed forces being subject to the proposed court.

He added: "I think we need to be very careful that, as the bill goes through, we don't put ourselves in a situation where a junior person carrying out orders ends up before the court."

Lawyers for the Ministry of Defence - who were consulted before the bill was drafted - said the concerns expressed by the military were "theoretical". Domestic courts would in the first instance rule on charges made under the new international law and would do so in a sensible way, MoD officials said. However, appeals could be made to the international court.

A spokesman for Amnesty International, which strongly supports the court, said it would provide an "extra layer of protection for military personnel embarking on risky operations like Sierra Leone".

webTitle: Floods kill 75 people as heavy rains return

fields.headline: Floods kill 75 people as heavy rains return
fields.standfirst:
Mozambique thrown back on foreign aid despite careful preparation and fast action
Special report: Mozambique floods
fields.trailText: Mozambique thrown back on foreign aid despite careful preparation and fast action
fields.body:
Rising water on the Zambezi river has killed 75 people and driven 81,000 from their homes, Mozambique's energy minister, Castigo Langa, told parliament in Maputo yesterday. With the country facing a second year of flooding, the Mozambican navy has already moved more than 8,000 stranded people, using rubber boats donated last year.

Adequate warnings, advance planning and the use of the Cahora Bassa dam to control river flows have so far kept casualties down. But rain is continuing in central Mozambique, Malawi and Zambia, the lake behind Cahora Bassa is full, and greater discharges are likely.

At Caia, a major town on the river, the water is three metres above flood level and rising. Low lying parts of all the riverside towns are flooded, and the sugar mill towns in the delta near the sea could soon be submerged.

The authorities evacuated 17,000 people from the isolated riverside town of Inhangoma on Monday as flood waters reached areas previously considered safe. Most of these people are being moved by naval boats, but South African helicopters which arrived at the weekend also lifted out 400 people.

Displaced people need to be supplied with tents, food and water purification kits, but most roads in the Zambezi valley are unpaved, have turned to mud, and are largely impassable. Supplies must be dropped by air, and 16 aircraft are engaged in the task.

The Mozambique air force's only two helicopters have been working in the Zambezi valley for more than a month.

This year's floods are on the Zambezi river in central Mozambique. Last year's floods were on the Limpopo and Incomati rivers in the south of the country. But both are setting records - the Limpopo floods were the worst in 150 years.

Mr Langa told parliament that this year's Zambezi floods are not yet as bad as record floods of 1978, but soon might be.

Both last year and this year, floods were predicted, and Mozambique was prepared and began relief and rescue operations. But Mozambique remains one of the world's poorest countries, and as floods break records and the number of displaced grows, it has been forced to call for international help.

Last year the initial rescues were carried out by the Mozambican navy, Mozambique Red Cross, and private boat owners, who between them saved 29,000 people. Malawian and South African air force helicopters arrived as the floods worsened, and saved 16,000 people. Agencies from industrialised countries saved only 287 people.

This pattern has been repeated, the Mozambican navy and private boat owners carrying out rescues until the crisis worsened and South Africa came in to help. This year, however, Malawi has been hit by its own floods, so is unable to help in Mozambique.

Last year's floods in the south of Mozambique were the worst for 150 years, killing 700 people. This year Mozambique was prepared and started evacuations, but as the water rose, it became clear that it could not cope on its own.

More than 40 accommodation centres have been set up, more aircraft are arriving (including some hired with British aid), and a joint logistics operations centre (JLOC) has been established in Beira, in central Mozambique.

The Disasters Emergencies Committee, a consortium of British aid charities, agreed on Tuesday that money it gave for last year's flood and remained unspent could be used for the latest flood, bringing the amount it has allocated to this years floods to£1.2m.

Villagers fear fleeing

This year the water is rising and help is arriving. Good management of the giant Cahora Bassa dam and coordination with the upstream Kariba dam on the Zimbabwe-Zambia border have delayed the rise of the flood water downstream, allowing more time for evacuation.

A worrying similarity to last year's floods is the refusal of people to abandon their houses and cattle when they are warned that floods are coming. With no insurance, people are very reluctant to lose their meagre possessions. Many of those rescued from trees and roofs last year admitted afterwards that they had been warned but did not believe it.

Joseph Hanlon is the co-author, with Frances Christie, of the book Mozambique and the Great Flood of 2000, published by James Currey (Oxford) this week.

webTitle: Milosevic regime smuggled gold, bank chief says

fields.headline: Milosevic regime smuggled gold, bank chief says
fields.trailText: A group of state-owned Serbian mines illegally exported gold worth £4.3m during Slobodan Milosevic's rule, the Yugoslav central bank governor claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
A group of state-owned Serbian mines illegally exported gold worth £4.3m during Slobodan Milosevic's rule, the Yugoslav central bank governor claimed yesterday.

Mladjan Dinkic said it was not yet clear who had profited from the sale of more than 700kg (1,500lbs) of gold, although a close Milosevic ally was a regular visitor to the mining complex.

The news came as the UN war crimes tribunal in the Hague offered to try Mr Milosevic partly in the Yugoslav capital. The offer, announced in London by a deputy prosecutor, Graham Blewitt, is aimed at ending the impasse with Belgrade, which refuses to extradite him.

He added that an new indictment charging Mr Milosevic with responsibility for war crimes in the Croatian and Bosnian wars, in addition to those relating to the 1999 Kosovo conflict, would be issued soon.

Mr Blewitt said it would be legitimate for Serbia to try the dictator for fraud before he faced the tribunal, if the Serbians were ready first.

Mr Dinkic's allegation followed a request by Serbian prosecutors for the police to investigate reports that Mr Milosevic sold 173kg of gold from the Bor mines in eastern Serbia in Switzerland last year and then deposited the profits abroad.

The companies involved in those deals and the Yugoslav customs service deny that there were irregularities, and Mr Milosevic's supporters insist that the allegation is part of a witch-hunt.

But Mr Dinkic, a key reformist, said that information given by mine officials showed that the Bor mines had sold gold illegally in each of the three years 1998-2000.He suggested that other, hidden, records would reveal much higher amounts.

He said said that none of the evidence gathered so far led back to Mr Milosevic, but a close ally of the former president, the former federal deputy prime minister Nikola Sainovic, was reported to have visited the mine every Friday.

"Whether Sainovic has connections with Milosevic and whether he himself is linked to this still remains to be determined," he said.

The gold sales would have breached the international trade embargo on Yugoslavia if the proceeds had gone to any of the blacklisted bank accounts belonging to Mr Milosevic, his family and aides, or to state companies.

The Yugoslav customs chief, Vladan Begovic, said last week that the gold was processed for foreign firms and did not belong to the mine.

Dr Dinkic said: "There was a de facto abuse in these dealings - false evidence and documentation. It remains to be determined where the money is and who profited from it."

Mr Dinkic's allegation followed a request by Serbian prosecutors for the police to investigate reports that Mr Milosevic sold 173kg of gold from the Bor mines in eastern Serbia in Switzerland last year and then deposited the profits abroad. The companies involved in those deals and the Yugoslav customs service deny that there were irregularities, and Mr Milosevic's supporters insist that the allegation is part of a witch-hunt. But Mr Dinkic, a key reformist, said that information given by mine officials showed that the Bor mines had sold gold illegally in each of the three years 1998-2000.He suggested that other, hidden, records would reveal much higher amounts. He said said that none of the evidence gathered so far led back to Mr Milosevic, but a close ally of the former president, the former federal deputy prime minister Nikola Sainovic, was reported to have visited the mine every Friday. "Whether Sainovic has connections with Milosevic and whether he himself is linked to this still remains to be determined," he said. The gold sales would have breached the international trade embargo on Yugoslavia if the proceeds had gone to any of the blacklisted bank accounts belonging to Mr Milosevic, his family and aides, or to state companies. The Yugoslav customs chief, Vladan Begovic, said last week that the gold was processed for foreign firms and did not belong to the mine. Dr Dinkic said: "There was a de facto abuse in these dealings - false evidence and documentation. It remains to be determined where the money is and who profited from it." Reuters

fields.headline: Fraying thread sales hit Coats
fields.trailText: Coats Viyella is to make further cuts among its 1,500 British textile workers as domestic thread orders tail-off.
fields.body:
Coats Viyella is to make further cuts among its 1,500 British textile workers as domestic thread orders tail-off.

New chief executive Martin Flower said there were fewer UK clothing manufacturers so Coats would have to "realign our capacity as volumes continue to fall".

The group, which has four main industrial thread plants in Britain - in Glasgow, Peterlee, Durham, Belfast and Lisnaskee in Northern Ireland - has been through a huge restructuring which cost it £80.2m over the past 12 months.

Coats sold the rights to the Van Heusen name in Europe and Asia. It continues to hang on to its Jaeger and Viyella retail clothing brands which employ 3,000 staff but made clear these will also go in time.

The company, which is gradually switching thread manufacturing to lower cost countries such as China, announced a profit before tax and exceptionals of £50m compared with a £6m loss last time for the year to December 31.

Sales from continuing operations rose 8% to £1.4bn. Margins on its threads and retail business rose 2%. Its shares ended the day up 1p at 45.25p.

webTitle: Byers backs down on top pay

fields.headline: Byers backs down on top pay
fields.trailText: Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers yesterday watered down his measures for curbing boardroom excess, leaving shareholders with fewer powers than they had hoped to control spiralling pay deals.
fields.body:
Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers yesterday watered down his measures for curbing boardroom excess, leaving shareholders with fewer powers than they had hoped to control spiralling pay deals.

His announcement, delayed by more than six months due to a cabinet dispute over how to tackle the issue of pay, came as Barclays revealed Matt Barrett, its chief executive, was paid £1.7m in cash last year, even before any share or option awards were taken into account.

The scale of Mr Barrett's pay, which some remuneration experts believe could reach £30m over three years, was one of the pay deals which helped to ignite the debate over the level of pay last year.

Mr Byers yesterday proposed secondary legislation requiring companies to disclose more details about how pay is determined and produce a performance graph. But he is not making it compulsory for companies to vote on remuneration polices, waiting instead for the outcome of a review into company law.

"Companies and shareholders around the world increasingly recognise the importance of a proper link between pay and performance in the boardroom. In the US, companies are already required to publish performance measurement comparisons. I believe we should so the same," Mr Byers said.

He also said he would want to see evidence that remuneration committees were entirely made up of non-executive directors and companies were keeping shareholders involved in the pay setting process.

The announcement comes just as the annual general meeting season gets under way at which companies traditionally alter the pay deal terms of their executives.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Thai financier extradited
fields.body:
Thai financier extradited

A judge yesterday ordered the extradition from Britain of a financier blamed by Thai authorities for the south-east Asian currency crisis. Pin Chakkaphak, past president of the collapsed Finance One, was cleared of £33m theft charges but told he must face allegations of false accounting in Thailand. His lawyers later won leave to appeal after describing the judgment by Judge Colin Pratt as "astonishing".

In 1997 it emerged that Thai foreign reserves had been used to support institutions such as Finance One, which collapsed the year before.

Media malaise hits Dow Jones

Dow Jones, publisher of the Wall Street Journal, warned of a sharp fall in earnings for the first quarter because of the weakening advertising market. It said it would defer spending and begin cutting costs, including with job cuts. Advertising volume fell 32% in February and is expected to be down by similar levels this month.

EasyJet's numbers up

EasyJet, one of Europe's biggest discount airlines, reported a 28% surge in the number of passengers using its service during February from the previous year's figure. EasyJet carried 531,235 passengers last month, up from 413,469 a year ago. Load factor - how successfully an airline fills seats - stood at 82.3%, unchanged from February 2000.

Cannons looks at buyout

Health and fitness club operator Cannons said yesterday it was considering a management buyout said to be backed by Royal Bank Development Capital. Cannons shares, which have risen 9% since the buyout rumours emerged at the weekend, were up 7p at 148.5p.

Cannons has given the institution a period of exclusivity to complete due diligence on a proposed cash offer at 155p per share, valuing Cannons at about £360m. Cannons reported its full-year profits before goodwill, tax and exceptionals at £19.15m, up 39%.

Serco embroiled in Shetlands row

Scatsta airport on the Shetlands was last night at the centre of a row over safety involving Serco, the government's preferred bidder for the sale of air traffic control services. Balpa, the airline pilots' union, yesterday gave a "black star" warning status to the airport, where Serco provides air traffic control. Serco said it was fulfilling all the requirements of its contract.

fields.headline: Bags of profit for LVMH
fields.trailText: The LVMH luxury goods empire yesterday announced a 27% profits increase, fuelled by booming sales of Louis Vuitton celebrity suitcases.
fields.body:
The LVMH luxury goods empire yesterday announced a 27% profits increase, fuelled by booming sales of Louis Vuitton celebrity suitcases.

Demand for the expensive leather bags, a must-have accessory for any self-respecting supermodel and soccer stars such as David Beckham, was so great at the end of last year that LVMH could not make enough.

"Louis Vuitton turned in an exceptional performance in 2000," said LVMH. Sales rose 37% and drove the total for the combine's fashion and leather goods division from euro 826m to 1.169bn (£745m). Other brands in the division include Loewe, Kenzo, Givenchy and, within newly acquired Gabrielle Studio, Donna Karan.

In the perfume division, J'Adore raked in sales of euro 100m in its first year, the first perfume to do so for more than 10 years.

The group pinpointed Hennessy cognac as its other star performer. Last year the wines and spirits division launched Hennessy Pure White to appeal to younger drinkers and overall operating income climbed 23%. Champagne sales rose 3%, after the 35% increase in 1999 produced by the millennium celebrations.

The results from the sprawling group were slightly weaker than expected. Operating income was up from euro 1.5bn to 1.96bn, but analysts had been expecting euro 2bn.

Sales in the first two months of this year are ahead only 13%, compared to the 35% growth in the same period last year.

fields.headline: Turbo geared to charge
fields.trailText: The market has been hard on Turbo Genset recently. Although the company specialises in the design and manufacture of high-speed alternators, it has been treated like a flaky dot.com. Its shares, which were changing hands for £7 in September, hit 377.5p earlier this month.
fields.body:
The market has been hard on Turbo Genset recently. Although the company specialises in the design and manufacture of high-speed alternators, it has been treated like a flaky dot.com. Its shares, which were changing hands for £7 in September, hit 377.5p earlier this month.

But things might be about to change. Yesterday Turbo, which is also listed on the Toronto stock exchange, advanced 52.5p to 437.5p as Canadian institutions snapped up the stock ahead of changes to the TSE 300 share index.

Turbo is to join the TSE 300 on March 16, and traders reckon Canadian institutions that track the index will need to buy between 8m and 11m Turbo shares before then to maintain weightings. Turbo is the 80th biggest listed company in Canada.

Given the tightly held nature of Turbo shares, this could result in the price being squeezed all the way up to £5.

fields.headline: At this price?  Aortech
fields.trailText: There were harsh words in the City yesterday about Scottish heart valve maker Aortech, which chose Budget day to sneak out news that its £64m fundraising had been an unmitigated flop.
fields.body:
There were harsh words in the City yesterday about Scottish heart valve maker Aortech, which chose Budget day to sneak out news that its £64m fundraising had been an unmitigated flop.

The company has a material named Elast-Eon, which is flexible enough for use in joints and valves and carries a low risk of rejection. It also has a heart monitor named TruCCOMS, which measures the flow of blood more accurately than established technology.

These ideas have sent investors' pulses racing, pushing the shares up ten-fold in two years. Unfortunately, in the words of one analyst, the management "got greedy".

Aortech's cash call included £30m to be spent on unspecified "acquisition opportunities", even though its healthy share price gave it leeway to use paper for any purchases. Chairman Gordon Wright and chief executive Eddie McDaid wanted to sell £2m of their own shares at the same time, which never goes down well with investors.

A further big slug of money was earmarked for research and development, although Aortech has been boasting that its main products are almost ready for launch.

This is not the first time Aortech has upset its followers. Its interim results last year included a nasty surprise that animal trials on its heart valves would need to be repeated in the US. Its shoulder-shrugging attitude to this delay irritated investors.

The firm abandoned its fundraising after a 30% fall in the shares over two weeks. The price dived further yesterday, down 10p to 522.5p.

The debacle is embarrassing for adviser Morgan Stanley. Its implications for Aortech are more serious: the firm will run out of cash unless it can raise funds by the end of the year.

Yesterday's closing price valued Aortech at £158m, which is cheap. But initial sales of TruCCOMS have been poor, and the launch of Elast-Eon has been put back to 2007. Prudent investors should sell.

fields.headline: Weak Shire shows its value
fields.standfirst: Market forces
fields.trailText: Anyone who is thinking about selling their shares in Shire Pharmaceutical , down 54p at £11.26, should call brokers at CSFB. Apparently they are big buyers of the shares, which are expected to be weak in the run-up to its acquisition of BioChem Pharma.
fields.body:
Anyone who is thinking about selling their shares in Shire Pharmaceutical , down 54p at £11.26, should call brokers at CSFB. Apparently they are big buyers of the shares, which are expected to be weak in the run-up to its acquisition of BioChem Pharma.

CSFB believes any weakness will be a potential buying opportunity. It thinks the fundamentals of the combined company will be strong.

Not only will the new Shire have good growth prospects, but a low risk, diversified revenue stream.

Nevertheless, traders expect the shares to underperform until the pricing period for the £2.7bn all-paper acquisition ends on March 27.

Because of the deal's complex arrangement they say it will be in the interest of arbitrageurs - traders who make money from the differences between two share prices - to send Shire lower in the coming weeks.

Put simply, the lower Shire goes the better it is for the arbitrageurs. Because Shire has guaranteed BioChem shareholders $37 it will be forced to issue more shares the further its price falls. And the more stock it has to issue, the less attractive the deal starts to look.

When it was first announced in December, Shire shareholders were expected to own 53% of the combined group, and BioChem investors 47%. Obviously this will change if Shire has to issue more stock.

Considering JDS Uniphase, the market leader in fibre optics, issued a profits warning, trading in Yahoo! had been suspended, and rumours of a Nokia profits warning were doing the rounds, leading shares were remarkably calm yesterday.

With the City more interested in the Budget than events on Wall Street, the FTSE 100 index came to rest 10.2 points weaker at 6,001.8. Market turnover reached 2bn shares. Elsewhere, the FTSE Techmark 100 index fell 3.94 points to 2,394.16.

International Power was among the top performers as it celebrated its surprise reprieve from relegation to the FTSE 250 with a gain of 11.5p to 242p. The company, which looked to be kicked out of the FTSE 100 on Friday, was saved by the poor performance of logistics group Exel , off 19p to 841p, on Monday.

On the downside Pearson slipped 52p to £14.58 after the City's top rated media analyst - Patrick Wellington of Schroder Salomon Smith Bar ney - lowered his rating on the company. Moving to a "neutral" recommendation, Mr Wellington said, by the standards of its international counterparts in education and financial publishing, the stock was no longer cheap.

Lower down, the reason behind Tuesday's sudden sell-off of jewellery retailer Signet , 2.75p lower at 71.5p, became evident. Zale, North America's biggest jewellery and Signet's main rival, yesterday warned that its second-half earnings would decline sharply from a year earlier, due to a slowdown in consumer spending in the United States.

As Signet makes 70% of its money in North America, short sellers are more convinced than a profits warning will accompany full-year figures on March 27.

Elsewhere, internet security group Baltimore fell 6.5p to 223p, despite Merrill Lynch setting the record straight on next week's share lock-up expires. As reported, 7.25m shares are eligible for sale next Thursday, and a further 11m on April 25, but in both cases Merrill expects holders to hang on to their shares.

"Considering Baltimore is trading at its lowest point since November 1999, we do not believe the majority of these shares will be hit," Merrill said, as it repeated its "buy" rating.

On the Alternative Investment Market, Medical Marketing rose 9p to 129.5p, lifted by news that CellFactors, a company in which it has a 30% stake, has been granted a US patent for the use of neural cells in the treatment of brain disorders.

webTitle: Arts: The Servant has finally made it to the theatre.

fields.headline: More crumpet, sir?
fields.standfirst: After 53 years The Servant has finally made it to the theatre.  Lyn Gardner reports
fields.trailText: After 53 years The Servant has finally made it to the theatre. Lyn Gardner reports.
fields.body:
When Robin Maugham was a young man he once walked into his bedroom to find a naked teenage boy face down on the bed. The boy had been procured by a family servant who knew exactly what Maugham wanted but was too ashamed to admit it. Maugham later wrote about the event and insisted that he declined the offer. But the incident helped inspire his 1948 novella The Servant, in which a wily domestic first satisfies his master's needs then uses his weaknesses to dominate him.

Robin Maugham, otherwise known as Robert Cecil Romer Maugham, 2nd Viscount Maugham of Hartfield, called his 1972 autobiography Escape from the Shadows, but he never really succeeded in escaping anything. His own father, the Lord Chancellor, declared The Servant obscene and tried to prevent its publication; his uncle, W Somerset Maugham, eclipsed him as a writer; and he was gay, at a time when having sex with another man could land you in prison.

Even his one successful book was taken away from him. In 1963, The Servant was made into a film by Joseph Losey, who had fled McCarthyite America to become one of the best chroniclers of the changing face of 1960s Britain. Losey and the actor Dirk Bogarde had wanted to film Maugham's book since the early 1950s. Bogarde was to play Tony, the rich, indolent young man who buys a Chelsea town house and falls under the influence of his sinister manservant, Barrett. But by the time they made the film, Bogarde, who was also co-producer, was 42 and too old for the role. Instead he suggested James Fox for Tony and, after Ralph Richardson proved too expensive, he took the part of Barrett.

But Losey's film, which transposed the story from the post-war austerity Britain to the early 1960s, was not quite Maugham's book. Not least because it had a different writer: Harold Pinter, making his screenwriting debut. Pinter's masterful screenplay captured the menace and sexual repression of the original but changed almost everything else except the two main characters.

Maugham loathed it. "It was quite dreadful," he said shortly before his death in 1981. "The orgy scene at the end was a cock-up . . . It was perfectly obvious that Pinter had never been to an orgy."

Maugham, who drifted into alcoholism, tried to reclaim the story. In the late 1950s, still feeling stifled by his uncle (also homosexual, but cushioned by his enormous literary success in the days before "outing" was commonplace), he attempted to turn The Servant into a play. But it did not please audiences in Worthing and never made it to the West End. After the film was released, Maugham tried repeatedly to turn his story into drama, well into the 1970s when he tried to interest Lionel "Oliver!" Bart in a musical version - an idea so bizarre, you wish it had happened.

As theatre director and novelist Neil Bartlett says in a new introduction to The Servant: "Maugham's story had a power over its author, which, despite his best literary intentions, he could never quite tidy away into a polite or finished form. A degree of wayward, unsettling anxiety and energy is the secret to all sensational or scandalous storytelling - it overrides the decorum of both writing and reading stories. Much of Maugham's story is clumsy, ugly, unresolved, incomplete; these are exactly the qualities that make it unforgettable."

Bartlett, artistic director of the Lyric Hammersmith, is now turning The Servant into theatre. He has gone back to both Maugham's original and the 1958 stage adaptation to create a play that reverts to the confessional story-telling style of the original. Like so much of Bartlett's recent work, such as The Picture of Dorian Gray, it looks beneath the surface of the written word and overturns every grubby emotion to reveal our true attitudes to sex, class and ourselves.

When the film of The Servant was released in 1963, the Profumo affair was being exposed, which seemed to reflect the collapse of "upper-class decency" in a morass of sex and lies. Yet, as Bartlett suggests, the tale may well be relevant today. Barrett, he claims, "revels in the unspoken truth of post-war society: that the war and the welfare state have done nothing to alter the fact that the whole system exists only to maintain the comfort of the few." Robin Maugham may be largely forgotten, but we will never be able to forget The Servant.

 Neil Bartlett's adaptation of The Servant is in preview at the Lyric Hammersmith, London W6. Box office: 020-8741 2311. The book has just been reissued by Prion Press, price £5.99.

webTitle: Arts: Giles Tremlett meets Spanish director Alex de la Iglesia.

fields.headline: 'An action movie for adults has to have sex, death and love'
fields.standfirst: Giles Tremlett meets Spanish director Alex de la Iglesia, the bloodier successor to Pedro Almodovar
fields.trailText: Giles Tremlett meets Spanish director Alex de la Iglesia, the bloodier successor to Pedro Almodovar.
fields.body:
Alex de la Iglesia is worried. The 34-year-old director of five films - three of them hits in his native Spain, one with a cult following across the world - is to receive his first major retrospective, courtesy of Manchester's Cornerhouse. Surely, he frets, something must be wrong. "Does it mean I am getting old? I have only made five films. It seems ridiculous to talk about me having a particular style. I hate style."

This young Basque, a former philosophy student at Bilbao's Jesuit university and writer of underground comics, is the most succesful of a new generation of Spanish directors. Inspired, sometimes nurtured, by Pedro Almodovar, this new pack - who include Bajo Ulloa and Santiago Segura - have now emerged as powers in their own right. De la Iglesia, whose darkly humorous films combine violence, slapstick and subversion, is their natural leader.

His coming-of-age party at the Cornerhouse comes at a time when Spanish cinema is bursting with confidence and spilling over its own borders. Actors and directors are suddenly appearing on the global stage. Almodovar kicked off a remarkable year for Spaniards by winning last year's foreign film Oscar for All About My Mother. Now Javier Bardem has been nominated for a best actor Oscar for his portrayal of Cuban poet Reinaldo Arenas in Julian Schnabel's Before Night Falls. His future in Hollywood, alongside the already established Antonio Banderas and Penelope Cruz, looks settled. In France, meanwhile, Sergi Lopez has just won a best actor César for his role in Dominik Moll's Harry, He's Here To Help.

The traffic is also beginning to move the other way. Nicole Kidman has just spent two months hidden away with director Alejandro Amenabar in a studio outside Madrid, working on a sinister Edgar Allan Poe tale. At the same time, Danny Aiello, Joe Mantegna and George Hamilton are working under director Manuel Gomez Pereira. De la Iglesia has also set his sights high. His next film, provisionally entitled The Return of Fu Manchu, will be shot entirely in English. Banderas has said he wants to play the cop; the director is hoping Michael Caine will take the title role.

Of all the new pack of directors, De la Iglesia owes most to Almodovar. As a 23-year-old, he sent the director a proposal for his full-length film, Accion Mutante, along with a rough tape of a short that he was making. By the time he was called to see Almodovar, the short had run out of money and still had no sound.

"I had to do all the voices and the music while the film was running, and I made a complete, shameful idiot of myself," he explains. Almodovar, however, was impressed and took less than an hour to agree to produce Accion Mutante. "I guess I just showed him how much I wanted to make films," says De la Iglesia.

Two years later Spanish film-goers were presented with a tale about the adventures of an intergalactic, physically disabled terrorist group who kidnap the daughter of a wealthy businessman. Accion Mutante was spoof science fiction with added violence and an Almodovarian twist. There were buckets of blood and some truly repulsive heroes. It was not the sort of thing Spanish audiences were used to.

"You don't have to be serious and make films about the Spanish civil war. You can do other things," says De la Iglesia. He can barely conceal his impatience with art house directors. "I can't stand people who put their own interests before those of the spectator. The audience has to enjoy it. That does not mean you cannot plant a series of ideas or concepts in their minds as well."

Accion Mutante became - and remains - a cult movie for young Spaniards. It was enough of a success to guarantee its director a second film. El Dia de la Bestia (The Day of the Beast), starring Alex Angulo as a mad, bookish priest who works out that the Antichrist is about to appear in Madrid. The film was a massive hit in Spain, winning six Goyas and distribution deals around the world.

The director was amazed and his ambitions grew. Within a few months he was in the US directing Rosie Perez, of Do The Right Thing fame, and Javier Bardem in Perdita Durango, a gory Tex-Mex road movie scripted by the author of David Lynch's Wild At Heart, Barry Gifford. Relentlessly violent, it failed in Spain but,even when cut by 10 minutes to avoid an X certificate, was a success elswhere. "It is my best film," he states. Stephen Spielberg, an admirer of Bardem, praised it recently, saying he had watched it to the end despite his dislike of violent movies.

The Spanish director's love of sex and violence does, however, pose a threat to his career prospects outside Spain. He hopes to start filming The Return of Fu Manchu in the autumn but refuses to tone it down. "It is an action movie for adults. That means there has to be sex, death and love."

While preparing Fu Manchu over the past three years he has also turned out a couple of domestic hits. Muertos de Risa (Dying of Laughter), which broke box office records on its first weekend, tells the story of two friends who form a succesful comedy duo, whose act involves them beating each other up on stage. They make everybody else laugh, but come to hate one another. Finally they kill each other on live television.

The film stars Santiago Segura and El Gran Wyoming, two comic character actors who are popular in Spain but unknown elsewhere. "In the States they tell me they are just like Abbott and Costello or Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis," says De la Iglesia. "Every country has its own comic duo."

La Comunidad, by far the most commercially successful of the 104 feature films made in Spain last year, has a similarly Spanish setting. Almodovar's former muse Carmen Maura plays an estate agent who discovers a suitcase full of money in a Madrid apartment she is trying to sell. The other neighbours have spent years waiting to get their hands on it, and will stop at nothing to keep the cash in the building. "It is a horror film. It is as though she walks into a castle and finds it full of monsters," says De la Iglesia.

La Comunidad will kick off the Viva festival, which opens next week. Alex de la Iglesia will be there to answer questions. Perhaps, by then, he will have come to terms with the fact that he is worthy of a retrospective.

 La Comunidad, introduced by Alex de la Iglesia, opens the Viva! film festival at the Cornerhouse, Manchester, next Thursday. The festival runs until March 25. Box office: 0161-200 1500. De la Iglesia will also be at a screening of La Comunidad at the Metro, London W1, on March 16. Box office: 020-7734 1506.

fields.headline: Arthur Smith
fields.trailText: Theatre and cricket have never had sex, but the art form has certainly admired the game.
fields.body:
Theatre and cricket have never had sex, but the art form has certainly admired the game. Harold Pinter and Tom Stoppard are registered cricket lovers, while Samuel Beckett is chiefly known as the only Nobel prizewinner to have been recorded in the cricketers' bible, Wisden. Sam Mendes, I am told by a low-grade off-break bowler who was flayed around the ground by the Oscar-winner, could have played professionally.

There is a sadder link: both cricket and theatre are in crisis. Both are victims of falling audiences and increasing lack of interest, both are overshadowed by big, bad, newer, hugely-funded competitors in the form of football and film. Both also have the capacity to be eyebrow-slopingly boring, but, equally, may provide moments of ecstasy that make their rivals look pedestrian.

Richard Eyre recently made a big speech conceding that a bad night out at the theatre is worse than being beaten on the buttocks with a spiked stick. And much more expensive. On Saturday I was on Radio 4's Loose Ends, where Ned Sherrin was interviewing RSC boss Adrian Noble, and I assumed he'd ask him about what Eyre said. He didn't, he told me afterwards, because it was too obvious. Like cricket, theatre is always being criticised for being out of date and dull.

As a theatre-lover, I was reassured by Ned, whose perspective is longer than nearly anyone else's. Then I saw Port Authority by Conor McPherson, a much-vaunted playwright. Three competent actors took it in turns to do monologues, each punctuated by an irritating, pointless bell. No movement, no dialogue, no set, no costumes, and writing that just wasn't good enough to warrant what I'd paid. Then I went to see Shockheaded Peter and was scared, titillated and enthralled in a way no pop video, TV show or film could ever manage.

Theatre isn't dead, but it would be nice if there were a new Don Bradman writing for that big, bare stage.
