webTitle: Arts: Obscure objects. Artists and letters.

fields.headline: Writing on the wall
fields.standfirst: What is it about artists and letters?  Jonathan Jones  continues our occasional series on strange fixations
fields.trailText: What is it about artists and letters? Jonathan Jones continues our occasional series on strange fixations.
fields.body:
The letter in painting is tantalisingly visible, plainly in view, yet absolutely mysterious. It is there for us to see yet, apart from the odd name or greeting - "To the excellent Gisze in London, England", says one of the letters hung on a letter rack in Hans Holbein's portrait of the 16th-century merchant, George Gisze - we cannot decipher its contents.

Letters appear in art in letter racks like the one in Holbein's painting, or in the act of being written - with a quill pen and a pot full of ink, by a servant, in Gerard ter Borch's An Officer Dictating a Letter (1655-8); we see letters being sealed with wax, handed to a messenger, delivered and read. What we rarely see is the message inside, the words on the white sheet held up to the sunlight. The letter in art is an object of fascination precisely because its contents are obscure.

Vermeer's paintings explore every scenario the private theatre of letter writing has to offer. He depicts men, and especially women, writing, reading, and receiving letters, yet never once is a word legible. Instead the letter itself is meaningful: we see the texture of the paper, its thinness, its whiteness. Letters are exchanged between the men and women of Delft with an email-like rapidity in Vermeer's paintings.

In Mistress and Maid, a woman lays down her pen in the middle of writing a letter because she is interrupted by the delivery of a letter addressed to her. We guess the letter is from the person she is writing to, and interpret her response - she touches her chin in surprise - as alarmed, mystified. It's a moment of everyday drama. What makes letters dramatic in Vermeer's paintings is the unresolved intensity with which people concentrate on them: his letter writers and readers look at letters in silent absorption, searching each word for significance. You can feel them looking through the letter, trying to see the face of the writer, trying to decide if a particular expression is a sign of true love, false seduction, or just polite gallantry. They miss and want the person who sent the letter, they are brought together by the words, yet they read the letter alone.

Vermeer's Woman in Blue Reading a Letter (c.1662-4) stands at a table before an open window, holding the crinkled letter up to the light; her face is lost in it and she seems upset, as if she's been told someone won't be coming after all. The sense of distance and absence is intensified by a map of the Netherlands on the wall behind her, and makes us feel the writer is far away. We feel the space between them. As the title of Vermeer's painting The Love Letter (c.1669-70) makes plain, the letters in his paintings are intimate, passionate, and secret. Letter writing is the perfect dramatic territory for him because it is private; his writers and readers are engaged in little domestic adventures, flirting by mail.

Yet we only guess all this. The words are not for us to read. By involving us so intensely in a correspondence we cannot follow, Vermeer makes epistolary novelists of us all. We are invited to imagine what is on the page, to picture the loversealing a letter and giving it to a servant to send to this woman waiting in a quiet, neat room in Delft. Ambiguity makes the letters sinister as well as exciting. When Vermeer's women receive a letter, they look anxious rather than delighted. Interrupted as she plays the viola da gamba, the woman in The Love Letter looks at her servant with a note of warning, even as the servant laughs. She might be telling her to keep it quiet, or the servant might be threatening to make the letter public. Endless possibilities, a novel with no ending.

Telling a narrative through letters was popular with early novelists: Samuel Richardson's Pamela is told entirely through letters and, like Vermeer's paintings, deals with women's lives, the domestic sphere. The letter has moved from the world of men and politics to that of women in love. Renaissance paintings use the letter as an index of male prestige: men in portraits open or seal letters as proof they are involved in the world of politics or business. In Mantegna's fresco of the court of Ludovico Gonzaga in Mantua, the women, children and animals are blissfully ignorant as the duke is handed a letter telling him the Sforzas in Milan desperately need his help. The letter is weighty, political; in the domestic Dutch art of Vermeer and his contemporaries, it becomes se cretive, personal.

If 17th and 18th-century paintings of men and women sending letters occupy the same secluded, middle-class world as the early novel, they are more ambiguous. Richardson's Pamela gives us the actual letters the heroine exchanges with her lover; when the artist Joseph Highmore paints Twelve Scenes from Samuel Richardson's Pamela (1744), he removes Pamela from the novel's realism to the open-endedness of the image. In the first painting, she's interrupted writing a letter, but it's up to us to decide what it says - the words are unreadable. The letter in art is a clue to what art itself is. Images are a letter still in its envelope, whose significance we guess with anticipation or fear. A painting can be read like a story, but it can be seen as an object, too, like the letter itself. An unopened letter is a thing of paper and wax, whose meaning resides in its physical presence.

In a painting like Chardin's Woman Sealing a Letter (1733), there are no words, and the physical action of sealing the letter seems meaningful, poetic, expressive. It's an elaborate ritual, as a servant holds a candle so she can dip her stick of red wax into the flame and lovingly seal the letter she has written with the quill on the table. Chardin systematically explores the visual world in opposition to the verbal: in this painting, there's a sense she need never even send the letter, that the meaning lies in the sensuality of letter writing, rather than the words on the page. Perhaps we don't need the words. Perhaps words are lies. That's the other tension in the faces of Vermeer's readers: can the letter be trusted? It's easier to lie on the page than face to face, and letters are easily interrupted on their journey from sender to reader.

Safer by far to trust the physical presence of the letter, the love note written on paper you yourself gave your lover, scented with that favourite perfume. Vermeer and Chardin, in their celebrations of the physical ritual of letter writing and denigration of the words on the page, make an argument in favour of art itself, a defence of visual as opposed to verbal communication. They trust the obscure language of objects more than the noise of writing.

This distrust takes its most extreme form in Jacques-Louis David's The Death of Marat (1793). Of all the shocking things in this painting of the French revolutionary leader Jean-Paul Marat dead in his bath - the naked, olive-tinged flesh of the corpse, the terrible modern emptiness of the composition, the way it is foreshortened, stripped of depth - nothing is quite as transgressive as the letter he holds in his hand, written by his killer, Charlotte Corday. For almost every previous artist, the letter had been an object signifying desire, its words unreadable, its meaning a delightful mystery; David shatters this convention.

Corday's letter, written in a big, mad scrawl, faces us. We can read it. In reality, Corday got in to see Marat by hand-delivering a note offering to name conspirators against the Jacobin wing of the revolution. David makes her letter more like a disfigured love letter or, in today's terms, a nutty fan letter: "It is enough that I am unhappy to deserve your good will." A self-indulgent, selfish request at a time of national emergency, and a lie, designed to get her close enough to stab him. In David's painting it is the generosity of Marat, his openness to the letter, the fact he has made time to read these deranged words, that has led to his death. Communication has been cut through with a knife: the letter is suspect and the writer a stalker. Just like Chardin, David finds the truth of the letter in its physicality rather than its words. The writing as a visual fact is too big, insistent, with an over-emphatic underlining of the name Marat.

David's painting is modern in its alienation, its terror. In modern art, the suspicion of words becomes a fear that every word is a lie, communication a form of violence. Turner prize-winner Douglas Gordon sends messages that say "It's over" or "Nothing can be hidden forever", and the letter becomes a message without a context, scary and anonymous. The "mail artist" Ray Johnson founded The New York Correspondence School in the 1960s as a network of people willing to accept his bizarre mailings. A pop artist left behind by the art market, Johnson maintained his links with the art world through his letters. They feature collages, cartoons, puns, and are, quite self-consciously, a little creepy in their desperate desire to engage the recipient in some kind, any kind, of communication. For Johnson, the words don't matter: his letters have nothing to say. What he wants to affirm is communication itself, maintained through endlessly circuitous jokes, gossip and funny pictures. It wasn't enough: he eventually killed himself.

The letter is a metaphor for art, in its physicality, its embodiment as paper, wax, a stamp, some squiggles. Before you read a word, you have an impression of a letter. When you read it, you might be more confused than when you just saw it as folded paper. You might know less, rather than more, about the person who sent it. Just like art.

Vermeer's paintings explore every scenario the private theatre of letter writing has to offer. He depicts men, and especially women, writing, reading, and receiving letters, yet never once is a word legible. Instead the letter itself is meaningful: we see the texture of the paper, its thinness, its whiteness. Letters are exchanged between the men and women of Delft with an email-like rapidity in Vermeer's paintings. In Mistress and Maid, a woman lays down her pen in the middle of writing a letter because she is interrupted by the delivery of a letter addressed to her. We guess the letter is from the person she is writing to, and interpret her response - she touches her chin in surprise - as alarmed, mystified. It's a moment of everyday drama. You can feel them looking through the letter, trying to see the face of the writer, trying to decide if a particular expression is a sign of true love, false seduction, or just polite gallantry. They miss and want the person who sent the letter, they are brought together by the words, yet they read the letter alone. The words are not for us to read. By involving us so intensely in a correspondence we cannot follow, Vermeer makes epistolary novelists of us all. We are invited to imagine what is on the page, to picture the loversealing a letter and giving it to a servant to send to this woman waiting in a quiet, neat room in Delft. She might be telling her to keep it quiet, or the servant might be threatening to make the letter public. Endless possibilities, a novel with no ending. The letter is weighty, political; in the domestic Dutch art of Vermeer and his contemporaries, it becomes se cretive, personal. If 17th and 18th-century paintings of men and women sending letters occupy the same secluded, middle-class world as the early novel, they are more ambiguous. Images are a letter still in its envelope, whose significance we guess with anticipation or fear. A painting can be read like a story, but it can be seen as an object, too, like the letter itself. An unopened letter is a thing of paper and wax, whose meaning resides in its physical presence. It's an elaborate ritual, as a servant holds a candle so she can dip her stick of red wax into the flame and lovingly seal the letter she has written with the quill on the table. Chardin systematically explores the visual world in opposition to the verbal: in this painting, there's a sense she need never even send the letter, that the meaning lies in the sensuality of letter writing, rather than the words on the page. It's easier to lie on the page than face to face, and letters are easily interrupted on their journey from sender to reader. webTitle: School-blast pupils were making fireworks explosion

fields.headline: School-blast pupils were making fireworks explosion
fields.trailText: China was shaken yesterday by the news that dozens of children have been killed in another accident blamed on poverty and poor safety standards.
fields.byline: John Gittings and AFP in Beijing
fields.body:
China was shaken yesterday by the news that dozens of children have been killed in another accident blamed on poverty and poor safety standards.

The explosion at a primary school in Jiangxi province on Tuesday occurred while pupils were putting fuses into firecrackers, a grieving parent said.

The official toll so far is 41, most of them pupils aged eight or nine.

"When I saw a leg or an arm sticking out, I went after it," Ding Mingxing, one of the villagers who rushed to the scene, said. "I rescued four kids, three boys and a girl, but I couldn't find my son."

Mr Ding said the children were forced to assemble firecrackers to help the school financially.

"[The school authorities] called it 'supporting oneself through school by working'," he said. "The kids who didn't do the work were forced to pay fines."

The explosion in Fanglin, Wanzai county, happened the day after the prime minister, Zhu Rongji, said in Beijing that China suffered from "frequent occurrences of grave accidents".

Television stations showed a scene of complete devastation. Part of the school's second floor was reduced to rubble. Soldiers searched through bricks and rafters, some using their bare hands.

Provincial leaders immediately returned from the national people's congress, where Mr Zhu made his comment, to take charge of the enquiries into the incident.

County officials admitted that an accident with firecrackers might have been be to blame, but said that the investigation was still under way.

Rural schools have been badly hit by economic reforms which have shifted education budgets on to local governments, which are often unable to pay teachers their full salaries or buy equipment.

Villagers said that the fireworks enterprise had been set up by the headteacher with the help of the village's Communist party secretary.

Mr Ding said that he and other parents had complained about the business to officials at a higher level, but the matter was not treated seriously.

He said that the school was trying to fill a rush order in time for the Grave Sweeping Festival on April 5, when families tend their ancestors' graves and light firecrackers. About 190 people were inthe school at the time.

Wanzai county is in a mountainous area of Jiangxi - one of China's least developed provinces - close to the border with Hunan.

It has several fireworks exporting companies.

Most of the rural people not working on the land are engaged in the fireworks business, and many of them assemble firecrackers at home.

Last year more than 50 people were killed in two separate explosions caused by the illegal manufacture of fireworks in the province.

The serious accidents of the type referred to by Mr Zhu include mining disasters, bridge collapses and river dykes washed away by floods.

fields.headline: Winners in the multi-party deal
fields.body:
Shimon Peres (Labour)
foreign minister
The Nobel peace laureate, 77, takes the edge off Sharon's hardline reputation. But the coalition deal has a "Peres blocking" clause that prevents him from charting an independent course. He is arguably the last Israeli politician to command some trust among Palestinian leaders. Despite his dovish reputation in the past decade, he has been a close friend of Sharon for more than 50 years.

Binyamin Ben Eliezer (Labour)
defence minister
Born in Iraq 65 years ago, he hails from Labour's right wing, and has been called "Little Sharon" by peace activists. A former brigadier-general, he commanded Israel's forces in the occupied territories and set up Israel's proxy militia during its occupation of Lebanon. He backs Sharon's stand against resuming peace negotiations until the Palestinian uprising ends.

Limor Livnat (Likud)
education minister
A brash and outspoken supporter of Sharon's rival in the Likud party, the former prime minister Binyamin Netanyahu. Livnat, 50, believes that negotiations with the Palestinians should be stalled until Yasser Arafat makes way for a leader who "shares our values". She has said she will work to increase the Zionist content in the school curriculum

Eli Yishai (Shas)
interior minister
The appointment to the cabinet of Yishai, 38, - leader of the Shas party, which combines ultra-orthodoxy with an ethnic pride movement for Jews of Middle Eastern origin - has antagonised secular Israelis. The 1m Russian immigrants are particularly uphappy. Shas was crucial to bringing down the last government. Sharon must be careful to stay in Yishai's good graces.

webTitle: Sharon puts a third of knesset in government

fields.headline: Sharon puts a third of knesset in government
fields.standfirst:
Israel unsure if the coalition will bring peace or wrench itself apart

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israel unsure if the coalition will bring peace or wrench itself apart.
fields.body:
Ariel Sharon, vilified in the Arab world but embraced by his own people as a saviour they hope can contain the Palestinian uprising, took office as prime minister of Israel yesterday.

Alongside the popular hope pinned on his national-unity government of seven parties, an atmosphere of dread was also apparent: if this coalition and this leader prove unable to bring peace to the country, Israelis wonder what options will be left.

Mr Sharon presides over the largest government in Israeli history, embracing a third of the 120 MPs. It has 27 ministers and as many as 15 deputy ministers.

But while his parliamentary majority looks rock solid - more than 70 members of the knesset, although his own Likud party has only 19 seats - he comes to power at a time when many Israelis feel despairing and powerless and the security forces are on high alert for attacks in Israel.

The Islamist militant group Hamas, which says it was behind this week's suicide bombing in the coastal city of Netanya, has renewed a warning that it has ordered 10 suicide bombers to strike in Israel to mark Mr Sharon's installation as prime minister.

Nabil Abu Rdainah, an adviser to the Palestinian Authority president Yasser Arafat, said yesterday that Mr Sharon faced a stark choice between resuming negotiations with the Palestinians and seeing more blood shed.

The uprising in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip has taken more than 420 lives in five months, almost all of them Palestinian.

Mr Sharon refused to resume talks while the Palestinians are in a state of revolt.

"It's a moment of choice for the new Israeli government, a choice between a continuation of dialogue with the Palestinians [and] the continuation of a policy of siege of threats and pushing this process into a new escalation," Mr Rdainah said.

Mr Sharon acknowledged the pressures, and the high expectations of his own people.

"I feel the weight of the responsibility, especially in this period," he told army radio hours before presenting his cabinet to parliament.

"I am sure that ,together with my colleagues in the government, we will know how to make the best response to the present dangers facing Israel."

The Palestinians, and the world beyond, will be closely watching the ageing warrior; the Arabs have not forgiven him for his role in the Lebanese massacre of hundreds of Palestinian refugees in Beirut in 1982, and for his ruthless expansion of Jewish settlement in the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

Mr Sharon will make his first foray on the world state as prime minister on March 19, when he is expected to meet US leaders in Washington after speaking at the annual conference of a Israel lobby group.

His huge cabinet - the price of securing the loyalty of Labour and other factions - is an unwieldy affair, which will be liable to deadlock because of its size and diversity, and contains the seeds of its own disintegration.

It took a month for Mr Sharon to put it together, and he hopes it will allow him to stay in power where others have fallen, serving out a parliamentary term ending in 2003.

His chance of survival was improved yesterday when parliament voted overwhelmingly to abolish the direct election of the prime minister, which was introduced after the assassination of the incumbent Yitzhak Rabin in 1995 and has proved a destabilising factor in Israeli politics.

But he presides over a fractious collection of left, right and religious parties.

On the left stands the incoming foreign minister, Shimon Peres, the architect of a peace process which has been washed away by the blood of the hundreds killed in the past five months.

On the far right stand Rechavam Ze'evi, the tourism minister, and Avigdor Lieberman, the infrastructure minister, who want Mr Sharon to use even more muscle against the Palestinians.

Ordinary Israelis, who gave Mr Sharon two-thirds of the popular vote in the February 6 election, want him to go on the attack against the field commanders of the Palestinian intifada, and so do the hardliners in his cabinet.

But that may not get easily past Mr Peres, who will push for a relaxation of the army's siege of Palestinian areas and the resumption of the peace negotiations.

Mr Sharon could also face a rebellion in the Likud, where there is much frustration that his generosity to coalition partners has left the party with just eight ministerial seats.

"Looking at Sharon's cabinet, it looks like a multi-headed hydra, a concoction of ministers and deputy ministers, a cacophonous parliament disguised as a cohesive cabinet," Hemi Shalev, a columnist for the newspaper Ma'ariv, wrote yesterday.

"Long before he turns to deal with the Palestinians, Sharon will be forced to use a 'strong hand' merely to bring order around the cabinet table."

 The Israeli army dug a trench around Bir Zeit University, the biggest Palestinian educational institution in the West Bank, yesterday, and cut off its telephone and power lines, just before the start of the summer term.

Bir Zeit is seen as an activist centre.

About 65,000 Palestinians were also cut off by the trench, human rights groups said.

The Israeli peace group Gush Shalom called it an act of "state terror".

webTitle: Battered Gaullists ready to consign Paris to the left

fields.headline: Battered Gaullists ready to consign Paris to the left
fields.trailText: After 24 years running the capital, the Gaullists have implicitly admitted that they are likely to suffer a crushing defeat in the first round of the municipal elections on Sunday.
fields.body:
After 24 years running the capital, the Gaullists have implicitly admitted that they are likely to suffer a crushing defeat in the first round of the municipal elections on Sunday.

Their mayoral candidate, Philippe Séguin, held his last campaign meeting in an atmosphere of defeatism: the press and even some party officials saw the poorly attended event in the Palais des Sports on Tuesday as a farewell ceremony

Mr Séguin, 57, who had hoped to follow Jacques Chirac and Jean Tiberi to the city hall, avoided local issues and concentrated on the bitterness about divisions on the right and a hostile press.

He ruled out a deal with the dissident Gaullists led by Mr Tiberi, even though he had just been given a gloomy analysis of his go-it-alone strategy.

Without an interim merger with his arch-rival, he was told, the left would win 110 seats in the second round on March 18, the right only 53.

After a "media lynching", the press had already decided that the left was unbeatable, Mr Séguin said: a remark which one adviser interpreted as "the preparation of the post-match explanation for a personal setback".

The impression that he had given up was reinforced by his reluctance to discuss his plans for Paris or to mention his Socialist opponent, Bertrand Delanoë.

Instead, he attacked the Socialist philosophy at the national level, accusing the government of building an unjust society based on "leftwing capitalism and a new religion - inequality".

The Socialists and Greens, who will fight the second round together, could win as many as three-quarters of the capital's 20 arrondissements , giving them control of local town halls. Plans are already being made for a celebration echoing the festivities after François Mitterrand's presidential victory in 1981.

Paris is seen as the key to next year's presidential and parliamentary elections, in which the Socialist, Communist and Green coalition could end up controlling all the main centres of power.

Mr Delanoë, a close ally of the prime minister, Lionel Jospin, has been given the chance to set a new social agenda headed by promises of more créches, better health care, more council housing, the renovation of poorer areas, anti-pollution measures, and better public transport.

Before his high-profile campaign for the mayoralty, he was best known for publicly stating his homosexuality - now seen as an asset in a city with an estimated 10% of its population gay, lesbian or bisexual.

The Socialists and Greens, who will fight the second round together, could win as many as three-quarters of the capital's 20 arrondissements , giving them control of local town halls. Plans are already being made for a celebration echoing the festivities after François Mitterrand's presidential victory in 1981. Paris is seen as the key to next year's presidential and parliamentary elections, in which the Socialist, Communist and Green coalition could end up controlling all the main centres of power. Mr Delanoë, a close ally of the prime minister, Lionel Jospin, has been given the chance to set a new social agenda headed by promises of more créches, better health care, more council housing, the renovation of poorer areas, anti-pollution measures, and better public transport. Before his high-profile campaign for the mayoralty, he was best known for publicly stating his homosexuality - now seen as an asset in a city with an estimated 10% of its population gay, lesbian or bisexual.

fields.headline: Latinos outgrowing black Americans
fields.standfirst: 2000 US census shows Hispanics are about to take their place as the biggest ethnic minority
fields.trailText: 2000 US census shows Hispanics are about to take their place as the biggest ethnic minority.
fields.body:
A dramatic and unexpectedly big rise in the numbers of Hispanic Americans recorded in the latest US census puts black Americans on the verge of losing their 200-year status as the biggest ethnic minority in the population of more than 281m.

Results from last year's census show that there are now 35.3m people of Hispanic origin living in the US, compared to 36.4m black Americans.

Since a significant minority of black Americans are also Hispanic, it is possible that the historic primacy of primarily English-speaking blacks is already at an end.

Population projections have long indicated that the rise in the numbers of Hispanics will transform the traditional demography of the United States in the new century.

They suggest suggest that Hispanics will overtake blacks around 2010. But early results from last year show that the process is taking place much faster than predicted.

The numbers of Hispanics rose by nearly 60% in the decade since the 1990 census, from 22.4m in 1990 to 35.3m in the new census.

The new total is about 3m bigger than population experts had expected.

A US government official estimate late last year put Hispanic numbers at 32.8m.

"The earlier projections about US demography in the 21st century are all now going to have to be revised," Jorge Del Pinal, a senior census bureau official, said yesterday.

Officials believe that the surge in Hispanic numbers may reflect the success of a big effort by the Clinton administration to ensure that last year's census succeeded in reaching minority communities of all kinds, some of which have traditionally feared the census.

Poor standards of counting in the past may have made that earlier figures inaccurate, they said.

Another reason could be a resurgence of cultural pride and confidence in some parts of the Hispanic community about identifying themselves as Hispanic, Mr Del Pinal said.

The total number of black Americans increased from 30m in the 1990 census to 36.4m in 2000.

The picture is complicated, however, by new options in the ethnic and racial sections of the census form last year which enabled Americans to identify themselves as belonging to more than one ethnic group.

About 1.76m Americans identified themselves as both black and belonging to another group, leaving 34.7m Americans who considered that they were simply black.

Detailed official census figures on race will not be issued until next week, but the Washington Post newspaper yesterday published the results of a preliminary examination of some technical studies about census accuracy which contained the new figures.

Mr Del Pinal confirmed the broad accuracy of the figures yesterday.

"It's appropriate perhaps that it's happened at the beginning of the new century," Harry Pachon of the Rivera Policy Institute told the Post yesterday. "It's a present-day reality of what the United States has become." .

The new figures underscore one of the most profound social and cultural changes ever to affect the United States.

The effect is particularly powerful in states such as California, Arizona and Texas, where bilingualism is increasingly part of everyday life.

Nearly two thirds of the Hispanic population of the US comes originally from Mexico, 15% from central and south America, 13% from Cuba, and Puerto Rico, and the rest from other Spanish-speaking parts of the world, including the Dominican Republic.

For all the prominence of such rich and powerful people as the singer-film star Jennifer Lopez and the baseball star Sammy Sosa, the overwhelming majority of Hispanics are among the poorest citizens of the US.

The census figures also highlight an elusive aspect of modern American life, the fact that many Americans consider themselves to have multiple ethnic identities and are increasingly reluctant to be classified as either white or black.

For exactly this reason, some civil rights groups opposed the census bureau's decision in the 2000 census to allow Americans to tick more than one ethnic or racial box on the census form.

The figures will have a significant impact on the redrawing of electoral district boundaries, which is just about to begin.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Brussels strike over reforms
fields.body:
Brussels strike over reforms

European commission civil servants will strike on March 19 unless the vice-president, Neil Kinnock, backs away from his reform plans.

Their unions say he refuses to negotiate in good faith on his proposals, which include such innovations as performance-related pay. Andrew Osborn, Brussels

Fiji government in doubt

There was confusion in Fiji yesterday after the national television service reported that the interim government was relinquishing power in the light of a court ruling that it was illegal and democratic rule should be restored.

The government refused to confirm the report. There was no response from the army, which installed the government after last year's coup. AP, Suva

Aussie troops 'too macho'

Australian soldiers annoyed New Zealand, Thai and South Korean troops in the 1999 East Timor peacekeeping operation by being too aggressive, too loud and wearing sunglasses, according to a report in Canberra yesterday. AP, Canberra

69 Dominicans missing at sea

At least 69 migrants from the Dominican Republic are missing at sea, feared drowned, after setting sail for Puerto Rico 10 days ago. Reuters, Santo Domingo

fields.headline: Pass notes No 1834
fields.standfirst: Wales
fields.trailText: Wales
fields.body:
What, the proud and noble Celtic nation that produced Owain Glandwyr, Dylan Thomas, and Nye Bevan? No, I was thinking more of the place full of rugby-playing irritants who always seem excessively pleased with themselves.

Pardon? I'm sorry, I just came over all Anne Robinson. That, after all, was how the professionally charmless quiz show host recently chose to characterise this most delightful of nations. "I've never taken to them," remarked the Liverpool-born harridan.

Well, that's just the kind of offensive, regionalist slur I'd expect from a car-stealing, workshy Scouser. Quite. "What are they for?" she went on. It's hardly surprising that even this usually sunny-tempered people have taken exception to their grotesque and wholly inaccurate belittlement. Indeed, Robinson may yet have to appear before the Welsh select committee to "explain herself" amid calls for her to be sacked.

Quite right too. It's not as if this is the first time someone's sought to impugn the good name of this handsome, diligent, and generally fantastic community, is it? Only last month, 18 intellectually brilliant and morally upstanding members of the entirely useful Welsh assembly called for an end to the "persistent anti-Welsh racism" of the UK media.

Were they thinking of anyone in particular? Well, the rabid musings of the Sunday Times's AA Gill might have popped into their alluringly-formed heads. Back in 1999, he came perilously close to being prosecuted for incitement to racial hatred after referring to the Welsh as "ugly, pugnacious little trolls."

Shocking behaviour! My sentiments exactly. I mean, when you think of all that is great about the Wales, it makes your blood boil.

Don't say: "I have a certain amount of Welsh blood - but not probably more than about an eighth." (Michael Heseltine)

Do say: "Every day when I wake up, I thank the Lord I'm Welsh." (Cerys Matthews, Catatonia)

fields.headline: Country Diary
fields.standfirst: The pecking order
fields.trailText: Arhvaneran
fields.body:
Arhvaneran

Although there was a short break in the weather at the beginning of February, the first two months of this year have seen the longest periods of freezing conditions since we moved into the strath 16 years ago. Garden birds have had difficulty coping, so we have been putting extra food out, including black sunflower seeds in special containers.

One of these is 4ft in depth and over 3.5in in diameter, with 12 ports from which the birds feed. It takes over 7lb of the sunflower seeds, but still needs topping up on a regular basis, as birds such as greenfinches, chaffinches, great, blue and coal tits, and house sparrows flock around the new feeder. As a result, less attention is given by the birds to the peanuts in nine other feeders, but they too need regular topping up.

What has been interesting is that certain birds still only go to the peanuts and have so far totally ignored the sunflower seeds. These include seven long-tailed tits that visit about four times a day, and every time I see them I smile at the name the poet and naturalist John Clare gave them in the lines, "And coy bumbarrels, twenty in a drove,/Flit down the hedgerows in the frozen plain/And hang on little twigs and start again."

So far this winter there have only been a few siskins, but they too have ignored the sunflower seeds as does the single tree creeper that comes in a few times each day. We have been buying apples for the blackbirds, and they attack them with so much gusto it is as if they have to kill the apple before they can feed. We have also been putting out a saucer of cat food for a feral cat, which has shown no interest in the garden birds, despite the blackbirds' keenness on the cat food too.

webTitle: G2: Gone west. Jenny Colgan is seeking fame and fortune in LA

fields.headline: Gone west
fields.trailText: If I'd wanted to be this miserable I'd have gone to India in my gap year.
fields.body:
I knew things were about to go a bit Pete Tong when the heavily bewigged man at the Pennsylvania Department of Motor Vehicles took my passport, held it up to the light, looked at it down his nose, and then decided to examine it over his spectacles from both near and far away.

"You're here from Australia to take your driver's exam?" he asked finally, in an incredulous voice.

"No, I'm here from Europe," I answered, in an incredulous voice. He looked up at me for the first time.

"Here's my ID number," I said, proffering my tax card.

"Uh-huh."

"And that's my passport, with my I-94 in it, as requested on your form."

This time the pause was so long I could watch his wig grow. Supervisors were called over. The atmosphere grew tense. Over my shoulder I could see test-takers pressing buttons on the oversized computer tester. "Railroad ahead," I said under my breath. "Right lane narrows".

"Here's your problem," says the clerk, backed up by his jumpy-looking supervisor."You need an I-94. This thing in your passport is an I-94W."

I knew Dubya was going to be a disaster for America.

"But that's my visa waiver," I say, cheerfully. "It means, if I wanted a visa, I could have a visa, but to save me going to all the fuss of queuing at the embassy, you, the Americas, because you like us, the Brits, so very much, don't require me to go and get the real thing. Although, if I wanted one, I could of course, have got one any time.

"Right?" I say.

The test-taking guy on my left is stuck on the stag warning sign, for Christ's sake. I could walk this. This turns out to be a prescient thought.

"Uh-huh," says Mr Wig again.

"I've studied very hard," I say sincerely. "I know stopping distances."

"But you're not a US resident."

"For three months I am!"

"Uh-huh," he says.

So that is how I have learned that in America, "Uh-huh" means, absolutely no way, not ever, forget about it, go away please.

To recap: I am on my way to Los Angeles. Where I know nobody. To write a screenplay. That nobody is interested in. And I am not even allowed to drive a car. Things are not looking too good. Oh, and I can't even get to LA as the weathermen are predicting the largest storm on the east coast has seen in 15 years.

"Things couldn't be worse," I say to my American friend - my last American friend, in fact, for 3,000 miles.

"Hmm. Well, let's see. Maybe you've brought over that mouthy-foot disease and you're currently infecting the entire livestock population of America and President Bush will trace it back to you and you'll get executed."

"He can't do that! I'm only a temporary resident!"

After checking out the surrounding states to see if any have easier/more corrupt entrance qualifications, I am definitely stuck: the only way for me to be able to drive on this continent would be to put in an application for Canadian citizenship. Two years ago.

My guidebook is helpful. It says there are a couple of areas you can walk in LA, but you have to drive to get to them first. The British embassy is less helpful. It says: "If you have a death or are in prison, press one." Otherwise, please hold until you do in fact either die or get taken to prison for refusing to get off the phone.

Perhaps my driving problem will help once I get there. Perhaps this will prove a good way to meet people. Perhaps I will become famous for it, and people will say: "Have you heard about the girl who lives in Los Angeles who can't drive a car? Let's make friends with her!"

In the meantime, however, I am stuck in the polar - and polar is the appropriate word - opposite of LA, Philadelphia. Philadelphia has a slogan: "The city that loves you back." I'm not entirely sure I'm comfortable with that. And surely, if it really loved me, it would let me caress its tarmac with a shiny red car.

It has been solidly sleeting for seven hours, and excitable weather forecasters are predicting the most horrendous storms in history for the next three days. Now, let me see. I seem to recall a plan about writing comedy scripts lying next to swimming pools, sipping Mai Tais. I mean, if I'd wanted a really dreadful time I'd have gone to India on my gap year like everybody else (and then come back and pretended it was brilliant). My agent, rather ominously, gave me as a going-away present a book just called Story. In my depressed state, I'm too scared to open it, in case it is a sea of blank pages with the words: "Write one."

 Jenny Colgan is seeking fame and fortune in Los Angeles. She will be reporting fortnightly on her progress.

fields.headline: Radio pick of the day
fields.trailText: Moneybox Budget Call | Crossing Continents | Changing Places
fields.body:
If you can't work out what Gordon Brown did to your finances yesterday, telephone Vincent Duggleby and his expert panel, who offer assistance in Moneybox Budget Call (9.0am, Radio 4).

It's 50 years since large numbers of Moluccan islanders fled from Indonesia to the Netherlands. As Christians they had rebelled against Moslem independence and sought refuge with their former colonists. Olenka Frenkiel has recently visited them for Crossing Continents (11.0am, Radio 4) and, though their material conditions have improved, the old spiritual wounds obviously remain raw.

The new series of Changing Places (4.0pm, Radio 4) finds Howard Stableford exploring a consortium of imaginative recycling schemes. John Barrett developed a method of turning old wine bottles into flat sheets of glass. Clem Spencer makes demolition waste into chipboard. And, to the delight of Paignton Zoo, Tom Young transforms its sewage into a compost called Zoo Poo.

Last year 635 million people holidayed abroad at an average cost of £475 a head. That's an industry generating £300 billion a year, the world's greatest single source of overseas income. Unfortunately, as Susan Marling discovers in People And Places (8.30pm, World Service and Friday 2.30am, Radio 4), the people whose environment and culture attract the visitors seldom benefit. One project in Kenya hopes to correct this.

webTitle: Satellite, cable and digital pick of the day

fields.headline: Satellite, cable and digital pick of the day
fields.trailText: A Man Escaped | Live Golf
fields.body:
Films

A Man Escaped (Robert Bresson, 1956) 6pm, FilmFour
This classic of European art cinema is based on the true story of a resistance fighter's escape from a Nazi fortress in occupied France, but Bresson adds a deep spiritual significance. The break-out is documented in minute detail, and all along seems guided by a higher power. A quiet, meditative masterpiece, it inspired many prison movies to come, including FilmFour's next offering:

Birdman of Alcatraz (John Frankenheimer, 1961) 8pm, FilmFour
A biopic of Robert Stroud, the murderer whose ornithological studies helped him to survive a lifetime's imprisonment. Burt Lancaster plays the birdman and in the protracted battle to free him there's heavyweight support from Karl Malden and Edmond O'Brien. Neville Brand, that mad con of Riot In Cell Block 11, is on the other side of the bars, as a hostile warder.

Cool Hand Luke (Stuart Rosenberg, 1967) 8pm, Sky Cinema
Paul Newman is in his prime as the prisoner who maintains inner freedom despite the brutalities of a Deep South chain gang. But the hardnut action is lightened by a witty, funny streak - great moments like the much celebrated egg-eating contest. Strother Martin is the vicious camp boss, and George Kennedy won an Oscar for his tough convict who comes to respect Luke.

True Crime (Clint Eastwood, 1999) 10pm, Sky Premier
Clint is a veteran reporter smelling something fishy in the case against a convicted murderer (Isaiah Washington), and there are only 12 hours left to save him from execution. A taut tale, if the plotting is a little obvious, with the journo routinely finding evidence the police have missed. But the focus is on the characters - choicest being the confrontations between Eastwood and his editor, James Woods. We could have done with more of that.

Sleepers (Barry Levinson, 1996) 10.30pm, FilmFour
In the 60s, four kids from the New York slums are sent to reform school ruled by sadistic paedophile Kevin Bacon; 15 years on, two of the kids, now Scorsese-style wiseguys, kill their onetime abuser and are protected by another of the four, now assistant DA, Brad Pitt. Levinson lays on the prison hellhole abuse with a trowel and settles into an overheated courtroom battle, secure in theknowledge that top-notch acts such as Robert De Niro's priest and Dustin Hoffman's faded lawyer will keep the show rolling.
Paul Howlett

Sports

The break-out is documented in minute detail, and all along seems guided by a higher power. A quiet, meditative masterpiece, it inspired many prison movies to come, including FilmFour's next offering: Birdman of Alcatraz (John Frankenheimer, 1961) 8pm, FilmFour A biopic of Robert Stroud, the murderer whose ornithological studies helped him to survive a lifetime's imprisonment. But the hardnut action is lightened by a witty, funny streak - great moments like the much celebrated egg-eating contest. Strother Martin is the vicious camp boss, and George Kennedy won an Oscar for his tough convict who comes to respect Luke. fields.headline: Hams and eggs
fields.trailText: Home Front | The Human Face | Coronation Street
fields.body:
For sheer shameless showbiz, I recommend the entrance of the egg in a new series of Home Front (BBC 2).

Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen was faithfully reviving the kind of bright white cubist house favoured by Hercule Poirot, while Diarmuid Gavin created a Metro Goldwyn Mayer film set in the garden.

But something, Diarmuid felt, was missing. A mechanical Oscar was abandoned in case it crushed the children. Then inspiration ("I've got it!") came like tongues of fire to ignite his hair.

He had remembered a U2 concert where the band arrived in a giant lemon. (I think it possible that a spaceship was intended, but I'm more than happy to go along with the lemon.) "That shape and rock'n'roll and Hollywood and entertainment lead me towards a mirror ball in the shape of an egg!"

He was on the mobile to his egg man. "Think of a grenade! You know the raised markings on a grenade? Do you understand this?" It is a tribute to Anglo-Saxon phlegm that they did not hesitate to make a six-foot grenade in the utmost secrecy for a bloke called Diarmuid.

The egg was smuggled into Luton under cover of Sunday and a large tarpaulin. The owners of the house and their children, coincidentally called Crow, were finally allowed to look. They gasped, then laughed till they cried. In the Metro Goldwyn Mayer garden, the glittering egg twirled on the spot as if to show off its best side. It was ridiculously pretty in an overweight way. Spotlights bounced off its silver skin. It looked like a brontosaurus baby which wanted to go into show business. Anyone could see the kid had star quality, it just shone. The egg posed... paused... then opened to show a mirrored cocktail cabinet, shining with enough gin to make Noël Coward slur his consonants.

I was knocked sideways. There is, just one thing. Luton is probably famed for its abstemiousness but - did anyone put a lock on this thing?

Home Front exercised the chuckle muscles, which John Cleese recommended highly, if irritably, in a new series, The Human Face (BBC 1). According to Dr Kataria, the founder of some 600 laughing clubs in India, including a popular one in Bombay (now Mumbai, for heaven's sake) prison, "A laughter session makes you feel fresh through all the day. Also it boosts your immune system, and all the minor symptoms of coughs, colds, throat infections will go down significantly." Mr Kadokawa, who runs a smiling school in Japan, had more concrete concerns. " You can boosts sales 30% to 50% by smiling." His class, raised in an inscrutable culture, practised smiling widely with chopsticks in their teeth. Healthy and wealthy, then. Whoopee.

President Clinton, whose unusually mobile and expressive face may help to explain his popularity, deserved a warm screen credit for his contributions. He demonstrated both the turned down smile, as seen when the bill turns up, and that fleeting, distressed rumple of the brow that indicates someone is lying ("I want you to listen to me. I am going to say this again. I did not have sexual relations with that woman.")

I hardly needed professors to tell me that someone who smiles easily is likely to be happily married and that a look of contempt and disgust is an early warning of divorce. Curiously, the psychologist, who monitors such danger signals, claimed that the recipient of withering looks is vulnerable to infection for four years.

John Cleese, whose natural element is incinerating rage, managed to get into a row with a robot, several computers, a passing motorist, Liz Hurley, his lovely assistant, and, of course, the BBC. Who are due to catch a nasty cold any day now.

Meanwhile Coronation Street (Granada) is paying the price of filming well before transmission. Impervious to the smoke of funeral pyres, Fred Elliott, master butcher of this parish, is organising a Weatherfield-wide sausage competition. There is no suggestion that, at the moment, pigs have more pressing matters on mind. On the plus side, he has acquired an assistant, Boris, whose agitated eyebrows indicate that summat's going on backstage there. Though, admittedly, not much. Fred, Ashley and Boris, each fractionally dafter than the last, are strongly reminiscent of a music-hall act. Many successful Coronation Street partnerships seem to come spiritually somewhere between the sea lions and the Road to Mandalay.

webTitle: Astronomers shed new light on van Gogh

fields.headline: Astronomers shed new light on van Gogh
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Astronomer-detectives have pinpointed the exact moment when Vincent van Gogh painted one of his more enigmatic works.
fields.body:
Astronomer-detectives have pinpointed the exact moment when Vincent van Gogh painted one of his more enigmatic works.

White House at Night is a twilight study of a solitary village house and a bright evening star, painted shortly before the artist's suicide in 1890. The painting disappeared before the second world war, hidden from Nazi looters in the 1930s, and reappeared in Russia in 1995. It is now at the Hermitage in St Petersburg.

Donald Olson of South West Texas State University is a kind of astronomer-sleuth.

Last year he used astronomical evidence to persuade the world that the Franklin's Tale, by Geoffrey Chaucer, referred to a freak tide in Brittany on the night of December 19, 1340.

In 1999, he traced the origins of the term "blue moon", and in the same year tracked down evidence that the young Abraham Lincoln witnessed the great Leonid meteor storm of 1833, and used the experience in folksy tales when he became president of the United States. In 1998, Prof Olson proposed that the star mentioned in Act 1, Scene 1 of Hamlet - the "same star that's westward of the pole" - could have been the famous supernova of 1572, identified by the astronomer Tycho Brahe.

Now, according today's New Scientist, he has used computer calculations and a field trip to a town northwest of Paris to pinpoint the moment of creation of a van Gogh.

Only five of the painter's works show the night sky. "I was surprised his paintings have such a strong basis in reality," Prof Olson said. He and his colleague Russell Doescher noticed that van Gogh painted Venus and other planets with strong yellow halos. He organised a student field trip to Auvers-sur-Oise, where the painter stayed in 1890 after a year in an asylum, and located the white house in the painting.

Once he had found it, he knew which way van Gogh had been facing when he began painting, and then calculated that he began the work from the bottom up, in the course of an afternoon and evening, just six weeks before the artist shot himself.

"You can see it's about 7pm from the sunlight on the house but as the sun sets, Venus becomes bright and obvious," he said. Venus would have been in approximately that position in the sky at 8pm on June 16, 1890. "We can say exactly when he was painting."

webTitle: Obituary: Countess Elisabeth von der Schulenburg

fields.headline: Countess Elisabeth von der Schulenburg
fields.standfirst:
German aristocrat who became a nun and a sculptor - and formed her own special relationship with the Durham miners

Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: German aristocrat who became a nun and a sculptor - and formed her own special relationship with the Durham miners.
fields.body:
When she died, aged 97, Elisabeth von der Schulenburg was perhaps the most celebrated nun in Germany. As a sculptor and with her drawings, Sister Paula, the adoptive name conferred by her Ursuline order, helped support her religious family. She was also a legend in two countries, England and Germany, whose conflict so much defined the near-century she lived through.

Born and brought up in an historic Prussian military family, the only girl among five boys, Tisa, as she was always known, rebelled from adolescence onward. She shocked her father, who had been chief of staff to the crown prince during the "Kaiser's war" of 1914-18, by marrying a divorced Jewish businessman, Fritz Hesse. He was nearly 20 years older. She was always proud, nevertheless, that Count Friederich treated his son-in-law with impeccable manners.

In Berlin in the late 20s and early 30s, Tisa's looks - she was tall, striking and very attractive to men - brought her talent and personality to the notice of the liberal and left intelligentsia of the Weimar Republic. She became friends with the Manns - Thomas and Heinrich - Einstein, Kassirer, Remarque and Brecht. Her rich husband read the writing on the wall earlier than most, and in 1933 they left Berlin and settled in Highgate.

In old age, Tisa remembered the English years as her happiest. She became a friend of Henry Moore and formed a lifelong association with the mining community in Durham. It started with her giving art lessons to unemployed miners and went on well into the 1980s. She also joined an Artists Against Fascism group; this at a time when her family, including the father whom, characteristically, she very much loved, were moving into the Nazi camp.

The conflict between Tisa's affection for her family and her horror at what was happening in Germany came to a head in 1939. Her father died and was given a state funeral by Hitler. Divorced by this time, but with her artistic and social life firmly grounded in an England which she always associated with personal and political liberty, she attended the funeral. While she was there, her favourite brother, Fritz-Dietlof, drew her aside from the others and confided that he had joined a resistance conspiracy. Following the July 1944 attempt on Hitler's life, he was hanged in Plotzenzee prison.

On her return to her adopted country shortly before war was declared, she was refused re-entry at Croydon airport. "My trouble was that the Germans thought I was a Communist and the British thought I was a Nazi," she recalled - she was to spend the war years in Germany.

After the war and the breakdown of another marriage, Tisa felt that Germany had turned into "a gigantic graveyard". The sensitivity to suffering of any kind which was a feature of her art - she was one of the first artists to tackle the Holocaust thematically - blended with a determination, her own record notwithstanding, to avoid collective responsibility. Brought up as a Lutheran, she became a Catholic nun in 1950, and until the second Vatican Council of 1963 her order was a strict one. After what she considered a second liberation by Pope John XXIII, she wore elegant clothes again and paid regular visits to Fritz-Dietlof's children, four of whom live in the British Isles. Her passionate and unstuffy character and her total recall of the human background to so many of the 20th century's pivotal events made her a most original woman, and her work had the strength and individuality to reflect this.

Grey Gowrie

Vince Rea writes: I first met Tisa Schulenburg at the Bede Gallery in Jarrow in 1974, introduced to her by the writer Sid Chaplin. She had come to the gallery to see archive material about the Jarrow Crusade and to see the place where William Jobling, the Jarrow miner, was gibbeted on Jarrow Slake during the miners' strike of 1832.

You knew at once that she was a person who lived at a higher voltage than most. In those days the Bede Gallery, apart from organising exhibitions based on working-class history, was also a rallying point where young artists and writers would meet to talk, swap ideas and share enthusiasms.

Tisa was an active participant in the culture she was visiting and won the respect and trust of everyone. Later, she invited me to Newcastle to see her drawings. She had been involved in the north of England since 1936 - she stayed in the Spennymoor settlement for miners. Mining had a special fascination for her. She had been allowed twice down a mine, which in those days was an exception. She made many sketches.

In a sense, Durham became home to her more than London. She taught the unemployed miners in their clubs how to carve, she talked with them, sketched them and she made friends with them.

In 1975, an exhibition of her work at the Bede Gallery was a great success. Miners and their families came from Durham and the surrounding mining villages, Spennymoor, Easington, Westoe and Horden. She had encouraged the miners to bring their paintings, drawings and carvings. The exhibition seemed to break down the barriers that surrounded art and art galleries at that time.

People had found out that Tisa was a German countess. One comment that Tisa always found funny was: "Hey man. She'd been decked out in diamonds from the day she was born, wid hav ti win the pools 50 times ti get back ti where she started from." Tisa had no money, but what she did have was herself and her art. She would give you both. Her art was not made to promote trends in art, it was made to express a sincere human sentiment. Tisa had an intelligence and compassion for the lives of those she encountered. She kept in touch with me as the years rolled by, sending me new prints that she had produced.

When a new gallery finally got off the ground in the middle of Jarrow shopping centre, Tisa was overjoyed. At 96, she seemed incredibly alive and in good spirits. We planned a one-man show for Tisa's work at the gallery. When I wrote to her asking for some more holocaust prints, the reply I received was a scrawl and hardly discernible. An accompanying letter explained that Tisa was lapsing in and out of consciousness. So, instead of writing to her, I decided to have a video recording made of her private view and visitors to the exhibition, in the hope that she might recognise that it was her show.

We all in Jarrow admired her because of her commitment throughout her long life as an artist and her humanitarian ideal. Hers is a committed art, demanding a better future. She would like her art to be for the workers mainly, an art to be understood by all.

 Elisabeth von der Schulenburg, sculptor, nun and miners' friend, born December 7 1903, died February 8 2001.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: Send letters to online.feedback@guardian.co.uk. Please include a full postal address and telephone number. Short letters stand a better chance of being published. No attachments, please
fields.trailText: Your mail
fields.body:
Digital blow

On March 1, Online reported on the problem of copyright violation through appropriation of the source code for web pages.

This issue strikes at the heart of digital society. There are huge social benefits from the free reuse of source code, because otherwise everybody has to recreate the same basic techniques.

But the original author should be rewarded for their work - if they give it away free, they can't earn a living.

How can the web survive in these circumstances? The same question applies to "open source" systems such as Linux, and to the battles over Napster technology for bypassing copyright ownership. The lives of technologists, artists, and ordinary people depend on the answers.

The Arts Council of England and the Cambridge University Computer Laboratory have recognised the need for debate that crosses the arts/technology divide, including opinion-formers, legal experts and policy makers. The resulting conference in Cambridge next month has a few places open to the public - details are at: www.cl.cam.ac.uk/CODE/

Alan Blackwell
alan.blackwell@cl.cam.ac.uk

Taxi please

Re ordering a taxi via SMS (Online, March 1): What a ludicrous idea. Anyone who has ever used SMS or paging knows that messages cannot be guaranteed to arrive to a time like that. Your taxi may well turn up if your initial SMS arrives with the cab company within a reasonable time, but the confirmation messages are pointless and could arrive days late, if at all. As SMS facilities in European cities become more clogged with kids txtng 3ch thr, something ostensibly useful such as a way to book a taxi will become rapidly pointless, if it isn't pointless already.

Sam Nelson
sam@cs.stir.ac.uk

Suspicion

SA Mathieson (Insight of the Law, Online March 1) quotes the idea that "there should be reasonable suspicion of [benefit] fraud before a [bank] customer's information is surrendered". Given the pressure claimants are under to have benefits paid directly into bank accounts (very convenient), the mere fact of claiming benefit seems to be sufficient excuse.

D. Cameron
Stoke-on-Trent

Bemused

Two letters on March 1 regarding Freeserve make me wonder. I have signed up for Freeserve Anytime but am beginning to wish I hadn't. It barely works at all. Connecting to the service is a pain. The dialup number has two components, namely a six-digit prefix and an 0845 call number. The first six digits are supposed to access the special free terminal arranged with BT, which then enables contact with the 0845 number. Almost invariably when my dialer has got as far as the prefix digits there is a click, then the charming computerised BT lady voice announces: "The network is busy, please try later," or words to that effect. The following digits achieve nothing, although if you dial them separately, contact is established at once, but at a cost.

On two occasions in the past week I have achieved access at the first dialing. Every other time I get the BT lady, and dial again and again, sometimes as many as 20 times before getting the proper connection noises.

Three emails, a phone call to customer services and two expensive calls to the Freeserve "help" line only apologised and referred me to BT, who referred me back to Freeserve, saying there were not enough slots in the free connector for the number of customers, kindly explaining to me how the system works, which was interesting but didn't achieve anything.

henry@henhud.freeserve.co.uk

I have come across friends who have thought that merely opening the Outlook Express inbox would automatically download mail from their ISP, not realising that they need to log on to their mail server.

Thus they only got mail when they wrote a message and actively clicked the Send/Receive button.

des@dgeere.freeserve.co.uk

The only service open to those without BT phone lines is BT Internet Pay-as-you-go which I do not want. I have used BTinternet for several years and I had no wish to move website or change my email address but I will now be forced to as I will not be bullied into paying for one of BT's overly expensive lines.

Andrew Aitken
andrew.aitken@btinternet.com

fields.headline: What's new
fields.trailText: Out of the Sonicblue | Pretty pictures | Mobile music
fields.body:
Out of the Sonicblue

Sonicblue, the company behind the Diamond Rio range of MP3 players, is now moving in on the CD personal market. Its debut player, the £170 Rio Volt PSX100, spins CD-roms loaded with MP3 files, as well as standard CDs, CD-Rs and CD-RWs.

Its unique feature, however, is that it is the first to go on sale in the UK to playback Windows Media Audio (WMA) files stored on a CD-rom. The format's efficient compression system means a CD-rom can store at least 17 hours of near-CD quality WMA music - seven hours more than the 10 hours of MP3 files it can archive.

The player is also the first on sale to feature the ID3 tagging system which flashes up the name of the artist and the track on the player's backlit LCD screen.

Coming at the end of the month is the Rio 800, Sonic blue's newest addition to its MP3 player range. The model shares its styling and many of its features with the existing Rio 600 model. It will play back WMA files, and Apple fans should note that it is one of only a handful of MP3 players that is Mac-friendly.

The Rio 800 also comes with a voice recorder and 64MB storage - twice that in the 600. It is expected to cost around £250.

Pretty pictures

Philips is targeting gadget-grabbers with a new range of PC peripherals.

Due at the end of March is the latest in its series of webcams, the £100 PCVC750K. This oval-shaped camera sits atop a PC screen and takes both moving and still images.

Its unique facility is its built in-scanner which provides real-time transfer of text, images and 3D objects to the PC. Gadget-lovers will also enjoy using its voice recognition system that instructs the camera to automatically take a picture when the user says "cheese."

Philips also plans to offer an LCD monitor with an integrated TV tuner. Due to hit the shops in October, the 17-inch screen includes Teletext. Its picture-in-picture technology gives the user the option of surfing the net while watching a TV programme simultaneously.

The company has also unveiled the Fisio 610, a GPRS (General Packet Radio Service) mobile phone that is more akin to current GSM models than it is the handheld PC type GPRS prototypes paraded by other makers. There's no colour screen or HTML-ready web browser - rather the Fisio offers always-on, fast downloading of Wap sites. Like other mobiles in Philips' range it offers voice activated dialling and control. Expect to see it in the stores when GPRS networks are fully up and running in the summer. An entire range of Fisio phones is slated to reach the market in June.

Other accessories Philips is promising this year include a trio of LCD projectors priced at £2,000-£2,900, new LCD and CRT monitors and a range of flat speakers.

Mobile music

Sony has become the latest manufacturer (after Samsung and Siemens) to offer a mobile phone that doubles as a music player. However, its CMD-MZ5 boasts a unique feature - an integrated ATRAC 3 converter. Using its accompanying analogue/ optical cable, music can be transferred to the mobile's Memory Stick storage card from any hi-fi device, not just from a PC. The phone also comes with a 64MB Memory Stick that the maker claims stores up to two hours of near-CD quality tunes. Rival models only have 32MB of storage.

The phone also has a long battery life. Sony claims that after listening to two hour's worth of music, the phone has 60 minutes of talk time left. Music can be listened to either via a pair of earphones or through attachable powered speakers.

Other facilities include a Wap browser, the ability to send and receive email from an existing account, a 500-space phonebook, a calendar and four games.

The phone goes on sale in May priced at around £300-350.

fields.headline: A dream screen
fields.standfirst: Making film for Palm OS handhelds is tough, but  Chloe Veltman  finds one man pushing the limits of the fledgling art form
fields.trailText: Making film for Palm OS handhelds is tough, but Chloe Veltman finds one man pushing the limits of the fledgling art form
fields.body:
When Rodney Ascher stepped into a San Francisco bar for a cocktail one evening, he had no intention of turning a quiet drink into the subject of a film, least of all a film people could carry around with them in their pockets.

"I happened to have a disposable camera on me and on a whim took 24 shots, thinking one might be suitable for the cover of a friend's punk rock album," he remembers. As things transpired, none of the pictures was punk rock material. However, with a little digital animation magic, they became the source for a miniature movie, a 30-second neon jewel created to fit a PDA (personal digital assistant).

Most people still think of PDAs as electronic organisers in which to store addresses or make notes: sending email over a handheld device is still considered to be radical. With their tiny interfaces and even smaller memories, not even the most short-sighted of film makers could call the PDA a dream screen.

But for Jason Wishnow, a 27-year-old digital movie pioneer and the founder of NewVenue.com , established in 1996 as the first curated website for films made expressly for the internet, the handheld device is the moving picture's new frontier. "Originally, I wanted to push the limits of the internet because that was a new,unexplored medium. Now the PDA offers similar challenges to the early days of online film."

The challenges facing anyone making a film for PDA are daunting. "Video on a PDA is like video on the web a few years ago - small, choppy and the less detail the better," says Wishnow. Aside from the compromising size of the screen and pea-sized memory, there's the fact that many PDAs can only play video in black and white and do not have sound. "They are day planners, they are organisers, they are modest productivity tools. PDAs were not built to be home entertainment centres," says Wishnow. "But because they are powered by a microchip, they can be."

Seeing these technological shortcomings as a virtue, Wishnow launched the world's first PDA film competition in November. Known as The Aggressively Boring Film Festival, 69 digital artists and film-makers submitted entries that could be downloaded from the NewVenue website (www.newvenue.com/takeout) to the Sony CLIÉ handheld device and played using the gMedia playback software produced by the Palo Alto-based wireless multimedia company Generic Media.

Festival entries ranged from Dan Rootman and Chris Shiki's Bad Ass Jack and the Fat Stack, a grainy spoof gangster flick with dialogue cards to tell the story in lieu of sound, to Louise McKissick's first prize-winning I Love You. This 15-second visual poem about the I Love You computer virus involves the artist's lips whispering sweet nothings to 3,000 ladybirds crawling on the inside of a tea cup.

The technology for streaming video has greatly evolved. On March 1, Generic Media launched its gMovie Maker, allowing users to convert video, animation and still images into the gMovie format on Macintosh and Windows-based computers. The gMovie files can then be transferred to a handheld device using the gMovie player, which works on all Palm OS devices, not just the CLIÉ. Although the system does not yet support audio, PDA videos can now appear in glorious colour.

For McKissick, the mobile platform simply presents a new outlet for expression. "I'm always trying to put my work in an unconventional format. I like the idea of being in places where people don't usually expect to come across art." While for Ascher, the tech nology provides a new challenge: "You have to force yourself to pare down your work to the bare minimum and create really simple, iconographic images."

Despite the merits of experimenting with a new technology and the creativity of the film makers, the future of streaming video on handheld devices doubtless lies beyond the realm of art house cinema. "Think about mobile TVs. Did they take off?" asks Brad Smith, the data editor at the wireless industry publication Wireless Week. Wireless video companies such as the San Diego-based PacketVideo are concentrating on promoting consumer content such as news headlines, sports highlights, games and online trading to complement their web-streaming technology. "Streaming video to handheld devices is about providing people with information they need to know right now," says Lauren Cole, of PacketVideo's applications and services department.

Nevertheless, Wishnow is not giving up on the fledgling art form. Having introduced the notion of video on PDA to the world with his film festival, he is revving up for the sequel: The Massively Boring Film Festival. "The notion of a 1.5 x 1.5 inch black-and-white film without sound may seem extraordinarily dull, but the limitations of the medium can actually be quite liberating for filmmakers," he says. "It's all about transcending the tedium."

fields.headline: Shelf life for Sega toys
fields.standfirst: Michael Fitzpatrick on a new robot sensation
fields.trailText: Michael Fitzpatrick on a new robot sensation
fields.body:
You might not have a cool million for a real android but Sega is hoping its cheaper mini human-like toys will please the masses as its robotic hound Poo-Chi have more recently.

Working with Tiger Electronics, Sega has come up with the BOT series of humanoid toys that can walk, dance and 'talk' with people through facial expressions, body language and messages that appear on its LCD face.

While less sophisticated than Sony's Aibo cyber dog and light years behind Honda's life-size human-like robot Asimo, Sega claims BOTs are the first humanoid toy robot to be marketed commercially.

The first BOT to be launched this May, the C-Bot measuring 21.5cm tall and weighing about 400 grams, will be able to show emotions such as laughing and crying through its LCD, as well as using hand and neck movements to convey expression. The new droid will also be able to display on a monitor messages that have been sent to the owner over a mobile phone. Sega says that C2 will sell at around £30.

By the summer C-BOT will be joined by M-BOT a 1,980 yen (£12) robot that dances to music, and the W-BOT, a 4,980 yen robot that walks on two feet and can navigate its way around obstacles.

Inspired by the success of Sony's Aibo, the BOTs now complete a family loosely based on Sony's more advanced robotic dog. After Sony's pet wonder sold out within minutes on the internet Sega came up with copy-cat but much cheaper Poo-Chi. The toy went on to sell more than 100 million units worldwide. Sega and Tiger hope to sell more than 1.5m units in the first year.
