webTitle: Acorn may no longer exist but its legacy lives on

fields.headline: From the BBC Micro, little Acorns grew
fields.standfirst: Acorn may no longer exist but its legacy lives on in countless ways as Joia Shillingford reports
fields.trailText: Acorn may no longer exist but its legacy lives on in countless ways as Joia Shillingford reports
fields.body:
Though worth £100m today, Hermann Hauser, the co-founder of Acorn in 1978, says some of his best moments are when people come up to him in the street and say: "Thanks for the BBC Micro."

Acorn's home computer - put on the map by the BBC in the early 80s - could have been a world beater that saw off competition from the US giants Apple and IBM. But, though Acorn itself has disappeared, its legacy is becoming more apparent.

Less than four months ago, Element 14, a chip design company spun out of Acorn, was sold to the US chip giant Broadcom for around $600m in shares. ARM Holdings, another Acorn chip-design spin-off, has a market value of £4.5bn.

Though proud of Acorn's legacy, Hauser, now one of the biggest backers of technology in Cambridge through the venture capital firm Amadeus Capital Partners, believes Acorn could have survived.

He says: "First, we should have really analysed how we compared to competing computers around the world. This would have shown us we had a real lead in terms of speed, price (£299-£399), operating system and expansion slots compared to our nearest rivals, the Apple II and Sinclair Spectrum.

"The BBC Micro was twice as fast as the Apple II, and could integrate text and colour graphics on the same screen. And it had built-in networking, which no other computer had at the time. You could even customise its hardware using BBC Basic rather then machine code."

Having worked out it had a lead not just in the UK but globally, Hauser believes Acorn should have gone around the world persuading people to adopt its products as the industry standard. "Then, we should have licensed our hardware and software to anyone that wanted them," he says. If it had done so, Acorn would still be collecting the royalties and IBM might never have been able to establish what later became the Wintel (Windows and Intel) hegemony.

Instead, even when it received offers to license its technology, such as a request from the home computer company Commodore to use its Econet networking system, it said no. "We thought our wonderful, proprietary technology gave us an advantage over competitors, so we hogged it," says Hauser.

Nevertheless, Acorn did want to sell PCs in the US. It set up a subsidiary with some managers it did not know very well and set about getting regulatory approval for its machines. This was very expensive and took a long time because of the unusually high number of devices that could be plugged into a BBC Micro. All had to be tested in connection with it, and the machine's radiation emissions also had to be reduced.

Around $20m was sunk into the US operation, says Hauser, which contributed to the cash-flow problems the company experienced in 1983-5. Its share price plummeted and Olivetti, of Italy, bailed it out, eventually taking a majority stake.

One thing it did get right - or almost right - was that it subcontracted the manufacture of its machines. However, its contracts with manufacturers were not flexible enough. So when it missed the Christmas slot for selling a new model, the Acorn Electron, which was followed by a dramatic downturn in demand for home computers, it could not stop its manufacturers making the machines.

This was another blow to its cashflow. Research and development spending was too high and several times the company appointed senior managers who were more interested in technology than in the day-to-day mechanics of running a business. Hauser is happy to admit that he is not a good manager, though his enthusiasm for ideas helped give Acorn the buzz of a leading research lab.

He says: "The big obstacle to getting company culture right is to stop people falling out with each other. You also have to be tolerant. When one of our most brilliant members of staff told me he would be coming in to work on Monday dressed as a woman, I was a bit taken aback. But he showed me the research on transsexuals, we talked about it, and she and I are still great friends."

The company culture was also reinforced over pasta. Hauser says: "If I was still in the office between 7pm and 8pm, I would be getting really hungry, so I would treat anyone else who was around to a meal at the Italian Kitchen."

Many of the company's most successful products started there, and there was a lot of competition to produce the best ideas. Also, there was real excitement about chip technology, rather like the excitement generated by the internet more recently.

The BBC spotted the trend early and made a programme called The Chips Are Down, which predicted there would be a computer in every home. "Some people thought this was the BBC getting weird," says Hauser. But at Cambridge University, where he studied physics and hung out with chip evangelists, "it was an idea we really believed in."

Hauser believed that to design a really efficient computer, you also needed to design the chip inside it. Originally, Acorn planned to use Intel's 286 chip in its Archi-medes computer. But because Intel would not let it license the 286 core and adapt it, Acorn decided to design its own.

This became the ARM (Acorn Risc Machine) chip, designed by Steve Furber and Sophie Wilson, and implemented by Jamie Urquhart, now a director of ARM. By then, most people were buying IBM-compatible PCs because they were cheap and lots of software was available. But because the ARM chip was so fast, there was a good market it.

Apple wanted to use the ARM in its Newton handheld so ARM (Advanced Risc Macines) was spun off as a separate company with Apple as a shareholder. But as ARM sales grew, it did so wellon the stockmarket that it began to distort Acorn's share price. Eventually, a sitation developed where Acorn's shares were worth less than its 25% stake in the business.

So Acorn, which had made BBC Micros for more than a decade, was dissolved in 1999, with the proceeds of the ARM stake going to shareholders. Element 14 was sold to Morgan Stanley, giving E14's management the option of buying it within three months, and Acorn's set-top box technology was sold to Pace Micro Technology for a nominal sum.

To Hauser, Acorn has metamorphosed rather than died. He says: "So many of the people I had worked with are still around as part of Element 14 (Stan Boland, the one-time Acorn head, and Sophie Wilson) or ARM.

Lots of other companies, most but not all successful, can also boast a connection with Acorn. For example, Alex van Someren, the ponytailed chief executive of the internet security company nCipher, dropped out of Eton after Hermann Hauser told him there was a job for him at Acorn when he left school.

Before that, he and his brother Nicko made money selling peripherals for the BBC Micro, such as go-faster boards. And after Olivetti's involvement in Acorn, Hauser (then vice president of research for Olivetti) and fellow Acorn director Andy Hopper set up a research laboratory for Olivetti, from which many companies were spun out.

These include Virata, a Nasdaq-listed telecoms company with a market value of more than $700m. It makes technology to expand the capacity of ordinary phone lines.

In the US, employees of the one-time chip giant Fairchild Semiconductor are known as Fairchildren after going on to do great things in Silicon Valley. In the UK, Acorn has given rise directly or indirectly to more than 30 companies, and many Little Acorns have become multi-millionaires.

It seems the BBC and its television programme, Micro Live, helped foster more than a home and school computer revolution, helping Britain into the digital age.

fields.headline: Games reviews
fields.trailText: European Super League | F1 Racing Championship | Grandia 2
fields.byline: Greg Howson, Jack Schofield, Andy Bodle
fields.body:
Destined to mediocrity, like Chelsea

European Super League Dreamcast
£39.99 Virgin Interactive *****

Football games on the Dreamcast are a bit like Chelsea FC - all the right ingredients but the reality can be woefully inadequate. With its tasty graphics and relatively easy development environment, you would expect Sega's machine to be well stocked with talent. But, rather like those underperformers at Stamford Bridge, the Dreamcast is stuck with unplayable arcade conversions like Virtual Striker 2 and the tedious Sega Worldwide Soccer. While every footy fan has ample reserves of optimism, anyone hoping for a late winner will be sadly disappointed with the latest signing - European Super League.

The game is not that bad, it is just depressingly average. For starters there are only 16 teams, which even when taking account of the vagaries of licensing, seems overly stingy.

Then there's the game itself. Marvel at Zidane's accurately modelled bald patch and the admittedly impressive stadia but groan as the match kicks off. Unless the sprint button is held down, the players move with Le Tissier-like sloth, though without his control and poise; players often run past the ball rather than retrieving it. Throw in comical tackles, random shooting and a ball that fails to adhere to the laws of physics and you've got a dead cert for relegation. But play a little longer and the flaws recede slightly.

Goals, while flowing too readily, are satisfying, and the slow pace allows a measured build-up. The graphics are smart, with the realistic venues adding something. Of course, all this talk of the realistic this and the accurately modelled that, tells you one thing: on the pitch, the game is destined to mid-table mediocrity. (GH)

Dice with Irvine but not Montoya

F1 Racing Championship PC
£29.99 Ubi Soft *****

There's no shortage of F1 racing games, especially arcade racers running on games consoles. However, the serious player who wants a proper simulation is almost certainly playing Geoff Crammond's Grand Prix series, which started with Revs on the Acorn BBC micro. But GP3 is there to be overtaken.

Coming up behind is Ubi Soft's F1 Racing Championship, the follow-up to F1 Racing Simulation, Monaco Grand Prix and other Ubi Soft efforts. Will the latest version, delayed until March 23, finally sweep past GP3?

The answer, sorry, is that I can't say. I found F1RC virtually unplayable, not because of the quality of the game, but because it was like taking a night drive wearing Raybans.

F1RC offers an impressive range of adjustments, down to the rigidity of rear anti-roll bars. When it comes to the graphics, you can decide whether or not to have tri-linear or anisotropic filtering, or both. But the programmers have left out the virtual knob for screen brightness, and even with the monitor turned up, the image on my PC was mostly black. (Ubi Soft says it was beta test code and no one else has had this problem.)

Fortunately Ubi Soft has added a beginner mode for people who can't handle the amateur, pro and expert levels. This enables virtually anyone to win with any car. You can bounce off tyre walls and still extend your lead by 15 seconds a lap. In the dark.

Step up to amateur, however, and it gets serious: the car becomes a pig to drive, and you can't treat the grass as an extension of the tarmac. The awkward placing of the read-outs does not help, especially the rev-counter half-way up the screen on the right. Mastering F1RC will take time and effort - probably more than mastering GP3.

But when you get really good, you will be able to take part in the equivalent of real grand prix races against 21 other drivers, either on the internet or a local area net-work. Direct connection and split-screen modes are provided for two-player battles.

While Ubi Soft claims FR1C is fabulously realistic, with tracks modelled to the nearest centimetre, one thing punctures the pleasure: the cars and drivers are based on the 1999 line-up. You can dice with Pedro de la Rosa, and back-end Irvine's Ferrari, but you can't touch wheels with Montoya. This may not trouble the serious gamer, who will hunt the web for new cars to download, but it will disappoint anyone who wants to play the current season. (JS)

A fun, vibrant user-friendly challenge

Grandia 2 Dreamcast
£39.99 Pinnacle/Ubi Soft *****

It seems like only yesterday that Grandia, the Japanese role-playing game, was launched on the western gaming world. In fact, it was around the middle of last week; it's just that the sequel has been translated more quickly than its predecessor.

Not that Grandia 2 is your typical rushed rehash. This is a more grown-up affair, with properly fleshed-out characters. The story also has a little more weight: as brooding youngblood Ryudo, you hook up with the pious Elena and others in a bid to swing the ultimate battle between good and evil.

The graphics, too, are a world away from the bland shades of Grandia, although this has much to do with the fact that this is on Dreamcast instead of PlayStation. Both character models and backgrounds are far more vibrant and detailed, and the combat animations are almost worthy of a PC game, although the characters' lack of faces means that empathising with your team is a doomed enterprise.

One thing Grandia 2 has retained is the control system - no great shock, since the interface was undoubtedly one of the original's biggest pluses. Combat in particular is both user-friendly and fun. A hybrid of real-time and turn-based action, it is not dissimilar to that used in Final Fantasy. However, it does offer more possibilities: as well as simply attacking, defending and casting spells, you can evade attacks and even foil an enemy attack. You can choose to run away, or even avoid battles altogether. Not that you need to: even the bosses are relative pushovers.

And this is the only area where Grandia 2 falls down. Not only are the battles easy, the puzzles wouldn't tax the average contestant on Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? This, combined with the linear storyline, makes it possible to finish a big game in less time than is usual for such a game. Having said that, it is refreshing to finish a game before the lease on your house runs out. (AB)

fields.headline: Games watch
fields.trailText: Saved | MS gaming
fields.body:
Saved

BarrysWorld, the online gaming site (www.barrysworld.com), is continuing in business, though it went into voluntary liquidation earlier this year. More than 100 companies registered their interest with the liquidator, with Electron ics Boutique carrying off the prize.

John Steinbrecher, EB's chief executive, said: "Until now, customers who purchased products in our stores with online gaming capabilities had to go elsewhere to experience this element of play. Electronics Boutique will now be able to provide an all-encompassing experience."

Electronic Arts, the biggest video game publisher, has also added to its online capabilities. It has just taken over the Pogo games site, which has about 17m members. Excite@Home had dropped out of a deal to buy Pogo (www.pogo.com) and EA snapped it up for about a quarter of the price.

MS gaming

Microsoft has unveiled the Links 2001 Course Converter (www.microsoft.com/games/links2001/), a free utility for people who own copies of LinksLS or Microsoft Golf. The converter will convert up to 36 golf courses into a format that can be used in Links 2001. The game also includes the Arnold Palmer Course Designer utility, which enables PC golfers to create their own courses.

Microsoft has also announced that a sequel to Asheron's Call, its popular online multiplayer role-playing game, has been under development for more than a year. The developer is Turbine Entertainment Software. Asheron's Call is only available via the Microsoft Game Zone at www.zone.com.

However, the Xbox teaser circulating recently is actually a spoof made for $60 by a 22-year-old American student, Roger Tinch. Daily Radar, a games news site, is hosting the 18-megabyte movie at www.dailyradar.com/features/game_feature_page_2379_1.html

Snake's alive!

You could appear in Konami's forthcoming Metal Gear Solid 2: Sons of Liberty game on the Sony PlayStation 2 or, to be accurate, your name could turn up on a dead enemy soldier's dog-tag. The Japanese company wants your name, birth date, blood type, nationality and other details, and there is an entry form at www.konami.co.jp/kcej/products/mgs2/mgs2name/index_e.html. The exact purpose of this is to be revealed. . .

webTitle: Women: On International Women's Day, four columnists report from their own neck of the woods.

fields.headline: So what's new?
fields.standfirst: Today is International Women's Day. How are things going globally? Four newspaper columnists report from their own neck of the woods
fields.trailText: Today is International Women's Day. How are things going globally? Four newspaper columnists report from their own neck of the woods.
fields.body:
Australia

Rosemary Neill

As we mark International Women's Day, Australian women are caught in a cultural pincer movement. On one flank are those who insist Australia is essentially a nation of mates and good blokes. On the other is a high camp sensibility which is increasingly a part of mainstream culture, as characterised by last weekend's Sydney Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras.

I have sometimes balked at the caricature of Australia as a macho theme park where real men wear dark blue singlets, flaunt their third trimester beer guts and consider light beer an insult to their masculinity. But then the cricketer Don Bradman died and I found myself wondering how an obsession with sport and mateship has gone beyond jingoism and turned into a national psychosis.

After the record-breaking batsman died last week, flags were hung at half-mast. Normal TV programming was suspended, broadsheets exiled regular news to the weather page and the emotionally constipated prime minister, John Howard, almost wept.

The landslide of media coverage has been like a blokey reprise of the mass mourning that followed the death of the Princess of Wales. Mostly male journalists have churned out sentimental bilge that banishes female readers to the sidelines of national mythology. One of the country's most respected political commentators wore his jockstrap on his sleeve when he wrote: "In a nation of mates, Bradman transcends mateship."

The media hysteria about an old man's death (Bradman was 92 and hadn't played Test cricket in over half a century) leaves a lot of women and men cold. When a colleague wrote a piece saying his death had left her unmoved, readers were furious at an irreverence that is admired everywhere else in antipodean culture.

Then again, Bradman was the nation's favourite son and Australia has always produced favourite sons and prodigal daughters. While the notion of sisterhood is seen as a quaint 70s anachronism, the mates thing is a religion - not long ago, the PM tried to convince voters to insert the word "mateship" into the constitution.

Although Aussie men are loath to admit it, there is a strong homoerotic impulse about the intense mateship that is said to characterise their friendships in sport, war and politics. This helps explain why a country that can seem so macho and homophobic is also a mecca for gay men.

The Sydney Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras, one of the biggest cultural and tourism events of the year, often falls in the same week as International Women's Day. While Reclaim the Night marches struggle to attract participants, a parade featuring more sequins and waxed flesh than a Vegas floor show attracts thousands.

While the Bradman hysteria has exposed those men who would rather forget women, Mardi Gras celebrates (at least in part) men who want to be women. While female identity is marginalised in Australian sports mythology, it is distorted and enlarged by Mardi Gras. Given this duality, it is no accident that the two best-known Australian women internationally are Germaine Greer - a refugee from ockerism - and Dame Edna Everage - a glittering parody of it.

Kylie Minogue also ranks highly among famous Australian women. She will never be a favourite son, but she has been christened a gay icon.

 Rosemary Neill is a columnist on the Australian.

Turkey

Ferai Tinc

It was a December night when I went to the poor eastern city of Batman, trying to find out what was driving the women there to kill themselves.

Nafiye, a middle-aged peasant woman who lived with her husband, her "kuma"(her husband's second wife) and her nine children, had tried to kill herself eight times. She kept repeating: "Life has become an unbearable burden. I can no longer carry on." It was not because she was sharing her husband with another woman - it was Nafiye herself who had brought the woman home, to share her own responsibilities. It wasn't even the poverty. It was, she said, that life had lost its meaning. A month after we met, I heard she had "liberated herself" from that life.

Thirty-eight women committed suicide in Batman last year and officials and specialists all agree that there is one main cause: lack of education. According to Turkish Ministry of Education figures from last year, 99.4% of boys started primary school as opposed to only 89.8% of girls. At secondary school and university, the percentage of women students is even lower.

With the declaration of the republic in 1923, Turkey made a radical decision to turn her face towards Europe and, as the country modernised, women were given more rights and were encouraged to go to school. But despite this, women still get less support than men for their education, both socially and officially.

In 1988, 16.7% of women aged 15-49 had no education at all. In areas where feudal relations remain strong, families give priority to their sons' education - daughters can stay at home or go out to work because, after all, the girl will marry and will not be responsible for making money for the family. That's the man's business.

However, exposure to the realities of the modern world is forcing people to see how behind the times they really are. With television and internet cafes now widespread, even in remote corners of the country, families have begun to understand the importance of education for girls.

In Batman, as in other parts of the region, women's organisations are setting up special classes for girls and their mothers, covering everything from reading and writing to carpet weaving. There has been a high uptake and the positive effects of these classes are evident. Some of the women here admit that they, too, have wanted to commit suicide in the past; everybody has their reason. "But after this course, I am changed," one woman says. "Now I can make my own plans for my own future."

 Ferai Tinc is foreign policy columnist of Hrriyet Daily News.

India

Tavleen Singh

You can be an Indian woman and spend your whole life in India, without ever seeing the cloistered, brutal world in which the average Indian woman lives and dies. My first glimpse of it came from a story I did more than 20 years ago as a junior reporter. The story was of a dowry death, though the term was unheard of in the early 70s, and through the short, sad life and terrible death of Kanchan, 22, I learned that the India in which I grew up had nothing to do with the India in which most Indian women live.

My safe, middle-class India was a place of westernised boarding schools and English headmistresses who fed ideas of career and rebellion. The worst thing that could happen was an arranged marriage to a man who may turn out to be a philanderer or a brute. But there were always choices.

In Kanchan's world, there were none. When she finished college, her parents started "looking for a boy". When they found one, they borrowed money and arranged the wedding. Her bridegroom was a stranger but she was told it was her job to "adjust". This was easy for her to accept, brought up as she had been on the old Indian idea that a girl is paraya dhan, somebody else's wealth, and that good Indian girls leave their parents' home as brides and return only as corpses.

Kanchan found these ideas did not matter to her husband or his family. Only one thing did: she had not brought enough dowry. So began a year of beatings, abuse and brutality. She told her parents, pleaded for help; they reminded her she must learn to "adjust". She tried but her efforts were not good enough for her mother-in-law and sister-in-law, so one day they held her down, poured kerosene over her and set her on fire. Then they locked the door and left her to die. By the time the neighbours heard her screams, it was too late.

Twenty years on, the big change is that most dowry deaths get reported. They rose from fewer than 500 per year in the 70s to more than 5,000 in the 90s. What remains unchanged is that most Indian women still have no choices and their voices remain unheard, except as occasional headlines, when sisters make suicide pacts to escape dowry demands and are found hanging from ceiling fans.

The voices that get heard instead are those of educated, middle-class women. So for the past five years, the most important feminist issue in India has been the demand to reserve for women 33% of seats in parliament and the state legislative assemblies.

If this becomes law, will it make a difference in that other India, where 20,000 rapes are reported every year and baby girls can be killed before they are born? Women legislators will make no difference unless society changes and society will change only through women's education. Literacy in Indian women, at just over 30%, is half that of men, so they often do not even know that their world is cloistered and brutal or that it does not have to be.

 Tavleen Singh is senior columnist at India Today.

Hong Kong

Christine Loh

Hong Kong women are among the luckiest in the world. They are well-educated and relatively wealthy, and the city's gross national product now exceeds that of the UK. But if there were a gross national happiness index, Hong Kong might not rank so high.

Hong Kongers have an extremely stressful lifestyle in what is probably the world's fastest moving city. The go-go, high-octane charge is exhilarating but it can wear you down, and the pressure on women starts early.

Children grow up in families in which both parents work and many mothers have little time to spend with their children. Instead they hire full-time, live-in helpers, women from south-east and south Asia who leave their families so they can earn enough abroad to send money home to give their children a better life.

Girls are doing well at school, but boys have a higher chance of getting into the school of their choice, even with lower grades, because the system is skewed to produce sexual balance in co-ed schools. The Equal Opportunity Commission is currently taking the government to court over its school place allocation system.

As they grow up, Hong Kong girls are bombarded by ads selling the image of the ideal woman - emaciated and unhealthy-looking. Yet women are also urged to eat. Fast food is everywhere but it is making us overweight and this is painful for women whose self-image is so often tied to body shape.

Furthermore, in this highly materialistic society, shopping has become a hobby and a measure of wellbeing. For middle-and upper-class women in particular, there is enormous pressure always to be well-groomed.

Time is what a woman finds hardest to have for herself. After coping with her job, the traffic jams and a stressed child with homework to do, she is exhausted. Her husband is equally stressed and intimacy in the bedroom falls by the wayside.

The hidden pain among Hong Kong women is the issue of the mistress. With increasing travel to mainland China, the "across-the-border mistress" has become popular and affordable, even for men in low-income brackets such as truck drivers. For the mistress, it is a purely financial transaction. Her body and looks are assets which can help her to become better off - more like Hong Kong women. A few years ago, when a legislator suggested male waywardness should be criminalised, women responded angrily.

Hong Kong women have made it in material terms, but we must find ways to feed ourselves emotionally and spiritually. And we fear that if we get off the treadmill, we will lose everything.

 Christine Loh is a contributor to the South China Morning Post and CEO of a public policy thinktank.
fields.bodyText: Australia Rosemary Neill As we mark International Women's Day, Australian women are caught in a cultural pincer movement. On one flank are those who insist Australia is essentially a nation of mates and good blokes. On the other is a high camp sensibility which is increasingly a part of mainstream culture, as characterised by last weekend's Sydney Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras. I have sometimes balked at the caricature of Australia as a macho theme park where real men wear dark blue singlets, flaunt their third trimester beer guts and consider light beer an insult to their masculinity. But then the cricketer Don Bradman died and I found myself wondering how an obsession with sport and mateship has gone beyond jingoism and turned into a national psychosis. After the record-breaking batsman died last week, flags were hung at half-mast. Normal TV programming was suspended, broadsheets exiled regular news to the weather page and the emotionally constipated prime minister, John Howard, almost wept. The landslide of media coverage has been like a blokey reprise of the mass mourning that followed the death of the Princess of Wales. Mostly male journalists have churned out sentimental bilge that banishes female readers to the sidelines of national mythology. One of the country's most respected political commentators wore his jockstrap on his sleeve when he wrote: "In a nation of mates, Bradman transcends mateship." The media hysteria about an old man's death (Bradman was 92 and hadn't played Test cricket in over half a century) leaves a lot of women and men cold. When a colleague wrote a piece saying his death had left her unmoved, readers were furious at an irreverence that is admired everywhere else in antipodean culture. Then again, Bradman was the nation's favourite son and Australia has always produced favourite sons and prodigal daughters. While the notion of sisterhood is seen as a quaint 70s anachronism, the mates thing is a religion - not long ago, the PM tried to convince voters to insert the word "mateship" into the constitution. Although Aussie men are loath to admit it, there is a strong homoerotic impulse about the intense mateship that is said to characterise their friendships in sport, war and politics. This helps explain why a country that can seem so macho and homophobic is also a mecca for gay men. The Sydney Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras, one of the biggest cultural and tourism events of the year, often falls in the same week as International Women's Day. While Reclaim the Night marches struggle to attract participants, a parade featuring more sequins and waxed flesh than a Vegas floor show attracts thousands. While the Bradman hysteria has exposed those men who would rather forget women, Mardi Gras celebrates (at least in part) men who want to be women. While female identity is marginalised in Australian sports mythology, it is distorted and enlarged by Mardi Gras. Given this duality, it is no accident that the two best-known Australian women internationally are Germaine Greer - a refugee from ockerism - and Dame Edna Everage - a glittering parody of it. Kylie Minogue also ranks highly among famous Australian women. She will never be a favourite son, but she has been christened a gay icon.  Rosemary Neill is a columnist on the Australian. Turkey Ferai Tinc It was a December night when I went to the poor eastern city of Batman, trying to find out what was driving the women there to kill themselves. Nafiye, a middle-aged peasant woman who lived with her husband, her "kuma"(her husband's second wife) and her nine children, had tried to kill herself eight times. She kept repeating: "Life has become an unbearable burden. I can no longer carry on." It was not because she was sharing her husband with another woman - it was Nafiye herself who had brought the woman home, to share her own responsibilities. It wasn't even the poverty. It was, she said, that life had lost its meaning. A month after we met, I heard she had "liberated herself" from that life. Thirty-eight women committed suicide in Batman last year and officials and specialists all agree that there is one main cause: lack of education. According to Turkish Ministry of Education figures from last year, 99.4% of boys started primary school as opposed to only 89.8% of girls. At secondary school and university, the percentage of women students is even lower. With the declaration of the republic in 1923, Turkey made a radical decision to turn her face towards Europe and, as the country modernised, women were given more rights and were encouraged to go to school. In areas where feudal relations remain strong, families give priority to their sons' education - daughters can stay at home or go out to work because, after all, the girl will marry and will not be responsible for making money for the family. That's the man's business. However, exposure to the realities of the modern world is forcing people to see how behind the times they really are. With television and internet cafes now widespread, even in remote corners of the country, families have begun to understand the importance of education for girls. There has been a high uptake and the positive effects of these classes are evident. Some of the women here admit that they, too, have wanted to commit suicide in the past; everybody has their reason. "But after this course, I am changed," one woman says. "Now I can make my own plans for my own future."  Ferai Tinc is foreign policy columnist of Hrriyet Daily News. fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Health secretary Alan Milburn was condemned by a high court judge yesterday for "premature and inappropriate" intervention to close a group of children's homes run by the Somerset-based Prospects Care Services.
fields.body:
Court rebuke for Milburn

Health secretary Alan Milburn was condemned by a high court judge yesterday for "premature and inappropriate" intervention to close a group of children's homes run by the Somerset-based Prospects Care Services.

Bluebird broadcast off

The BBC has abandoned plans to broadcast the salvage of Donald Campbell's Bluebird speedboat live on Sunday. The Ministry of Agriculture feared crowds at Coniston Water, Cumbria, could spread foot and mouth disease.

Blair protest costs £100

Jo Wilding, 26, who threw a mouldy tangerine at Tony Blair as a protest against sanctions against Iraq, was yesterday given a two year conditional discharge and ordered to pay £100 costs by Bristol magistrates.

Samaritans' phone switch

The Samaritans have switched their telephone services from British Telecom to Cable and Wireless after discovering that one in five potential suicides could not get through.

fields.headline: Barristers face radical shakeup
fields.standfirst: Lawyers rile at report claiming they break trading rules
fields.trailText: Rules restricting the way barristers can practise and the system of Queen's Counsel were branded anti-competitive yesterday in a report by the office of fair trading.
fields.body:
Rules restricting the way barristers can practise and the system of Queen's Counsel were branded anti-competitive yesterday in a report by the office of fair trading which could lead to the scrapping of the remaining distinctions between solicitors and barristers and the eventual fusion of the legal profession's two branches.

In an attack on the QC system and the Lord Chancellor's role in it, the report questions why the government should be involved in a process which makes it possible for the top 10% of barristers to charge enhanced fees.

The trade secretary, Stephen Byers, is expected to back proposals to apply the full force of competition law to the professions, in a statement in the Commons today.

The Bar Council, which will face a tough battle to retain the existing system, reacted angrily, calling the report "glib and dogged in its ignorance of how the interests of justice play a role in the issues at stake".

The report follows an investigation into restrictive practices in the legal, accountancy and architects' professions, announced by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, in his 1999 pre-Budget report.

Its publication on the day of the Budget signals the government's determination to expose professionals to the same market forces which apply to other suppliers of services.

The director general of fair trading, John Vickers, says two of the three remaining distinctions between barristers and solicitors - bar rules banning barristers from practising in partnership, or seeing clients without a referral from a solicitor - have "significant adverse effects" on competition.

The third distinction - the bar's refusal to allow barristers to handle the whole litigation process, limiting them to advocacy, advising and drafting court papers - "prevents potential efficiencies and limits the numbers of lawyers who are able to conduct litigation on behalf of clients."

The report's attack on the QC system was seen yesterday as ammunition for ministers who question government involvement in a system which enables senior lawyers to hit the public purse for higher fees. Lord Irvine, who chooses the QCs, wants to retain the power, but critics argue that if the title is to remain it should be conferred by the profession. The Lord Chancellor's role is a legacy of the time when QCs were appointed to handle the work of the crown.

Mr Vickers said yesterday: "Governmental involvement in distinguishing between junior barristers and QCs has no parallel in other markets. This demarcation affects competition between suppliers, but it is hard to see what benefits it brings to consumers."

Sir Leonard Peach, the former commissioner for public appointments, had recommended improvements in the QC selection system at the Lord Chancellor's request. But his report "did not address the fundamental issue of whether, given that the historical origins of the title no longer correspond to its function, it was right for the government to have a responsibility for conferring on selected practitioners a title that manifestly enhances their earning power... relative to others".

Mr Vickers' report expresses concerns about inadequate peer review in the selection of QCs, the lack of continuous appraisal once appointed, and the fact that no professional exams are required.

It points out that a quality mark serves no consumer purpose, since under the referral system the solicitor, who already knows the field, chooses the barrister to handle a case. The restriction on clients going direct to a barrister denies freedom of choice, the report says. It "restricts barristers' ability to compete with each other and solicitors, and requires customers to employ two types of lawyer where one might do".

Mr Vickers concludes that the profession's dual structure "may add unnecessarily to costs". But rather than pressing for an immediate end to the split profession, he advocates further liberalisation of professional rules. However, removal of the rules would leave no distinction ibetween barristers and solicitors.

Roy Amlot QC, chairman of the Bar Council, said: "We would have to question the report's conclusions in almost every respect. No credible assessment of the public interest benefits which would arise from the changes has been produced. People are more than just consumers, they are citizens who require the protection of a strong framework for justice, including an independent legal profession."

The report also calls for a relaxation of professional rules banning lawyers, accountants and other professionals from forming partnerships with each other, to provide consumers with a one-stop shop.

The Law Society, representing solicitors, welcomed the recommendation.

webTitle: Couple win royalties on Blur album

fields.headline: Couple win royalties on Blur album
fields.trailText: The husband and wife credited with discovering the rock band Blur won their high court claim for £250,000 against the recording giant EMI yesterday.
fields.body:
The husband and wife credited with discovering the rock band Blur won their high court claim for £250,000 against the recording giant EMI yesterday.

Judge Boggis QC ruled that David and Helen Balfe were entitled to royalties from the band's eponymous album as part of a deal in which they sold their record label, Food, to EMI in 1994 for £475,000. He also ordered EMI to pay legal costs totalling £50,000.

The terms of the deal had entitled the Balfes to royalties from Blur's next two albums. The Great Escape, sold 2.15m copies worldwide, but their second, Live At Budokan, had a restricted release in Japan and sold only 80,000. They argued that they were entitled to royalties from the band's third album, Blur, in countries where the live album had not been released.

webTitle: Curtains fall on struggling regional theatres

fields.headline: Curtains fall on cash-hit regional theatres
fields.standfirst: Three playhouses miss out on funds from £15m rescue package and face closure
fields.trailText: Three playhouses miss out on funds from £15m rescue package and face closure.
fields.body:
Three regional theatres face closure despite today's shareout of £15m to put live drama back on its feet, the Guardian has learned.

The Croydon Warehouse Theatre, which brought on such cutting edge companies as Frantic Assembly, has been told it will get none of the money being handed out today by the Arts Council, the first part of a £70m rescue package over the next three years that the culture secretary, Chris Smith, wrung from the Treasury.

Two other regional theatres also got nothing: Chester Gateway, which after a financial crisis had hoped to resume producing later this year; and The Swan in Worcester, despite the strong backing of its local councils. The executive director of a fourth, the Theatre Royal in York, is resigning in frustration after its budget was cut in real terms.

The latest leak is a crippling blow to the Warehouse, the only producing theatre left in south London, which having survived years of threat from developers, had at last found a new venue.

Artistic director Ted Craig said he was "angry and bewildered" by the London Arts Board's decision and accused them of "picking us out at random. I think they felt someone had to suffer and because we have had running difficulties over our home, through no fault of our own, they chose us. That they should do this at a time that our council, which has been brilliantly supportive, has identified a great new venue that will be a real boon for Croydon makes no sense. Pruning the best shoot on the tree is just stupid."

Croydon council said it would not take the decision lying down. The deputy council leader, Tony Newman, said the "shabby way" the Warehouse and Croydon had been treated was not acceptable. "The London Arts Board talks a great deal about how it is going to try to redress the imbalance south London suffers from, but we are still waiting.

"We have made them aware of our extreme disappointment and will be appealing this vigorously. We have always made it clear than we would ensure the Warehouse had a home, it has an international reputation and we are very proud of the work it does."

The Warehouse can feel especially aggrieved at missing out because although the money from the review was originally sold by Mr Smith as a boost to regional companies like it, the Arts Council later caused controversy by deciding it should go to the "wider theatre ecology".

Although the Big Ten regional producing theatres are likely to be the main beneficiaries, today's review is likely to reward many touring companies too as a part of the Arts Council's shift towards backing "talent as well as buildings".

Mr Craig said he felt particularly angry because the arts board had refused to tell him why decided the Warehouse should miss out. "Even if you set aside the fact that we are one of the foremost new playwriting producing theatres in the country - and that we are uniquely a regional and a fringe venue - we meet and surpass all of the targets the Arts Council and the LAB have set for theatres."

He said as well as its promotion of new writers through its 16-year-old international playwriting festival, the Warehouse encouraged black and Asian companies, had strong schools programmes, and was open nearly 70 hours a week. "There will £6.29m extra for London over the next few years and I cannot for the life of me see why we do not deserve some of that. One does not want to seem churlish-because Chris Smith has done great job in getting the money, its is great news for theatre and so badly needed - but I know am not alone in thinking this is unjust."

The Arts Council insisted the money was a big step in countering many years of underfunding. A spokesman hinted there would be a "few very big pleasant surprises" and "an overwhelming number" of the country's producing theatres would benefit.

"The Arts Council was very clear in statements that this money was not just for the regional producing theatres."

A large number of the 270 companies and theatres who would gain would have their budgets increased by a quarter or more, he said.

Pruning the best shoot on the tree is just stupid." Croydon council said it would not take the decision lying down. The deputy council leader, Tony Newman, said the "shabby way" the Warehouse and Croydon had been treated was not acceptable. "The London Arts Board talks a great deal about how it is going to try to redress the imbalance south London suffers from, but we are still waiting. "We have made them aware of our extreme disappointment and will be appealing this vigorously. We have always made it clear than we would ensure the Warehouse had a home, it has an international reputation and we are very proud of the work it does." The Warehouse can feel especially aggrieved at missing out because although the money from the review was originally sold by Mr Smith as a boost to regional companies like it, the Arts Council later caused controversy by deciding it should go to the "wider theatre ecology". Although the Big Ten regional producing theatres are likely to be the main beneficiaries, today's review is likely to reward many touring companies too as a part of the Arts Council's shift towards backing "talent as well as buildings". Mr Craig said he felt particularly angry because the arts board had refused to tell him why decided the Warehouse should miss out. "Even if you set aside the fact that we are one of the foremost new playwriting producing theatres in the country - and that we are uniquely a regional and a fringe venue - we meet and surpass all of the targets the Arts Council and the LAB have set for theatres." He said as well as its promotion of new writers through its 16-year-old international playwriting festival, the Warehouse encouraged black and Asian companies, had strong schools programmes, and was open nearly 70 hours a week. "There will £6.29m extra for London over the next few years and I cannot for the life of me see why we do not deserve some of that. One does not want to seem churlish-because Chris Smith has done great job in getting the money, its is great news for theatre and so badly needed - but I know am not alone in thinking this is unjust." The Arts Council insisted the money was a big step in countering many years of underfunding. A spokesman hinted there would be a "few very big pleasant surprises" and "an overwhelming number" of the country's producing theatres would benefit. "The Arts Council was very clear in statements that this money was not just for the regional producing theatres." A large number of the 270 companies and theatres who would gain would have their budgets increased by a quarter or more, he said.

webTitle: RAF men die in yacht accident off Tenerife

fields.headline: RAF men die in yacht accident off Tenerife
fields.trailText: Two RAF men were killed during an official training exercise when their yacht capsized and was smashed on rocks off the coast of Tenerife yesterday.
fields.byline: Jeevan Vasagar  and Giles Tremlett  in Madrid
fields.body:
Two RAF men were killed during an official training exercise when their yacht capsized and was smashed on rocks off the coast of Tenerife yesterday.

Flight Sergeant Steven Fryer, 46, died alongside an unnamed colleague when the Minerva was caught by a freak wave as it tried to enter a harbour in rough weather, said Spanish police.

Two other RAF colleagues suffered minor injuries and another two escaped unhurt.

Visibility was understood to have been poor - it was still dark at 7.30am - as the Minerva sought to enter Guia Disora harbour in southern Tenerife following an overnight voyage from La Palma.

The two dead were among five men who were pitched into the water.

It is not yet clear what precisely caused the men's deaths.

A Ministry of Defence spokesman said the skipper and master of the Minerva would both have been RAF men with yachting qualifications, while the rest of the team, including the two dead, would have had mixed levels of experience.

"Obviously we sympathise with the families. The accident will be fully investigated," the spokesman said.

Flight Sergeant Fryer was married with three children, including two sons also in the RAF. He had been based at RAF Bruggen in Germany.

The Minerva had set sail from Plymouth last September for Exercise Yellowbirds 2000. The expedition was intended to build character and encourage team work. The ship, which had never been involved in an accident before, was due to return home on April 1.

webTitle: Eminem songs 'may have influenced' suicide girl

fields.headline: Eminem songs 'may have influenced' suicide girl
fields.trailText: A father yesterday told an inquest that he feared his teenage daughter's "infatuation" with the rapper Eminem may have encouraged her to take her life.
fields.body:
A father yesterday told an inquest that he feared his teenage daughter's "infatuation" with the rapper Eminem may have encouraged her to take her life.

Kayleigh Davies, 13, of Eastleigh, Hampshire, hanged herself after being sent home from school for drinking on December 20, the last day of term.

Her father, Martin, a supermarket worker, told the inquest in Winchester that she had been fascinated by suicide and had developed a "love affair" with Eminem. She also wrote about and drew pictures of hangings in her diary.

"After she died I looked through some of her CDs which we let her listen to," Mr Davies said. "There was stuff by Eminem and Dr Dre. It does talk about suicide, and whether that put it in her mind I don't know."

He said she had also been struck by a TV documentary about stars who died young. "She did think it was quite cool the way these people had ended their lives with all guns blazing."

Last month a coroner in Devon criticised Eminem's "depressing" lyrics at an inquest into the suicide of David Hurcombe, 17, who wrote out the words to the track Rock Bottom in a note before throwing himself under a train.

One of the American star's biggest hits is Stan, about an obsessive fan who kills his girlfriend and commits suicide. But in the song Eminem, whose real name is Marshall Mathers, tells the man to get counselling and warns him not to act rashly.

Yesterday the Mid Hampshire coroner, Grahame Short, heard that Kayleigh had been sent home from Alderman Quilley school in Eastleigh after being caught with alcohol. Her headteacher assured her she would not be expelled or excluded, although she had been in trouble before.

In a statement read to the court, her mother, Karen, a shop assistant, said she had rung Kayleigh to tell her off and warn her that she would be taken into care.

Mr Davies said she had become aggressive after being repeatedly bullied at Alderman Quilley and a previous school. "She said to me, 'Dad I just can't handle it.' I said: 'What you have to do is stand up and let them know you won't tolerate it.'

"Like any teenager she had a few moods and a few sulks, but she was a good daughter and a good sister to my son.

"One or two times she said, 'I'm going to kill myself,' but it was just teenage talk."

A postmortem examination showed that Kayleigh had 47mg per 100ml of alcohol in her body on the day she died. The drink-drive limit is 80mg per 100ml.

Recording a suicide verdict, Mr Short said: "I don't know how much she believed about what she wrote and how much she was influenced by rap music, but it seems to me that she had found it difficult to cope with the pressures of school, home and growing up. She was quite insecure and easily influenced."

fields.headline: Morality and mutiny
fields.trailText: Are military commanders arguing about the point at which an act of war turns into crime (Forces fear war crimes threat, March 7), or is it simply that they don't agree with the politics of legislation by Brussels? Sounds like mutinous action to me.
fields.body:
Are military commanders arguing about the point at which an act of war turns into crime (Forces fear war crimes threat, March 7), or is it simply that they don't agree with the politics of legislation by Brussels? Sounds like mutinous action to me.
Dave Neale
Wakefield, W Yorks

 So the Sky Mirror sculpture at Nottingham's Playhouse theatre is capable of incinerating pigeons who stray into its beam of focused sunlight (Sculpture has death-ray potential, March 7)? Perhaps we should sell it to the Pentagon as Britain's contribution to the national missile defence system.
David Harper
Cambridge

 I recently retired and am weary of fabricating varied interests when constantly asked by friends how I spend my time. Thanks to Cecily Croke (Letters, March 6) I now have the courage to come clean and "out" myself as a committed, full-time lone reader.
Elizabeth Campbell
Reading

 Those mourning the disappearance of the M5 camel (Letters, February) will be more than rewarded by the stunning sight of the Willow Man (or Sunset Giant), striding across farmland near Bridgwater. The huge willow sculpture, a millennium project by Serena de la Hey, has I think, frightened the camel away - sensitive motorists and children be warned.
Jill Walmsley
Minehead, Somerset

 It is a rare experience to be quite unable to take one side or the other in a brawl (Mugabe men beat up Tatchell, March 6).
Michael O'Donovan
Murrintown, Co Wexford

 Man sacked for having a beard; Guardian writes leader about same (March 6). Why am I not surprised? Chris McColl
Bournemouth

fields.headline: Justice in jeopardy
fields.trailText: I am dismayed that the Guardian should endorse the proposal to abolish the double jeopardy rule (Leader, March 7).
fields.body:
I am dismayed that the Guardian should endorse the proposal to abolish the double jeopardy rule (Leader, March 7). All the remarks about how a revised system would be applied in theory miss the point that the British criminal justice system rarely works in practice as it is supposed to in theory.

What is this "compelling" new evidence that will allow an acquittal to be set aside? Is it, for example, prison grass or cell confession evidence, whereby the police can persuade a vulnerable witness to say the defendant told him he'd done it? If the court of appeal said not, then that would be irrational, bearing in mind that convictions are already obtained on the basis of such supposedly "compelling" evidence.

If it's to be DNA or other scientific evidence, one should bear in mind that there are already a number of cases where a miscarriage is thought to have resulted from either misconstrued or misleading DNA evidence.

The overriding aim should be to ensure that the judicial system functions much more efficiently from the outset; that alone is what will prevent the convictions of the innocent and the acquittals of the guilty.

We already know how reluctant police forces are to acknowledge that their original instincts were wrong. (In no proven miscarriage of justice case have the actual murderers been subsequently prosecuted, even in those, like the Stefan Kiszko and Carl Bridgewater murder cases, where the identity of the culprit is widely suspected.)

One suspects that the abolition of double jeopardy will allow the police to continue to target those properly acquitted, and will ultimately become just another way of filling our jails with innocent people.
Bob Woffinden
London
woffindens@compuserve.com

 The rantings of Jack Straw (Straw's war against lawyers, March 5) have a sinister element. He had just been informed that defence solicitors are refusing to sign, on Law Society advice, a contract imposed upon them by the legal services commission to take effect from April 2. At the same time the commission is advertising for staff to join the pilot public defender service at salaries in excess of what private practice can pay.

The perception is that the Government is freezing out independent lawyers, who may take on the state and expose potential miscarriages, in favour of tame public defenders who will do what they are told.
Michael Burdett
London

fields.headline: Hot air over emissions
fields.trailText: It is good news that road traffic volume only grew by 0.3% last year, when GNP grew by 3%. It is good that Professor Begg's commission for integrated transport has published this data so quickly (Analysis, March 6) . But there is no room for complacency.
fields.body:
It is good news that road traffic volume only grew by 0.3% last year, when GNP grew by 3%. It is good that Professor Begg's commission for integrated transport has published this data so quickly (Analysis, March 6). But there is no room for complacency. The blip to railway patronage after Railtrack speed restrictions last autumn resulted in a 3% increase in national road traffic volumes during October and November. On present trends this is an extra 100 road crash deaths.

If the UK is to meet John Prescott's Kyoto greenhouse emission targets (Blair pledges green industrial revolution, March 7), then road traffic will have to be cut, not just the rate of growth reduced. Sadly the Begg commission has yet to promote any targets for cutting traffic volumes. While traffic adds to climate changes in the longer term, every year traffic kills about 25,000 people though crashes and toxic emissions.

Most car journeys are short (70% under 5 miles long) and made in urban areas, where asthma and other respiratory diseases are a public health epidemic. If the NHS did not have to treat the victims of road traffic, it would have capacity to reduce waiting times for the treatment of unavoidable illnesses. Polluted water (and cholera) in the 19th century, polluted air (and respiratory diseases) are man made. We must set targets now for the highways agency and local highway authorities to plan for less motor traffic. For most people, a car free weekday would be a 20% reduction in use.
Prof Lewis Lesley
Liverpool JM University
transport-science@rapid.co.uk

 Car user figures rose less than predicted. It was suggested this must be due to the increase in fuel prices acting as a disincentive. I offer another explanation. Many of us rural dwellers now work away from home because we have been forced to by financial considerations and lack of job opportunities. We cannot buy comparable houses for comparable prices in the cities.

We thus travel long distances by rail at weekends and only short distances from our rented accommodation. I predict that next year figures of car use will rise sharply because the rail problems have put us back into our cars. Give us a reliable integrated public transport system and we will use it - no fuel hikes needed.
Gail Coleshill
Crewkerne, Somerset

 The prime minister perpetuates a dangerous mistake when he says the Kyoto targets would "reduce global greenhouse gas emissions by 5.2% of their 1990 levels by 2008-12". Under Kyoto, only developed country emissions would be cut by 5.2%. Even if Kyoto is implemented in full, global emissions will rise by about 30%.
Titus Alexander
London
titus@gci.org.uk

 Tony Blair highlighted the "need to put business, technology and environmental protection in harness together". He could take a further step and harness the research councils and department of trade and industry. At Strathclyde University we have had in the last six months proposals to establish a doctorate in energy and sustainable engineering rejected and a proposal to establish a Faraday Centre (linking universities and business) in dispersed clean energy systems meeting a similar fate. These didn't fail on the grounds of competence but because research funding is limited.
Dr Stephen Armstrong
University of Strathclyde

 Let us hope that Tony Blair's promise of £100m does not simply go into generating more hot air in Westminster.
Dr Jonathan Barnard
Cambridge

webTitle: Letters: True cost of women's work

fields.headline: True cost of women's work
fields.trailText: Richard Reeves (The way we work, G2, May 6) argues more needs to be done to get men into childcare jobs. His solution? Give male childcare trainees an extra £1,000.This is not far from arguing men have more intrinsic value than women.
fields.body:
Richard Reeves (The way we work, G2, May 6) argues more needs to be done to get men into childcare jobs to "break down our outdated, self-fulfilling assumptions about gender roles". His solution? Give male childcare trainees an extra £1,000, because men are "put off by the low salaries."

This is not far from arguing men have more intrinsic value than women. What we need is a re-evaluation of jobs which places a higher value on caring work and pays the millions of women who do this work a decent wage for their skill, experience and commitment. We need a radical overhaul of equal pay legislation and an investment in women's work far beyond anything we have seen.
Margaret Boyle
Hebden Bridge, W Yorks
naw@belvedere.clara.net

 Richard Reeves misses the point. Such a move would also be illegal. The real problem is a vicious circle. Child care is women's work because it is low paid - and it's low paid because it is women's work. Fear of paedophiles may be real, but just go to any home for older people, and you will find the same predominance of women workers.

The solution would be to recognise the importance of child care by paying higher wages. Any policy that really rewards work of equal value with equal pay across society would give care workers a much needed boost.
John Monks
General secretary, TUC

 Will the same incentive be offered to women who wish to work in science, engineering, business, the media or any other profession where men outnumber women?
Emma Collin
(Playleader), Manchester

fields.headline: Scoused out
fields.trailText: The scousers' use of tart is not analogous to the use of bitch. Tart is an abbreviation of sweetheart, and thus originally a term of affection.
fields.body:
Why do you continue to give Fritz Spiegl space (Letters, March 5)? Like others with sepia-tinted notions about scouse, he is able to scupper the work that has been done to counter prejudice. Yes, some Liverpool-born males do use the phrase "me tart" (Letters, March 3), but they are a dying breed and can as often be found among the Mersey diaspora in Melbourne and Santa Monica.
Ian Parker
Hampton Wick, Surrey

 The scousers' use of tart is not analogous to the use of bitch. Tart is an abbreviation of sweetheart, and thus originally a term of affection. Bitch has never been that. These days people will inquire of a dog-owner "Is it a boy or a girl? Somehow bitch sounds indecent. But bitch is apparently OK for women. Grrr!
Vivien Bailey
St Albans, Herts

fields.headline: Exploding myths about the Real IRA
fields.trailText: There is something curiously outdated about your leader (Prove that politics works, March 6). The Belfast agreement has already delivered several substantial gains for Sinn Fein.
fields.body:
There is something curiously outdated about your leader (Prove that politics works, March 6): "When Sinn Fein can boast of progress, there will be no constituency to nourish the Real IRA or its murderous collaborators." The Belfast agreement has already delivered several substantial gains for Sinn Fein. These include two Sinn Fein ministers controlling the bulk of public spending, on the two high-profile Departments of Health and Social Services, and Education.

All paramilitary prisoners have now been released early, apart from a handful in the Republic and those associated with organisations not on ceasefire. Parliament has agreed substantial reforms to the policing service and the criminal justice system is to be overhauled. There has been substantial demilitarisation. There is also an equality agenda, plus moves to increase the provision of Irish language facilities and a bill of rights. However, none of this impresses the Real IRA.

Political progress must be combined with effective anti-terrorist measures. Strong laws introduced in the wake of the Omagh atrocity of August 1998 have not yet been used. All efforts need to be made to prevent the Real IRA from crossing the border and could possibly draw on the recent strength of the Irish government's efforts to stop foot and mouth disease being carried across the border.
Harry Barnes MP

 Your leader says the best task for Northern Ireland is to "prove that politics works" but the new executive - doubtless on Treasury orders - refused to let the elected assembly see what happens to public resources going to private and voluntary agencies. Unfortunately the terrorists and paramilitaries are part of that private and voluntary state; one that has richly benefited from the budgetary haze permeating much of the province.

The new assembly's finance and personnel committee and their audit committee and their public accounts committee all supported legislative amendments allowing them to follow public money wherever it goes. But they were frustrated in their first brave attempt to avoid importing parliamentary impotence from Westminster.
Des McConaghy
Liverpool
fields.bodyText: There is something curiously outdated about your leader (Prove that politics works, March 6): "When Sinn Fein can boast of progress, there will be no constituency to nourish the Real IRA or its murderous collaborators." The Belfast agreement has already delivered several substantial gains for Sinn Fein. These include two Sinn Fein ministers controlling the bulk of public spending, on the two high-profile Departments of Health and Social Services, and Education. All paramilitary prisoners have now been released early, apart from a handful in the Republic and those associated with organisations not on ceasefire. Parliament has agreed substantial reforms to the policing service and the criminal justice system is to be overhauled. There has been substantial demilitarisation. There is also an equality agenda, plus moves to increase the provision of Irish language facilities and a bill of rights. However, none of this impresses the Real IRA. Political progress must be combined with effective anti-terrorist measures. Strong laws introduced in the wake of the Omagh atrocity of August 1998 have not yet been used. All efforts need to be made to prevent the Real IRA from crossing the border and could possibly draw on the recent strength of the Irish government's efforts to stop foot and mouth disease being carried across the border. Harry Barnes MP  Your leader says the best task for Northern Ireland is to "prove that politics works" but the new executive - doubtless on Treasury orders - refused to let the elected assembly see what happens to public resources going to private and voluntary agencies. Unfortunately the terrorists and paramilitaries are part of that private and voluntary state; one that has richly benefited from the budgetary haze permeating much of the province. The new assembly's finance and personnel committee and their audit committee and their public accounts committee all supported legislative amendments allowing them to follow public money wherever it goes. But they were frustrated in their first brave attempt to avoid importing parliamentary impotence from Westminster. Des McConaghy Liverpool

webTitle: Tories vow to ban asylum seekers from the seaside

fields.headline: Tories vow to ban asylum seekers from the seaside
fields.trailText: The Conservatives have pledged to ban asylum seekers from coastal resorts as part of a range of measures aimed at "regenerating" the UK's declining seaside towns.
fields.body:
The Conservatives have pledged to ban asylum seekers from coastal resorts as part of a range of measures aimed at "regenerating" the UK's declining seaside towns.

The move, unveiled today as part of the Tories' new coastal regeneration policy, would be accompanied by measures to increase partnership funding for the tourism industry and cut down on red tape.

Local authorities would have new powers to deal with "nuisance" travellers, there would be stronger protection for the coastline and a crackdown on litter and graffiti.

Meanwhile, a council leader has urged rundown former industrial areas to turn to tourism to help breathe life back into their communities.

Sir Ron Watson, chair of the Local Government Association's (LGA) tourism executive said resort regeneration should not be limited only to seaside towns and that areas with no history of tourism should seek to attract visitors.

"This is a time for challenges to find new and innovative ways of attracting tourists," Sir Ron said at yesterday's LGA culture and tourism conference in Scarborough.

The conference was used to relaunch A Change of Scene, the LGA's guide on how local government can exploit Britain's £60bn tourist industry, which accounts for 1.8m jobs and supports 125,000 businesses.

The guide stresses that tourism is not limited to coastal holiday resorts and the rolling landscapes of the countryside.

Earlier this week, the government held its second annual tourism summit to discuss new initiatives to help boost the industry, including a plan to boost "resort regeneration" with the help of lottery funding.

The Tories' coastal regeneration policy centres on a seven-point plan, titled Common Sense for Coastal Towns, which aims to regenerate and revive coastal communities.

Launching the plan in Plymouth, shadow environment secretary Archie Norman said: "Under Labour, Britain's coastal towns have suffered a barrage of attacks from new stealth taxes, more red tape and bureaucracy, stifling local business and plans to concrete over our irreplaceable countryside and coastline."

fields.headline: Vega's double header breaks Pars
fields.trailText: A double from Ramon Vega and two penalty strikes by Henrik Larsson helped Celtic hammer Dunfermline for the second time in a week.
fields.body:
Thankfully, Celtic and Dunfermline are spared meeting like this for at least a few weeks. After having got the measure of each other at the weekend, these two quickly slipped into bad habits, errors on both sides deciding this fourth-round replay.

Jimmy Calderwood, the Dunfermline manager, reckoned his side's 3-0 league defeat by Celtic on Sunday was as big a beating as he had observed at East End Park; his strategy was therefore one of containment, with six across the midfield, buttressed by alert tracking back and double-teaming.

That such diligence should be rewarded with conceding the evening's first goal spotlighted Dunfermline's immaturity. Having been previously confined to shooting from distance - Lubomir Moravcik, twice, then Didier Agathe - Ramon Vega powered home an Alan Thompson corner after Dunfermline's concentration lapsed. Vega, his powerful physique in stark contrast to the Pars' spare frames, rose unchallenged in the six-yard box to head with conviction.

Five minutes later an already subdued, two-thirds full Celtic Park was plunged into silent disbelief when Neil Lennon and his goalkeeper Robert Douglas allowed a quite ridiculous equaliser. A long ball from the right from Steven Hampshire bounced at chest height before Scott Thomson flicked the ball over both Lennon and a bemused Robert Douglas.

Despite several promising attacks, including a forced goal-line clearance from Agathe, Dunfermline's defensive torpor allowed Vega to head home again, this time from Moravcik's cross.

Soon enough, Andrius Skerla fell all over Henrik Larsson in the box and Ian Ferguson repeated the indiscretion minutes later to allow the Swede to convert two penalties.

Robert Tomaschek's goal gave Hearts a 1-0 win over Dundee in last night's other fourth-round replay.

Celtic (3-5-2): Douglas; Mjallby, Vega, Valgaeren; Agathe, McNamara (Lambert, 62min), Lennon, Moravcik, Thompson; Larsson (Crainey, 81), Johnson (Petrov, 62).

Dunfermline (3-5-2): Ruitenbeek; Doesburg (Bullen, 69), Skerla, Rossi; Hampshire, Nicholson, Ferguson, McGroarty, Dair (Dijkhuizen, 81); Crawford, Thomson.

Referee: W Young.

webTitle: FA Cup fifth-round replay: Blackburn 3 - 0 Bolton

fields.headline: Hignett provides premier finish
fields.trailText: Three second-half goals buried their promotion rivals Bolton for the second time in as many weeks and set up a quarter-final tie against Arsensal.
fields.body:
If this was the game that neither side wanted to win, Blackburn provided a convincing argument that their hearts and minds were set on reaching the quarter-finals of the FA Cup. Three second-half goals buried their promotion rivals Bolton Wanderers for the second time in as many weeks and enhanced their credentials as Premiership material in the waiting.

A stunning volley from Craig Hignett, set up by Marc Keller's crossfield drive, set the seal on the kind of confidence-giving performance that can counter the drawbacks of any fixture backlog.

Bolton drew first blood by changing six of their starting line-up from the weekend, compared with the five switches made by Blackburn's manager Graeme Souness. Though that seemed to indicate a focus on league matters rather than a trip to Arsenal on Saturday, neither side could have been deemed ostensibly understrength.

Only Bolton's defence showed signs of major surgery, with Colin Hendry denied the chance of an emotional return to Ewood Park through a calf injury, forcing Ian Marshall to adopt defensive duties in the centre while another former Blackburn man, Leam Richardson, was drafted in at right-back.

It did not take long for the home side to seize the initiative, catching an enterprising Bolton on the break but unable to find the killer ball, unlike during their 4-1 league victory at the Reebok last month. Bolton's goalkeeper Steve Banks was also forced to delve into his memory banks when faced by a Hignett free-kick at the same spot from where he was beaten in that game. This time Banks was able to fumble the ball over the bar.

The chance served to lift Blackburn, who produced a flurry of chances. Mark Hughes twice posed a threat from close range, planting a back-post header at Banks and clipping over from a drilled Marcus Bent cross.

As if to sum the half up, Bent, in a rich vein of scoring form with a goal in each of the last three games, powered his header from a Hignett free-kick marginally wide of an upright. Prompted by the striker's profligacy, and the choices at his disposal, Souness chose to sacrifice Bent for his side's top scorer, Matt Jansen.

Tellingly the Bolton manager Sam Allardyce opted to delay the introduction of his four outfield substitutes, who all started Sunday's game at Fulham. The switch did little to disrupt the Blackburn rhythm as Damien Duff, who struggled to make a first-half impression, imposed himself on the game and had claims for a penalty turned emphatically down. Bolton, however, lacked a string-puller of the calibre of Israeli international Eyal Berkovic.

Consequently Michael Ricketts remained largely isolated, even when Nicky Summerbee was pushed into a more offensive role as part of a three-man attack.

It was no surprise when Berkovic produced the moment of excellence that allowed Blackburn the rewards for their industry. Blocked by a wall of Bolton defenders, the playmaker jinked across the line until he spotted the tightest of gaps through which to thread the ball. Garry Flitcroft timed his run to meet the pass and carried enough momentum to force his way in front of the last Bolton man and slide a shot past the approaching Banks after 55 minutes.

Now Blackburn were more content to consolidate, introducing Damien Johnson for Alan Mahon, and almost paid the price when Bolton squandered two free-kicks from promising positions. Blackburn were not as wasteful when their chance to wrap the game up was presented. When Ian Nolan was judged to have pushed Jansen, who was challenging for a Flitcroft cross, over in the area Hignett sent Banks the wrong way. There was no way back for Bolton.
