fields.headline: Taylor suffers double-take at ref's repeat
fields.trailText: Meetings between desperately out-of-form teams are usually sadly predictable. The football is poor, the players too fearful of failure to take risks, the match dreary and depressing. Not so last night, though, as these two sides produced an occasion of breathless endeavour and a memorable match packed with incident.
fields.byline: Adrian Milledge at the Britannia stadium
fields.body:
Meetings between desperately out-of-form teams are usually sadly predictable. The football is poor, the players too fearful of failure to take risks, the match dreary and depressing. Not so last night, though, as these two sides produced an occasion of breathless endeavour and a memorable match packed with incident.

That is not to say that no mistakes were made. Quite the opposite, in fact. But if the game became a cheerful comedy of errors it was the mistake of one man, the referee, that threatened to spoil it.

Shortly after half-time Peter Crouch, QPR's elastic forward, picked up the ball midway into Watford's half and, for the first and only time, ran at the defence. As he burst into the box, Darren Ward and Nigel Gibbs combined to dispossess him, the ball going out, it seemed, for a corner. But amid half-hearted appeals from the prostrate Crouch, Andy D'Urso pointed to the penalty spot.

Even then the drama was not over. Gavin Peacock took the kick, sending it low and to his right, but it lacked direction and Espen Baardsen saved. Peacock hung his head and the Watford fans behind the goal celebrated. But D'Urso spotted encroachment and demanded a retake. This time Michel Ngonge, who left Watford for west London shortly before Christmas, sent Baardsen the wrong way for his second goal in as many games.

"We could have been a little fortunate with the penalty," said Ian Holloway, "and for him to let us take it again was lovely, but I thought the referee had a very good game."

Graham Taylor disagreed. "He can only give what he saw," he said. "But there are unfortunately some referees who have to play a part in the game, who feel nobody will notice them otherwise.

"I think D'Urso will go on to become a good referee but in the meantime I think people will suffer. We have referees at the moment who know the laws of the game but don't know the game. Hopefully they will learn that."

However it was gained, a draw was not an unfair result. The sides shared the first half but once the penalty was scored Watford took over. "They came at us like a steam train," said Ian Baraclough.

The Hornets have not been operating on schedule over the past couple of months but when Tommy Smith crossed in the 66th minute Allan Nielsen rattled in to glance a header wide of Lee Harper and in the last minute Neil Cox's free-kick from 30 yards struck the bar.

 Iain Dowie has left QPR to allow the new manager Ian Holloway to bring in his own backroom staff. Dowie, latterly assistant to the former manager Gerry Francis after joining the club in 1998 from West Ham, was under contract to the end of the season but has been paid compensation.

fields.headline: Forest back in orbit after rocket by Bart-WiIliams
fields.trailText: Forest's stalling promotion drive enjoyed a fuel injection last night when a stunning free-kick from Chris Bart-Williams proved enough to see off Barnsley. So, after the weekend 2-0 defeat at Wolves, Forest are firmly back in the pack chasing a First Division play-off spot, although their manager David Platt will know that he cannot always rely on wonder goals from his club captain to get them there.
fields.byline: Jim Bruce-Ball at the City Ground
fields.body:
Forest's stalling promotion drive enjoyed a fuel injection last night when a stunning free-kick from Chris Bart-Williams proved enough to see off Barnsley. So, after the weekend 2-0 defeat at Wolves, Forest are firmly back in the pack chasing a First Division play-off spot, although their manager David Platt will know that he cannot always rely on wonder goals from his club captain to get them there.

But after Saturday his team desperately needed a quick fix and after 90 seconds they got it. Bart-Williams had been delivering some home truths in no uncertain terms before the game to get his team to stand up and be counted, and he swiftly showed just what he meant.

David Johnson received a shove in the back on the edge of the area and Bart-Williams hardly disguised his intention of curling the free-kick into the top left-hand corner. He executed the strike with such accuracy, however, that Kevin Miller in the Barnsley goal was never going to get close. The centre-back is Forest's top scorer with 12 goals this season.

Barnsley's best chance of the half fell to Neil Shipperley, who had only Dave Beasant to beat from a tight angle after 42 minutes. The goalkeeper saved bravely at his feet.

David Johnson might have made the game safe for Forest just before the interval when a Stern John through-ball split Barnsley's defence and left the striker with a one-on-one against the goalkeeper. But Johnson, whose pace was giving the former Forest favourite Steve Chettle a constant headache, failed to lift the ball over the onrushing Miller.

As Barnsley's defence had not been breached in five of their last six games, Shipperley and Bruce Dyer found themselves under unaccustomed pressure to deliver. Dyer might have equalised on 11 minutes but he completely mistimed his shot from 12 yards.

After half-time Shipperley finally escaped the close attention of Bart-Williams and the striker's neat turn from 12 yards out gave him a shooting chance, but his effort lacked power.

Keith Foy thought he had made it 2-0 in the 63rd minute when David Johnson's trickery released him on the left. Foy at least managed to lift it over Miller only to see his effort drift wide of the post.

From the ensuing goal-kick Barnsley were handed a gilt-edged chance to get back into the match. The kick found Darren Barnard on the left flank and he sprinted into the Forest area before thumping a powerful shot on goal - where Beasant was again in charge.

fields.headline: Booth fails to lift weak Wednesday
fields.trailText: Sheffield Wednesday's manager Peter Shreeves insisted last night his struggling side were out of intensive care, despite his embattled side's failure to take all three points against a gutsy Portsmouth side.
fields.body:
Sheffield Wednesday's manager Peter Shreeves insisted last night his struggling side were out of intensive care, despite his embattled side's failure to take all three points against a gutsy Portsmouth side.

Prior to last night's match, the Owls had won three of their four games under Shreeves's stewardship. Perhaps it was expecting too much for them to keep on track against Pompey, especially bearing in mind that Graham Rix is now at the helm and desperate to prove he can cut it as a manager himself.

Shreeves was upbeat, though, suggesting that Wednesday "are now out of intensive care but still in the general ward.

"I see it as a point gained. It would have been nice to make it four wins out of five, but life is not always like that. We have taken 10 points from five games since I took charge and that's a good average in the jungle we find ourselves in.

"The trick is keeping that going, but the spirit in the dressing room is good."

With better composure when it really mattered, Wednesday would have won the match. Their substitute Michele Di Piedi was the main culprit, pulling a shot wide of goal from six yards with only a couple of minutes remaining.

Wednesday's keeper Kevin Pressman had earlier pulled off a superb save to deny Kevin Harper on 79 minutes. But long chunks of play elapsed without a single effort on goal at either end, with both sides desperate not to lose.

Portsmouth, who played some fluent football, are by no means safe from the drop themselves. Now, to compound matters, they must await the verdict on the injured duo of Darren Moore and Thomas Thorgersen.

"Both look serious," Rix said afterwards. "Moore is in hos pital with a shoulder injury and Thorgersen has damaged his knee. We will know better tomorrow."

Portsmouth's new manager was delighted with a point, however.

"I would have settled for that before the game," he said. "The lads battled, defended well and tried to play football. However, we will remain in trouble with a lot of other teams until such time as we are mathematically safe."

Their substitute Michele Di Piedi was the main culprit, pulling a shot wide of goal from six yards with only a couple of minutes remaining. Wednesday's keeper Kevin Pressman had earlier pulled off a superb save to deny Kevin Harper on 79 minutes. But long chunks of play elapsed without a single effort on goal at either end, with both sides desperate not to lose. Portsmouth, who played some fluent football, are by no means safe from the drop themselves. Now, to compound matters, they must await the verdict on the injured duo of Darren Moore and Thomas Thorgersen. "Both look serious," Rix said afterwards. "Moore is in hos pital with a shoulder injury and Thorgersen has damaged his knee. We will know better tomorrow." Portsmouth's new manager was delighted with a point, however. "I would have settled for that before the game," he said. "The lads battled, defended well and tried to play football. However, we will remain in trouble with a lot of other teams until such time as we are mathematically safe."  You've read the piece, now have your say. webTitle: Chelsea banish awayday blues in style

fields.headline: Chelsea banish awayday blues in style
fields.trailText: It has taken 11 months and 17 matches but finally Chelsea have done it. A deserved victory last night brought them their first away win in the league since last April and carried them to within four points of a place in the Champions League.
fields.body:
It has taken 11 months and 17 matches but finally Chelsea have done it. A deserved victory last night brought them their first away win in the league since last April and carried them to within four points of a place in the Champions League.

Goals from Eidur Gudjohnsen and Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink inside seven first-half minutes proved sufficient to see off a West Ham side who defended poorly and offered little in response until Joe Cole headed wide in the 70th minute. For Claudio Ranieri, who found Chelsea 17th when he officially took over, the picture is looking brighter.

Given that West Ham had won only once in the league since Boxing Day and their manager Harry Redknapp had described this as a game his side could have done without four days before the FA Cup quarter-final against Tottenham, Chelsea must have fancied their chances of finally winning away in the Premiership.

Yet apart from a long-range volley wide by Slavisa Jokanovic the visitors struggled to create clear openings initially as both teams looked short of fluency, West Ham's plans disrupted by the departure of Stuart Pearce because of injury inside a quarter of an hour.

Cole, back from an ankle injury, did provide the odd spurt of inspiration for West Ham but Chelsea looked comfortable at the back until they survived two close shaves inside a minute just before the half-hour.

How Cole wasted the first chance was remarkable, the England midfielder somehow hitting the bar from around four yards after Carlo Cudicini had parried an Ian Pearce header. Almost immediately Rigobert Song's flying header from a Cole cross flashed wide.

But just as it seemed West Ham might gain the upper hand, Chelsea scored twice in seven minutes. Gudjohnsen got the first, picking up a pass from Jesper Gronkjaer on the edge of the area and taking advantage of West Ham's failure to close him down to fire past Shaka Hislop.

A similar lapse almost allowed Hasselbaink to double the lead, before the Dutchman did get on the scoresheet aided by more poor West Ham defending. Gustavo Poyet headed a lofted Frank Leboeuf pass into Hasselbaink's path and he beat Christian Dailly before scoring with a fine shot from outside the box.

With Chelsea now in complete control and passing with far greater conviction, Gronkjaer shot over. Having thrown away a 2-0 lead at Ipswich they will hardly have considered the points secure at half-time but West Ham looked so short of ideas and penetration that there was little to suggest the home side could recover.

Redknapp sent on Kaba Diawara at the interval in place of his earlier substitute Sébastian Schemmel in an attempt to pep up a performance which had been greeted with booing at half-time.

But Chelsea soaked up all West Ham could offer and continued to look the more likely scorers. Hasselbaink wasted a chance and Gudjohnsen, put through by Hasselbaink and too quick for Dailly, should have done better than poke the ball wide when one on one with Hislop.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: The player
fields.standfirst: He was an acclaimed academic. But in his 30s, Al Alvarez turned his back on literary criticism and embarked on a high-risk life of poker and rock climbing.  Stephen Moss  meets a man with few regrets
fields.trailText: He was an acclaimed academic. But in his 30s, Al Alvarez turned his back on literary criticism and embarked on a high-risk life of poker and rock climbing. Stephen Moss meets a man with few regrets.
fields.body:
Al Alvarez has lived his life backwards. In his 20s, fresh out of Oxford, he took the literary world by storm, and at 28 was the youngest person ever to deliver the Christian Gauss lectures on literature at Princeton. He published books of criticism, single-handedly redefined poetry with his attack on what he dubbed the "gentility principle", and championed young poets such as Sylvia Plath. A long and distinguished academic career, punctuated by occasional weighty critical tomes, beckoned. But it didn't happen, and Alvarez, now 71, is glad he had the good sense to grow up.

If he had carried on with life in what he once called the "squirrel cage", I might be heading up the steps to Alvarez's tall, sunny, exhaustively lived-in house in Hampstead to discuss his latest critical outpourings on poetry; as it is, I have come to talk about poker, a game he discovered just as his love affair with academe was beginning to fade. Poker: Bets, Bluffs and Bad Beats appears next week, Alvarez's second book on a game that has been an obsession for the past 40 years. His first, The Biggest Game in Town, about the World Series of Poker in Las Vegas, appeared in 1983. Stu "the Kid" Ungar and Nick the Greek have well and truly replaced George Herbert and Richard Lovelace in Alvarez's critical pantheon.

I am anxious to explore the curious trajectory of his career, to understand why he turned his back on academic life, gave up being poetry editor of the Observer (the platform from which he had launched his assault on well mannered English poetry), and stopped playing the literary game; or, rather, insisted on playing it by his own rules. "I haven't really got a career," he says. "All I have done is stayed independent. In a differently ordered culture, I probably would have had some sinecure professorship, but I was too early for that. I was always good at teaching; I just didn't like having colleagues."

He had been back to his old Oxford college, Corpus Christi, the week before, and was given a tour by the new college president. "It has the most beautiful library, where Erasmus worked, and every time I go to that library my heart goes out to it and I think I should have done this, I should have stayed on," he reflects. "But then when you meet all the faculty, charming though they are, I realise it's not what I wanted to do, it's not how I could possibly have led my life. I did have the opportunity, but I thought, 'I don't want to spend my life writing books about other people's books'."

In his new poker book, he recalls reading Herbert O Yardley's classic introduction to the game, The Education of a Poker Player, for the first time. It taught him how to play; but it also taught him some more important lessons. "When I first began to play," he writes, "I was in my late 20s and had the profound ignorance that often goes with excessive education. I had been through the most high-minded academic mill, read a vast number of books, and written a couple of my own, but in my personal life I was naive to a degree that still makes me blush. I had a marriage I couldn't handle, a childish desire to be loved by the whole world, and an equally childish conviction that everything would turn out right in the end . . . I was wrong."

Very wrong. At 27, he married the 20-year-old grand-daughter of Frieda Lawrence (the widow of DH Lawrence) after a whirlwind romance, and they had a son. But the marriage was a disaster, triggering a bout of the depression that dogged Alvarez throughout his 20s, and caused him to attempt suicide in 1960. He drew on that experience in his best-known book, The Savage God, published in 1971, which explored the links between suicide and creativity. The other impulse driving that book was his friendship with Sylvia Plath, who had committed suicide in 1963. In his autobiography, Where Did It All Go Right?, he says that he failed Plath. "I wasn't up to her despair and it scared me. My own suicide attempt was two years behind me, and I didn't want to go that way again."

The autobiography ends with Alvarez's marriage in 1966 to his second wife, a Canadian child psychotherapist called Anne Adams. His reasoning: "Happiness writes white. It does not show up on the page." He describes the book as the story of "gloom and doom turning into pleasure", and recalls the effect of meeting Zero Mostel, the comic actor, who became a close friend. "When I first met him," Alvarez recalls, "he seemed to represent everything that was lacking in my life. He was a galleon in full sail, laden with pleasure; I was a castaway, clinging to the wreckage. Being exposed to all that appetite and energy and hilarity made me realise that there was a world elsewhere."

Alvarez bade farewell to academic life, cauterised his wounds with The Savage God, and wrote poetry, novels, and reportage for the New Yorker that eventually made its way into hard covers - The Biggest Game in Town; Offshore (based on his stay on a North Sea oil rig); and Feeding the Rat, about an unsung mountaineering friend. Climbing is Alvarez's other lifelong passion, though age and a busted right ankle mean he can no longer shin up sheer rock faces.

"Feeding the rat" - testing yourself, exposing yourself to danger - has always been necessary to Alvarez. Poker is part of that, and he still puts his money on the table in London casinos a couple of nights a week, though he was forced to abandon a high-rolling game in which he played for 20 years when he suffered serious losses. "Poker is about control," he says. "It's like rock climbing. You see a television programme about rock climbing and you think these guys are insane, but it's not like that - it's all about working things out and being in control."

Poker and climbing share another similarity that appeals to Alvarez - both are democratic. "Nobody gives a shit what you do or where you come from as long as you sit down with sufficient money and ante up on time," he says. "It's the same in the climbing world. I used to go more or less every weekend to a place called Harrison's Rocks, and there was an oddjob man, a guy who worked as a gardener, a security guard, a kid doing his O-levels, a tycoon in the software industry, and me. There was complete democracy, and I loved that."

Alvarez's new poker book - a coffee-table guide to the game - is a potboiler, and part of me (that part obsessed with the odd trajectory of his career) wants to grill him about all the "real" books unwritten, all the studies of Herbert and Lovelace that might have been. But this battle-hardened man with a gammy leg, a sleepy eye and an infectious laugh, who looks and talks like a retired brigadier, is ungrillable. If he does lose any sleep over what he has done, and not done, it doesn't show.

He called his collected essays Beyond All This Fiddle, echoing the American poet Marianne Moore's edgy reflection on poetry: "There are things that are important beyond all this fiddle." Literature, if not its academic study, has always been important to Alvarez, but not at the expense of life. The rat has insisted on being fed. "I've wasted a lot of time climbing rocks and playing cards and goofing about, but I've had a lot of fun. If I dropped dead this moment, I would have had a great time."

 Poker: Bets, Bluffs and Bad Beats is published on Monday by Bloomsbury (£20)

webTitle: Budget case study: Single parent, one child

fields.headline: Single parent, one child
fields.standfirst: Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Lindsey finds it hard to make ends meet as eight-year-old Kylie's father Gerry disappeared a long time ago, and pays the 26-year-old Lindsey no maintainance. She will welcome the increase in the introductory rate of the children's tax credit.
fields.body:
Lindsey finds it hard to make ends meet as eight-year-old Kylie's father Gerry disappeared a long time ago, and pays the 26-year-old Lindsey no maintainance. She will welcome the increase in the introductory rate of the children's tax credit, which will now be worth £10 when it comes in next April - an extra £1.50 a week. The working families' tax credit will also be more valuable to her: she will receive £5 more a week.

Lindsey does not have to pay for childcare - she and her mum Jacqui juggle shifts at the petrol station with looking after Kylie - so will not feel the benefit of the increased childcare tax credit. She will, however, have the opportunity to earn a little more and still pay just 10% tax, as the 10p tax band has been widened by £360. If she is on the minimum wage, she will definitely be earning more: this week it was announced that the minimum wage will go up to £4.10 an hour in October, and to £4.20 a year after that.

Kylie may benefit from the £1bn spending on education announced by the chancellor.

fields.headline: Lone pensioner
fields.trailText: Margaret was widowed last year when her husband Victor finally put both feet in the grave. She will still feel the benefit of the rise in the basic state retirement pension, which goes up to £72.50 for a single person - an extra £5 a week. This will increase by a further £3 from April next year.
fields.body:
Margaret was widowed last year when her husband Victor finally put both feet in the grave. She will still feel the benefit of the rise in the basic state retirement pension, which goes up to £72.50 for a single person - an extra £5 a week. This will increase by a further £3 from April next year.

Victor worked for the same company for 26 years so it is likely that Margaret will receive a regular pension from this, and will not be affected by the rise in the minimum income guarantee, which has risen to £92.15 a week for a single pensioner.

The increase in the personal allowance for people aged between 65 and 74 goes up £200, meaning the first £5,990 of her income is not taxed, although this is only worth £20 if she is a 10% tax payer.

Margaret will not get the full aged personal allowance if her income is more than £17,600.

fields.headline: Pensioner couple
fields.standfirst: Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Ray and Jessie Hilton, a married pensioner couple in Liverpool, can look forward to an above-inflation £8 increase in the state pension for couples. It will rise by another £4.30 from April 2002.
fields.body:
Ray and Jessie Hilton, a married pensioner couple in Liverpool, can look forward to an above-inflation £8 increase in the state pension for couples. It will rise by another £4.30 from April 2002.

The winter allowance and Christmas bonus are also being retained for another year. The couple, who have a modest joint income, will enjoy a small income tax cut and will find their tax allowances linked to earnings from 2003 when a new pension credit is to be introduced.

Ray will welcome the abolition of betting duty. Jessie will be glad the chancellor has promised no real rise in tobacco duty. They will also benefit from changes to the VAT system which could pave the way to free museum entrance.

Ray will have noticed, too, that his elderly mother Kitty will continue to benefit from free TV licence granted to the over-75s.

webTitle: City expects early interest rate cut

fields.headline: City expects early interest rate cut
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Budget 2001
Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: City analysts were last night pencilling a further cut in interest rates in the wake of yesterday's Budget package, although opinions were divided over whether it would be delivered ahead of an expected spring election.
fields.body:
City analysts were last night pencilling a further cut in interest rates in the wake of yesterday's Budget package, although opinions were divided over whether it would be delivered ahead of an expected spring election.

The chancellor's freeze on a range of excise duties will mean a fall in the headline rate of inflation and that, coupled with the decision not to reduce the inflation target, is seen as stepping up the pressure on the Bank of England's monetary policy committee.

Nick Parsons at Commerzbank in London said a cut was "virtually certain" before a May election. The way Gordon Brown was "trying to talk down the amount being given away" invited a rate cut.

Tony Norfield at ABN Amro said the Budget presented the bank with a difficult decision. While the excise duty freeze would cut headline inflation, the tax cuts and spending increases would boost the economy. "With the headline rate heading below 1.5%, it looks as if the Bank is going to have to cut," he said.

Financial markets largely took the Budget package in their stride. But the decision to abolish the minimum funding requirement - which in effect has forced pension funds to buy long-dated gilts - as part of the chancellor's backing for the Myners review of the fund management industry did send a frisson through the government debt market.

"It was a knee jerk reaction. The devil will be in the detail," said Andrew Milligan, head of global strategy at Standard Life Investments.

Elsewhere, the pound was unchanged at $1.4613 and 63.45p to the euro while the FTSE 100 share index ended at 6001.8 - down 10.2 points on the day and eight points down on the chancellor's speech.

webTitle: Calls for reform of annuities rejected

fields.headline: Calls for reform of annuities rejected
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Budget 2001
Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: The government yesterday insisted that it is keen to help those retiring receive a better deal when they come to convert their pension fund into an income for life - but it still rejected calls for reform of the "unfair" rules that force people to buy an annuity.
fields.body:
The government yesterday insisted that it is keen to help those retiring receive a better deal when they come to convert their pension fund into an income for life - but it still rejected calls for reform of the "unfair" rules that force people to buy an annuity.

Gordon Brown also said the government was looking into introducing a US-style savings account aimed at encouraging those on lower incomes to save more, where money invested by the individual is typically matched by a contribution from the state.

But overall, there was little for small investors in the chancellor's package of measures. "This was not a Budget for savers," said Ian Luder, head of the private client practice at accountant Andersen.

As announced in November's pre-Budget report, the contribution limit of £7,000 for individual savings accounts, or Isas, will remain for a further five years instead of reducing to £5,000. But the chancellor rejected calls for a cut in, or abolition of, stamp duty on small share purchases by private individuals.

There had been widespread calls for a relaxation of the rules that force those retiring to convert their pension money into annuity by the age of 75. Annuity rates - which determine how big an income an individual will receive from the pension fund they have built up - have halved since 1991 because of falling interest rates and people living longer, resulting in shrinking retirement incomes.

The government said yesterday that annuity reform was "a complex area" and many of the ideas submitted would have involved substantial costs.

The Treasury is to continue discussions with interested parties on "workable and affordable" alternatives.

webTitle: Champion of the children on target

fields.headline: Champion of the children on target
fields.standfirst:
Families  More help for working parents  'Baby bonus' will be worth up to £1,400

Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText:
Families
 More help for working parents
 'Baby bonus' will be worth up to £1,400
fields.body:
Budget measures targeted at helping low-and middle-income families boost the government's policy of eradicating child poverty.

From June, the adult benefit in the working families' tax credit (WFTC) will go up by £5 above inflation. A similar increase is proposed in the disabled person's tax credit (DPTC). The new rates, combined with the increases in the national minimum wage, will guarantee a family on WFTC a minimum income of £225 a week from next October, up from £214 a week in April.

Working parents will also get more help with the expense of childcare from June through an increase in the limits for eligible costs in the childcare tax credit component of WFTC. These go up from £100 to £135 for families with childcare costs for one child and from £150 to £200 for families with two or more children.

Because this credit covers up to 70% of eligible childcare costs, the changes mean a maximum of £94.50 per week for one child and £140 for two children towards registered childcare costs.

As predicted, the new children's tax credit (CTC) will be worth up to £10 a week when it comes into effect in April. This is £1.50 a week more than the starting rate announced in last year's Budget and represents a tax cut for about 5m families with children under 16. The CTC replaces the married couple's allowance but is available to unmarried couples and single parents.

To increase support for families with very young children - "the time when family income tends to fall as family costs rise", as the chancellor put it - from April 2002 the CTC will be increased by a further £10 a week for families in the year of a child's birth.

The Treasury has confirmed that this "baby bonus", which will be worth up to £1,040 for about 500,000 families each year, will be paid at this higher rate for the entire tax year (from one April to the next) in which a baby is born. If, for example, a family claims the bonus payment for a baby born in September, it will receive a lump sum backdated to the previous April and the rest through their pay packets on a monthly basis until the following April.

Families on income-related benefits who will not benefit from the increases in WFTC or the CTC, will get an increase of £1.50 a week in the child allowances in income support and jobseeker's allowance from October 2001, to match the rise in the CTC in this Budget.

As announced in last year's Budget, child benefit goes up in line with indexation from April to £15.50 for the first child and £10.35 for subsequent children.

Martin Barnes, director of the Child Poverty Action Group, said: "This is a good Budget for families and children. The chancellor has proved that he is a champion for children by his dogged and persistent commitment to children and low-income families."

More than 3m children would remain in poverty, however, and the government could and should do more. "If the momentum of this Budget is maintained, income poverty for children could be ended within 10 years and not 20."

Kate Green, director of the National Council for One Parent Families, said: "The chancellor's measures are a shot in the arm for working lone parents who will now be a step closer to a decent income. The substantial increase in the childcare tax credit is tremendous for lone parents for whom the cost of childcare is still a major barrier to work.

"We are also pleased to see the chancellor signal some recognition of the importance of full-time parenting with the £1.50 increase for children in income support."

Overnight difference

Family income before the Budget £22,888 net
Income after yesterday's measures £24,798 net
The plus factor? +£1,910

webTitle: Budget: Bringing up baby becomes easier

fields.headline: Bringing up baby becomes easier
fields.standfirst: Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: There are to be large increases in maternity pay aimed at making it easier for new mothers to have a period at home after their child is born before they return to work.
fields.body:
There are to be large increases in maternity pay aimed at making it easier for new mothers to have a period at home after their child is born before they return to work.

Statutory maternity pay, or SMP, at present paid at a flat rate of £60.20 a week after the first six weeks, is to go up to £75 from next year and to £100 from April 2003.

Maternity allowance, paid to self-employed women and others not eligible for SMP, will go up by the same rate.

All women entitled to SMP or maternity allowance - approximately 360,000 a year - will get either the new flat rate or, as under present rules, 90% of their previous average earnings if that is lower.

From April 2003 the period of maternity pay at the enhanced rate will also increase from 18 to 26 weeks, giving mothers on SMP or maternity allowance entitlement to a further eight weeks of pay.

Working fathers will also for the first time be given the right to two weeks' paid paternity leave at the same £100 flat rate from April 2003.

Adoptive parents, who are entitled to only 13 weeks' unpaid leave, will be paid for adoption leave for the same period and at the same flat rate as SMP.

Adoptive parents will be able to choose which of them takes time off work and receives payment. From April 2002, the Sure Start maternity grant will go up from the £300 one-off payment to £500.

The grant is part of the government's programme aimed at promoting the wellbeing of children under four years old in Britain's most disadvantaged areas.

It is payable to all low income families provided they meet basic health check requirements for their child.

The increase will benefit some 215,000 families on income related benefits and tax credits every year.

Christine Gowdridge, the director of the Maternity Alliance, said: "The £40 increase in maternity pay over two years is very significant, especially for low incomes families - a real boost at a time when they need it most. "

John Edmonds, general secretary of the GMB public service workers' union, said: "Gordon Brown has thrown a lifeline to thousands of working mothers.

"Many working women are forced into a devil's choice between spending time with their child during the vital first months or leaving their child to earn income to support it through its early years.

"These measures will go a long way to freeing women from the maternity trap."

Kate Green, the director of the National Council for One Parent Families, said: "This is a tremendous step."

fields.headline: Pensioners' increase outpaces inflation
fields.standfirst:
 Single OAPs to get £72.50  £115.90 for couples

Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown, yesterday sought to defuse pensioners' anger about Labour's record in its first four years with a comprehensive set of reforms designed to end pensioner poverty. He said it would allow "today's workforce - tomorrow's retirement pensioners - to plan ahead".
fields.body:
Gordon Brown, yesterday sought to defuse pensioners' anger about Labour's record in its first four years with a comprehensive set of reforms designed to end pensioner poverty. He said it would allow "today's workforce - tomorrow's retirement pensioners - to plan ahead".

The basic state pension is to increase by more than the average wage, rising by £5 a week for a single person to £72.50 from April. Couples will see their basic go up from £107.90 to £115.90 - a 7.4% increase.

Further increases are already pencilled in for April 2002 - to £75.50 for single pensioners and £120.70 for couples. This is in addition to retaining the winter allowance and the free television licence for the over 75s.

The minimum income guarantee is to be simplified with one rate for all those who qualify. From April, single pensioners will be guaranteed an income of £92.15, and couples a minimum £140.55.

Better off pensioners will benefit from income tax changes thanks to the extension of the 10p tax rate, an above inflation uplift in the personal allowance for the over 65s and a £600 rise in the income limit for these age related allowances.

A pensioner couple each with £8,000 income before tax will be £87 a year better off; those on £20,000 each will gain £312 between them after the income tax changes kick in.

But helping tomorrow's pensioners to plan today is as high on the chancellor's agenda.

"Since November, we have been consulting on our new pension credit, to be introduced in 2003. Pensioner couples with incomes below £200 and single pensioners with incomes below £135 a week, will receive the new pension credit," Mr Brown said.

The pension credit is set to give "extra support" to around half of all pensioner households. It will allow those with lower retirement incomes, which are nevertheless above the basic state pension level, to keep a large proportion of their savings income or income from their company pensions.

He said the intention -from 2003 - is to abolish capital rules which penalise pensioners with savings above £3,000, end the weekly means test, and increase the minimum income guarantee by linking this to rises in earnings throughout the next parliament.

Age Concern director general Gordon Lishman hailed Mr Brown as the first chancellor in 20 years to raise the basic state pension above the rate of inflation. But he criticised the Treasury for creating a "massively complex system and endless form filling for pensioners" who relied on the pension credit and minimum income guarantee.

Jack Jones, president of the National Pensioners' Convention, said pensioners wanted a more substantial increase in the basic state pension rather than more means tested benefits.

fields.headline: 'Fancy footwork on tax concessions'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: "It's difficult to argue against this budget," said pensioner Sean Kenny, adding with a wink at his wife Pat, "but then I believe we may have an election coming on soon."
fields.body:
"It's difficult to argue against this budget," said pensioner Sean Kenny, adding with a wink at his wife Pat, "but then I believe we may have an election coming on soon."

Behind Gordon Brown's bullet points for the retired, the former metalworker detects some fancy footwork over supposed tax benefits.

The Birmingham couple's joint pension comes to £130 a week, supplemented by £15 from a scheme Mr Kenny joined during a stint as a porter at Boots, and £5 a week which Pat receives from a former job making zip fasteners. The total keeps them well below the tax threshold, and both are suspicious of how many pensioners will benefit from the new earnings-linked allowances which kick-in in 2003.

"Gordon Brown says 70% of pensioners will benefit but I can't imagine where he gets that from," said Mr Kenny, who at 70 (and with Pat a year younger) is a few years away from the added perk of a free TV licence. "We're not curmudgeonly about the increase we're getting in the actual pension, but we'd rather it was more, and earnings-related, than the government concentrating on tax concessions."

The couple also believe that the rise smacks of spin. Mr Kenny, who was a precision grinder in the "workshop of the world" before recession killed his job in the mid-80s, said: "I don't know why Hugh Dalton got sacked for leaking his Budget, when our pension increases were announced back in November."

The money is not all it seems, he believes. Taken over a three-year period, he calculates that the £5 single and £8 couple largesse announced by the chancellor yesterday hardly makes up for the less-than-generous increases of previous years.

There is a further additional £4.80 pension increase for a couple already scheduled for April of next year. But the Kennys will still need a lottery win before they get at all excited about petrol price cuts. The realities of life mean that Sean's precious Austin Mark One 1800 is mothballed in the garage.

"The end of betting duty won't affect us either," said Sean, who left Dublin 58 years ago for work in the Midlands. He and Pat are relieved, though, that their £15 weekly bill for drink will not be rising."I applaud a lot of the general measures," said Sean, whose four grandchildren stand to benefit from extra school funding.

The goal of a fully earnings-related pension, however, will still keep the Kennys as obstreperous over-60s - they have protested and joined sit-ins in recent years - since their domestic economy will remain fragile.

fields.headline: A cautious but cunning Budget
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Budget 2001

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: This was not a Budget to win an election, but a Budget for an election that is already won. Its handouts were slight, its promises distant, its perspectives closer to five years than five weeks. It was like a matching reward for the two years of parsimony with which Gordon Brown began his tenure. Having started in 1997 by creating a first-term platform to prove how conservative he could be, yesterday he built one for the second term in which he and Tony Blair must show how socialistic, at heart, they really are. They have shown long-term rigour, almost to a fault.
fields.body:
This was not a Budget to win an election, but a Budget for an election that is already won. Its handouts were slight, its promises distant, its perspectives closer to five years than five weeks. It was like a matching reward for the two years of parsimony with which Gordon Brown began his tenure. Having started in 1997 by creating a first-term platform to prove how conservative he could be, yesterday he built one for the second term in which he and Tony Blair must show how socialistic, at heart, they really are. They have shown long-term rigour, almost to a fault.

Given the size of the surplus, Mr Brown could have given far more away. Most of his predecessors would have done. He doesn't need to be paying down the national debt at this record-breaking rate. Given the imminence of May 3, or even June 7, he could have made blatant offerings to a much wider group of voters than families with children. But given that this is a Blair-Brown government, the most intimate and potent duumvirate of modern times, there was always a decent chance that it would exploit its political strength in order to take economically cautious decisions.

Though they've kept a close eye on the voters, this is what they have done. Before the Budget, uprating of pensions and then the minimum wage reminded many millions that the government was listening. The ministers have looked after the masses. New micro-measures are targeted to keep motorists and hauliers and drinkers happy. But the larger politics of the Budget are almost counter-intuitive. They marry the long road of economic reform to the long life of those who now plan undeviatingly to traverse it.

Over Mr Brown's five Budgets, the occasion has been transformed. The Budget is supposed to be an economic climax, and that's the way it is still treated. We all play the game. There are special supplements and ceremonially spacious television programmes. The details are breathlessly awaited. The rituals of pomp and circumstance have barely changed since the first Budget I can remember, which was Reginald Maudling's in the early 1960s.

While happy to go along with such ornamentalism, Mr Brown has changed the substance into something else. His Budgets have grown into a cunning mixture of measures already leaked and other measures, especially taxes, that the Budget statement itself may omit to specify at all. Once the sacred unveiling of an economic secret, it has become an amalgam of the repetitious and, sometimes, the unrevealed. Once the occasion for a grand overview of the great forces that touched the famous Budget Judgment, it is now an interim statement of work in progress by the chief executive of UK plc.

That's how Gordon Brown sounded yesterday, rattling through a long series of undifferentiated passages, no rise and fall, no break between, no rhetorical shape, some of them detailed, others vague, others alluding to future statements and documents to come. He seemed impatient more than triumphalist, though he had a happy story to tell. The great man was being briefly interrupted in his life's work of digging ever deeper into the entrails of the economy and society. He has been doing it, after all, for more than a decade - 24/7, as they say, every hour, every day, every week - since he was John Smith's deputy in the Kinnock shadow cabinet.

So there was something peremptory in his lack of need to explain his final Budget of the first term. Far from awaiting this definitive statement, Budget-watchers are now meant to have kept up with the copious preliminaries. Anyone who missed those earlier speeches and half-revelations, the unrepeatable sub-texts of the Budget statement itself, doesn't deserve to understand the sheer critical mass of strategy that lies behind it, the long-termism, the profundity of Brown-Blairite social reforms.

In this, Mr Brown is unlike any predecessor not only because of his own seriousness but because of the system he invented in the first week of his tenure. Handing monetary policy over to the monetary policy committee of the Bank was not only good for the stability of the economy. Almost as telling, it released the chancellor from the most neuralgic part of his job, fixing interest rates, thus giving a strategist such as Mr Brown time and space to undertake the deeper tasks for which he went into politics. Even in times as untroubled as the present, the aura of the monetary judgment in the old days would distract from the rest of the Budget.

Freed from that, Mr Brown continues on his path. The philosophy of work as the cure for all deprivation is replenished with every Budget. No worries there about recent evidence that Brits work their backs off for longer hours than anyone in Europe. Whether beset by drugs or burdened with children, people have to pass the fit-for-work test, for which the state will provide sticks as well as carrots.

That's the first common thread. The second, now, is the commitment to public services. The new billions announced yesterday were not as big as they could well afford to have been. It sounds as though the Treasury has been listening more than it would ever admit to the hyper-caution of the International Monetary Fund, which recently, to Mr Brown's rage, dared to cast a shadow of a doubt on his prudence.

But in the second term, for which this Budget is designed, will come the major political test for Blairism. There is another, of which the chancellor is acutely aware, the lamentable record of the British economy, despite the fine general out-turn of the last five years, in productivity.

A failure to make a serious impact on productivity over the next half-decade will leave the UK economy struggling against euroland. But the prime targets have to be education and health and crime, and also, I would say, defence, the quality of which will deserve to settle the fate of the Labour government by the end of the next parliament.

Mr Blair and Mr Brown understand that. They have a complicated relationship. No prime minister and chancellor have been more equal. None have been at the same time such rivals and such friends. But they have got where they are together, and taken the country on a track they did not argue about. They had a common vision of how the first term should start and how it should end. Their history together may produce an explosive chemistry, especially when their respective acolytes get together and start making trouble.

But the principals themselves have far more to be said for them than against them. The record Mr Brown was able to celebrate yesterday, however unexuberantly, did not have to happen. They made it happen.

Political life was rather different the last time Labour was in power.

Nearly four years in from the start of the 1974 government, Tony Benn recorded the state of things at the pre-Budget cabinet meeting, when Denis Healey had Mr Brown's job.

"Denis went on about industrial performance, design and marketing, just mouthing the phrases; in the end what we're saying is it's the working class that are responsible for all the troubles. I actually came away more depressed than I have ever been.

"Full employment is no longer on the agenda of a Labour government. They haven't even got a strategy for the 80s. They simply haven't got a strategy."

Things have improved just a little.

fields.headline: Amazon in card security row
fields.trailText: A raid by hackers on the online retailer's offshoot has put customer credit details at risk, writes Stuart Millar.
fields.body:
Amazon, the world's biggest online retailer, was embroiled in a humiliating computer security row last night after it emerged that intruders had access to the credit details of thousands of a subsidiary's customers for four months.

Bibliofind, which connects buyers and sellers of rare and secondhand books, has contacted users to admit that hackers penetrated its defences in October last year, managing to maintain undetected access to its 98,000-customer database until last week. During that time, the raiders are believed to have downloaded names and addresses, credit card details and telephone numbers. It is understood that the attack was spotted during a security review prompted by the site being defaced.

Some customers have been told by their credit card issuers that their cards have been suspended as security has been compromised.

The extraordinary breach will come as a huge embarrassment to Amazon.com. The online books and auctions operation, which took over Bibliofind in April 1999, has grown to be come the net's biggest retail success with a reputation for electronic security that has helped it overcome widespread public fears about fraud.

Yesterday, Amazon executives in Seattle, Washington, were distancing themselves from the episode. Callers were referred to Bibliofind, which Amazon insisted was an entirely separate operation.

Bibliofind moved to assure customers that there was no evidence that any of the stolen information had been used to commit fraud.

Its spokesman Jim Courtovich said: "We have no information at this time to suggest that customers' credit cards have been misused."

The events are the subject of an investigation by the US authorities.

The site will no longer hold customer credit details. Instead, all payments will be made direct by purchasers to the individual bookseller.

Users of the site, which was closed down over the weekend after the breach was spotted, have been sent an email informing them that a security violation "compromised the security of credit card information".

The email concluded: "To ensure this doesn't happen again, we have removed all customer credit card information, physical addresses, and phone numbers from Bibliofind's servers. We expect to bring the Bibliofind system back into operation shortly."

In a development that will deepen the embarrassment of Amazon and Bibliofind, a British internet news website claimed yesterday to have evidence that the company had been warned at least once that its defences may have been violated.

The Register published claims from a US internet retailer that he had detected a spate of attempted credit card frauds around October. Items of $1,200 to $2,000 in value were ordered with valid US cards, most of them to be shipped to eastern European destinations. The retailer became suspicious and contacted cardholders.

"We asked them if they shopped online anywhere else, as we suspected someone's database had been hacked," the retailer told the Register. "The only common link was Bibliofind." He had contacted the company, but it denied its site had been hacked into.

Last night, a Bibliofind spokesman said any warning would have been investigated.

webTitle: Polly Toynbee: will Brown's prudence deliver in the long term?

fields.headline: Prudence pays off?
fields.standfirst:
The chancellor's last Budget before the general election leaves his history of meanness still in question

Special report: Budget 2001
Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: The chancellor's last Budget before the general election leaves his history of meanness still in question.
fields.body:
The chancellor's final budget brought the curtain down on the end of New Labour, Act One with a mighty confident flourish. Flowers were thrown, opposition cabbages didn't even reach the stage. Now he retires to the dressing room to prepare for Act Two. Meanwhile the audience contemplates his grand opus so far, wondering what comes next.

This last great performance gave us the chancellor in red mode, poor children's friend, the stealth-taxing secret socialist. No other word but redistribution describes how the money has flowed towards the poorest with a little taken from the top. Why, even his henchmen now use the wicked R-word once banned from New Labour's lexicon. Average and poorer families were again the target of his munificence, new mothers, child care, paternity leave - a budget for poorer women, so a new mother will be £2,240 a year better off. Another 170,000 children will be lifted above poverty levels. And as more billions poured in for hospitals, schools, drug treatment, urban regeneration and myriad good causes - free museums, films, dilapidated churches, sports clubs - that now familiar Brown budget wonderment struck again.

For who could imagine a Labour chancellor with £16bn in his pocket, inflation licked, national debt and interest rates down, full employment within grasp? All pensioners (who claim) are in April lifted out of poverty - an unthinkable promise back in 1997, almost as extraordinary as ending child poverty. There has never been so big a step up for the poor. As for the rest? Good times brought jam to every social slice - 4% higher consumer spending each year, average living standards up rosily, mortgages an average £1,200 cheaper, growth outstripping all predictions. Happy days and the best is yet to come, as the public spending jam rolls out in earnest now.

So there are red roses aplenty for red Gordon. He has turned the political debate away from tax cuts - there were none, only extra credits for the poor. That was a crucial test of his nerve. How tempting with so much cash to knock another 1p off pre-election income tax. It was a 1999 error not repeated because it didn't need to be. Labour has gained in confidence since then and the public mood is with them - pressing for spending, not for tax cuts.

This chancellor congratulates himself on long-termism, but after an excellent first act, the end of his story is still unknown, judgment too early to make. For all the feel-good glow each of his budgets brings, there remains the big long-term question. Will he effect a fundamental and long-term shift in Britain's tax and spend regime? The year 2003-2004 is the crunch by which time the spending now laid out must have delivered undeniable results in health, education and transport - with public services proud, well-paid and thrusting ahead for all to see. Current public patience will run out by then. Tory posters reading "You paid the cash, so where are the nurses/teachers ..." and so on make people snort with scorn at Tory cheek now - but not by then if change is not everywhere about to be seen. As people get yearly richer, so expectations of public services rise too. Never before has a Labour government produced increases in public investment above trend growth, and yet the big picture is still a history of under-spending.

If it turns out that Act One was as good as it ever gets, then this first term was not enough. If recession rolls in on a dark tide from across the Atlantic, then we will look back and wonder how Labour did so little when the times were extraordinarily good. Why so timid, why so slow? The chancellor may have ended boom-and-bust but what we had instead in public spending was bust-and-boom. The depth of that bust is becoming ever more apparent: the price of prudence was painfully high. It will now not be until 2003-4 that Britain returns to the same level of public spending as a proportion of GDP that it inherited in 1997. A killer fact.

Of course it is not quite as simple as that. Within that total, the huge sums previously wasted on unemployment and debt interest have been redistributed to excellent effect. But none the less, over any length of time, the amount a country taxes and spends defines fairly accurately the quality of its public service. We will still not be spending nearly enough. It was Tony Blair himself who promised NHS spending would meet the EU average, thus drawing attention to the yawning gap between Europe and Britain in every other public sphere as well. The disastrous failure to spend in 2000 - with a massive £5bn capital undershoot - accidentally added to the time of famine, delaying results.

Another killer fact is that, despite the quite radical redistribution by government, the gap between the rich and poor has still widened under Labour. It always happens in prosperous times, but Labour made no attempt to claw back any of the extra income flowing in to top earners - let alone taxing their growing capital wealth. Indeed, capital gains and inheritance taxes have shrunk to insignificance. Let the Tories grumble about Labour's "45 new stealth taxes", the big picture is still that the rich are getting richer faster than the rest and the poor are still being left behind.

The ongoing comedy of Conservative policy - made not so much on the hoof as in the Magimix - gives Labour the chance to confront the tax question head on. William Hague, excited by George Bush's trillion dollar promise, now says he will make a mind-boggling £114bn tax cut. Suddenly lurching for a wild west alternative, the Tories now oblige Labour to talk honestly about tax. But an open advocacy of virtuous taxation has always been noticeably lacking in every Gordon Brown budget speech. He has extinguished public demand for tax cuts, but that's only half the battle. Hague's axe-man cuts require a broad and principled case to be made positively for taxes: they are not a "burden" if they buy the things that people want.

Praise of public wealth can face down the Tory nostrum that we each spend our own money better than the government does. If Labour's 10-year plans work as well as intended, there will be good evidence that public money well-spent buys much more collectively than citizens can each buy individually. But such words never spring easily to the chancellor's lips. This was a prudent budget - no horse-frightening in the City before an election. But future budgets need more radical shifts. Too often New Labour appeases and buys off opposing forces: this third-way strategy makes few friends or permanent changes. Long-term security for a left of centre government comes from persuading the public of the case for higher taxes - not from stealth or subterfuge. On taxes the people will not be fooled for long, but they might be persuaded to pay more.

webTitle: Soft line on health risks draws fire

fields.headline: Soft line on health risks draws fire
fields.standfirst:
Tobacco/drink  3p on packet of cigarettes  Tax break for small brewers

Special report: smoking
Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: The chancellor came under fire from health professionals yesterday for "going soft" on drinkers and smokers in a sharp change of policy that many interpreted as a populist pre-election gambit.
fields.body:
The chancellor came under fire from health professionals yesterday for "going soft" on drinkers and smokers in a sharp change of policy that many interpreted as a populist pre-election gambit.

Gordon Brown froze duty on beers, wines and spirits following complaints from the drinks industry about a surge in smuggling, and added a surprise tax break for smaller brewers. Tax on a packet of cigarettes went up just 6p, in line with the rate of inflation.

The Royal College of Physicians said it was disappointed, pointing out that the government had previously pledged to increase cigarette tax by 5% in real terms every year.

The college's president, Sir George Alberti, said: "Tobacco and alcohol are the UK's major killers and causes of disease - this does nothing to discourage consumption of either."

Clive Bates, the director of lobbyist Action on Smoking and Health, echoed this view, pointing out that an inflationary rise in tobacco tax would not keep pace with rising salaries.

"This means cigarettes will become more affordable," he said. "They want to have a popular, smokers' Budget just before the election."

The Treasury said the price of a packet of five small cigars will typically rise by 2p, while 25 gram packs of hand-rolling and pipe tobacco will now cost 5p and 3p more respectively.

There was a mixed response from the tobacco industry.

Gallaher said: "We called for a freeze. We are disappointed that there is any increase, but give a cautious welcome to the chancellor moving away from excessive above-inflation duty increases."

Forest, the smokers' action group, said the change in policy was insignificant, and called on Mr Brown to copy a recent reduction in tobacco duty in Sweden.

For drinkers, Mr Brown extended a freeze on spirits duty to encompass beer and wine, citing "the competitive position of the industry".

This was interpreted as a reference to complaints about a flood of cheap imports from the continent - a report this week by Stuart Neame, the chairman of the Independent Family Brewers of Britain, found that each extra penny of tax on beer led to an extra 25,000 pints being brought in by "booze cruisers" daily.

In a bonus for real ale enthusiasts, the Treasury said it was "minded" to introduce a lower rate of duty for smaller brewers. This follows concern for the future of companies such as Shepherd Neame, Young & Co and Fuller, Smith & Turner, following the emergence of powerful "mega-brewers" such as Interbrew and Scottish & Newcastle.

fields.headline: Bold return for Shakespeare's orphan
fields.standfirst:
King John
Viaduct Theatre, Halifax
****
fields.trailText:
King John
Viaduct Theatre, Halifax
****
fields.body:
King John is the unloved orphan among Shakespeare's plays. Yet after years of neglect, a brace of Johns suddenly appears. Scooping the RSC by three weeks, Northern Broadsides offers a bold, exhilarating, percussive production, directed by Barrie Rutter and Conrad Nelson, that makes one boggle at our theatre's disdain for this engrossing chronicle.

What startles one is the play's modernity: it accords with our own scepticism about power politics. We see a cynical battle for the English throne between John, the de facto ruler, and the French king, who shamelessly uses John's nephew, Arthur, as a political pawn. The choric Bastard starts out as a bumptious opportunist who makes "Commodity", or naked self-interest, his god. And you could hardly have a more outrageous example of spin than the Bastard's belated attempt to terrify the French with the prospect of "warlike John" when the king lies desperately enfeebled. Even the character's famous, final vaunt - "This England never did, nor never shall, lie at the proud foot of a conqueror" - sounds a bit like William Hague at Harrogate.

But, far from being a patriotic battle-hymn, the play is, especially in the first half, a corrosively satiric study of sordid power struggles. And this production, played on a red-carpeted traverse stage, brings out excellently the mixture of bombast and expediency. Nothing is better than the scene where the English and French armies compete to win Angiers. Military might is evoked through fiercely pounded kettledrums. Yet beneath the percussive noise, you sense the conflict's essential squalor. John, desperate to keep his throne, sticks close to his militant mum for comfort. And the boy Arthur, whose claim the French endorse, is a quivering figure terrified out of his wits.

Admittedly, the second half is less cohesive. But, in addition to clarifying the zigzag fortunes of the rival parties, both directors contribute strong performances of their own. Nelson as the Bastard not only drums like Buddy Rich but even makes sense of the character's transition from acerbic commentator to national icon. And Rutter lends the papal legate, Pandulph, a sinister sophistry as he persuades the Dauphin that defeat is a kind of victory.

There are even greater depths of insecurity in the vacillating John than those yet discovered by the eccentrically named Fine Time Fontayne. But there is a splendidly troubled Hubert from Gerard McDermott, and Marie Louise O'Donnell as Constance hits exactly the right note of raging egotism when she cries, after the betrayal of her son Arthur, "What becomes of me ?" fields.bodyText: King John is the unloved orphan among Shakespeare's plays. Yet after years of neglect, a brace of Johns suddenly appears. Scooping the RSC by three weeks, Northern Broadsides offers a bold, exhilarating, percussive production, directed by Barrie Rutter and Conrad Nelson, that makes one boggle at our theatre's disdain for this engrossing chronicle. What startles one is the play's modernity: it accords with our own scepticism about power politics. We see a cynical battle for the English throne between John, the de facto ruler, and the French king, who shamelessly uses John's nephew, Arthur, as a political pawn. The choric Bastard starts out as a bumptious opportunist who makes "Commodity", or naked self-interest, his god. And you could hardly have a more outrageous example of spin than the Bastard's belated attempt to terrify the French with the prospect of "warlike John" when the king lies desperately enfeebled. Even the character's famous, final vaunt - "This England never did, nor never shall, lie at the proud foot of a conqueror" - sounds a bit like William Hague at Harrogate. But, far from being a patriotic battle-hymn, the play is, especially in the first half, a corrosively satiric study of sordid power struggles. And this production, played on a red-carpeted traverse stage, brings out excellently the mixture of bombast and expediency. Nothing is better than the scene where the English and French armies compete to win Angiers. Military might is evoked through fiercely pounded kettledrums. Yet beneath the percussive noise, you sense the conflict's essential squalor. John, desperate to keep his throne, sticks close to his militant mum for comfort. And the boy Arthur, whose claim the French endorse, is a quivering figure terrified out of his wits. Admittedly, the second half is less cohesive. But, in addition to clarifying the zigzag fortunes of the rival parties, both directors contribute strong performances of their own. Nelson as the Bastard not only drums like Buddy Rich but even makes sense of the character's transition from acerbic commentator to national icon. And Rutter lends the papal legate, Pandulph, a sinister sophistry as he persuades the Dauphin that defeat is a kind of victory. fields.headline: Punters to enjoy levy-free flutter
fields.standfirst: Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Punters will be able to enjoy a flutter without a paying a penny in tax by January next year after yesterday's Budget ushered in sweeping changes to the betting duty system.
fields.body:
Punters will be able to enjoy a flutter without a paying a penny in tax by January next year after yesterday's Budget ushered in sweeping changes to the betting duty system.

The decision means that for the first time since April 1968, there will be no tax on gaming and both bookies and punters stand to gain.

The present 9% levy on betting, which is passed directly on the customer, is being replaced by a 15% tax on bookmakers' gross profits.

Ladbrokes, Coral, William Hill and the Tote all vowed to shut their offshore operations and come back home after the chancellor scraped the deduction of 9p on the pound from punters' bets.

The tax was one of the reasons why they had set up major operations on the internet, allowing their customers to place bets duty-free from the UK, while they were based in offshore tax havens.

Bob Scott, head of Eurobet, Coral's offshore division, said the chancellor's decision would revolutionise the betting industry.

"The government has promised it would support the growth of e-commerce in the UK and this announcement gives a massive boost to the betting and gaming industry, paving the way for UK based bookmakers to lead the world."

fields.headline: Boost for drugs research
fields.standfirst: Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown's offer of tax breaks to encourage British pharmaceutical companies to wage war on "killer diseases" won cautious approval yesterday - and a warning that more could be done.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown's offer of tax breaks to encourage British pharmaceutical companies to wage war on "killer diseases" won cautious approval yesterday - and a warning that more could be done.

The Budget held out the possibility of a 50% tax credit on research and development into medicines to combat malaria, tuberculosis and HIV/Aids in the developing world, following consultation with the drugs industry and other parties.

Mr Brown also said he wanted the UK to push for a new international purchase fund for global health, "that will not only develop new life-saving drugs but make existing drugs more widely available".

The proposals - first outlined in the pre-Budget report last November - call for discussions on incentives to encourage the pharmaceutical industry to increase its donations of drugs to developing countries.

fields.headline: Tax breaks for reinvestment
fields.standfirst: Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Intellectual property and goodwill are to be subject to a new tax relief regime as part of the attempt to stimulate greater innovation and activity in the corporate sector.
fields.body:
Intellectual property and goodwill are to be subject to a new tax relief regime as part of the attempt to stimulate greater innovation and activity in the corporate sector.

The proposals provide relief for the cost of acquiring assets such as brands, "know-how" or software and introduce rules aiming to treat all intangible assets by the same measures.

Previously tax breaks had been made available only on some intangibles or by "rollover relief" when a company sold assets on. Under the proposals, companies will be able to get relief that matches the write-off on the profit and loss account, including expenses on the creation of intangibles through patents, for instance. Tax breaks will also be made available on the costs of an aborted takeover which can run into millions of pounds.

Kriss Bush, tax adviser at the investment bank Lehman Brothers, described the move as a "dramatic step". "These rules are moving in a direction which parallels the US where they have been a strong stimulant for economic activity."

A consultation document on the issue was published yesterday. It follows a move flagged a year ago to bring tax relief on intellectual property and goodwill in line with the profit and loss account. Yesterday's paper, which asks for responses by the end of May, sets out detailed proposals in cluding draft legislation covering the key points.

Mary Monfries, senior manager at PricewaterhouseCoopers, said the government had clearly listened to some industry concerns. It was to introduce a "reinvestment relief" within the new regime based on the current capital gains rollover relief. "This is good news, because the government seems to be preserving rollover relief capability whilst making income tax reliefs more consistent," she said.

Tom Spillett, senior tax manager at BDO Stoy Hayward, said the proposals were framed with new economy firms in mind. But he was disappointed not to see relief extended to "capital nothings" - cash spent building goodwill through advertising, for instance.

fields.headline: Bank keeps rates at 5.75%
fields.trailText: The Bank of England put interest rates back on hold today following last month's quarter point cut, as City analysts had anticipated.
fields.body:
The Bank of England put interest rates back on hold today following last month's quarter point cut, as City analysts had anticipated.

At their announcement, the Bank's monetary policy committee kept rates at 5.75% despite some calls for an early cut and concern about the economic slowdown in the United States.

The Bank governor, Sir Edward George, had said earlier that the committee would not be afraid to move rates in the runup to a general election and a change today would have been acutely politically sensitive, as it would have be seen as an instant verdict on yesterday's Budget.

A senior treasury official yesterday briefed the MPC on the Budget measures at the start of its two day rate-setting meeting.

Some economists believe that the chancellor's relatively modest £4bn giveaway still leaves room for further rate cuts, with June the favoured date, after the election, expected in May, is safely out of the way.

With the latest survey data showing growth in the service sector remains "buoyant", despite concerns elsewhere, most analysts believe that the MPC are right to wait before moving rates again.

fields.headline: Blunkett given £1bn for school problems
fields.standfirst:
¥ £2,000 lure for ex-teachers
¥ £100m extra for repairs
¥ Direct grants for heads

Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: An extra £1bn over three years for schools includes more for books and repairs and £200m to tackle teacher shortages, the government's most pressing education problem.
fields.body:
An extra £1bn over three years for schools includes more for books and repairs and £200m to tackle teacher shortages, the government's most pressing education problem.

David Blunkett, the education secretary, said that under the overall package - £837m of which goes to England - the government will be spending £500 more per pupil than in 1997. Education spending will rise by 5.2% this year.

A package to be published on Monday will include £2,000 grants for returning teachers, expected to be mostly women who left to have children. They will receive £500 when they return to teaching and £1,500 if they stay for a year.

Those who return to subjects short of teachers - maths, science, technology, English and modern languages - will receive £4,000 grants (£1,000 up front, £3,000 after a year), matching the "golden hello" to new graduates. An estimated 230,000 people who trained as teachers are working outside the system. Ministers hope the scheme will bring back about 2,000 over 18 months.

Although the number of graduate recruits to teaching is rising - there are 2,300 more in training than last year - Mr Blunkett has accepted they will take time to get in post. He has conceded that some schools, particularly in the south east, are struggling to recruit, but he rejects talk of a crisis.

Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the National Union of Teachers, said: "The chancellor's announcement is acknowledgement at last at the highest levels in the government of the depth of the crisis hitting teacher supply." He was doubtful whether former teachers would return for a "£2,000 bribe", however.

Repeating a popular move in last year's Budget, headteachers will receive direct grants to spend however they want - providing they go broadly towards raising standards. When the direct grants and capital grants are taken together, the smallest primary schools of under 100 pupils will receive an extra £3,000 on top of the £10,000 already promised. The larger ones will get £63,000 instead of the previously announced £50,000.

Grants for secondary schools will rise from £57,000 to £68,000 for the few schools under 200.

The very largest, of more than 1,200 pupils, will see their direct and capital grants rise in total from £92,000 to £115,000.

Overall, the direct grants are worth £100m a year in England. Ministers want the money to be spent on books, equipment and extra staff.

Mr Brown also delivered an extra £100m a year for school building repairs. The money for capital spending will increase from £19,000 to £28,500 for a typical secondary and from £6,500 to £9,750 for a typical primary.

Additional credits under the private finance initiative will be worth £200m next year and another £200m the year after. The government says it has delivered major refurbishments to 370 schools since the election but has a target of 650 by 2004.

David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, said: "I'm absolutely delighted that the chancellor has upped the ante and has increased the money going straight into school budgets to be spent by heads and governors as they wish."

But Phil Willis, the Lib Dem education spokesman, said: "This pre-election Budget bribe comes too late for thousands of teachers who have already left the profession."

fields.headline: Couple, both employed
fields.standfirst: Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Dr Matt Ramsden and his teacher wife Charlie, who live comfortably on a combined salary of £65,000 in a terraced house in a small Lancashire town, will toast the chancellor's health when they next slip into the Rovers Return - and not just because the duty on beer, wine and spirits has been frozen.
fields.body:
Dr Matt Ramsden and his teacher wife Charlie, who live comfortably on a combined salary of £65,000 in a terraced house in a small Lancashire town, will toast the chancellor's health when they next slip into the Rovers Return - and not just because the duty on beer, wine and spirits has been frozen.

Both will benefit from the raised income tax threshold at the 10p rate. The couple have been thinking of starting a family and will be heartened by news that the new children's tax credit for families with babies will be set at a higher level from 2002. Maternity pay, which is being extended from 18 weeks to 26 weeks from 2003, is being increased from £60 to £100 a week and Matt would also be entitled to two weeks' paid paternity leave.

Charlie, who teaches English at a local comprehensive, will applaud the extra money given to secondary schools while Matt will be relieved by the £135m pledged to recruit frontline NHS staff.

The cut in duty on unleaded petrol until June will reduce Charlie's commuting costs.
