fields.headline: Birmingham Royal Ballet
fields.standfirst:
Alexandra Theatre, Birmingham
***
fields.trailText:
Alexandra Theatre, Birmingham
***
fields.body:
Balanchine was a master at giving dancing shape to music but in his exquisite 1941 setting of Bach's double violin concerto in D minor, Concerto Barocco, our intuition of the choreography's relation to its score is unusually direct. It's partly that the construction and ornamentation of the music are so transparent, partly that the ensemble is so small (three principals and eight chorus), but with every phrase, every surprise counterpoint, every group figuration, we see the dancers not only imaging the bright tracks of the music, but also the tensions and spaces between.

This limpid contact between dance and music puts terrific pressure on the dancers, though. Here, watching the first-cast ballerinas Leticia Muller and Nao Sakuma side by side, it's bluntly evident how much more serenely and interestingly the latter can match her dancing to the score. With her secure line and musical instinct, she's able to mirror a grandly rising crescendo in the strings with the sweeping arc of her leg, and to articulate their quick pouncing staccato with her own sharply pointed moves.

Muller, by contrast, tends to cut the music short and blur its contrasts, so that you're far more aware of a movement logic at odds with the score. It's not that she's dancing badly, just that she breaks the charmed symbiosis between ear and eye. This happens with the corps too, when rogue discrepancies of line and rhythm are far more noticeable than they would be in a more crowded piece. Yet we are talking deviation from perfection here, and BRB perform Concerto with love and conviction. The moment it's over you want it to start all over again.

The same cannot be said for Stanton Welch's Powder (1998), which is also set to one of the world's classical hits - Mozart's clarinet concerto in A major. This is a dance for seven couples (nominally the Muses and their boyfriends), who alternately frolic and mooch to Mozart's score. The most coherent idea Welch comes up with is to have his cast dressed in underwear. Otherwise he stuffs every kind of robotic, classical, clownish move he can think of into the choreography, in a way that neither acknowledges the music's beauty, nor subverts it, but tags lazily along on its coat-tails. Given that Welch is a favourite choreographer of the Royal Ballet's director-elect Ross Stretton, one hopes this isn't typical of his work.

 At the Alexandra Theatre, Birmingham (0870 607 7533) until Saturday, then touring.

fields.headline: Hackers humiliate Amazon
fields.standfirst: Intruders had access to customer credit details for four months at site owned by world's biggest e-tailer
fields.trailText: Intruders had access to customer credit details for four months at site owned by world's biggest e-tailer.
fields.body:
Amazon, the world's biggest online retailer, was embroiled in a humiliating computer security row last night after it emerged that intruders had access to the credit details of thousands of a subsidiary's customers for four months.

Bibliofind, which connects buyers and sellers of rare and secondhand books, has contacted users to admit that hackers penetrated its defences in October last year, managing to maintain undetected access to its 98,000-strong customer database until last week. During that time, they are believed to have downloaded names and addresses, credit card details and telephone numbers. It is understood that the attack was only spotted during a security review prompted by the site being defaced.

Some customers have been informed by their credit card issuers that their cards have been suspended because security has been compromised.

The extraordinary breach will come as a huge embarrassment to Amazon.com. The massive books-to-auctions operation, which took over Bibliofind in April 1999, has grown to become the net's biggest retail success with a reputation for electronic security that has helped it overcome widespread public fears about fraud.

Yesterday, Amazon executives in Seattle, Washington, were distancing themselves from the episode. Callers were referred to Bibliofind, which Amazon insisted was an entirely separate operation.

Bibliofind moved to assure customers that there was no evidence that any of the stolen information had been used to commit fraud.

Its spokesman Jim Courtovich said: "We have no information at this time to suggest that customers' credit cards have been misused."

He declined to go into detail about the circumstances of the violation, which is now the subject of an investigation by the US authorities.

The site will no longer hold customer credit details. Instead, all payments will be made directly by the purchaser to the individual bookseller.

Users of the site, which was closed down over the weekend after the breach was spotted, have been sent an email informing them that a security violation "compromised the security of credit card information". The email concluded: "To ensure this doesn't happen again, we have removed all customer credit card information, physical addresses, and phone numbers from Bibliofind's servers. We expect to bring the Bibliofind system back into operation shortly. We apologise for any inconvenience this may cause you."

But in a development that will deepen the embarrassment of Amazon and Bibliofind, a British internet news website claimed yesterday to have evidence that the company had been warned on at least one occasion that its defences may have been violated.

The Register published claims from an American internet retailer that he had detected a spate of attempted credit card frauds around October last year.

Items of between $1,200 and $2,000 in value were ordered with valid US cards, most of them to be shipped to eastern European destinations. But the retailer became suspicious and contacted the individual cardholders.

"We asked them if they shopped online anywhere else, as we suspected someone's database had been hacked," the retailer told the Register. "The only common link was Bibliofind." He had contacted the company, but it denied its site had been hacked into.

Last night, a Bibliofind spokesman said that any warning would have been fully investigated.

webTitle: Wider income band helps most those on low pay

fields.headline: Wider income band helps most those on low pay
fields.standfirst:
Income tax  Pensioners get boost  NICs down on low incomes

Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText:
Income tax
 Pensioners get boost
 NICs down on low incomes
fields.body:
The chancellor elected to go for the cheapest option by widening the 10 pence income tax band rather than cutting the basic tax rate or increasing personal allowances by more than inflation.

He was clearly targeting lower earners and pensioners with relatively small amounts of savings.

Although most of the country's 28m taxpayers will benefit from the bigger band, which will be increased from the first £1,520 of taxable income to the first £1,880 from April 6, earners on the low wages are the ones who will benefit most.

Gordon Brown said that the aim of his £1bn a year tax cut was "to ensure that more of savers', pensioners' and working people's income" will be taxed at the lowest rate.

As a result, he said, 7.5m pensioners would pay no tax or just 10p in the taxable pound. And he hinted that there would be a further widening of the lower band "in the next parliament".

The 10p rate was first introduced in the 1999 Budget as part of the government's "welfare to work" mission when it replaced the previous lower band of 20 pence.

But in last year's Budget, the government disappointed many by only increasing the band by £20.

Even now, pensioners and other savers will have to reclaim the tax through the Inland Revenue as banks and building societies still pay interest net of the 20p savings rate.

While Age Concern welcomed the widening of the lower band, which it said would help "older tax payers on modest incomes", the charity's director general, Gordon Lisham, said it would be "of no benefit to the 60% of pensioners who do not pay tax".

Higher earning employees will be hit by the changes announced in November's pre-Budget report, which increases their national insurance contributions (NICs) by 6.3% through the raising of the upper earnings limit to £29,900 a year in the coming tax year.

But lower earners will be better off as the lower earnings limit at which employees start to pay NICs will be raised to the same level as the income tax personal allowance.

The well-heeled will also be disappointed that, despite previously indicating that a major reform on inheritance tax was on the way, the chancellor clearly did not see this as an election winner and has simply increased the threshold in line with inflation by £8,000 to £234,000. This, he said, would mean that 90% of estates would not be subject to inheritance tax.

Similarly, some have been disappointed that the capital gains tax threshold for individuals has been increased in line with inflation to £7,500.

webTitle: Budget case study: Married, one employed, one child

fields.headline: Married, one employed, one child
fields.standfirst: Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Families with children will, on average, be £420 a year better off by October. Pete's earnings as a middle-ranking IT expert mean the Gifford family is just eligible for the working families' tax credit, so they will be £5 a week better off from June.
fields.body:
Families with children will, on average, be £420 a year better off by October. Pete's earnings as a middle-ranking IT expert mean the Gifford family is just eligible for the working families' tax credit, so they will be £5 a week better off from June. When the new children's tax credit is introduced in April, they will also receive an additional £10 a week rather than the expected £8.50.

If Pete and Jenny have more children, they will benefit from the increase in maternity pay from £60 to £75. By 2003, this will rise to £100 a week and Jenny will qualify for the money for 26 weeks, rather than the present 18 weeks. Pete would also receive paternity benefit of the same amount for two weeks.

Jenny's return to work will be easier with the childcare tax credit being increased, meaning she will be able to claim up to £94.50 a week to help pay for an after school minder for Adam. The previous limit was £70.

fields.headline: Urban bad-boy fantasies
fields.standfirst:
Fun Lovin' Criminals
Barrowlands, Glasgow
***
fields.trailText:
Fun Lovin' Criminals
Barrowlands, Glasgow
***
fields.body:
The shower of beer rains down from the back during the best-loved songs, all fighting talk and bravado (Scooby Snacks and The Fun Lovin' Criminal). There are dry periods, notably during the slower tracks, late-night lounge lovelies from the new album, Loco, and the last one, Mimosa, but at the end of each song the same manly chant - "Hue-Eee, Hue-Eee" - fills the venue.

For those mystified by the Crims' pulling power (they sold out on both nights here) in the UK, a live gig explains it all. The band offer a fantasy of urban bad-boy antics, a mirage of rap culture. The FLCs are perfect for a generation of men who don't leave home until their late 20s. The crowd was young, mostly male, well-laundered and fed, and they wanted to be bad, just a teensy bit, for a couple of hours.

This relationship - pop band feed audience fantasy - is nothing new, but Huey, Mackie and Fast wear it well. Producing a big, bold sound between just the three of them, they fly through musical styles - heavy metal ("feel free to scream along if you like"), punk-tinged thrash numbers, hillbilly riffs (the perkily named Dickholder with which they open the show) and laid-back vibes. None is any more or less convincing, though it's a relief to get away from the pounding guitars for Love Unlimited, their Barry White tribute. For this number, as a mark of respect, the band's enormous mirrorball over the stage is lit by spotlight.

The FLCs bring larger-than-life charisma, passion (on the up-tempo numbers Fast pounds the keyboards like a muppet possessed by funk) and, in a 10-minute break, Huey's Acting School, in which he and a sidekick impersonate Darth Vader and Obi-Wan Kenobi as played by De Niro and Pacino. Huey speaks of drinking ("It took 13 beers just to get us up here tonight"), tells un-PC jokes and implores us all to cross our fingers. You cross and hope they won't do any more heavy metal, but it's not about the music. "Let's hope we all get laid tonight," Huey growls, as the beer begins to fly and the "Hue-Eee" chant starts to rumble.

 Fun Lovin' Criminals play Carlisle Sands Centre (01228 625222) tonight and Sheffield City Hall (0114 278 9789) tomorrow, then tour.

fields.headline: One is this year's unlucky number
fields.standfirst:
Families of all sizes benefit but entrepreneurs suffer and pensioners are disappointed

Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Families of all sizes benefit but entrepreneurs suffer and pensioners are disappointed.
fields.body:
The chancellor declared he was offering a Budget for the family, and tax cuts were focused specifically on working families. Low and middle earning married couples with two children are by a wide margin the biggest winners.

If they have a joint household income of £20,000 to £50,000 a year, net family income rises by £1,828, or £35.15 a week. This includes the benefit of the £520 children's tax credit and the widening in the 10% tax band and personal allowances.

To give encouragement to parents, the children's tax credit, to be introduced next month, will be worth £10 a week, £1.50 more than announced in the pre-Budget report in November. The calculations below show the impact of children's tax credit and working families tax credit, but families will not automatically receive these benefits. Only 2.9m of the 4m PAYE families eligible for children's tax credit, which comes in April, have put in a claim. If they don't claim it, they won't get it.

Childless, employed couples will also be enjoying a mini windfall. If each earns between £10,000 and £25,000 a year before tax, the government will effectively be giving the couple an extra £1,308 a year. Single parents are next in the pecking order: they will be up to £1,206 a year better off.

Worst off are the single self-employed, represented below by Eastenders character Mark Fowler. A small businessman earning £30,000 gains £43.20 annually from the widening of the 10% tax band, while the increase in his personal allowance adds another £33. What Mr Brown gives with one hand, he takes away with national insurance increases. NI changes lop £135 a year off the income of the self-employed businessman, leaving him with a net loss of £59 a year. Owing to the peculiarities of national insurance, the single self-employed earning above £40,000 moves back into positive territory, gaining £148 a year from yesterday's changes.

If the tax cuts are spread over all income bands and all earners, the average household will be £240 a year better off, the chancellor said yesterday. He added that families with children will see an average gain of £420 a year. Pensioners were expected to be among the biggest beneficiaries of a pre-election Budget, but their income improvements are significantly smaller than those of younger, married people.

It will also not be the poorest pensioners who will be getting the most. The retired person with an income of £4,000 gets no extra benefit - because they don't pay tax anyway. The richer pensioners - a couple with an income of say £30,000 each - will be receiving an additional £159 a year once all the measures announced yesterday come into effect.

A lone pensioner like Margaret Meldrew, with a gross income of £15,000, will receive an additional £87.

Otherwise the Budget involved tweaking at the edges. All of our stars below might benefit from the abolition of entrance fees to art galleries and museums, and most will be glad of the freezing of duty on wine, beer and spirits.

And should the actors themselves need a cigarette to relieve stress in between takes, they will find their packet of 20 costing an extra 6p (in line with inflation) as of yesterday.

fields.headline: Women and children first
fields.standfirst:
Brown puts families at centre of his Budget with more cash and time for parents

Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown put women and children first as he set out the details of his fifth Budget yesterday, outlining a vast array of measures to support families and children.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown put women and children first as he set out the details of his fifth Budget yesterday, outlining a vast array of measures to support families and children.

The extension of the 10p income tax band and the increase to the minimum wage - where 70% of those affected are women - will help millions of families. The newly married chancellor's financial package also includes an increase in maternity pay, longer maternity leave, a new paternity leave, more help with childcare costs for lower paid families and even a cut in the VAT rate on child car seats.

The children's tax credit, which comes into effect next month, has been increased before it starts and there is extra help for small employers to enable more firms to recoup the cost of statutory maternity pay.

Some of the moves were political necessities. Polls have shown that married women with children are among the most sceptical of New Labour, and the government was under pressure to help families after the abolition of the married couple's allowance.

But the array of measures to help parents and children has confirmed Mr Brown's family-friendly credentials and underlined his commitment to address child poverty.

Anne Longfield, chief executive of Kids Club Network, a charity for out of school childcare, said: "These will be very popular measures. They provide help where people need it most. It will bring us more into line with Europe, where governments support and reward families. We are finally recognising that providing support for children is good for parents and for the community."

The level of the children's tax credit had been set at £8.50 a week, but it will now be £10. It represents a tax cut for some 5m families with children under 16, the equivalent of nearly 3p off the basic rate of tax for a family on average earnings.

From April next year, the credit will be doubled to £20 per week for the parents of new babies for a year. Some 500,000 new parents will benefit.

Many elements of the chancellor's package represent a victory for the former social security secretary Harriet Harman. She lobbied Mr Brown hard and did her own research to persuade him of the case for helping mothers - and fathers - to spend more time at home with young children.

More than 4.5m women with dependent children now work outside the home, compared with 3.5m in 1984, and both parents now work in two-thirds of families - up from less than half in the 1980s.

But for many women the costs of childcare are still a disincentive to take paid employment. For these Mr Brown had another carrot - an increase in the childcare tax credit component of the working families tax credit. From June he is hoisting the help available from 70% of childcare costs up to £135 for one child and 70% of £200 for two or more children. The current credits are £100 and £150.

Ms Longfield said the increases meant the credits were now "more in line with what childcare actually costs", but noted out that they still offered only 70% of the full cost.

The chancellor has also pledged to consider how to help with childcare for parents who work shifts and those with disabled children who require formal childcare in the home.

Ms Harman discovered that new mothers felt pressurised to return to work, with half - in mainly low-paid jobs - returning when their babies were just weeks old in order to bring home more than the statutory maternity pay. Three-quarters of women do not use longer maternity leave entitlements "for financial reasons".

Under the current system mothers are entitled to 40 weeks' maternity leave, but they get £60.20 statutory maternity pay for just 18 weeks. From April 2002 maternity pay will go up to £75 a week and from April 2003 it will rise to £100. At that time paid maternity leave will be extended from 18 weeks to 26, and a paternity leave - two weeks with £100pw - will be introduced. Adoptive parents will also now qualify for leave and pay.

Last night Ms Harman said the reforms would help mothers stay with their babies longer. "This will make a huge difference to mothers, and in political terms it is wonderful that these issues, which were just not on the agenda for so long, are now at the heart of a Budget."

Christine Gowdridge of the Maternity Alliance, a campaign group which has pressed hard for improved maternity rights, said: "This rise is redressing 30 years of neglect - it brings maternity pay back to what it ought to be if it had risen regularly since it was introduced in 1975."

But there was concern about the chancellor's plan to compel lone parents with under-fives to attend "work-focused" interviews. The National Council for One Parent families warned that parents with infants could now "feel pressurised into putting a job before their parenting responsibilities".

fields.headline: Single employed person
fields.trailText: This is not a budget aimed at the well off and the single, and London-living pathologist Sam Ryan is both. She makes extensive use of her car, driving around the country to work on different cases and so will benefit from cuts in fuel duty. If she buys ultra-low sulphur petrol she will be paying 2p less a litre (or 3p less if she drives a diesel car); if not, the duty on unleaded petrol has been cut by the same amount until supply of the new fuel is nationwide.
fields.body:
This is not a budget aimed at the well off and the single, and London-living pathologist Sam Ryan is both. She makes extensive use of her car, driving around the country to work on different cases and so will benefit from cuts in fuel duty. If she buys ultra-low sulphur petrol she will be paying 2p less a litre (or 3p less if she drives a diesel car); if not, the duty on unleaded petrol has been cut by the same amount until supply of the new fuel is nationwide.

Sam is a high earner, so is likely to have plenty of money to invest: the chancellor's extension of the Isa rules, allowing £7,000 to be saved each year until 2006, will let her lock away more tax free. She will also be able to make more capital gains on her investments before having to pay tax on them - the threshold has risen by £300 to £7,500.

As a woman of culture (she's a professor) the scrapping of admission charges at art galleries might be of interest.

fields.headline: £835m boost to staffing and equipment
fields.standfirst: Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: The chancellor's promise of an extra £835m for the NHS over the next three years will see a cash handout of up to £1m for 200 acute hospitals to renovate old wards and provide new equipment.
fields.body:
The chancellor's promise of an extra £835m for the NHS over the next three years will see a cash handout of up to £1m for 200 acute hospitals to renovate old wards and provide new equipment.

NHS trusts will get between £500,000 and £1m a year for the next three years as part of the total investment package.

The money will be paid directly to hospital trusts and will go towards equipment such as cancer scanners and X-ray machines as well as to ward renovation.

More than £130m will be spent on recruiting extra staff. Last year Alan Milburn, the health secretary, promised to recruit an extra 20,000 nurses, 7,500 consultants, 6,500 therapists and 2,000 GPs by 2005.

But hospitals and primary care managers were not confident that the extra staff would materialise, given long training periods and lack of capacity in medical schools and university nursing departments.

The other main ingredient of the package will be £450m over three years in a capital renewal fund - to be paid direct to GP surgeries - bypassing the health authorities. The figures revealed that there was £250m still unaccounted for - on which the Department of Health could give no information last night.

The financial package came on top of last year's promise to raise spending from £49.3bn in 1999-2000 to £68.7bn in 2003-4 - an increase of 6% a year in real terms.

Christine Hancock, general secretary of the Royal College of Nursing, said the new NHS recruitment fund showed the government was taking nursing shortages seriously.

"Pay is still a key factor in improving nurse recruitment and retention and we'd like to see this new money targeted at continuing the trend of above-inflation pay increases.

"We are glad to see extension to maternity benefits and maternity and paternity leave. We would like to see further investment that help staff balance their caring responsibilities with their home life," she said.

John Chisholm, the chairman of the BMA's General Practitioners Committee, said: "The recruitment drive must include special attention to primary care.

"We are desperately short of family doctors. There is a crisis in general practice recruitment and retention which must be taken seriously."

fields.body:
The delivery was so brisk, the announcements rattled off at such machine gun speed, you could almost have missed the message. But once the order papers were waving and the chancellor was back in his seat, its significance began to sink in. Mr Brown has reshaped the British political landscape. He became yesterday the first chancellor of his party able to head into an election bragging about a record of extraordinary success: the lowest unemployment and inflation rates for a generation, eye-popping surpluses and a greater repayment of the national debt in one year than had been accomplished in the previous 50. Where his predecessors devoted their pre-election Budgets to crisis management, Mr Brown could boast about four years of economic stability. The once automatic association of Labour with economic incompetence is finally broken.

The second tectonic shift in what happened yesterday goes to the heart of the long-term, centre-left project for Britain, fundamentally altering the terms of trade of our politics. For decades, the debate essentially ran on Conservative lines: whoever offered the lowest tax rates could be expected to win. That made elections a "Dutch auction" on taxes, with Labour routinely outbid by the slash-and-burn Tories. Yet yesterday Mr Brown could refuse the obvious trick - a penny cut in income tax - in favour of a mix of tax breaks targeted at the poorest and around £2bn extra for public spending. In other words, he has chosen to stake Labour's electoral hopes on the belief that when voters face a choice between £8bn worth of Tory tax cuts and Labour's promise of investment in schools and hospitals, they will go for the latter. If that is right, and every sign points that way, it marks a victory not just for Labour but for the whole progressive, social democratic cause.

The mixture with which he achieved this is full of commendable things. Millions of families on low or modest incomes will get a huge boost through the complex bundle of benefits and tax credits now on the way. Pensioners, neglected before, have had a good deal and pegging the minimum income guarantee to earnings means the poorest will receive a 40% rise over the next 20 years. While much of that was predicted, one welcome surprise was an inner-city regeneration scheme that involves six tax cuts costing £1bn over five years.

But is even all this anywhere near enough? This government has to make up for decades of underinvestment, not least its own - most damagingly in its first two years in office. Even now, public spending at 39% of GDP remains below the spending levels of the Major, Thatcher, Callaghan, Wilson and Heath governments. There are still 3.2m children living in poverty, twice as many as in the last year of the last Labour government. And despite Mr Brown's carefully targeted increases in spending, inequality will continue to grow, because the poorest of the poor- unemployed, chronically sick or disabled people without children - only have benefits linked to prices, not earnings.

All this is unfinished business. Yet even this pre-electoral moment was not a time for Mr Brown's faithful old servant Prudence to be retired. Having laid the basis for substantial increases in public spending over the next few years, his macroeconomic duty now was not to overegg the pudding, whatever the temptations. Despite the widely publicised public sector surplus - £16.4 bn in the current financial year, against an original forecast of £6.5 bn - to have "given away" anything like the lion's share in this Budget would in effect have been to invite the Bank of England's monetary policy commitee (MPC) to raise interest rates sharply. This is because, as the chancellor's forecasts show, domestic demand in the economy is expected to rise at over 3% in real terms this year and gross domestic product as a whole to carry on growing at about 2.5% a year. This rate, for all the chancellor's emphasis on raising productivity, is in line with what the Treasury and Bank of England regard as sustainable without putting excessive inflationary pressure on the economy.

In this context, going ahead with targeted tax cuts of £2bn and adding £2bn. to public spending is well within the bounds of prudence. The concessions to the fuel protesters of some £1.5bn come on top of that £4bn, but are counterbalanced by lower debt interest and social security payments (the latter because of the higher level of employment). The additional growth in public sector investment over the next few years (up from 3.4% a year in real terms to 3.7%) is in any case set to turn the present surplus into a deficit before long. The projected deficits are well within the fiscal rules the chancellor has laid down (borrowing only for capital expenditure) and, even if these do not please the International Monetary Fund, they have not so far caused any obvious concern to the MPC.

So the chancellor has hit on a sensible balance - but a balance which is only defensible if the momentum for public spending and public investment can be sustained and accelerated beyond a general election which yesterday's package should have helped to guarantee that Labour will win. Mr Brown's dream of a country where people get what they want from public services and where poverty is squeezed out of the system is going to demand more, much more, of the same. Yesterday, in that sense, was just a down payment.

fields.headline: Nash Ensemble
fields.standfirst:
Nash Ensemble
Purcell Room, London
Review: ****
fields.trailText:
Nash Ensemble
Purcell Room, London
Review: ****
fields.body:
For more than 30 years the Nash Ensemble has championed contemporary music and British composers in particular. Tuesday's concert was a tribute to those endeavours, not only in its musical content but also in the presentation of the Royal Philharmonic Society's Leslie Boosey Award for services to British music to the ensemble's artistic director, Amelia Freedman.

The programme provided a pithy demonstration of what Freedman and her group have done. There were no brand new works, but the chance to hear again a range of pieces by living composers whom the Nash has supported. The performances, conducted by Martyn Brabbins, were universally excellent, though the cramped acoustic of the Purcell Room did not always do them justice.

Certainly Colin Matthews's Fuga, a feisty spin-off from his big vocal work The Great Journey, sounded less coherent than it does in a bigger space. The intimacy of the hall was better suited to George Benjamin's tour de force Viola Viola. The soloists, Lawrence Power and Susan Knight, relished every morsel of Benjamin's inventive string writing. Elliott Carter's miniature song cycle Tempo e Tempi offered a complete contrast - cool settings for soprano (Claron McFadden) of a sequence of Italian lyrics by Montale, Ungaretti and Quasimodo, surrounded by spare, sinewy instrumental lines.

Paul Watkins and Ian Brown's poised account of Mark-Anthony Turnage's suite of cello-and-piano lullabies, Sleep On, prefaced Harrison Birtwistle's The Woman and the Hare, which the Nash premiered two years ago. If David Harsent's poem is sometimes opaque, then Birtwistle's setting, dividing the text between a soprano (McFadden) and a reciter (Julia Watson), is wonderfully judged. The composer plans to extend the 15-minute work, but it is marvellously satisfying as it stands.

fields.headline: £1bn plan to eradicate urban decay
fields.standfirst:
Housing  VAT slashed on refurbishing vacant property  Tax initiatives to speed up regeneration  £2,000 for start-up firms

Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText:
Housing
 VAT slashed on refurbishing vacant property
 Tax initiatives to speed up regeneration
 £2,000 for start-up firms
fields.body:
Thousands of empty houses could be brought back into use after a large cut in value added tax levied on the cost of refurbishing vacant properties.

In a £1bn, five-year package of regeneration to breathe new life into run-down inner cities and less favoured regions, the Treasury announced last night that VAT would be slashed from 17.5% to 5% on an estimated 150,000 properties which have been empty for three years or more. Buildings empty for 10 years will be given a zero rating.

Although the chancellor shied away from meeting demands from a government urban task force for full VAT harmonisation at 5% on the cost of building new houses - at present zero-rated - and refurbishing older ones, housing charities and builders welcomed yesterday's policy shift.

Calling for balanced economic growth for every region, Gordon Brown acknowledged that rising prosperity in the country as a whole "still left people in too many places behind." With an eye on tax breaks in US cities, he talked of harnessing public and private investment with new fiscal incentives to extend opportunities and enterprise "from some of the country to all of the country".

To speed up regeneration, he also announced six tax initiatives - ranging from accelerated tax relief at 150% for cleaning up tens of thousands of acres of contaminated land to 100% first-year capital allowances for bringing empty flats over shops back into the residential market.

In addition, consultation would take place on further corporation tax relief for firms investing in new urban regeneration companies which have been set up in Liverpool, Sheffield, east Manchester and the old steel town of Corby. Up to eight others are planned

To cut the cost of small business borrowing in poorer areas, a new community investment tax credit would be introduced alongside the first community development venture capital fund - a partnership between government, financial institutions and the charitable sector.

In addition, the small business service would offer up to £2,000 worth of advice for any start up company drawing up a business plan.

Last night regeneration minister Beverley Hughes hailed the £1bn package as a significant step forward for urban renewal. But housing organisations were also enthusiastic.

Ashley Horsey, chief executive of the Empty Homes Agency, a charity partly funded by the Department of the Environment, estimated that the VAT cut would mean that the average cost of renovating an empty property would be slashed by £1,200 to under £9,000.

Although an estimated 760,000 houses and flats are empty at any one time, the 150,000 likely to qualify for the new 5% rate are reckoned to be the hard core. "This is fantastic news - a big step in the right direction," Mr Horsey added. "It tells us that this government really is serious about bringing empty properties back into use."

The House Builders' Federation was clearly overjoyed that VAT had not been slapped on the cost of building new homes. Pierre Williams, its spokesman, added: "The government is acknowledging our massive efforts to use brownfield [recycled] land wherever possible, and the industry is well on the way to reaching a target of building 60% of new homes by 2008."

Although it is now estimated 57% of building is taking place on recycled land, the federation called for a speedier, "can-do" approach from local planning authorities. The chancellor will later this week underline his determination to strengthen the role of eight regional development agencies by giving them greater freedom to spend money from a "single pot" budget - due to rise by £500m to £1.7bn by 2003-2004.

The RDAs have frequently complained they have no power to switch resources between these programmes.

fields.headline: White collar walls pierced
fields.standfirst: Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Accountants, lawyers and architects will be allowed to tout for business by telephone under proposals published by the office of fair trading yesterday in an attempt to kick-start competition among professional "cartels".
fields.body:
Accountants, lawyers and architects will be allowed to tout for business by telephone under proposals published by the office of fair trading yesterday in an attempt to kick-start competition among professional "cartels".

The report advocates the abolition of walls between professions, to permit the creation of "one-stop shops" taking in estate agents, surveyors and lawyers.

It stops short of an expected pre-election attack on rocketing wage rates among top professionals. The proposals, aimed at relaxing fee structures, nonetheless drew a furi ous response from architects.

The OFT study, sent to Gordon Brown and trade secretary Stephen Byers, advocates eliminating restrictions on marketing. In addition to permitting phone canvassing, it advocates allowing professional firms to publish comparisons between their fees and those of rivals.

The suggestion was cautiously welcomed by accountancy bodies. Peter Owen, director of professional standards at the Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales, said: "You get phone calls from everyone else so why not from accountants? Some of the rules in this area have got a bit of a 19th century flavour and we're quite relaxed about changes to them."

He expected rivalry to re main relatively genteel: "I can't see accountants going round saying 'we're going to give advice on money matters for 5p less than Fred Bloggs down the road'."

Other parts of the report proved more controversial. The OFT attacked fee guidance issued by the Royal Institute of British Architects, saying it could "restrict or distort price competition". It suggests ending the practice whereby the RIBA advises customers on what they should expect to pay for architectural advice.

The RIBA's president, Marco Goldschmied, maintained that fee guidance was a "common sense practice" merely intended to stop customers getting ripped off, rather than to keep prices high for architecture firms.

fields.headline: Britannic sheds 2,000 jobs
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Britannic Assurance said yesterday that it will jettison its door-to-door salesforce over the next year with the loss of 2,000 jobs.
fields.body:
Britannic Assurance said yesterday that it will jettison its door-to-door salesforce over the next year with the loss of 2,000 jobs.

It took the number of direct insurance sales staff told they will lose their jobs to nearly 6,000 in three weeks, after similar announcements by the Prudential and Sun Life of Canada.

Britannic said about 1,600 sales staff around the country would be made redundant along with 400 support staff at its Birmingham headquarters. It said a direct sales force was no longer viable after a squeeze on margins. A fall in investment returns and the introduction of stakeholder pensions on April 1, which restrict management charges to 1%, were blamed by the company. It will be left with a specialist sales team of 100 advisers.

The company will take a charge of £93m to pay for the redundancies and closure of 100 branch offices with the aim of saving £82m from its operating costs in the first year. Sales are expected to fall 40% over the next year, but should return to their present levels by 2003.

Chairman Harold Cottam said the impact of falling returns and lower charges had hit Britannic harder than many rivals. "When you are selling to a customer with £50,000 to invest, the 1% charge amounts to much more than if the sum is £5,000."

He said the decision to cut the direct sales operation, which amounts to more than 40% of the workforce, had been made after a review which saw little prospect of improvement in the markets. "If you look at the medium term it is hard to see [investment returns] improving and, there was the prospect of the direct sales team becoming a burden on the life fund."

Operating profits increased by 7% to £174.5m for the year to December. Including exceptional items, pre-tax profit was £64.4m, compared with £153.6m a year earlier.

The dividend increased by 11.6% to 54p.

webTitle: VAT change ends museum entry charge era

fields.headline: VAT change ends entry charge era
fields.standfirst: Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Free entry to Britain's national museums and art galleries came a step closer yesterday after the chancellor announced changes in VAT.
fields.body:
Free entry to Britain's national museums and art galleries came a step closer yesterday after the chancellor announced changes in VAT.

Until now any museum scrapping charges lost its business status and was not allowed to reclaim the VAT it paid on items it purchased.

Yesterday's move rectifies this and fulfils the government's long-standing pledge to provide free access to museums and galleries.

It was welcomed by campaigners, who said the old system had cost the institutions millions of pounds. The government will consult museums and galleries on the details of the scheme, which will be introduced by September.

The V&A in London, where visitor numbers halved after charges were introduced, immediately responded with a promise to reintroduce free admission "as soon as possible".

The announcement ended a bitterly fought campaign. Culture secretary Chris Smith lobbied for the change, and the concession was anticipated in last year's Budget. There was deep disappointment when it failed to materialise.

"This is an outright victory, it is fantastic news," said David Barrie, director of the Art Fund, the independent charity which has led the campaign. "I believe it will lead to a major extension of free admission. It is nice, for once, to be able to congratulate the government wholeheartedly on something really well done."

Sir Nicholas Serota, the director of the Tate, and Neil MacGregor, director of the National Gallery, praised the commitment of the culture secretary. "Chris Smith has been an ardent and consistent advocate of the principle of free admission to the national collections. The benefits of his policy are vividly demonstrated by the huge number of visitors to Tate Modern," Sir Nicholas said.

The initiative means the end of the much criticised compromise, Quids In, which would have given grants to museums to help cut their entry charges to £1. It was supposed to start next autumn.

webTitle: New Deal enters the fast lane

fields.headline: New Deal enters the fast lane
fields.standfirst:
 Six-month hiatus ended  Skills test for young jobless

Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText:  Six-month hiatus ended  Skills test for young jobless
fields.body:
Unemployed young people were given notice yesterday that they face interviews about their readiness for work before they are allowed to sign on.

Gordon Brown yesterday signalled a shift in the government's New Deal scheme, to move claimants more quickly into employment assistance programmes.

The result will be that many young unemployed people expecting six months on benefit before facing the choice of a place in the New Deal or losing their right to claim will have to make that choice from the moment they claim social security.

Mr Brown said youth unemployment had fallen by 80%. The aim now was to tackle the problems that beset the remaining 20% and future benefit claimants .

There will be a move to "stage two" of the New Deal, which is likely to involve claimants undergoing tests to judge their level of skills and any problems that might prevent them getting a job.

Employment service staff are expected to conduct the interviews and assess each claimant. Those who are told they could benefit will be sent on courses to enhance their skills or literacy, or improve their attitude. Under current rules they must wait six months before they are eligible for support.

"The starting point is a new 'employment first' principle," Mr Brown said. "In the past the unemployed signed on for benefit before they looked for work. Now, before receiving benefit the 'employment first' principle means they will first have to be interviewed about job opportunities and the steps they are ready to take to get back into work."

The New Deal had exceeded its target of moving 250,000 young people into jobs. More than 270,000 had gone through the scheme into jobs, at half of the planned cost.

He stressed that the demands of the economy meant that 2.5m more employees with degrees or higher degrees would be needed by businesses along with a wider workforce with higher skills and more qualifications.

"So at the heart of our approach is that government must meet its responsibilities, providing incentives for work and training; companies must meet their responsibilities to upgrade skills in the workplace; and people must take up their responsibilities to work and to prepare for the jobs of the future."

For claimants over 25 years old who have yet to find work, the government is proposing to spend £200m from April on intensive coaching and stronger sanctions if they fail to take up the offer of support.

Drug addicts unable to find work are the target of a £40m programme that will mean they receive mentoring and training, but they will need to get off drugs before they can sign up. "We will fulfil our responsibility to help them; they must fulfil their responsibility to become drug-free."

Paul Convery, head of the independent Unemployment Unit and Youthaid, applauded what he called a move away from the mechanistic formula laid down by the New Deal. "It is a bit criminal forcing people to tread water and wait six months before they get help."

fields.headline: 'Family first' concessions dubbed rhetoric
fields.standfirst: Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: As a young family struggling on low incomes, Cas Short and Tom Wichelow, above, believe the concessions offered by the chancellor - putting families first - smacks of rhetoric.
fields.body:
As a young family struggling on low incomes, Cas Short and Tom Wichelow, above, believe the concessions offered by the chancellor - putting families first - smacks of rhetoric.

They are both social workers who live in Hove, Sussex, with their two young children. Cas, 34, earns £13,000 a year as a children and families social worker and Tom earns £11,000 a year as a residential social worker. Until April 2001, they will be claiming working families tax credit at £67 a week.

Cas returned to work part-time when their youngest son, Freddie, was four months old, although she would have liked to stay off for longer.

They pay £264 a month for childcare costs for seven half-day sessions at a council subsidised nursery. They cannot afford any more childcare sessions and Tom looks after their sons for the remaining three sessions.

"Childcare is so prohibitively expensive," says Cas. "We have no choice but to pay for childcare because I work part-time Wednesday to Friday. Tom works on Saturday and Sundays and on Tuesday afternoons and evenings. Our childcare costs represent a quarter of what I earn every month, which seems very high.

"Since Labour came to power they have made a difference. Working families tax credit saved my life when I was on maternity leave with Freddie, even though I had to return to work earlier than I planned. If it hadn't been for this £67 a week then we would have been significantly in debt.

"The increase in maternity pay would have been helpful for me when I was off on maternity leave with Freddie. I feel sad that I had to leave him so early, even though it was with his father.

"Looking after a young family is very stressful and we feel very stretched financially. It was a lot easier when I just had Charlie because I was able to save money. It was much more difficult when we had two.

"It is very irritating seeing the chancellor holding on to the purse strings so tightly. My wages are a pittance because I work in the public sector and we are on low incomes."

The introduction of children's tax credit from April 6 will be worth £520 a year to them. The childcare element of the working families tax credit will also help. But Cas had hoped the chancellor would deliver more concessions to families.

The flat they live in is worth £100,000, but they cannot afford to move to the area they would prefer because of their low wages.

The couple do not smoke, mostly use public transport and only spend £10 a week on petrol.

"It does not do enough to take the pressure off low income families," said Cas.

webTitle: Cheer as Brown cuts the red tape

fields.headline: Cheer as Brown cuts the red tape
fields.standfirst:
Small business VAT bill rules changed  Threshold raised to £54,000  Start up of self assessment

Special report: Budget 2001
Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText:
Small business
VAT bill rules changed
 Threshold raised to £54,000
 Start up of self assessment
fields.body:
Budget measures to cut red-tape, simplify VAT and reduce the burden of accounts preparation for up to half a million firms yesterday won a rare cheer for the chancellor from the small business lobby.

In a radical simplification of the VAT structure, small businesses with turnover below £100,000 will no longer have to keep every invoice and transaction to calculate their VAT liability. Instead, their VAT bill will be calculated as a percentage of turnover. The VAT threshold - the point at which small businesses have to be registered and charge their customers VAT - was also increased in line with inflation to £54,000.

Steven Alambrites of the Federation of Small Businesses said: "VAT has always been a major burden on small businesses, and firms such as hairdressers and small shops won't now have to keep every bill and invoice. It will save a lot of paperwork."

Deloitte & Touche partner John Kennedy said: "This is a substantial simplification, cutting the red tape for at least 324,000 businesses."

But the biggest surprise was an overhaul in the way that small businesses will be able to send in their accounts.

Mr Brown said: "Last year we exempted small businesses from the costly obligation to submit audited accounts, cutting small business costs by £220m. The next step is an even more radical proposal; to make the annual company accounts the basis for calculating tax, thus cutting more red tape and costs once again."

In effect, the measure treats small businesses in a similar way to individuals filling in a self-assessment form; firms will be able to send in their accounts and have the taxed worked out on them by the Inland Revenue, rather than having to employ an external accountant to calculate the figures.

Inland Revenue says it will shortly begin consultation with small businesses on the proposals, which it says will significantly reduce the complexity of the tax system for small businesses.

In a concession to creative artists, authors and composers whose incomes vary markedly one year to the next, the Revenue said it would allow them to average their income for tax purposes over two years, which will enable many to cut their tax take from 40% to 22%.

The Federation of Small Businesses praised measures to expand places under the modern apprenticeships scheme.

The federation said: "A lot of small businesses can't afford training or fear that their trained staff will simply be poached, so the tax credit for training is very welcome."

The DTI said it would spend £1bn increasing the number of apprenticeships from 220,000 this year to 320,000 over the next few years.

Small businesses also welcomed the competition commission's findings that they pay excess bank charges, which the chancellor endorsed in his speech yesterday.

Mr Alambrites said: "Small firms are constantly undermined by the supernormal profits that the big banks make by charging loan rates of 4-5% above base rate.

But the chancellor needs to stop negotiating with the banks and instruct them to do something."

However, a separate small business lobbying group, the Forum of Private Business, was less enthusiastic about the Budget.

The forum's executive chairman, Stan Mendham, said: "The accounting simplification and VAT changes are all good, but he has done nothing about the biggest gripe for small businesses - the uniform business rate. There were also no exemptions for small employers facing employment regulations."

Measures such as improved maternity pay and maternity leave put an especially heavy burden on small employers, which, although they are eventually reimbursed by government, have to carry administer and initially pay for the schemes, putting pressure on their cash flow.

fields.headline: Multinationals face clampdown
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Budget 2001
Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: The Treasury signalled its intention yesterday to press ahead with modified plans to clamp down on tax avoidance by multinationals.
fields.body:
The Treasury signalled its intention yesterday to press ahead with modified plans to clamp down on tax avoidance by multinationals.

Mr Brown caused an outcry with last year's Budget when he announced proposals to abolish the use of so-called mixer companies, employed by multinationals to smooth profits from various high and low tax jurisdictions abroad before they enter Britain to be taxed at a uniform rate.

He later watered down the proposals to allow mixing as long as it was done onshore rather than offshore, where it is easier to avoid tax.

In yesterday's Budget press releases - issued after Mr Brown's Commons address - the Treasury said that new regulations filling in the details of the proposals would soon be laid before parliament.

David Norton, of accountant Anderson, said : "They are very technical changes to highly complex rules but I think they aim to simplify things and are generally beneficial - although not every multinational will see things that way."

Kate Barker, chief economic adviser at the Confederation of British Industry, said: "It's a whole lot better than in the last Budget but it's still not as good as it should have been."

In the wake of last year's announcement, the Treasury was besieged by multinationals who claimed they had not been consulted about the move. The chief executive of Vodafone, Chris Gent, issued a veiled threat to move Britain's biggest company to a more lax fiscal jurisdiction, such as Ireland.

Ms Barker said large firms would be disappointed that the government had delayed implementation of the plan.

fields.bodyText: The Treasury signalled its intention yesterday to press ahead with modified plans to clamp down on tax avoidance by multinationals. Mr Brown caused an outcry with last year's Budget when he announced proposals to abolish the use of so-called mixer companies, employed by multinationals to smooth profits from various high and low tax jurisdictions abroad before they enter Britain to be taxed at a uniform rate. He later watered down the proposals to allow mixing as long as it was done onshore rather than offshore, where it is easier to avoid tax. In yesterday's Budget press releases - issued after Mr Brown's Commons address - the Treasury said that new regulations filling in the details of the proposals would soon be laid before parliament. David Norton, of accountant Anderson, said : "They are very technical changes to highly complex rules but I think they aim to simplify things and are generally beneficial - although not every multinational will see things that way." Ms Barker said large firms would be disappointed that the government had delayed implementation of the plan.  On Monday, the government will issue a further set of proposals for competitive reform of Europe's markets ahead of the Stockholm summit of finance ministers. fields.headline: £200m to bust drugs culture
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Budget 2001
Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: A £200m fund to wage war on drugs, backed by a celebrity anti-drugs campaign with prominent business and sports personalities, was announced yesterday.
fields.body:
A £200m fund to wage war on drugs, backed by a celebrity anti-drugs campaign with prominent business and sports personalities, was announced yesterday.

The cash, to be made available over the next three years, will go to police commanders and local authority anti-drugs coordinators to fight drug-related crime and break up networks of local dealers.

The money is to be channelled through the 350 partnerships against crime and disorder across England, bringing together police, local authority, drug action teams and voluntary organisations to devise local anti-crime strategies.

A Home Office spokeswoman said payments to the neighbourhood partnerships would average between £500,000 and £1m, with similar funds available in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.

A further £15m is be made available to finance an advertising campaign which will feature anti-drugs messages from sports and business personalities to help reduce the demand for illegal drugs. "The war against drugs will never be won by government alone but neighbourhood by neighbour hood across the country, so further resources will be announced to support a new campaign, involving prominent figures from the world of business and sports to mobilise communities against drugs," said the chancellor.

The extra money was welcomed by DrugScope, the charity which represents those who work with drug abusers. "There is evidence that disrupting local drug markets can prove effective and any support for local communities is welcome," said director Roger Howard. "We are disappointed that more resources are not being channelled into helping drug users reintegrate into society when they come out of prison following treatment."

The funds compare with £3bn a year spent on the fight against drug abuse, more than two thirds spent on law enforcement.

Last week, Tony Blair announced extra initiatives as part of the government's 10-year anti-crime plan, in which he floated ideas such as a national register of drug dealers and specialist drug courts.The government believes that the campaign against drug abuse is central to its anti-crime plan. Almost two thirds of the 100,000 most persistent offenders misuse hard drugs, including heroin and cocaine.

webTitle: Budget case study: Married, two employed, two children

fields.headline: Married, two employed, two children
fields.standfirst: Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Kate and Patrick Russell run a profitable motel in the Midlands, where they live with their 15-year-old daughter, Nicola, and 22-year-old son, Mark. As high earners they do not benefit from working families tax credit.
fields.body:
Kate and Patrick Russell run a profitable motel in the Midlands, where they live with their 15-year-old daughter, Nicola, and 22-year-old son, Mark. As high earners they do not benefit from working families tax credit.

Aside from the cut in income tax, the family will enjoy a small rise in Nicola's child benefit to £15.50 - while Patrick, who inherited a sizable sum of money, will have noted with interest that the threshold for inheritance tax is being raised to £242,000.

Unfortunately the family's 2.5 litre BMW will miss out on the reduction in vehicle excise duty, but the cuts in unleaded and ultra-low sulphur petrol could aid Mark's requests to his father for a car of his own.

The motel will feel the impact of the minimum wage increase, but the business, and its accountant, will benefit from the simplified VAT system promised by the chancellor.

Kate and Patrick will also be eager to see the list of energy saving technologies that will qualify for 100% tax relief.

webTitle: Budget case studies: Single self-employed person

fields.headline: Single self-employed person
fields.trailText: There wasn't a great deal in this family budget for unlucky-in-love Mark Fowler who runs a fruit and vegetable market stall in east London.
fields.body:
There wasn't a great deal in this family budget for unlucky-in-love Mark Fowler who runs a fruit and vegetable market stall in east London.

Of course Mark, who earns around £18,000 a year, will benefit from the across-the-board cut in income tax which arises from an increase in the 10p rate upper limit. His tax liability could also fall now small businesses can use annual accounts as the basis for calculating tax.

Mark's pint at the Queen Vic will cost no more than usual, thanks to the freezing of duty on wine, beer and spirits and since it has been a good year on the stall, lower vehicle excise duty and cuts in duty on ultra-low sulphur petrol may tempt him to trade in his motorcycle for a small van. He will also be keeping tabs on the Small Business Service which the chancellor says will offer up to £2,000 worth of help for any start-up company drawing up their business plan - useful if Mark follows through his dream of opening a shop.

fields.headline: Jimmy Porter creaks again
fields.standfirst:
Look Back in Anger
Old Vic, Bristol
**
fields.trailText:
Look Back in Anger
Old Vic, Bristol
**
fields.body:
Jimmy Porter is approaching his half-century. He has always been cranky and now he looks downright creaky. One can only wonder that such an old-fashioned, wordy, absurdly misogynist play could ever have been considered revolutionary. Ken Tynan famously said that he could not love anyone who didn't want to see this play. With hindsight that sounds a bit like a man declaring undying devotion for someone with a ticket to The Mousetrap. John Osborne's play owes more to Agatha Christie than to modern theatre.

But if you lower your expectations by dissociating the play from its performance history, ignoring its place in the drama textbooks and treating Jimmy Porter as a person rather than an icon, it is possible to have a reasonably good evening at the theatre. If nothing else, Gareth Machin's production reminds us what a good potboiler this play is: the tensions, twists and turns of the plotting actually make an audience gasp if they are unfamiliar with the text. Gasping isn't a sound you hear often in the theatre nowadays.

The play is also as marvellous a portrait of a marriage as, say, Ibsen's A Doll's House, to which it owes so much with its squirrels and bears motif. Machin's production begins by capturing this well. Right from the start the dingy attic, where Jimmy and his friend Cliff (Mark Meadows, vigorously good) are reading the Sunday papers and Jimmy's wife, Alison, is ironing, crackles with unspoken tension. There is, in the vocabulary of the 1950s, "an atmosphere". It is the atmosphere of dead Sundays and a marriage dying on its feet.

But the portrait of the marriage only works if both sides are equally matched. Osborne ensures that both Jimmy and Alison are armed to the hilt and he keeps the balance of sympathies constantly shifting. But the actors have to do their bit. The play cannot work if the protagonists are not on an even footing. This is a bloody battle, not a walkover.

But the casting here means there is no battle, just a washout. Helen Franklin's Alison has a quiet, matter-of-fact power but, while Nick Moran may have proved his street cred with the success of Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels, he has absolutely no charisma as Jimmy Porter. In fact he has almost no stage presence at all. Apart from the accent, which is spot on, everything about Moran's performance is superficial, from his reedy, nasal voice, which frequently sounds camp, to the lack of expression on his smooth, strangely untroubled brow. The ironing board exhibits more animation and elicits considerably more sympathy. Look Back in Anger is only great drama when you love and hate Jimmy with the same passion with which he loves and hates the world and all around him. Moran ensures that you couldn't care less.

 Until March 24. Box office: 0117-987 7877.

fields.headline: Andrew Maxwell/ Addy Borgh
fields.standfirst:
Joseph's Well, Leeds
****
fields.trailText:
Joseph's Well, Leeds
****
fields.body:
Addy Borgh has them rolling in the aisles before he's even said a word. It's not just his moustache, which appears to have been dug up from Groucho Marx's final resting place. It's also his intriguing facial expressions and brilliant use of mime. For the opening minutes, Borgh does nothing more than "conduct" the audience applause, which swoops and fades like a classical orchestra with every twitch of his moustache or raising of his eyebrow.

Borgh has developed since his Edinburgh debut last year. His hangdog, Walter Matthau humour repeatedly hits the funny button during acutely observed sketches about stoned interviewees and hangovers. Some jokes fall flat, but those facial expressions are priceless during his spoofs of oral sex and camp horror.

Irish comedian Andrew Maxwell's intimate, conversational style is perfect for the small screen but he is also a natural live, thinking on his feet and easing into his surroundings with withering pastiches of Leeds males. Unlike some comics, Maxwell doesn't demand heckling to sustain a performance, so he appears genuinely bewildered when confronted by two particularly weird hecklers. One is a Brummie "necrophiliac", the other an Irishman who claims to represent a terrorist organisation. Both are roaring drunk.

But Maxwell turns what could have been an awkward situation into a triumph. As the hecklers get more surreal and unpredictable with ever pint, Maxwell nips from supermodels to Tricky to a genuinely impassioned attack on foxhunting, and never once loses his composure.

 Andrew Maxwell plays the Manchester Comedy Store (0870 5932932) March 16 and 17.
 Addy Borgh plays both Comedy at Sohoho, London WC1 (07956 273771), and the Meccano Club, London N1 (020-7813 4478) on Saturday.

webTitle: Green campaigners angry at £1.7bn 'budget for truckers'

fields.headline: Green campaigners angry at £1.7bn 'budget for truckers'
fields.standfirst:
Environment  Fuel lobby says cuts a sham  Tax breaks to be passed on

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: The government yesterday gave away £1.7bn of tax cuts to the road lobby in a move which pleased motoring groups but failed to appease hardline fuel campaigners and infuriated the green lobby.
fields.byline: Terry Macalister, John Vidal  and Paul Brown
fields.body:
The government yesterday gave away £1.7bn of tax cuts to the road lobby in a move which pleased motoring groups but failed to appease hardline fuel campaigners and infuriated the green lobby.

More than £1bn was spent on fuel tax reductions overall, with 2p per litre knocked off the price of ultra-low sulphur petrol (ULSP) and 3p taken off the equivalent kind of diesel.

Leading oil companies, such as BP, promised to pass on all fuel tax breaks with effect from 6pm last night when the government action took effect.

More than £400m was spent on cutting the rates of vehicle excise duty on private cars and light vehicles of under 1.5 litres while £105m went on reforming the truck licensing system.

The AA motoring organisation said it was "extremely pleased" with the changes although it did not rule out the need for a review of the road tax system.

The RAC's executive director Edmund King said: "Chancellors normally act like modern highwaymen at budget time but this time Flash Gordon has given something back."

Mr King said cutting the level of fuel tax would help the government start to regain the confidence of motorists, but would still leave drivers vulnerable to world petrol prices.

Brynle Williams, one of the fuel protest leaders described the fuel reductions as a sham. He had wanted to see an 8p cut and said the public would see through the government's plans.

Environmental groups accused the chancellor of pandering to truckers and the motorist lobby. They said the measures undermined Tony Blair's green speech on Tuesday when he said he wanted Britain to be a world environmental leader.

"These fuel price reductions will encourage more car use, increase congestion and pollution, and make the problem of climate change even worse," Friends of the Earth said. "Transport is the fastest growing source of CO2 emissions, the main climate changing gas." The National Society for Clean Air believed the introduction of ULSP would reduce emissions of nitrogen oxides by around 5%, but the overall impact on British air quality would be "so small as to be unmeasurable", spokesman Tim Brown said.

He added that cutting fuel duty, coupled with the shifting of the threshold for small car excise duty from 1200cc to 1500cc would reduce the incentive to buy more fuel-efficient vehicles and would probably increase CO2 emissions. "It reinforces the view that the motivation for cutting petrol duty is political, not environmental."

Transport 2000 accused the government of producing "a budget for truckers". Director Stephen Joseph said the government's own research showed that a single lorry can cause up to £28,000 damage to the environment and road system each year.

"Once these costs are included, the biggest lorries are under-taxed by around £30,000 a year. The chancellor has increased these lorry subsidies by over 10%. Instead of giving way to truckers, we need radical reform of lorry taxes, so the biggest lorries - foreign as well as British - travelling the farthest pay the most tax."

But environmental groups welcomed the 6p per kilogram incentives for road fuel gases and 20% duty cut for biodiesel.

Matthew Spencer, Greenpeace climate campaigner, said: "Brown has taken the shine off Labour's new-found green ambitions."

webTitle: Carey hails grants for listed buildings

fields.headline: Carey hails grants for listed buildings
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Budget 2001
Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: The chancellor is offering churches a grant to aid renovation of listed buildings as a way of offsetting the European commission's resistance to plans, announced in his November statement, to reduce the rate of VAT on repairs.
fields.body:
The chancellor is offering churches a grant to aid renovation of listed buildings as a way of offsetting the European commission's resistance to plans, announced in his November statement, to reduce the rate of VAT on repairs.

The sum involved - probably about £20m for the Church of England alone - is expected to represent the equivalent of what they would have received had his earlier proposal to cut the VAT rate from 17.5% to 5% gone through.

Having accepted the case last year that the tax was limiting what churches could do to preserve a large part of the national architectural heritage, the government was under an obligation to try to find a way around the problem.

The grant will apply to repairs on listed buildings begun after April 1.

Dr George Carey, the Archbishop of Canterbury, said: "This is a very welcome step by the government.

"We are grateful for the chancellor's continuing commitment to attempting to tackle this serious and long-standing problem.

"Tax levied on church repairs inhibits the social mission of churches up and down the country, whether in support of rural communities .. or hard-pressed urban areas."

webTitle: Amateurs win a place alongside charities

fields.headline: Amateurs win a place alongside charities
fields.standfirst: Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: The chancellor brought amateur sports clubs into line with arts groups and charities by making donations to them exempt from tax.
fields.body:
The chancellor brought amateur sports clubs into line with arts groups and charities by making donations to them exempt from tax.

The tax relief was secured yesterday after a 10-year campaign by sports groups around the country.

However, sports officials were disappointed that Mr Brown did not announce mandatory rate relief for clubs. Voluntary sports clubs are treated like small businesses and rate relief is at the discretion of local authorities.

Sports minister Kate Hoey said: "Thousands of sports clubs around the country will now be able to benefit from tax relief, meaning people will be able to leave money to them without it being taxed and also that, if the club is in profit, it will not lose a proportion of that to the Treasury."

Mel Welch, of the Federation of Yorkshire Sports Clubs, one of the groups campaigning for the tax concession, said:"Many people have been reluctant to leave money to sports clubs because they know it will be taxed. Obviously, we clearly need to define what is an amateur sports club and who will be able to benefit.

Nigel Hook of the Central Council of Physical Recreation said: "While we are very happy at the announcement of tax relief we also wanted to see mandatory rate relief for sports clubs."
